A star (*) denotes that prisoners have been previously in custodyâ€”two stars (**) that they have been in custodyâ€”an obelisk (â€ ) that they are known to be associates of bad charactersâ€”the figures after the name in the indictment denote the prisoner's age.
LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.

div0.p:
PRESENTâ€”The Right Hon. the LORD MAYOR; Sir
ROBERT WALTER CARDEN , Knt., Ald.; Mr. RECORDER; Mr. Ald. PHILLIPS; Mr. Ald. CONDER; and Mr. Ald. GIBBONS.

div1.p:
382.
ROBERT FRANCIS FAIRLIE (31), was indicted
for unlaw
fully taking a false oath before the surrogate.
MESSRS. GIFFARD and POLAND conducted the Prosecution.

HENRY WATTS . I am record-keeper in the office of the Vicar General of the Archbishop of Canterbury, at Doctor's Commonsâ€”produce an it affdavit of Robert Francis Fairlie, dated 4th January, 1862; it appears to have been sworn before the Surrogateâ€”it is my duty, from the affidavit; to make out a marriage licenceâ€”this (produced) is the licence I made out from the affidavit, after it had been swornâ€”it is my own handwritingâ€”the licence is then signed by the registrar, and a seal attached in the regular way.

DR. WILLIAM ROBINSON . I am Surrogate to the Vicar General of the Archbishop of Canterburyâ€”it is my duty to administer the oath to persons required to make affidavits under the Marriage Actâ€”this affidavit bears my signature, it was sworn before me, and sworn to by the person who signed if.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. How are these affidavits prepared, are they kept in form? A. I believe they are kept in form, but it does not lie within my provinceâ€”I have nothing to do with the affidavits, except as they are brought by the proctor before me, and then I swear the partyâ€”I believe the proctor prepares the affidavits in the ordinary course of businessâ€”I do not read it over or anything of that kindâ€”the form of the inquiry is, "Is this your name and handwriting, you know the contents of the affidavit, and you believe it to be true"â€”that is all that comes before meâ€”the explanations in relation to the contents or meaning of the affidavit, it is the duty of the proctor to makeâ€”it is not my duty.
MR. GIFFARD. Q. The last paragraph of the affidavit has reference to

the consent of the father, is that part of the form, or is it inserted afterwards in writing? A. It must have been inserted at the time because I see my initials opposite it: that is in writing, not a part of the printed form.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. Are you able to swear, from your own recollection, that you read that over to him? A. I did not read any part of my attentionâ€”I cannot say whose handwriting that is, in the part to which it over to him has been calledâ€”I cannot say when it was writtenâ€”it was not written in my presence.

REV. CHARLES LESLIE ALEXANDER . I am curate at the parish church of St. Mary's, Lambethâ€”on Sunday morning, 5th January, I performed a service of marriage, between Robert Francis Fairlie and Eliza Ann England, in pursuance of this licence, which was produced to me, not by bannsâ€”the license had then the seal of the Court on itâ€”after I had solemnized the marriage the signatures were made in the register by the personsâ€”the two persons whom I married signed the registerâ€”I have got the register here it is between Robert Francis Fairlie, of full age, widower, engineer address, Vassal-road; father's name, Archibald Fairlie, deceased, engineer and Eliza Ann England, minor, spinster; residence, St Paul, Deptford; father's name, and surname, George England; profession, engineerâ€”and these are the signatures of the two persons whom I marriedâ€”the seal of the license is generally taken off by the clerk, he keeps the license.

Cross-examined. Q. There was a lady and gentlemen present, witnesses to the marriage, Mr. and Mrs. Gibbons, I think? A. They wereâ€”I cannot say whether the young lady appeared to be at all unwilling, I think notâ€”there was nothing to attract my attentionâ€”she is described as a minorâ€”we do not put the actual age.

JOHN MCMAHON . I am acquainted with the handwriting of the defendantâ€”this signature in the affidavit is his handwriting; the signature in the register is also his handwritingâ€”I do not know the writing of Eliza Ann Englandâ€”I have known Mr. England twenty-five years.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known Mr. Fairlie? A. Eight or ten yearsâ€”I know his handwritingâ€”I know him to be a person of position and respectability, his position is very highâ€”1 do not know any
thing of his means, but I believe he has very competent means; he keeps a very good establishment, horses, a carriage, and so onâ€”I have not been to his house since the marriageâ€”I used frequently to visit at Mr. England's house at the same time that Mr. Fairlie visited there, many times; Mr. Fairlie showed a great deal of attention to the young lady, in the presence of her parents, which the young lady appeared not at all unwilling to acceptâ€”I heard Mr. England say that he would not allow them to be married; that was during the time I met him there frequentlyâ€”Mr. England had spoken to me, and said that he would not allow them to be marriedâ€”after that Mr. Fairlie was a visitor at the house, and decidedly showed attention to the daughter in the presence of her father and motherâ€”Mr. England is a director of the Crystal Palace Companyâ€”I have frequently seen Mr. England, the two young ladies, and Mr. Fairlie, at the Crystal Palace togetherâ€”I have seen them dining together frequentlyâ€”I have seen them sitting in the reserved seats frequentlyâ€”I have generally seen that the defendant used to be with Miss Eliza England, and to be seated next to her at dinner and elsewhere, not at all times, but generally, and in the presence of her parents.
MR. GIFFARD. Q. How recently, before the 4th January, in the present year, have you known Mr. Fairlie associating with Miss England in the way

you have described? A. I think November was the last time; no, it was not November, I think it was either the end of July or the beginning of Augustâ€”I was present when something passed between Mr. England and the defendent as to his permission, to the daughter's marriage; but I do not know the nature of the conversationâ€”it was a private conversation between Mr. Fairlie and him, it was spoken very low, and I did not pay attention to it; in fact I did not think it proper to do so, I thought it was some private conversation between them, and I held my head another wayâ€”I do not know the nature of the conversationâ€”after that the defendant himself made a statement to me as to what the result of it wasâ€”that must have been last spring some time, I think; I am not positive about the dateâ€”I remember it was at the London Tavern one evening, but the date I cannot sayâ€”it was at the Caledonian ball; there was a ball and dinner partyâ€”he told me that he had Mr. England's consent to show attention to his daughter in two years timeâ€”I said, "Very well, you must wait the time."

COURT. Q. Was it after that conversation that you saw manifest atten
tion being paid to the young lady, in the presence of her parents? A. After the conversation frequently.

GEORGE ENGLAND . I am the father of Eliza Ann England who has been married to the defendantâ€”I never gave my consent to the marriage of my daughterâ€”the signature to this register is my daughter's handwritingâ€”she was eighteen years of age on 6th July lastâ€”I remember a conversation which took place between the defendant and myself with reference to some atten
tions which he proposed to pay to my daughterâ€”I have had notice to pro
duce my diary in which that conversation was entered, and have it hereâ€”I showed it to the defendant after I had written, itâ€”it is under the date of Friday, 25th January, 1861; it is headed, "Mr. Fairlieâ€”had long conversa
tion respecting Lizzie," that is my daughter; "I told him, if he takes no steps in that direction for two years, from this day, I will then give him the same permission I have given Dickson; that is to the exercise of his powers to win the affections of my daughter, but on no account to make any attempts to pave the way before that time;" that is underlinedâ€”when I showed it to the defendant, about a week afterwards, he wanted to make it appear that I had said the promise was, that he should have her at the end of two years; and I said, "No; I will show you the entry that I made at the time," and when I read it I underlined those words, "pave the way "â€”that was done in his presenceâ€”he and I being both freemason's, belonging to the same lodge, he pledged me his word and honour, as a man and a mason, that he would strictly observe those conditionsâ€”that was the substance of what passed, and on those conditions he continued to visit at my houseâ€”about Septem
ber, 1861, I had occasion to observe that he was paying attention to my daughter; I spoke to him about it, and I said that he was not observing the conditions that I had previously imposed upon him, and which he had promised to maintain, and I then requested him that he would entirely cease his attention to my daughter, and if he could not keep his promise that he had so sacredly given, he was not again to visit my houseâ€”I think that was in Septemberâ€”he never visited my house after thatâ€”I remember my daughter going with Mr. Dickson and another daughter, on 4th January, to the Crystal Palaceâ€”I was not at all aware that she would meet Mr. Fairlie there, I thought he was then in Spain, for I had received a letter from him a few days previouslyâ€”I expected my daughter's return to my house that day; she did not come backâ€”I heard of her that evening from Mr. Dickson; he came to me and fetched me from Mr. Alderman Rose's, where I was
diningâ€”up to that time I had not directly or indirectly given the defendant reason to believe that I consented to hit marriage with my daughter; most positively to the contrary.

Cross-examined. Q. Is this your prosecution? A. I am the mover, most certainly; I appeal to the law for the protection it will afford me against such an outrageâ€”I know that the defendant went to Spain subsequently to the marriage; but before that he caused a communication to be sent to me, as if coming from him in Spain, although he was then in Londonâ€”I preferred this bill against him while he was in Spain with my daughterâ€”he is not my son-in-law, and never will beâ€”I applied to a Magistrate, the Hon. Mr. Nor
ton, and acted under his adviceâ€”I came here and preferred the billâ€”I received a letter from the defendant the very day my daughter left, when I got home at nightâ€”I received another from him during the period he was at Cadizâ€”my danghter sent letters one after another to her motherâ€”I never stopped themâ€”she gave them to me unopenedâ€”I have read thenâ€”I am not sure whether I have got them here, I think I haveâ€”my daughter has property so far as all children have in the success of their parentsâ€”she has none in her own rightâ€”of course she can never get a farthing's worth of my property except by my own will, unless I choose to will it to her, and you may depend upon it she never will; but this man thought she was to have 10,000l.; that was his expectationâ€”he knew it was entirely dependent upon meâ€”he knew exactly how my family were situatedâ€”I say that the under
standing with him was that he was to make no attempt to pave the wayâ€”I adhere to that most positivelyâ€”I swear most positively that I have not assisted him in paving the way since that timeâ€”my daughter's birthday was on 6th Julyâ€”I did not, on that occasion, receive from the hands of the defendant a very handsome bracelet, nor about that timeâ€”it was a law, time previous, in the previous yearâ€”I will swear it was not last yearâ€”it was previous to her birthday last yearâ€”I gave that bracelet to my daughter with my own handsâ€”I did not tell her who it came fromâ€”allow me to explainâ€”I insist upon explaining itâ€”I handed her the bracelet myself, and I represented that it was a present of my ownâ€”Mr. Fairlie had produced the bracelet, and asked my permission to give it to my daughter, Eliza Annâ€”I said, "No, Mr. Fairlie; after the pretensions you are making to that girl, I cannot allow you to do anything of the sort"â€”he said, "Well; I have been to the photographer's where a photograph exists of you; I have had a miniature photograph taken of it put into this bracelet; it is not of any earthly use to me as it is, will you accept it from me, and give it to your daughter, instead of any present you are about to make to her?" which he knew I was about to do, there being some festival, and I am in the habit of making my daughter's presentsâ€”he asked if I would accept it, aud give it to her, as if I had purchased it myself and get my portrait put into itâ€”I did so; and, for anything I know, to the present moment, the girl never know to the contrary, nor any of my family; even my wife does not know now that that took placeâ€”I allowed my daughter to wear it, falsely representing to her that I had purchased it for her, because it waa given to me by a friend as I then considered.

Q. But why should you take the credit of giving your daughter a forty guinea bracelet, when it waa given you by the defendant? A. I have explained the circumstancesâ€”forty guineas! four guineas you mean, I sup
poseâ€”I have got it now, and she never sees it again you may dependâ€”she left it at home when she elopedâ€”I mean to keep itâ€”she won't get itâ€”I know it to be his property, and I wish it had always remained hisâ€”I mean to

keeps it or else put it in the fireâ€”he never gave her a watch and chainâ€”the never had a watch and chain from himâ€”I give my children a gold watch and chain on their eighteenth birthdayâ€”that it my practiceâ€”I gave my daughter Eliza Ann a gold watch upon her last birthdayâ€”the defendant did not do it; I didâ€”I will tell you what he had to do with it, if you will allow meâ€”I was about to purchase the watch, at Bennett's; the defendant saw me there, and asked what I was doing there: he previously knew my intention of purchas
ing the watch for my daughter's eighteenth birthday, and he said, "I have a beautiful lady's watch, a better one than you will buy at Bennett's, because it made by Walker; it is no use to me, and you may as well buy it of me as anybody else"â€”knowing Mr. Walker's make, and that he made excellent watches, I purchased the watch from the defendant for 15l.â€”now, sir, did he give that watch?â€”I paid him the 15l. in a chequeâ€”I swear that; it was for the watch and chainâ€”it was 15l. for the watch, and I think 6l. for the chainâ€”I hoped I had got a good bargainâ€”that was the only reason I bought itâ€”to the best of my recollection I paid 15l. and 6l.â€”I have no memoran
dum of itâ€”I paid it to the defendantâ€”I gave that watch to my daughterâ€”I did not know that he had purchased it of Walker within a few hoursâ€”I knew betterâ€”I knew it was his late wife's watch, for he told me so himselfâ€”I objected to her having it, as Mr. Walker was in the habit of visiting ray family, and I did not wish him to know that I had given the defendant's late wife watch to my daughter; but he went and took Walker's name out, and put another name in in order that I should have itâ€”I purchased it properlyâ€”I do not remember a diamond crossâ€”I do not remember handing a diamond cross to my daughter that was purchased by himâ€”I cannot swear what I do not rememberâ€”in visiting the house, he has given my daughter musicâ€”I have two that; he and Mr. Dickson bothâ€”it was some opera meats bound up, and each of them presented it to the two girlsâ€”Mr. Dickson was engaged to the one, the defendant was prohibited from speaking to the other; and he gave his solemn word and honour that he would not do so in the shape of a suitorâ€”Mr. Dickson is not married to my other daughterâ€”he is engaged to be marriedâ€”he was introduced into my house by the defen
dantâ€”I never called myself "Father Tom" to himâ€”he called me soâ€”I might, in a joke, perhaps, have called myself soâ€”I don't rememberâ€”I do not think I ever did; but I may have done so, it is quite possibleâ€”(looking at a letter) this is my handwriting; the signature to this is "Father Tom" (looking at another) yes; that is all right; it is quite likely that I may have called myself "Father Tom" to him as late as September lastâ€”I know it now; it was an allusion to the piece of the "Colleen Bawn"â€”he called himself "Myles," and called me "Father Tom"â€”"Father Tom" is a priest in the "Colleen Bawn"â€”he used not to call my daughter "Eily"â€”I never heard him call her soâ€”I know what you meanâ€”it is not thatâ€”he called her "Lily," which I positively objected to; but that Lily had no reference to the piece, quite understand that; it was before thatâ€”I ran away with the lady that I am now married to, my former wife being alive at the timeâ€”if Sir Cresswell Cresswell had then existed I should not have done soâ€”1 have been married to my present wife a good deal more than three yearsâ€”I do not remember the dateâ€”it is a date I wish to forgetâ€”I do not remember the day very wellâ€”we celebrate the day every yearâ€”it was some years previous to what you stateâ€”the fact is, I was then living with my present wife, because I had a former wife then livingâ€”it was known to all my friendsâ€”I could not marry her, because my wife was then living; and Sir Cross
well Cresswell did not exist thenâ€”I married my present wife within fourteen
days after the death of the firstâ€”it was six or seven years ago, or something like that.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. This it an indictment at common law, not exactly for what it called perjury, but for a false oath, and I submit that the case has failed, because I contend that the alleged false oath must be as to some material fact, and the statement here alleged to be false, viz.â€”the consent of the father, was wholly immaterial, his consent not being necessary; if any consent at all was necessary it would be that of the mother; it has been decided that, as to an illegitimate child, it follows the mother's settlement, not the father's; there
fore the declaration that he had the father's consent, was a declaration to a matter wholly immaterial, and would not support an indictment for perjury. Another question also arisesâ€”who is the father? Supposing, in point of law, the prosecutor is not the father, it is not disproved that the defendant had the father's consent.
MR. RECORDER. The Affidavit states, "by and with the consent of George England."
MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Although he asserts him to be the father; that does not do away with the assumption of law that he is not the father.

MR. RECORDER. It is necessary, in order to obtain the certificate when that person is under age, that the affidavit shall state that the consent of the party whose consent is required under the provision of the Act, has been obtained.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. No doubt, and he might have been indicted for the violation of that Act of Parliament, 4 Geo. IV., oh. 76, sec. 14), is not obtaining the proper consent, but here he is indicted for alleging the consent of a person who has in law no power of assenting.

MR. RECORDER. Sec. 16 says, that if there is no such guardian, then the mother it the party to give consent; there seems to be nobody in this case pro
vided for as the person who it to give the consent.
MR. GIFFARD. Unless the Act of Parliament meant the natural father and mother.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. The only thing he could have sworn truly was, that there was no one who was entitled to give consent, and such a state of things is provided for in sec. 17. There is another objection, viz.â€”the absence of any confirmatory evidence that the defendant had not Mr. England's consent on the day in question, 4th January; the only evidence on that point would be the defendants letter, which has not been put in.

MR. GIFFARD. Then I will cure that objection by putting it in. (The letter was then put in and read, dated, Cadiz, 31st January, 1862; it entered into an explanation of the circumstances attending the marriage, requesting pardon for the step, which had only been taken because there appeared no hope of obtaining the prosecutor's consent.

MR. GIFFARD. That letter disposes of the last point; with reference to the first, my friend has ingeniously mixed up the affidavit which might have been made with that which was in fact made; the licence was undoubtedly issued in pursuance of the defendant's statement, falsely made, that he had the father's consent; true, he adds to it a statement which it is now contended in point of law was incorrect, and that Mr. George England it not the father, but that I apprehend it immaterial; he himself, by his statement at the Vicar-generals Office, made it essential to his getting the licence, that he had George England's consent, and then he falsely swears that he has that consent; how can that be said to be immaterial to the issue of the licence, when but for that statement of his, on oath, the licence would not have been issued. I further say that the Act of Parliament probably refers to the consent of the natural as well as the

p.hi: legal father and mother; it is said that the consent of the mother should have been obtained, but the law takes no more notice of the illegitimate child of a mother than of a father. For certain purposes the law recognises in the character of father or mother, the natural father or mother of an illegitimate child; but I am not aware that the law draws anp distinction between the father end mother's status in that respect; for certain purposes of affiliation &c. after the age of sixteen, the mother's settlement, must decide that of the illegitimate child but that it a matter technically arising out of the law; the law really takes no further notice of the illegitimate child of the mother than of the father. It is said that the defendant might have made an affidavit according to the facts, that so have procured the licence, but he does not do soâ€”he distinctly points out George England as the person that has given his consent, and falsely swears that he hat done so. Then it it not the same at Reg. v. Phlipott, 2 Denison, p. 302, where it was held, that as the defendant had thought proper to make a matter material, it raised the question, and the materiality of perjury arose. I am unable to distinguish the principle of that case from the present; then it is impossible to contend that but for that false allegation the licence would have been issued. I find no trace in the Act of Parliament of making the law applicaple to a false oath control the materiality of the perjury; there is no necessity for any averment of materialityâ€”there was no such averment in Reg. V. Chapman, 1st Denison, which was discussed at great length in the Court of Criminal Appeal.

div1.p: MR. RECORDER. I wish you would direct your attention to the form of your indictment; you distinctly aver as the offence here, that he stated so and so, and is your declaration you aver "he being the person whose consent was by law requried, before the said Vicar-general was entailed to grant the said licence." MR. GIFFARD. I apprehend that raises the same point, because if it be immaterial for this purpose it may be rejected; it is not necessary to him that ment proved, the mere fact that, it is averred carries it no further; the Jury may reject that portion of the indictment, and then it would stand that he had untruly sworn that George England had consented.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE (in reply). With regard to the averment of immaterial, there never wat any necessity for an averment of materiality in perjury at all; it was only put in by the pleaders when the alleged false state
ment did not show it to be material to the question; you must either show materiality on the face of the indictment, or aver it; in the present instance they have undertaken to show materiality on the face of it; they do not allege materiality, but they allege the absence of consent of the natural and lawful father, the person whom it is shown on the face of the indictment, according to the Act of Parliament, would be the person who alone could give consent; I should have contended, if that had been omitted, that the indictment would have been open to objection; that there was neither an averment of materiality, nor materiality thown. A distinction has been attempted to be drawn between this indictment and an ordinary indictment for perjury. I belive the only reason why a person cannot be indicted for taking a false oath before the Surrogate is, that it it not in a judicial proceeding, which it one of the elements of perjury, therefore is called "a false oath," but all the other mattert connected with Perjury are just as applicable at if within the strict form; therefore the state
ment, that a matter need not be material in order to support a charge of taking a false oath, cannot be supported upon principle. Again, it hat been urged that this is material, and on the ground that, however immaterial a thing may really be, yet if a person imagines it to be material, or uses it so as to produce any effect, in that case there is as much materiality at if the matter wat really

material; but the words are "material to the issue;" that is, it is something that if true, will go towards proving the issue and Reg. v. Philpott, it a strong authority in my favour, and from Lord Campbell's Judgment the distinctions between that case and the present it perfectly clear. (THE RECORDER called attention to Reg. v. Gibbons). I am not familiar with the details of that case, but at my friend has not quoted it, I may infer it it not in his favour. Supposing here that there was no father or mother, and he had sworn that he had the constent of the father, I apprehend that would be a matter wholly imma
terial, there being no such person in existenceâ€”here, he says, "I have the content of so and so, the father," then we must look to what legal power the father has; I contend that if the father had been present, and had given his consent, it would not have been a content within the meaning of the Act of Parliament, if the case I have quoted it correct: a guardian it bound to the appointed by the Court of Chancery, and he alone could give the consent required by the Act. It is clear that a legal connexion, and a legal position, must be referred to in the Act of Parliment, and it it for the purpose of maintaining those rights, and that position, that this number of restriction on put upon it; it does not anticipate the question of a father in relation to a bastard child, who hat no rights whatever in society, and has no claim upon the father, even to make him support it with its daily bread: if deserted by him, the could not by application to a Magistrate, or elsewhere, obtain any assistant from him within the Poor Law Act; the child, until the marriagt of the mother, follows the settlement of me mother, after that the has no rights, no position, no claim; if I am right in that, the father of such a child has neither right or claim upon her duty or obedience, and has no right whatever to expect that the should obtain his permittion to do any particular act.

MR. RECORDER (after consulting MR. COMMON SERJEANT). I am generally exceeding unwilling to stop a case upon a point of law without taking the opinion of the Jury upon the facts, especially when there is an opportunity, as there now is of reserving it for the consideration of the Court of Appeal, but if I entertain a clear opinion, I think I am bound to take that course; I do so here; and I am confirmed in that opinion by the Common Serjeant; I think that in this case the charge that is made is not established; there might be some question raised upon the point, of whether the particular averment was or was not material, but here the particular form of the charge is, that the defendant intended to obtain the licence without the consent of the lawful and natural father of the said Eliza Ann England; now that is not this case, because it appears upon the evidence that there is no lawful and natural father, and the distinct averment here made is, that the said George England is the lawful and natural father, that seems to be the form of charge made throughout, and that charge does not, upon this evidence, appear to be established, it is, therefore my duty to say, that in point of law, there is no evidence to support the charge.
NOT GUILTY .

383.
RICHARD SIMPSON (24), and
WILLIAM SMITH (28),
Felonionsly breaking and entering the shop of
William Birch, on 28th March, at
St. Benet, Gracechurch-street, and stealing 1 watch and chain, value 30l., his property;
also unlawfully breaking a certain glass, value 8l., the property of the said William Birch; to both of which they

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months each.

384.
ANTHONY DUTLEIN (31),
Embezzling and stealing the sums of 11l. and 5l., of
Samuel Wilson, Esq., his master.;
also forging and uttering a receipt for 3l., with intent to defraud; to both of which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”Mr. Alderman WILSON stated that the prisoner had been in his employment for nine months, during which period he had robbed him to the extent (at at present ascertained) of 23 l., and that he absconded, taking with him a new suit of clothes, and was apprehended in Germany, when a variety of forged documents were found upon him.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

385.
AMELIA LEVY (65),
Stealing 141 yards of silk, value 18l. 10s., the property of
William Cook, having been before convicted at this Court; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY.*â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

386.
CHARLES SAMUEL TOONE (20),
Stealing a chest of tea, value 6l., the property of
John Teede, in his dwelling-house; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

387.
RICHARD BRITTON (34),
Feloniously forging and uttering a request for the delivery of two pieces of linen, with intent to defraud.

HENRY TAYLOR . I am warehouseman to Messrs. James Henry Morley and William Powell, Manchester warehousemen, of Friday-streetâ€”Messrs. Brampton and Crawford are customers of oursâ€”on 17th February, the prisoner brought this order, (read) "17-2-62, Two pieces of fine linen, at 1s. 6d.â€”Brampton and Crawford, M. S."â€”I supplied him with the goods.
prisoner. Q. Did you ever see me before that? A. Noâ€”I recognised you at the police-stationâ€”I am sure you gave me the order.

COURT. Q. How long after he had brought the order was it that you went to the police-station? A. Two or three weeksâ€”I then saw the prisoner aloneâ€”I did not pick him out from other personsâ€”he signed for the goods in the name of Burn, and that is in the same handwriting as the order.

JAMES BLOWKER . I am porter to Messrs. Morley and Powellâ€”I remember the prisoner coming with this orderâ€”I knew him previously for three years I saw him take away the goodsâ€”I gave them to himâ€”he had formerly lived with Brampton and Crawford.
Prisoner. Q. You knew me perfectly well? A. Yesâ€”I am quite certain it was you.

ANN MARIA SIMONS . I am a buyer in the employment of Messrs. Bramp
ton and Crawfordâ€”I am in the habit of giving orders for goods for them, and signing my initials to the ordersâ€”this order is not my writingâ€”I never gave anyone authority to write itâ€”the prisoner was formerly in the employ
ment of the firm, but he left between two and three yean agoâ€”he was in the habit of taking out orders for me, with my initials to them.
Prisoner. Q. Is that anything like your writing? A. Noâ€”I sometimes entrusted other persons with orders to get goods for me.
Prisoner's Defence. I am well known about the City, the porter is mistaken about seeing me in the place on this morning; it is not proved that anyone every saw me with a parcel.
GUILTY .

p.hi: The prisoner was further charged with having been before convicted of larceny, as a servant, at Guildhall, on 19th November, 1859, when he was sentenced to six months imprisonment, to this part of the charge he

div1.p:
PLEADED GUILTY.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

388.
HERBERT BROWN (17), was indicted
for embezzlement.
JAMES HENLEY . I am a haberdasher in Tooley-streetâ€”on 11th March I purchased of Carlile and Co., of Bow-lane, some goods to the amount of
1l. 0s. 11d.â€”I paid the prisoner, and he gave me this invoice and receipt (read).

JOHN MOON . I live at 9, Gross-street, Walworthâ€”on 28th March, I pur
chased some goods of Carlile and Co., for Mr. Metzner of Islington, for 13s. 7d.â€”the prisoner served meâ€”I paid himâ€”he gave me this receipt (produced).

WILLIAM BOLDING . I live at 9, Suffolk-place, Lower-road, Islingtonâ€”on 28th March I purchased of Carlile and Co., some woolâ€”I paid 1l. 18s. 2d. for it to the prisoner, and he gave me this invoice and receipt (produced).

JOHN PITMAN . I am a partner in the house of Carlile and Co., 13, Bow-lane, Cheapside, warehousemenâ€”the prisoner was in our employment for some ten months as clerk, and afterwards as cashierâ€”he has not paid me these three sums, nor accounted for them in his cash-book, according to ruleâ€”his duty was to receive no money whatever except he had a ticket from the party who sold the goods, with the amount and number upon itâ€”on the 28th I saw an irregularity in the book, which called my attention to itâ€”I did not wish to create any suspicion in his mind, and let it remain till the 31stâ€”I then called him into the dining-room, and pointed out these discre
pancies, and asked him to give an explanation what he had done with the moneysâ€”they are entered in our cash-book, but not in the book which he keptâ€”I have examined it carefully and there are no such entriesâ€”it was my custom to go over his cash-book every night with himâ€”he said he knew nothing whatever respecting it, that there must be some mistake in itâ€”I gave him in charge, and he said the same to the officer.

EDWARD HANCOCK (City Policeman). I was called to the prosecutors, and took the prisoner in custodyâ€”Mr. Pitman drew his attention to these three accountsâ€”the prisoner said he knew nothing about them, he had never re
ceived the money at allâ€”I found on him 1l. 17s. in money, a silver watch and guard, and a gold carbuncle ring.

EDWARD CARLILE . I went through the prisoner's cash-book with him at nightâ€”it was my custom to add it up, and take the balance in hand from himâ€”he never accounted to me for these sumsâ€”he paid me the exact amount stated at the bottom of each of these pages, and that he stated as the whole of the money he had received.

Prisoner. I made no such statement at all, no statement was ever made when we balanced the money; I merely handed it over. Witness. It was his duty to hand over all the money he reoeived during the day, leaving 2l. 10s. in the tillâ€”he was in the habit of paying sums outâ€”those sums are shown in this book, and the amounts he received oppositeâ€”it was his tudy to pay me the balance.

GUILTY.â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury on account of his youth.
The prosecutor stated the amount of the prisoner's deficiencies to be about 29l. ex
tending over a period of about five weeks.â€”
Confined Eighteen Months

389.
THOMAS STEVENS (25),
Unlawfully being armed with certain dangerous and offensive weapons with intent to break and enter the ware-house of
John Richardson. Second Count, unlawfully having in his posses
sion certain implements of house breaking.

WILLIAM RUSSELL (City-policeman, 646). About half-past 10 on the night of 7th March, I was on duty near the premises of Mr. Richardson, of New-street, Bishopsgateâ€”my attention was drawn to the roof of the warehouse thereâ€”I found the prisoner lying down on the roofâ€”I took him to the warehouse and found that two panes of glass were broken, and the skylight

of Mr. Richardson's houseâ€”the prisoner was about a yard from the skylight at the time I took himâ€”as I was taking him to the warehouse he threw away this chisel (produced)â€”I searched him, and found on him some lucifer-matches, two knives, and a pocket-handkerchiefâ€”the knives are common pocket knivesâ€”the chisel is an instrument used in house-breaking.

Prisoner. Q. Did you see me throw the chisel away? A. Yes, with your left-hand, as I had hold of your rightâ€”I called to a boy to pick it up, which he did, and gave it to meâ€”he is not here, but I saw him pick it up.

JOHN FOULGER (Police-inspector). I examined the roof of Mr. Richard
son's warehouseâ€”I found the glass of the skylight broken, and the sash partly prised upâ€”I fitted this chisel to the marks where it had been prised and it fitted exactlyâ€”there is no question that this is the instrument that he partly prised it up with; there is a notch in it, and that notch exactly fitted a mark in the paint.

Prisoner. Q. In what part of the skylight were the marks? A. In the wood-workâ€”there is sufficient lead round the skylight to prevent the water getting through, but there is some wood-work alsoâ€”it is a lean-to in a shoping position, fitting down on to the frameâ€”the marks were on the frame, and under the sash as wellâ€”that part of the warehouse is much lower than any other partâ€”it is only about eight or nine feet high, and there to a gate at the end of it by which a roan could get up himself; with the assistance of another person he could get up in a minuteâ€”this chisel n the sort of instrument that we often find used in house-breaking.

GEROGE ARNOLD . I am foreman to Mr. Richardsonâ€”I left the laboratory that night about half-past 7â€”everything was safe thenâ€”no glass was broken in the skylight at that timeâ€”there were very valuable goods in the laboratory.
Prisoner. Q. Did you examine the skylight previous to leaving the place? A. I didâ€”I fastened it myself as I did every night.
Prisoner's Defence. I wish to call the attention of the Jury to this chisel; it is not much like a housebraeaking instrument.

p.hi: The prisoner was further charged with having been previously convicted, on 4th February, 1861, at Clerkenwell, of breaking and entering a warehouse, when he was sentenced to Twelve Months imprisonment; to which part of the charge he

div1.p:
PLEADED GUILTY.â€”
Four Years Penal Servitude.

390.
JOHN WILLIAMS (32),
Stealing a purse and money from the person of
Frederick Dart; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

391.
ALEXANDER MANWARING (16),
Stealing 2s. 6d. in money, and a screw, the property of
Charles Francis Hodgson, in his warehouse, and afterwards breaking out of the same.

ROBERT GOSLING (City-police-sergeant, 31). On the night of 28th March, about half-past 11, I was on duty near Gough-squareâ€”as I was passing Mr. Hodgson's printing-office there, I heard a noise inside the doorâ€”I stayed there for about a quarter of an hour, and heard some one at the lock inside the door, as if trying to get it offâ€”I then heard the lock taken off and laid down, and another lock apparently forcedâ€”I then saw the door open a little wayâ€”I directly pushed it against the prisoner, and got hold of himâ€”he said, "All right; I work here"â€”he tried to get awayâ€”the sergeant came up and took him in charge, while I went to search the

premisesâ€”I found a desk forced open in the warehouse, and in the counting-house, on the first floor, I also found a desk forced open, and a drawer above itâ€”in the drawer was this cash-box, forced open, and in the cash-box were a few papersâ€”I then came down and searched the prisoner and in his right hand I found a florin, and in his pocket a penny-piece, four halfpence, and a piece of steel, which is used by printers as a screwâ€”the chisel the prisoner dropped at the time I apprehended himâ€”the door that he took the lock off of is at the bottom of Pemberton-row, just out of Gough-square.
Prisoner. Q. You say I dropped the chisel? A. Yes; I heard it dropâ€”your hands were down at your sides at that time; not in your pockets.

JOSEPH TEGG . I am in the employment of Mr. Hodgson, of Gough-squareâ€”no one sleeps on the premisesâ€”I never saw the prisoner before this chargeâ€”he was not in the employmentâ€”I left the premises at two minutes to 10 on the night in questionâ€”I locked up the doors at that time, and fastened the windowsâ€”next morning I went and found one lock com
pletely forced off, and one brokenâ€”I saw this cash-box had been broken open; I do not know what had been in itâ€”a drawer had also been forced open, and two other drawers were open which had not been lockedâ€”the door leading into Pemberton-row is sometimes left open till after dark, for the men to go in and out.

CHARLES FRANCIS HODGSON . I am a printer, in Gough-squareâ€”I left my premises on the evening of 28th March between 7 and 8 o'clockâ€”I left the cash-box locked up in the afternoon, and placed it in a drawer, which was lockedâ€”it contained a florin, and some coppers, and some papers.
Prisoner. Q. Can you swear that is the florin? A. No.

THOMAS HEWSON . I am in the employment of Mr. Hodgsonâ€”I came to the premises on Saturday morning, the 29th, and found this crow-bar underneath my desk, in the warehouseâ€”it was not there when I left the previous night.

Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent. On 28th March a young man paid me 3s. which he owed me; it was a florin, two fourpenny-bits, a threepenny-piece, and a penny. I spent all the money but the florin and the fourpence. I changed the fourpenny-piece in Holborn to buy a penny pie, and came into the street where this robbery was committed. As I came aloug I per
ceived two men go in at the door. I went in to see what it was, and one of the men came and shut the door. I could not open it again. The men went up stairs, and then came down and went out. I took the lock off, and was trying to come out when the constable took me.

GUILTY.*â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

div0.p: PRESENT.â€”Mr. Ald. GIBBONS and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
392.
MARY COUCHER (42), was indicted
for wilful and corrupt perjury.
ARTHUR RUMBELOW . I am usher at Clerkenwell Sessionsâ€”I produce a copy of depositions returned there from the Thames Police-court.

WILLIAM LIVINGSTON . I am chief usher at the Thames Police-courtâ€”I was present when these depositions were taken before Mr. Selfe, and when the oath was administeredâ€”the signature, "Mary Coucher," to this deposition

is in the handwriting of the prisonerâ€”I saw it signedâ€”(Read: "Mary Coucher says: 'I am the wife of John Arton Coucher, superintendent of the Merchant Seamen's Orphan Asylum, in Bow-road, Bromleyâ€”I am matron of the Institutionâ€”the prisoner occasionally has worked there in helping the laundressâ€”she has done so for the last six or seven monthsâ€”up on her leaving the house last night, 16th instant, between 8 and 9 o'clock, I suspected her, and went to the gate after herâ€”I saw that she had a bundle, and said, "What have you there?"â€”she said, "A little supper"â€”I said, "It's rather a large supper"â€”I took it from her, and went into the house with itâ€”the prisoner returned to the houseâ€”I went into my own room with the bundle, and put it down on the table, and on opening it I found three half-quartern loaves, about two pounds of uncooked beef, about the same quantity of cooked beef, and a basin full of drippingâ€”the meat was in a piece of newspaper, and the whole of the articles were wrapped up in the apron producedâ€”I placed the bundle on the table in the state it was in when I took it from the prisonerâ€”I called in my husband, and showed him what I had foundâ€”this was half an hour afterwardsâ€”the cook had liberty to give the prisoner meat for supper, but not to be taken out of the house, but no liberty to give her uncooked meat or loaves of bread to be taken awayâ€”the meat is kept in the pantry, and the bread in the bread-roomâ€”the prisoner had no business at either placeâ€”the value of the loaves and uncooked meat is 2s.â€”the articles are the property of William Henry Hackwood and others, who are the Committee of the Institutionâ€”the wrapper is an apron such as the servants wear in the kitchenâ€”I remained in my room, when I had put down the prisoner's bundle, until my husband came into the room about half an hour afterwards. Cross-examined. I am going to leave the Institution with my husband in March nextâ€”I have had no cause of displeasure with the prisonerâ€”the bead laundry-maid was with the prisoner at the gateâ€”they came out of the laundry together.'â€”Signed M. Coucher."

MARY LAUGHTON . I am the wife of Jeremiah Laughton, who lived at 7, Brewer's-yard, when I left homeâ€”I have for some time past been a prisoner in the House of Correction, at Westminsterâ€”I was convicted at the Middle
sex Sessions in January, and was sentenced to twelve months' imprisonment, with hard labourâ€”on 16th January last year, I was at work at the Seamen's Orphan Asylum, in the Bow-road, as a charwoman and assistant laundressâ€”I had been there as assistant for, I should think, about the last seven monthsâ€”the defendant, Mrs. Coucher, was the matron of that Institutionâ€”on the evening of 16th January, between 8 and 9 o'clock, I was leaving the Asylum, having finished my day's work at a few minutes after 8 o'clockâ€”I was carry
ing a small newspaper parcel, and a basin of drippingâ€”I had the newspaper parcel in my left hand, in this manner, and the basin of dripping in my right handâ€”I cannot say what the newspaper parcel contained; it was so short a time that I had not looked into itâ€”Susannah Harvey, the cook, had given it me for my supperâ€”I was in the habit of having my supper given me to take home, and I supposed this to be my supperâ€”the parcel was not very large; not large enough to contain three half-quartern loaves, two pounds of uncooked meat, and two pounds of cooked meatâ€”the cook had also given me the basin of drippingâ€”there was no other wrapper of any kind attached to the parcel, out the newspaperâ€”I was wearing this apronâ€”there was nothing but the newspaper round the parcel; no wrapperâ€”that parcel was the only one that I carried outâ€”I came out of the kitchen into the yard, through the scullery door, straight to the gateâ€”Mary Ann Keast, the laundry-maid, stood at the

laundry-doorâ€”the laundry and scullery are two different places; the laundry is just opposite as you come through the doorâ€”you go from the kitchen, through the scullery, and into the yard at once; it is only about half a dozen steps from the kitchen to the yardâ€”I went through the Kitchen, and through the scullery door, and then into the yardâ€”as I passed the laundry door, Mary Ann Keast stood thereâ€”she said, "Are you going?"â€”I said, "Yes; I am"â€”I asked her whether she was coming to the gateâ€”she walked to the gate with meâ€”we were talking togetherâ€”on my way to the gate I saw Mrs. Coucher as soon as I came out of the kitchen into the yardâ€”I did not know then that it was she, but I know nowâ€”the laundry door is outside the scullery door, but it is on the other side of the yardâ€”I must pass the laundry door to go to the gate into the Bow-roadâ€”I went up to the gate with Mary Ann Keast, and when I got to the gate Mrs. Coucher came upâ€”I said, "Good night"â€”I believe Mrs. Coucher said, "Good night," and put her hand on the newspaper parcel that I carried in my left hand, and said, "What have you got here?"â€”Mary Ann Keadt was by at the timeâ€”I said, "My supper"â€”Mrs. Coucher said, "Give it to me"â€”she appeared very ravenous for itâ€”I said, "Yes; allow me to hand it to you"â€”as I handed it to her, she said, "That is all I wanted"â€”I handed her both the dripping and the parcel of supper that I had received from the cookâ€”I had not lost sight of them at all from the time of the cook giving them to meâ€”I had not altered them in any way by adding to or taking anything from themâ€”when Mrs. Coucher said, "That is what I wanted," she went the same way as she had come, towards her own room, with the parcelsâ€”I went straight back into the kitchen, and found the cook there stillâ€”I remained there from three quarters of an hour to an hour, as near as I can tellâ€”I told the cook why I remained in the kitchenâ€”I was waiting to know why Mrs. Coucher took my supperâ€”Mrs. Coucher did not come to me in the kitchenâ€”after waiting a long time the cook spoke to me, and I went homeâ€”after I had got home a policeman came to me, and I was taken to the station, and from the station back to the Asylumâ€”that was the same eveningâ€”when I was taken to the station, I saw a bundle there, in which were three half-quatern loaves, and the basin of dripping which Mrs. Coucher took from me, and the newspaper parcel, also some cooked and uncooked meat, the paper was brokenâ€”the paper parcel, the basin of dripping, and the other things, were all inside a coarse apronâ€”I returned with the police, and the apronful of things, to the Asylum; to the schoolmaster's roomâ€”Mrs. Coucher came, some
time after I went in, and the things were put on the table before herâ€”I said to her, "Are you going to say that you took that bundle from me at the gate?"â€”(I had been told by the inspector that I was charged with stealing those things)â€”she said, "Yes"â€”I was then taken back by the policemanâ€”I do not remember whether I said anything else to herâ€”Mrs. Coucher has seen me before leaving the Asylum at night with my supper, and she has given me a beef-steak pudding uncut, for my supper, to take away, from her own room, and told me not to tell any of the servants that she had given it to meâ€”she has known that I was in the habit of taking my supper awayâ€”Mrs. Coucher came to the police-station with me, and Inspector Kerresey was thereâ€”I do not remember whether it was before Kerresey that I asked Mrs. Coucher whether she charged me with stealing those thingsâ€”I was a good deal confused at the chargeâ€”I do not remember what I said to Kerresey.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. How long is it since Mrs. Coucher gave you the beef-steak pudding? A. I cannot say; I do not rememberâ€”she has ordered the cook before now, to give me any cooked food that was

leftâ€”I remembered the beef-steak pudding when I had it given to meâ€”since that this is the first time I remembered anything about itâ€”I cannot tell how long ago that wasâ€”I was very much obliged to her for itâ€”I thought it was my supperâ€”I believed that I was always allowed to have something for my supperâ€”I did not think anything about its being kind of her to give it meâ€”I did not think it was an act of kindnessâ€”I brought it into the kitchen, and the servants saw it; the cook and the laundry maidâ€”I was up before the Magistrate at the Thames police-courtâ€”I do not know who I had to re
present meâ€”I know Mary Ann Keastâ€”she was called as a witness before the Magistrateâ€”I do not know whether she was called by meâ€”after that I was committed to take my trial at Clerkenwellâ€”I was tried thereâ€”I had a lawyer there to defend meâ€”I recollect a gentleman addressing the jury on my behalf, making a very vehement speechâ€”I also called a person named Bennettâ€”I was charged there with stealing the loaves and the uncooked meatâ€”I heard Mrs. Coucher examined there, and, after hearing all, the jury found me guilty, and I was sentenced to twelve months' imprisonmentâ€”I do not think I have known Mary Ann Keast a twelvemonth yet; about a twelvemonth I should thinkâ€”it was not she that introduced me into that placeâ€”she was there before meâ€”it is about six or seven months since I went thereâ€”I knew her before I went there; she worked where I was work
ingâ€”it was not in consequenoe of her recommendation that I went thereâ€”I applied to Mrs. Coucher for work: Mary Ann Keast suggested to me to do soâ€”I was her fellow-servantâ€”I was in the habit of working there every dayâ€”the cook had authority to give me supper every night; cooked meatâ€”she had no authority to give me uncooked meatâ€”this (produced) is my apronâ€”you asked me at the Court whether I did not say that Mrs. Coucher took my apron from me, and I brought this; it is the only apron I am possessed of; it was not my apron that Mrs. Coucher tookâ€”the cook gave me the paper parcel containing my supper; but I never looked in itâ€”she gave me the dripping separateâ€”I cannot positively say whether I had my shawl and bonnet on when she gave me the parcel; I had them in the kitchen ready to put onâ€”after I got the parcel from the cook I want directly through the scullery door into the yardâ€”if I had not my bonnet and shawl on, I put them on immediatelyâ€”they where hanging on a chair in the kitchen where I stoodâ€”I know I had them on when coming from the kitchenâ€”when I went out from the kitchen I went by the laundryâ€”I went through the scullery doorâ€”the laundry is nearly opposite thatâ€”Keast stood at the laundry doorâ€”she was not waiting for me, that I know ofâ€”she walked with me to the gateâ€”she was present and saw everything that passed between Mrs. Coucher and meâ€”they knew at the Institution, where I livedâ€”I did not say anything about an apron when I went back to the kitchenâ€”I saw Harvey, the cook, there when I went backâ€”I did not take notice whether Elizabeth Partridge was there; I am not able to say she was not thereâ€”I did not notice whether a person named Elizabeth Sherman was thereâ€”it is not a very large kitchenâ€”those two persons might have been there without my noticing themâ€”I told the cook that Mrs. Coucher took my supper from meâ€”I did not say, "Mrs. Coucher has taken away my little bit of supper that I had wrapped up in an apron"â€”this was lecture night; they were at lecture when I leftâ€”I did not know that Mrs. Coucher's husband was at lectureâ€”I did not know that he was in the habit of attending the lectureâ€”there are two schoolmastersâ€”I leave between 8 and 9 o'clock every nightâ€”I do not know exactly what are the lecture nightsâ€”I knew afterwards that this was lecture night, but I did not know it at

the timeâ€”I heard Mr. Coucher say afterwards that they were at lectureâ€”I did not take any noticeâ€”I did not know at the time I left that they were attending lectureâ€”I did not know where Mr. Coucher wasâ€”I had been there six or seven monthsâ€”I did not know what night lecture wasâ€”I did not concern about when it was lecture night.
MR. ORRIDGE. Q. How many times a week were you there? A. I was there every day, Sundays and all.

MARY ANN KEAST . I live at 6, Brewer's-yard, Bow, and am a widowâ€”I was engaged at the Seaman's Orphan Asylum, at the Bow-road, as head laundry-maid, in January this year, and for some time previouslyâ€”Mrs. Coucher was the matron of the establishment, and Mary Laughton was em
ployed there as a charwomanâ€”I remember being iu the Asylum on the even
ing when Mary Laughton was given in oustodyâ€”I was at the laundry door when she was going awayâ€”that is, I should say, about three yards from the kitchen, or it might be a little moreâ€”from where I was, I could see a person coming in the direction from the kitchenâ€”I saw Mary Laughtonâ€”she had a paper parcel in her hands, it lay on her armsâ€”in the other hand she had a basin of drippingâ€”we spoke to one anotherâ€”she and I walked from the laundry door to the outer gateâ€”she had nothing else in her arms while walking from the place where I first saw her to the gateâ€”I saw Mrs. Coucher come upâ€”I was standing at the gateâ€”Mrs. Laughton said to her, "Good night, Ma'am"â€”Mrs. Coucher said, "Good night; what have you got there?"â€”Mrs. Laughton said, "I have got my supper"â€”Mrs. Coucher made for to take it from herâ€”she made a grab at itâ€”Mrs. Laughton said, "Allow me to hand it to you," and gave it to her; and Mrs. Coucher said, "That is all I wanted"â€”it was a paper parcel and a basin of dripping that she had from herâ€”I do not know what was in the parcelâ€”she did not take any other parcel, or cloth, or wrapper from herâ€”Mrs. Coucher, when she had got the things, went towards her own roomâ€”I went into the laundry, and Mrs. Laughton. I believe went into the kitchenâ€”I cannot say how long I stayed in the laundry; five or ten minutesâ€”it was quite impossible for Laugh
ton to have had three half-quartern loaves in the parcel without my seeing itâ€”some time previously Mrs. Coucher made a charge in respect of me and Mary Laughton about some calico; and in a few days Mrs. Coucher came to me and said, "Ann, I have found my mistake as regards that calico; and I have just merely come into the laundry thinking I should meet you and Mrs. Laughton; but I have inquired about it, and you tell Mrs. Laughton that it is quite correct about the calico; and it is on my side that the mistake is"â€”I had been before the Ladies' Committeeâ€”Mrs. Coucher was not present then; but she came in afterwards I believeâ€”it is a rule that we shall not be all present at the same timeâ€”I heard Mrs. Coucher say that Mrs. Laughton had a husband to do for her, and she thought there was a widow more in need of the work than she wasâ€”that was about a week or a fortnight before the charge about the calico.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. You say you did not go to the kitchen? A. I did notâ€”I went to the laundryâ€”I believe it was discovered afterwards that it was a very small portion of calico that was missingâ€”that was the reason of the mistakeâ€”Mrs. Coucher accused me and Mrs. Laughton; but she said afterwards that it was discovered to be some very small quantityâ€”I went into the kitchen that night to supper, during the time Mrs. Laughton was thereâ€”I was not with her in the kitchen after she had been stopped by Mrs. Coucherâ€”I went back to the laundry, where I stayed, it might be half an hour or twenty minutes, before I went back to the kitchenâ€”I went into the

and I think she went on 23dâ€”I went on Friday; and I think she went in on Mondayâ€”she was there every day when required; not every day from the time I have been thereâ€”I used not to see her every dayâ€”we continued on terms of intimacyâ€”I was quite acquainted with her all the timeâ€”I am not in the service stillâ€”I left the day after the jury found her guiltyâ€”I think Mrs. Laughton had an apron on that nightâ€”I did not hear two or three days before that there was an apron missingâ€”I never heard itâ€”I heard it was said that these things were found wrapped in a coarse apronâ€”we were not extra busy that nightâ€”I went to the laundry door to cool myselfâ€”I had seen her from 8 in the morning till ten minutes to 8 at night, in the cellar with meâ€”sht left the cellar firstâ€”I had been in the laundry about twenty minutes before she passed meâ€”I went to the door merely by accident to cool myself, and walked on to the gate with herâ€”I was in the habit of going to the gate with herâ€”I did not go every night; but I went that night because I wanted to remind her to be in good time in the morning as there was ill-feeling of Mrs. Coucher towards her and meâ€”(Mrs. Coucher had re
ported us both as not being in time in the morning)â€”finding her sent back, and her supper taken from her, I walked back to the laundryâ€”I know where the bread room isâ€”I have been in itâ€”the girl Laughton knows it alsoâ€”several loaves are kept thereâ€”I have gone there, and brought a half-quartern loaf down to the table, when we have been waiting for tea or breakfastâ€”anyone next me has said, "Well, you may as well run up, Ann, and get a quartern loafâ€”the bread room is open to anybodyâ€”Laughton has not done the sameâ€”I never took any into the laundryâ€”I know a boy named Whiteleyâ€”I did not, on one occasion, at the latter end of November, have two loaves in the laundry, nor did I put a cloth and the loaves under a pan, in the presence of George Whiteley; it is very likely I have given him a piece of bread, and other boys in the school; but I never cut it off a loafâ€”I never saw two loaves under a pan in the laundry, or in the cellar, or any where elseâ€”I had not been in the bread room for six or seven weeks; and then merely for breadâ€”there was nothing else that would bring me there; but the soap and sods was kept there; and I had occasion to go there every Monday morning for the soap and sodaâ€”I did not always go for it on Monday morning, because sometimes she left it out on Fridayâ€”this was on Thursdayâ€”I had not been in the bread room on Monday; I had been on the Friday week.

Q. Why did you tell me it was five or six weeks before? A. Well, I did not go into the bread-room, I was at the bread room doorâ€”I was not in the bread-room on Friday week, but I was on the Friday week before thisâ€”I was at the door but no furtherâ€”the soap and soda was left on the ledgeâ€”there is a slide which comes down; you have the advantage, you have been in the Asylum, and know all about itâ€”I did not see you there, but I heard soâ€”the cook told me the other week that you were thereâ€”she said that a gentleman, the lawyer that was plaintiff for Mrs. Coucher was thereâ€”I have said what I have got to say and you will get nothing more from meâ€”Mrs. Harvey told me that the counsel for Mrs. Coucher was in the asylum taking all the intelligence he could getâ€”I forget whether she mentioned your name, and I forget when she told meâ€”I have got a bad memoryâ€”it was when I came from the Old Bailey the last time she told me that the counsellor who had pleaded for the woman, had been in the Asylum getting all the in
telligence he could: had you not Eliza, the housemaid, in private to talk to you?â€”I do not know whether Eliza was aloneâ€”the cook told me that you were in the Asylum talking to Eliza, and so you was she also told me that you were talking to the boysâ€”I suppose the cook had a pretty good guess what you were there for; she said that you were there to learn the particu-lars

â€”that was before the last sessions, but you can have it the other wayâ€”I heard Mrs. Coucher give her evidence before the Magistrateâ€”I did not hear it at Clerkenwell, I was out of Courtâ€”at the time Mrs. Coucher asked Laughton what she had got there, and she said that it was her supper, I did not hear Mrs. Coucher say, "It is a very large supper," and she could not have said it without my hearing it.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Have you, in respect of bread, or soap, or soda, or any
thing else, the property of the Asylum, done anything but your duty? A. I never didâ€”I have never been guilty of misconduct or dishonesty while I have been in the Asylum, nor was I ever charged with itâ€”I have a character to prove it up to this dayâ€”with the exception of the calico business, I never heard a complaint of the honesty of Mary Laughton.

SUSANNAH HARVEY . I am cook at the Seaman's Orphan Asylumâ€”on the morning of 16th January, I gave Mary Laughton her supper to take home with her, which I was in the habit of doing to the knowledge of Mrs. Coucherâ€”it was wrapped in a pieoe of newspaper, and consisted of a piece of cooked beef, 1lb. I should think, and a small crust of bread only, as I had no more bread downâ€”I had given her a basin of dripping in the afternoonâ€”I gave her no uncooked meatâ€”when she took it she left the kitchen through the acullery which leads to the laundry, she returned in ten minutes, or not so long, without her parcel, and remained in the kitchen with me three quarters of an hour, or an hourâ€”I next saw her when she was brought back by the policeman, I had not in that interval seen Mrs. Coucherâ€”I first saw the parcel of bread and meat in the apron in the schoolmaster's room, there was a piece of cooked meat and a piece of raw meatâ€”I had not seen the un
cooked meat and the loaves of bread beforeâ€”I had not given them to herâ€”she could not have had that parocel when she left the kitchen without my seeing it.

Cross-examined. Q. She left the kitchen I suppose, and you did not see any more of her till she came back? A. She went from the kitchen through the sculleryâ€”you can see from the kitchen into the scullery; the door leads out of the kitchen into the sculleryâ€”I do not think she had a bonnet and cloak onâ€”I cannot say where she kept themâ€”I gave her her supper-beer, and she drank part of it, and handed the mug into the sculleryâ€”I cannot say whether she had the dripping in her hand when I gave her her supperâ€”she might have left it in the sculleryâ€”she must have gone somewhere to get it after I gave her her supper as I did not see it with herâ€”Mary Ann Keast came into the kitchen, but not for some time afterâ€”she was not there long before Laughton leftâ€”Keast said nothing to my recollectionâ€”I said to Laugh
ton, "It is no use for you to stop," and I think Keast said so alsoâ€”I supposed that Mrs. Coucher was at the lecture that nightâ€”it is her habit to goâ€”she does not stop there all the timeâ€”it is not a religious service, but a lecture on different subjectsâ€”at the time I saw the loaves it was my apron that they were in, I had missed it for three monthsâ€”Mrs. Coucher remains there still, as matron, and I as cookâ€”I do not know if I have ever seen you there, but if I have not, I have seen you elsewhereâ€”I never told Mary Ann Keast that you had gone to the Asylum to get intelligence, or that you were speak
ing to Eliza and the boysâ€”I heard that there was somebody there speaking to them, but I did not know who.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. You heard that some lawyer had been there getting information about this matter? A. Yes; and I told that to Keastâ€”at the time of the trial at the Middlesex Sessions, Mrs. Coucher was undernotice to leaveâ€”the first time I saw this apron, after Laughton was given in custody, was after it had been produced by Mrs. Coucher.
COURT. Q. Do you know from her whether any alteration has taken place as to her leaving or staying? A. I do notâ€”she is still there in the capacity of matron.

WILLIAM KERRESEY (Police-inspector). I was on duty at the police-station in the district in which the Asylum is situated, on the night, when Mrs. Laughton was brought there in custodyâ€”she was taken to the station and then to the Asylum, and then brought back againâ€”I said, "Explain to me, Mrs. Coucher, the nature of this charge"â€”she said that she stopped Mrs. Laughton going out at the gate at about 8 o'clock, with the parcel then producedâ€”the parcel then contained three half-quartern loaves, two pounds of un
cooked meat, about a pound and a half of cooked meat, and a basin of drippingâ€”Mrs. Laughton then said, "Oh, you liar, how can you stand there and say that? look'ee here, sir, Mrs. Croucher is going to leave, she said she would be one with us before she left, she must have put it there herself"â€”Mrs. Coucher replied, "What is the use of your saying that, Mrs. Laughton, when you know very well you had the parcel going out"â€”I asked if any bread and meat was missing, and whether they could identify itâ€”they said they could not, it was impossible for them to miss it from such a large quantityâ€”the charge was then entered for unlawful possessionâ€”there are constables doing duty in that road where the Asylum isâ€”I think the Asylum is about seven minutes walk from the stationâ€”a constable would be on that beat.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. You stated all you have stated now at Clerkenwell? A. No; I was not there; constable 389 wasâ€”he might have heard when all this was saidâ€”he brought the prisoner thereâ€”Mrs. Coucher said something to me and I sent a constable in search of her.

COURT to MRS. HARVEY. Q. When you saw the bundle afterwards, you recognized the piece of cooked meat you had given to her? A. Yes; I did not see the crust of breadâ€”she told me she had eaten that with her beer.

The prisoner received a good character.â€”
NOT GUILTY .

393.
WILLIAM ROUTH (54),
Embezzling 15s. 9d. the property of
Peter Scotland and another, his masters; to which he

p.rs: PLEADED GUILTY. Recommended to mercy by the prosecutors.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. RECORDER; Mr. Ald. CONDER; and Mr. Ald. BESLEY.

div1.p:
394.
ABRAHAM EMDIN (36), was indicted
for embezzling and stealing the sums of 14l. 3s. 6l., and other moneys, which he had received on account of
Robert King and another, his masters; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .
The prosecutor stated that the prisoner's defalcations amounted to 100l. in the present year.

395.
JAMES DEGARTON (16),
Feloniously uttering a forged order for the delivery of a suit of clothes, 6 shirts, and a necktie, value 2l. 10s, with intent to defraud; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .
MR. KEMP, for the prosecution, stated that the friends of the prisoner were desirous of placing him in a reformatory.

396.
SIMON PHILLIPS (18),
Embezzling and stealing the sums of 1l. 19s. 3d., and 9s. 4d., the moneys of
Isaac Lialter; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

397.
CHARLES WHITE (44),
Burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Robert Walter, and stealing therein 24 pounds of bacon, 2 pounds of butter, and 9l., his property; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

398.
WILLIAM PATZOLT (26),
Stealing 16 musquash skins, the pro
perty of
Charles Paulig; to which he

399.
GOETHARD POEHLER (29),
Feloniously receiving 2 fur seal skins, 70 musquash skins, 100 racoon tails, and 4 lamb skins, the property of
John Moritz Oppenheim and another.

LEOPOLD WARNECKE . I live at 14, Buttesland-street, Hoxtonâ€”I worked for about eight weeks, up to the 22d of March, with Messrs. Oppenheim, of Cannon-streetâ€”about three weeks before Christmas I took two seal skins from my masters' premises, and thirty-six black musquash skinsâ€”I took them to Poehlerâ€”he gave me 1s. each for the musquash skins, and 18s. each for the seal skinsâ€”I had previously taken some musquash skins to him, and he said if I had anything to sell I could bring it to himâ€”I told him, we were some skins short at one time at the warehouse, and he told me they paid so little money in the warehouses that you must take some skinsâ€”I recollect taking twenty-six coloured musquash skins to himâ€”he gave me 1s. each for themâ€”I took him about 100 racoon tailsâ€”he gave me a halfpenny each for the first, and 2 1/2 d. for the othersâ€”I took them to him at his own house, 28, High-street, Bloomsburyâ€”no one else was present when I took themâ€”I took them out of the warehouseâ€”I know that some of the skins I took to Poehler were placed at Wagner's.

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. How have you been in this country? A. Thirteen monthsâ€”I came from Hamburgâ€”I left there because there was no work for meâ€”I wanted to go to America; I had not money enough, and I came here firstâ€”I was never charged with any crime at Hamburgâ€”I was never turned out of Hamburg by the policeâ€”I did not leave there in consequence of the surveillance of the policeâ€”I worked for my living there as a furrier, as I do hereâ€”I never stole any skins then; never before I came to Messrs. Oppenheim'sâ€”I never stole any besides those I have mentionedâ€”I never sold any to any one but Poehlerâ€”I took ten musquash skins to make a boa and muff of, and I sold those to another man, but he did not know they were stolenâ€”I think I first began to steal from Messrs. Oppenheim in September; I cannot tell exactlyâ€”I got into their employment by working for Mr. Duck, of Tabernacle-walkâ€”I heard that there was a place open at Messrs. Oppenheim's, and went there, and he said I might come to workâ€”I referred them to Mr. Duckâ€”I left him because he had no more work for meâ€”he did not employ any one but myselfâ€”he had told me before he only had four week's work for meâ€”he did not take on other workmen after I leftâ€”I afterwards went to Mr. Duck againâ€”I took these skins in consequence of what the prisoner said to me; it was at his suggestionâ€”I had never taken any skins prior to thatâ€”I am not doing anything nowâ€”I have got no workâ€”I go to my friends at the West End to eat; Mr. Wagner and another gentleman.

CHARLES THOMAS GAYLOR . I am a detective-officer of the City-policeâ€”on Sa
turday, 22d March, in consequence of information, I went to Mr. Lillicrap, 19A, Davis-street, Berkeley-square, accompanied by Mr. Martin, the manager of Messrs. Oppenheim'sâ€”I saw Mr. Lillicrap, and he gave me these two seal skin muff borders, and these two pairs of cuffsâ€”the prisoner was working for Mr. Lillicrap at that timeâ€”Mr. Lillicrap called him downâ€”I showed him these skins, and told him that Mr. Lillicrap said he had bought them of himâ€”I asked how he accounted for the possession of themâ€”he said he bought them of some manâ€”I asked him whoâ€”he said he did not know the man; he thought he was a Jew; he did not think he was in the tradeâ€”I asked where he livedâ€”he said, "In High-street, Bloomsbury"â€”I left him in charge of Hancock, and went to his lodgings, 28, High-streetâ€”I after
wards went to Carnaby-street, and received from Wagner a parcel containing twenty-four musquash skins, which I produce.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner gave you his address, and you found it correct? A. Yesâ€”he said he bought them of a little Jew man, and he thought he was not in the tradeâ€”he also said he did not know who he wasâ€”I am quite sure he denied knowing the man.

WILLIAM PEARCE LILLICRAP . I am a furrier, at 19A, Davis-street, Berkeley-squareâ€”the prisoner worked for me as a furrier since September last, on the premisesâ€”I bought twenty-five musquash skins of himâ€”I think that was about September lastâ€”I gave him 35s. for themâ€”I also bought fifty racoon tails of him, for which I gave him 10s. 5d.â€”that was 2 1/4 d. eachâ€”the market value is about 7s. a hundredâ€”I did not ask him where he got them from; he had stated that previouslyâ€”on 4th January I bought two seal skins of him, and gave him a guinea each for themâ€”I asked him where he obtained themâ€”he said he bought them of a little Jew man, whom he dealt a little with previous to coming to meâ€”I asked him most distinctly where he got them from; if it was quite straight and squareâ€”they were not in a finished stateâ€”I sold one of them, and the other has been turned into two muffs and two pairs of cuffsâ€”these are themâ€”they were given up to the officerâ€”I also bought five musquash skins of the prisoner in Januaryâ€”I think I might have said to him the previous evening that I had a small order, and if he would be kind enough to get them for me I should be gladâ€”I had been laid up with rheumatism for nearly seven months, and could not go out in the eveningâ€”I gave him a sovereign to go and get them, and in the morning he brought them to me.

Cross-examined. Q. Was what you gave him for these skins a fair and reasonable price? A. 2 1/4 d. was considerably over the market price for the racoon tailsâ€”had the seal skins been finished, I should not, in all probability, have bought themâ€”I think I gave a fair market value for them, not being finishedâ€”my profit would be about twenty-five per cent; I cannot say what another man's profit would beâ€”the prisoner has been in my service since Septemberâ€”I had known him previouslyâ€”I had three years' reference with himâ€”I have no legal proof that he robbed me while he was in my service; I have a moral doubt on the subjectâ€”I heard no imputations against him before he came to me.

EDWARD HANCOCK . I am a detective officer of the City-policeâ€”I accompa
nied Gaylor to Mr. Lillicrap's, and afterwards took the prisoner into custodyâ€”I held out no promise or threat to him to make any statementâ€”on the way to the station he said he was confused and excited when we were at Mr. Lillicrap's place, and he did not exactly understand the charge, although he spoke English very well, he did not understand itâ€”I then told him he

would be charged with receiving, within the last three months, two seal skins, and a quantity of musquash skins, the property of Messrs. Oppen
heim, Cannon-street West, in the City, knowing them to be stolenâ€”he said, "If I had known that, I would not have bought them"â€”he said, "He came to me and wanted to sell them"â€”I said, "Who?"â€”he said, "Oppen
heim's man; I gave him 1l. a piece for the seal skins, and 1s. for the musquash skins; I sold the skins to Mr. Lillicrap for a guinea, and the musquash skins for 17d."â€”on the Monday following, as I was taking him to the Mansion-house, I said to him, "I do not know whether you are aware of the fact, we have some other musquash skins from Mr. Wagner"â€”he said he did not know: he thought this was wrong, and Warnecke told him to take them away, and he took them to Wagner's.

JOSEPH WAGNER . I am a hair-dresser, at 46, Carnaby-streetâ€”I gave a parcel of twenty-four musquash skins to the officer, Hancockâ€”I received them from the prisoner about nine days before thatâ€”he said, "I have left these here for Warnecke"â€”I knew Warneckeâ€”he said Warnecke would call for themâ€”I knew the prisoner when he lodged at Titchfield-streetâ€”I was there once or twice, and I have seen Warnecke thereâ€”they did not lodge together, but they were in the same lodgings.

FREDERICK TURNER . I am a shoemaker, at 4, Buttesland-street, Hoxtonâ€”Warnecke lodges in the same houseâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”I have seen him at the house at one timeâ€”I have sometimes seen him and Warnecke togetherâ€”I went to lodge there eight or nine weeks agoâ€”Warnecke was there before me.

CHARLES WALTER MARTIN . I am warehouse manager to Messrs. Oppenheim & Co., of 84, Canon-streetâ€”Warnecke was in their employment, and had been about eight monthsâ€”I had missed a quantity of skins from the stockâ€”in consequence of that I called Warnecke into a part of the warehouseâ€”I afterwards went with the officer to Mr. Lillicrap's, and inspected some muffs and cuffs that were shown to meâ€”they had formed part of a skin that we had missedâ€”it had not been finished; it was not in the state in which it would leave the warehouse if soldâ€”I believe the seal skin before me to be ours; it has our private mark on it, in one of the muffsâ€”I recognise the musquash skins as part of our propertyâ€”they have also a private mark; it is the letter "O"â€”I also know them by the peculiarity of the dyeâ€”they formed part of the skins we missedâ€”I know them by the peculiar handling of themâ€”Warnecke had no right to take skins out of our warehouse.
Cross-examined. Q. When did you first begin to miss these? A. In February lastâ€”Warnecke came into our employment in Julyâ€”we have missed skins during the whole of that time.

MR. COOPER. Q. What is the value of these seal skins? A. 45s. per skin wholesale price, in their present stateâ€”the musquash skins are worth about 1s. 9d., and the racoon tails from 5s. to 6s. a hundred.

GUILTY .â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

400.
AUGUSTE LOUIS DESCAMPS (30),
Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Mary Barnes, and stealing therein 3 forks, 50 cakes, and 1 box, the property of
Francis Strong.
MR. PLATT conducted the Prosecution.â€”(The prisoner being a foreigner the evidence was interpreted to him.)
MARY BARNES . I am a widow, living with my brother, Francis Strong, at Oak-cottage, Wellington-cottages, Bow, in the parish of Bromley St. Leonards

â€”I keep a little shop there for the sale of things; my brother is the land
