lordâ€”between 9 and 10 on the night of 16th March I saw that the house was quite safe, when I went to bedâ€”I fastened it myselfâ€”a little after 1 o'clock I was disturbed by the policemanâ€”my brother went down to let the police in, and I went down to open the shop doorâ€”I found the window partly opened, a pane of glass broken, and the things all disturbed, and a large carving-knife and fork, which had been in the cupboard, left on the window-sillâ€”I am sure the window was shut when I went to bedâ€”it appeared to have been forced open, because it was nailed on each side; I had driven in a nail myselfâ€”I saw some marks the next morningâ€”I missed three plated forks, which I had put in a side cupboard the night before; I also missed a box of cakes, which were safe in the houseâ€”I think the pro
perty is worth about 10s. altogetherâ€”these are the things (produced)â€”they were safe the night before.

GEORGE ATKINS (Policeman, 463 K). On the night of 16th March, about 12 o'clock, I was on duty in Wellington-street, Bowâ€”I saw the prisoner coming towards meâ€”when he saw me, he turned round suddenly and ran in an opposite directionâ€”I followed himâ€”he ran about 500 or 600 yards before I caught himâ€”as he went away I observed him, before I caught him, throw something over a fenceâ€”another constable came up and I gave him in charge to himâ€”I went to where I saw him throw something away, to examine, and found three German-silver forks and this crowbar or marline spikeâ€”I took him to the station, searched him, and found, in his pocket, these cakesâ€”I afterwards went to a garden close by where I had been, and there found this box, which was emptyâ€”I afterwards went to Mrs. Barnes' house and found the window openâ€”a pane of glass near the catch was broken, and there ware marks between the window-ledge and frame where some instru
ment had been prised in to prise up the windowâ€”I compared the crowhere with the marks on the window, and they correspondedâ€”it appeared in be done with a pointed instrument like that.

Prisoner's Defence. When the policeman arrested me I had nothing at all on my person. I am not guilty.
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

401.
JAMES MEAGER (33),
Feloniously forging and uttering a request for the delivery of 1s. worth of drink, with intent to defraud.

KATE HOLCROFT . I am barmaid at the Queen's Hotel, Queen-street, Sohoâ€”on 3d April the prisoner brought this ticket for a shilling's worth of drinkâ€”Mr. Jordan, whose name appears here, is the secretary of a club using our houseâ€”in consequence of the prisoner giving me this order, I gave him a shilling's worth of drinkâ€”I had never had such an order before that day (read:) "Please give the bearer a shilling's worth of drink; Mr. Jordan, sixth division.

Prisoner. Q. How do you know I gave you that? A. I am quite sure; I had never seen you beforeâ€”you were there drinking with other manâ€”I saw you three times altogether; three orders were produced; you only produced the secondâ€”it was betwen 3 and 4 o'clockâ€”I did not point out another man before I pointed out you at the stationâ€”I gave you in charge.

THOMAS JORDAN . I am secretary to the sixth division of a Bootmaker's Association, which meets at the Queen's Hotelâ€”the signature to this order is not mineâ€”I never authorised anybody to put my name to itâ€”I know nothing of the prisoner till he was given in charge.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you ask Jemmy Downy whether he was the man that got the drink? A. I was fetched over to know if I had given these orders, and if I knew any of the men who were drinking there; I only knew one, and that was Downyâ€”I called him out, but the barmaid said he was not the one that presented the order, and then she stepped across and pointed you outâ€”there were six or seven of you there.
THOMAS JACOBS (Policeman, C 182). I took the prisoner in custodyâ€”I told him what the charge wasâ€”he said he was innocent of it.
Prisoner's Defence. I was drinking with six or seven shipmates; I know nothing about this order; the barmaid came and pointed out some men before she pointed me out.
NOT GUILTY .

402.
JAMES MEAGER was again indicted
for a like offence.

KATE HOLCROFT . After the prisoner had presented the order in the last case he came again and presented a secondâ€”this is it (produced)â€”it might have been 10 minutes or a quarter of an hour after I received the firstâ€”I gave him the drink again.

Prisoner. Q. How much did you give me? A. They had a pot of beer, a quartern of gin, and fourpenny worth of bread and cheeseâ€”you had some of itâ€”you only came once to me; it was only the second order that you pre
sentedâ€”the two who presented the others I could not identifyâ€”I cannot say which order it was that you presentedâ€”I know it was the second oneâ€”I cannot say who presented the others.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: There was another indictment against the prisoner for a like offence, upon which no evidence was offered.

div1.p:
403.
GEORGE ISAAC BATCHELOR (16),
Stealing a post letter, the property of Her Majesty's Postmaster General; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”He received a good character.â€”
Confined Twelve Months

404.
WILLIAM NICHOLLS (25),
Stealing 2 post letters containing the property of Her Majesty's Postmaster General; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

405.
JOHN HAGAN (19), and
SAMUEL DAWES (19),
Robbery on
Richard Burrows, and stealing 1 watch and 1 handkerchief, his property.

RICHARD BURROWS . I am a tailor, at 13, Gilbert-street, Clare-marketâ€”on 4th March, about a quarter past 1 in the morning, I was in Broad-street, going homeâ€”I met a female, and asked her to show me to Drury-laneâ€”while I was speaking to her the two prisoners, and another person who made his escape, came upâ€”I have not any doubt the prisoners are two of the menâ€”they caught me by the collar and threw me downâ€”it was Dawes who threw me down, and when I was down Hagan and the other who escaped got on the top of meâ€”Hagan twisted the watch from my guard, out of my pocketâ€”it was worth 5l.â€”the woman was standing there at the timeâ€”the policeman came up in time to see them.

Cross-examined by MR. ORRIDGE (for Hagan). Q. Did you say it was Dawes who caught you by the collar? A. Yes; and Dawes wrenched the watch from me and gave it to Haganâ€”he knocked me downâ€”I did not see any persons about me at the time but the femaleâ€”I had been to see a friend in Lisson-grove, a master bakerâ€”I had spent the evening thereâ€”I came straight from there homeâ€”I did not go to any public-houseâ€”it was not at

a public-house I had been spending the evening, but at my friend's own houseâ€”I had been drinking a littleâ€”I was merely asking the woman the way to Drury-laneâ€”I have lived in Clare Market several yearsâ€”I did not know my way to Drury-lane just at that time, being a little the worse for liquorâ€”there was a gas-lamp not far from thereâ€”I was examined about this matter the next dayâ€”I am quite sure that Dawes the man who caught me by the collar, and knocked me down.
Cross-examined by MR. H. GIFFARD (for Dawes). Q. Which is Dawes? A. The one nearest me, in the pilot-jacketâ€”I have never said that it was Hagan took me by the collar.
MR. DICKIE. Q. Are you quite sure these two men were engaged in robbing you? A. Yes; quite sureâ€”I was sober enough to know themâ€”I saw them again directly afterwards at the station.

MARY SMITH . I am the wife of George Smith, painter, of 49, King-street, Long-acreâ€”on 4th March, about half-past 1 o'clock, I was in Broad-streetâ€”I met the prosecutorâ€”he asked me which was the way to Drury-laneâ€”he was not soberâ€”as I was telling him the way the two prisoners and another came upâ€”I am sure these are two of the menâ€”I did not know them beforeâ€”they caught hold of the prosecutor and threw him on the ground, and while he was on the ground Hagan and the one who escaped knelt on him, while Dawes wrenched bis watch from him, and gave it to Haganâ€”they ran awayâ€”I ran after them, and halloed, "Stop thief," and "Police"â€”the policeman came up and caught himâ€”they were not out of my sightâ€”they were just turning into Drury-lane when they were caught.

Cross-examined by MR. ORRIDGE. Q. Which prisoner was it that caught the prosecutor by the collar? A. Hagan, I think; no, I beg your pardon, I won't say which caught him by the collar; but I know I saw Dawes take the watch from him while he was on the groundâ€”I do not think there were any persons about, only the prisoners, two policemen, and I think two more young menâ€”the prosecutor was not pushed against by the prisoners; he was collared and thrown downâ€”I have never seen the prisoners beforeâ€”I am quite sure I never lost sight of himâ€”it was just outside the public-house door where the prosecutor was knocked down.

Cross-examined by MR. GIFFARD. Q. How many were there running alto
gether? A. Only the three menâ€”the one who escaped was the first to run away, and the two prisoners ran after himâ€”I halloed out, "Stop thief, police; they have taken a man's watch"â€”I did not chase them many minutes before they were captured.

JAMES GRANGER (Policeman, F 120). On 4th March, about half-past I in the morning, I was in Broad-street and heard a cry of "Police"â€”I ran to see what was the matter, and as I was going up I saw the prosecutor on the ground, with the two prisoners and another, not in custody, lying on the pavementâ€”just before I got up to them they got up and ran awayâ€”I asked Burrows what was the matterâ€”he said he had been robbed of his watchâ€”I ran directly after the prisoners, and we secured the two in Drury-laneâ€”I caught one, and Sergeant Hill stopped the other a little way down Charles-streetâ€”they were then taken to the station-house and locked upâ€”I am satisfied they are the two men I saw close to the prosecutorâ€”I took Haganâ€”he said he knew nothing of it, and I believe the other did to Sergeant Hill.

Cross-examined by MR. ORRIDGE. Q. How far did they run? A. I sup
pose 200 yardsâ€”I had the one in sight as the other turned into Charles-streetâ€”I had Hagan in sightâ€”I lost sight of the otherâ€”he had turned the
corner about ten or twenty yardsâ€”I knew them both before quite well by sight.

THOMAS HILL (Police-sergeant, F 5). On 4th March, about half-past 1 in the morning, I was on duty in Drury-lane, at the corner of Drury-lane I stopped the prisoner Dawes, running as fast as he could from Broad-street, when I stopped him he said, "I did not do it"â€”I brought him backâ€”I had not accused him of anythingâ€”I knew him to be a thief, and I stopped himâ€”I afterwards took him to the station-house.
GUILTY . Dawes was further charged with having been before convicted at Bow-street, on 12th November, 1861, when he was sentenced to one month's imprisonment; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY.

HAGAN**â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

DAWES**â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

406.
JOSEPH WILLS ( ),
Feloniously, unlawfully, and maliciously, wounding
John Earl on the neck and throat, with intent to do him some grevious bodily harm.

JOHN EARL . I live at 15, Pitt-street, and am a wood-sawyerâ€”on Satur
day, 1st of last month, I came home about twenty minutes to 12 at nightâ€”I found the street-door open, and the prisoner's mother standing at the door calling "murder"â€”in consequence of what she said I went into the parlourâ€”I had to pass through the shop to do thatâ€”I found the prisoner in the parlourâ€”I think I spoke to him firstâ€”I said, "Joe; what a fool you are making of yourself; I don't like to see old persons ill used, I have a mother of my own"â€”he turned and hit me with his left hand, and struck me in the chinâ€”I shoved him back with my left handâ€”he got back towards the fire-place, took up a poker, and made a thrust at me with it, and sent it through my trousers, drawers and allâ€”I shoved him backâ€”I did not wish to ill use him, because I knew he was not a man that could stand against me in physical forceâ€”he then made a cut at my headâ€”I caught the poker with my arms; it struck me hereâ€”it must have been rather hot; it caused a blisterâ€”I wrenched the poker from him, and threw it downâ€”he caught hold of my neckcloth, and drew it very tightâ€”I slipped my head through it, and got it offâ€”he tried to bite and kick meâ€”I struck him two or three times with my fist, and left him lying in the parlourâ€”the mother said, "Mr. Earl, for God's sake, come out; you do not know what injury he might do"â€”I went out in the passage; the mother was outsideâ€”she locked him in the parlourâ€”within three or four minutes afterwards he goes through the parlour into the shop, and comes into the passage againâ€”a door parts the passage, which opens by a latch-keyâ€”he gets the door partly openâ€”I got my feet against itâ€”he put his hand round the door, and said, "Take that you bâ€”"â€”that is the cut, through waistcoat and all, and here is the throat to show itâ€”it cut my skin, and flesh as well; it wounded meâ€”I have not quite recoveredâ€”I cannot get my head round very wellâ€”I had to go to the hospital, and a surgeon attended me.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. You gave him a black eye, I believe? A. I struck him pretty hard, as hard as I couldâ€”I was not very angryâ€”he had been drinkingâ€”I do not know that he has ever done me any harmâ€”I called him "Joe"â€”this was all over in about four minutes.

ALBERT HUNT . I am house-surgeon at the Middlesex Hospitalâ€”I examined last witness on his being brought to the hospitalâ€”I found a long wound ex
tending from the back of the neck on to the chin, about eight inches long,

such as might be inflicted by a sharp instrumentâ€”it was about a quarter of an inch deepâ€”if it had been a little deeper it would have cut the carotid arteryâ€”it was a very narrow escapeâ€”it is well now.
Cross-examined. Q. Where did it commence? A. Just at the back of the neckâ€”it did not bleed much.

THOMAS APPLEBY (Policeman, E 47). On the night this happened I was summoned to the house where the prosecutor wasâ€”I saw the prisoner sitting in a chair by the side of the fireâ€”he had a small poker in his handâ€”I told him to get up, and I took it from his handâ€”I raked out the fire, and found this small knife, almost red hotâ€”the prisoner said, "That is it that did it"â€”I assisted in taking him to the stationâ€”there is a mark on the knife, "J. W."

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

p.rs: GUILTY.â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury, believing that the prosecutor had used unnecessary provocation.

div1.p:
407.
FREDERICK COOPER (36),
Stealing one pair of fish-carvers, 6 dessert spoons, and 6 dessert forks, value 1l. 15s., the property of
Philip Lewis, his master; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

409.
WILLIAM TROWBRIDGE (21),
Stealing the sums of 11d., 10d., and 11d., the moneys of
Philip Lewis, his master;
also, feloniously forging and uttering a certain receipt for money, with intent to defraud; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Fifteen Months.

410.
RICHARD MANDINEAU (30),
Embezzling and stealing the sums of 13l. 5s., 13l. 1s. 11d., and 11l. 7s. 3d., the moneys of
Samuel James Baker his master;
also stealing 2l. and other money, of the same person; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.
The prisoner's deficiences were stated to be 180l., which he had endeavoured to conceal by false entries.

411.
ANN M'CARTHY (40),
Stealing 20lbs. of sugar, 11lbs. of mustard, and other goods, value 18s., the property of
George Mills Hill and another, her masters; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

412.
LUDOVIC ALEXANDER DROMAR (25),
Feloniously marrying
Susan Mundell White, his wife being then alive; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .

p.hi:
stated that the prisoner's first wife had deserted him, and cohabited with other men, and had given him into custody in order to extort terms from the second wife, towards whom he had behaved with the greatest kind
ness.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. GIBBONS and Mr. COMMON SERGEANT.

div1.p:
413.
JOHN BARRY (63),
Feloniously uttering counterfeit coin; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

414.
JANE BREHAM (46),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin, having other counterfeit coin in her possession; to whith she

415.
ANN ROSE (36),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Confined twelve months.

416.
ELIZABETH MANNING (18), was indicted
for a like offence; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

417.
ELLEN MAHER (32),
Unlawfully having counterfeit coin in her possession; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Confined Nine Months.

418.
SUSANNAH JOHNS (39), was indicted
for a like offence; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

419.
ELIZABETH SCOTT (57), and
MARIA WILLIAMS (18), were indicted for
a like offence; to which they

PLEADED GUILTY . *â€”
Confined Eighteen Months each.

420.
ELIZABETH MCCARTHY (22),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

421.
SARAH WARNER (18), and
SOPHIA HAYDON (26),
Unlaw
fully having in their possession a mould, hearing the impression of a shilling; to which

HAYDONâ€”
PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

JAMES BRANNAN . I was formerly inspector of police, and am now engaged by the Mintâ€”in consequence of information I received I went, on 6th March, to 4, Caroline-place, Whitechapel, at 7 o'clock in the morning, accom
panied by Inspectors Fife, Broad, Bryant, and several other officersâ€”the street door was openâ€”I proceeded up stairs; the room door was partially openâ€”I entered, and saw Warner partly sitting on the bed, and Haydon lying on the bed, endeavouring to undress herselfâ€”(I had heard a rustling noise as I ascended the stairs)â€”on the table, which stood near a clear bright fire, I found this plaster of Paris mould (produced) for making shillings, which was quite hot, and this tea-cup, containing fifty-six shillings in an un
finished state, some so hot that I could not hold themâ€”I found this ladle near the fire, containing a small portion of metal quite hot, and two gets quite warm; also some white sand, plaster of Paris, and all the implements of coiningâ€”there was no battery; they have got into the habit of electro
plating with the assistance of a wire only, which is also producedâ€”here is a pad for holding the mould when hotâ€”I said to Haydon, "Where is Bill?"â€”

she said, "What Bill, Mr. Brannan?"â€”I said, "Bill Wybrow"â€”she said, "I do not know; we were both drunk last night, and were picked up by two men, who brought us here; I was never here before in my life"â€”I sent for Mrs. Lyons, the landlady, who identified Haydon as having taken the roomâ€”she pointed to her and said, "This woman took the room of me"â€”Haydon said, "It is a lie."

WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is a mould for shillings; here are a great many shillings in this cup; they are all counterfeit, and many of them are out of this mouldâ€”these two gets have come out of this mouldâ€”here are other things necessary for making and plating counterfeit coin.
SARAH LYONS . I am the landlady of the roomâ€”I let it to Haydon the day before thisâ€”Warner was not with herâ€”the first I saw of her was in the presence of Brannan, when I was called up.

ARTHUR ELLIOTT (Policeman, G 13). I was appointed to watch Haydon for some days before she was taken, and have seen her with Warner on many occasionsâ€”they were associating together, and occupying rooms in the neighbourhood of Mrs. Lyonsâ€”I have watched them more than three weeks.
Warner's defence. I was out all night, and went in to lie down.

WARNERâ€”
GUILTY.*â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

422.
HENRY WILLIAMS (20),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

CATHERINE TURBERVILLE . I keep the Harper's Arms, Theobald's-roadâ€”on 17th March the prisoner came and asked me for half a pint of porterâ€”he then altered his mind, and said that he would have a glass of six ale, and put down a half-crownâ€”I tried it with my teeth, bent it, and said that it was badâ€”he said, "God's truth!" and I handed it back to himâ€”he took it upâ€”I asked him where he took it, and he said in change of half a sovereignâ€”he paid me a penny, and said that he would pay the halfpenny another time when he was passing, and I let him goâ€”on the 20th he came againâ€”I was not serving; but my barmaid said to me, in the prisoner's presence, that it was bad, and I saw a bad half-crown in her handâ€”he was given in charge.

Cross-examined by MR. ORRIDGE. Q. What would the glass of porter have come to? A. 1d.â€”he then altered his mindâ€”there was a man who I knew well there; and there may have been one person besidesâ€”it was between 10 and 11 at nightâ€”the exclamation, "God's truth!" was in astonishment.

JANE BONE . I am barmaid at the Harpers-armsâ€”I saw the prisoner give a half-crown to the landlady on 17th Marchâ€”I also examined it, and found it badâ€”it was given back to himâ€”he drank what he had, paid 1d. and left, after standing there half an hourâ€”on the 20th he came again, and called for three-halfpenny worth of gin, and gave me half a crownâ€”I tried it in the detector, and found it was badâ€”I called out to my mistress, and a constable was sent for, and the prisoner was given in charge with the half-crown.

Cross-examined. Q. How many minutes was he there on the 17th? A. About half an hourâ€”he was quite soberâ€”the half-crown was given back to him at onceâ€”there were two or three customers thereâ€”when I told him on Thursday that it was bad, he said, "God's truth!" the same expression that he had used on the Mondayâ€”he said on the Monday that he had it in change for a half-sovereignâ€”this (produced) is not the half-crown he produced on the Monday, because it was bent doubleâ€”I also bent the one on the Thursday.
MR. COOKE. Q. When you received it was it apparently a perfect one? A. Yesâ€”I bent it in the detectorâ€”I knew him again.
WILLIAM TOOLEY (Policeman, 169 E). I was called to the public house on the 20th, and took the prisonerâ€”I found 1d. on himâ€”I received the half-crown from the landlord.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . This half-crown is badâ€”if a half-crown like this was bent double, it could not be put back again; it would either break, or leave a very strong markâ€”this has not been bent double.

p.hi: The prisoners father gave him a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

423.
JOHN DAVIS (23), was indicted
for a like offence.

RICHARD DANIEL . I keep a stationer's shop in King-street, Covent-gardenâ€”the prisoner came on 15th February, asked for a pound's worth of postage stamps, and produced a sovereignâ€”I held the stamps in my hand until I saw whether the coin was good or notâ€”I handed it to my assistant, who stood close byâ€”he is not hereâ€”he handed it back to me, and I saw that it was badâ€”I sent for a constable and gave the prisoner in charge, with the sovereign which I marked.

GEORGE CANN (Policeman, F 112). I took the prisoner on 15th February, and received this sovereign (produced)â€”the prisoner gave his name Thomas Clarkâ€”he was remanded for a week, and was discharged on Monday, 24th February.

EBENEZER JACKS . I keep a chemist's shop at 11, Gower-street northâ€”on 11th March, between 9 and 10 in the morning, the prisoner came for two dozen and a half of postage stampsâ€”he gave me a half-crownâ€”I instantly detected that it was bad, and required anotherâ€”he emptied his pockets and said he had not got anotherâ€”I had given him the stampsâ€”I kept my eye on him while I went into the adjoining room to call my assistantâ€”he threw down the stamps, opened the door, and ran awayâ€”I followed, and caught himâ€”he resisted, and got away; but I overtook him, and gave the half-crown to the policeman.
HENRY CHAPPLE (Police-sergeant, E 36). I took the prisoner, and received the half-crownâ€”I found only five farthings on him.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is a bad half-sovereign, and a bad half-crown.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

424.
GEORGE FRASI (56),
Feloniously forging and uttering an accept
ance to a bill of exchange for 82l. 6s. with intent to defraud; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY ; and received a good character.â€”
Confined Fifteen Months

425.
GEORGE HAWKINS (54),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

DAVID SMITH . On 3d March I was in the Green Gate tavern, City-road, wiith a person named Allison, and the prisonerâ€”I was standing in front of the bar, and gave Allison a shilling to fetch a pot of beerâ€”the prisoner said, "Stop; I will pay for the pot of beer"â€”he gave Allison a shilling, and Allison gave the prisoner my shilling.

JAMES ALLISON . I was with the last witnessâ€”I have heard what he saidâ€”it is correctâ€”after I got the shilling from the prisoner, I took it to the bar and asked for some aleâ€”the prisoner was standing within a few strides of the barâ€”the barmaid served me; and when I gave her the shilling she said, "How many have you of these?"â€”the landlord came round in front of the bar, and I told him that the prisoner had given me the shillingâ€”I pointed him out, and he was given in custody.

SARAH ANN CHARLWOOD . I am barmaid at the Green Gate tavern, kept by Mr. Andersonâ€”on 31st March, Allison came and asked for a pot of ale, which came to 6d.â€”he gave me a bad shilling, and I asked him how many he had gotâ€”he asked me what I meant, and I called for Mr. Anderson, and gave it to himâ€”I saw him give the same shilling to the policeman.

WILLIAM ANDERSON . I was called in, and received a shilling from the bar
maidâ€”the prisoner was pointed ont to me, and I asked him if he had got any more of that sort of coinâ€”he said, "That is what your friend gave me"â€”the prisoner had pleaded poverty, and this man gave him a shillingâ€”I said, "You are a bad man to say such a thing; he is a respectable gentleman; I am sure he would not give you bad money"â€”he expressed a wish to go to the water-closetâ€”I followed him, and he chucked something awayâ€”I saw his hand move, and heard something clink against the wallâ€”the policeman and I searched and found a bad shillingâ€”I gave the prisoner in charge.

HENRY DODD (Policeman, G 142.) I took the prisoner, and received this shilling from Mr. Andersonâ€”I searched the prisoner and found on him a good shilling and twopenceâ€”I took him to the station, went back to Mr. Anderson, made a search in the direction he told me, and found this bad shilling (produced)â€”next morning, as I was taking him to the Thomas police-court, he said that he was an old fool to be beginning the game again; for the last time he was convicted of the same thing they almost killed him.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These shillings are bad.
Prisoner's Defence. A gentleman gave me the shilling to mind a horse for him; and another gentleman gave me another in the landlord's house; that is how I came by the two shillings.
GUILTY .

He was further charged with having been before convicted at this Court of a like offence in April, 1861, when he was sentenced to Nine Months' imprison
ment, to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

426.
CHARLES GRIMM (18), and
WILLIAM STONE (20),
Unlaw
fully having counterfeit coin in their possession, to which

STONEâ€”
PLEADED GUILTY.*â€”
Confined Six Months.

JAMES BRANNAN , junior (Police-sergeant, G 21). On 28th March I was on duty in Central-street, St. Luke's, and saw the prisoners, whom I had known for two months, ten or twelve yards from meâ€”Stone was looking in another directionâ€”Grimm caught sight of me, and knowing me well, he touched Stone on the arm, who immediately turned round, placed his hand in his trousers' pocket, and lifted up his arm in this positionâ€”I ran towards him, and pushed them both into the shop, No. 52, Central -Streetâ€”I said to Stone, "Give me that which you put up your arm, Mr. Stone;" and he handed me these three counterfeit sixpences (produced)â€”I kept them two or three minutes in the shop, and took them both in custodyâ€”on the way to the station I handed Grimm to another policeman, and while passing by No. 3, Central-street, Stone threw some sixpences into the passage of that shopâ€”I called Mr. Brant, the occupier, and asked him to give me those sixpencesâ€”he handed me these three counterfeit sixpences (produced)â€”I said to Stone, "What did you throw them away for?"â€”he said, "They are no use to me now"â€”they were both taken to the station and chargedâ€”Stone said, "We are both guilty"â€”Grimm said I wanted him to run but he would notâ€”I found on Grimm this pocket-book containing names and addresses of well
known dealers in counterfeit coin, some of whom have been tried in this Court, and some are now under the observation of the force; also a song or some
poetry which refers to my father; it is to the tune of "The Dying Soldier."

GEORGE BRANT . I am a picture frame maker, of 3, Central-streetâ€”on 28th March, I saw the constable passing my doorâ€”he asked me to see what was thrown on the groundâ€”I picked up three counterfeit sixpences and gave them to him.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These six sixpences are all bad and from the same mould.
(Grimm's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows;) "I met Stone about a quarter of an hour before we met Brannan, and Stone asked me to go with him."

GRIMMâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

427.
WILLIAM CONNELL alias Thomas Bosworth (50),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

HANNAH BROWN . My husband keeps a tobacconist's shop, at St. Andrew's-hillâ€”on Thursday, 6th March, I came out of the parlour into the shop to serve the prisoner who came and asked for a quarter of an ounce of tobacoo, the value of which was 3/4d.â€”he gave me a good half-crown, and I gave him 2s. and 5 1/4 d. in copperâ€”I laid the two shillings on the counter carelesslyâ€”they were separate, one was not on the top of the otherâ€”the prisoner then laid down a penny and said, "Take it out of that"â€”my suspicions were then raised that something was wrongâ€”he said, "Give me back my half-crown"â€”on his saying that, I cast my eye upon the shillings I had put down, and saw that a bad one lay on the top of the good one that I had given himâ€”they were still on the counter, but not exactly in the position in which I had placed themâ€”I said, "I see through this, you have laid a bad shilling on the top of my good one"â€”I have every reason to believe that the two shillings I gave the prisoner were goodâ€”my husband heard me say that he had given me a bad shilling, and he came forward, snatched the bad shilling from my hand, which the prisoner before that had tried to get from me, but had not succeededâ€”I had taken it upâ€”at the time the prisoner was offering the penny, I saw his hand more, but I had no suspicion until he said, "Give me back the half-crown"â€”he was standing quite close to the two shillings.

Prisoner. Q. Are you quite sure I am the man? A. Yes; quite sureâ€”it was about half-past 6 o'clock, on the 6th of March, when you came inâ€”I looked at the two shillings before I gave them outâ€”they were two good onesâ€”I did not try them in any wayâ€”I cannot say whose reign they were ofâ€”you laid the penny down, and I took back the good and bad shillingsâ€”I did not put them on the counter again, I kept them in my handâ€”my husband took the bad one from meâ€”you would have been glad to have got them againâ€”you tried hard for themâ€”why did you run away?
MR. CRAWFORD. Q. What do you mean by saying, "Why did you run away? A. When the prisoner found he could not get the money he bolted out of the shop and my husband after him.

NORMAN HENRY BROWN . I heard my wife charge the prisoner with the shilling being bad, that he had rung the changes, and I came forward and took the bad shilling from my wife's hand, and told him that it was badâ€”I proceeded to try it in the detectorâ€”he endeavoured to take it from my hand as I was in the act of trying it, and not succeeding, he bolted, and I went after himâ€”he was running away fastâ€”I did not catch himâ€”he was stopped by a policeman in plain clothes, and I gave him in charge with the bad shilling.

Prisoner. Q. When did you see me last? A. The 6th of March, at half-past 6 in the eveningâ€”I am quite sure you are the manâ€”when you came in I was in the parlour getting my teaâ€”I noticed no money on the counterâ€”I took the tad shilling from my wife (the witness's deposition being read stated "I came forward directly, I seized the shilling which was on the counter")â€”my wife was holding the money in this way, and I took it from her hand in hasteâ€”I tried it then in the detector, and after that you ran outâ€”you did not say that you would summons me the next day when you were sober, for the rest of your half-crownâ€”I do not remember anything of itâ€”I took the shilling to the station-houseâ€”I did not lose sight of itâ€”it is the same.

MR. CRAWFORD. Q. Was your wife taking it up from the counter at the time you seized it? A. She held it in her handâ€”she had just charged him with changing itâ€”I took it from her hand, and he attempted to get it from me, but did not succeedâ€”it was close on to the counter, and I took it and kept it till I got to Fleet-street.

SAMUEL GREENFIELD (City-policeman, 367). I was on duty in Upper Thames-street on the evening of 6th March, and saw the prisoner stopped by a policeman in plain clothes, and a lightermanâ€”Mr. Brown gave him into my chargeâ€”just before I got hold of him, I saw him drop this good shilling (produced) which was picked up and given to me at the time by the plain clothes officerâ€”I did not lose sight of itâ€”I took him with the plain clothes officer till I met a policeman in uniform, and directly after he took hold of him he was very troublesome, kicked the other one, and then shifted about, and put his hand in his pocket and threw out some more moneyâ€”I stooped down and saw something, I could not tell what it wasâ€”I got the plain clothes officer to pick it up, and it was two penny-piecesâ€”I took him to the station-houseâ€”when he was in the dock, and the inspector was taking the charge, he put his hand in his pocket again and dropped this good 2s. piece (produced)â€”I picked it upâ€”these (produced) are the two penniesâ€”he was searched and a halfpenny found on himâ€”Mr. Brown gave me this counterfeit shilling (produced) at the station-house.

JURY. Q. Was the prisoner sober? A. He had been drinking a littleâ€”he was not so drunk but that he knew what he was doingâ€”he was running quite fast when they stopped himâ€”I saw him run when I was down at the other end.

Prisoner. Q. Do you swear that you never lost sight of the 1s. 2d. which was picked up from the ground? A. Yes; when you were in the dock at the station, I placed the 1s. 2d. on the desk before the inspector to take charge of it, and you reached over and took it up, and had it in your handâ€”you did not put it in your pocketâ€”you said that the one shilling that laid on the desk and the twopence was the change out of the half-crown.

Prisoner. I told you to stand off, that I would not give it up till I heard what kind of a shilling it was that the female witness, Mrs. Brown, had lost; you said, "You had better give the shilling up again;" I said, "No, I shall not yet, till I understand the case, and you are bound to tell me true because I am tipsy;" and the inspector said, "Give me back the shilling, Mr. Connell, and it wont go hard with you;" is that right? Witness. The station-sergeant did say so; it was not an inspectorâ€”I did say, "Well, I don't sup
pose the prosecutor will press the charge against you"â€”you did not then give me back the shilling without any reluctanceâ€”the station-sergeant had to come out and take it out of your handâ€”you did not take it from the desk and put it into your pocketâ€”I never heard the Alderman at Guildhall tell me that I ought not to be in the forceâ€”when proceeding to the station

another constable came upâ€”the shilling dropped out of your pocket before thatâ€”the two-shilling piece did not drop out when you took out your pocket handkerchiefâ€”I took your handkerchief out of your breast-pocketâ€”you were not tipsyâ€”you had been drinking, but you knew what you were aboutâ€”had not been drinking very muchâ€”I had the 1s. 2d. in my hand, and I had to lay it in front of the inspector on the desk, and you reached over and took it up, and would not give it up; the station-sergeant had to come and help to take it out of your hand.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is a bad shilling.

Prisoner's Defence. The witness, Henry Brown, has sworn to a falsehood; he says he took the shilling off the counter, and the woman says she had them in her hand and never let them out of her hand; they lay on the counter, and all the time we were talking about them I could have taken them up off the oounter and gone about my business if I had liked; not being guilty, I let them lay there. She does not say she saw me touch the shillings, and I never handled them. She never marked or weighed the money, or sounded it, or tried it in the detector. She does not say what sort of shillings they were, Victoria, or William, or George the Third; she does not know whether they were good or bad. She say, "I think they were two good ones." The shilling that dropped out of my pocket was my own, and if it had not been I should never have given it up, but they held out a promise to me that they would not press the charge against me if I would give it up; I gave it np willingly. If ever there was a man sent to this Court innocent, I am that man, and as for running I was too tipsy to run. I had gone half way down the street when the prosecutor left the shop. He came up to me; I shoved him off with my-right hand, I never ran at all. He says I took it off the counter. That is a falsehood, and if he will say that he will say anything. I have got a respectable hard-working wife. I gave correct address, and the policeman saw my home, a clean respectable looking home. I have a family. I have no occasion to do such things. If I had done what a cunning man would have done, I should have put the had shilling under the good one, and not the bad shilling at the top.
GUILTY .â€”He was further charged with having been before convicted.

GEORGE HOBBS (Policeman, G 233). I produce a certificate ( Read: "Central Criminal Court, April, 1868, William Connell, convicted of feloniously uttering counterfeit coin.â€”Sentenced to Four Years' Penal Servitude.) I was present at the trialâ€”I had him in custodyâ€”I am quite certain the prisoner is the man who was then triedâ€”he gave the name of Francis Vandyke when I had him.
Prisoner. I acknowledge to the name of Vandyke but not of Connell.

GUILTY.**â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”The Right Hon. the LORD MAYOR; Mr. Baron WILDE; Mr. Ald. ROSE; Mr. Ald. PHILLIPS; Mr. Ald. CONDER; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
428.
CHLOM REICHBERG (45),
ABRAHAM JOSEPHSON (32), and
WOLFF HARWITZ (22), were indicted for
feloniously having in their possession, without the authority of the Emperor of Russia, certain copper Plates, stones, and other materials, upon which were engraved certain parts of a Russian promissory note.

GEORGE SCOTT . I am one of the detective officers of the Cityâ€”on 11th January, in the present year, I was with Brett and Legg, two other detective officers, in the Minoriesâ€”while there I saw Reichberg and Harwitzâ€”I took Harwitz into custody, and Brett took Reichbergâ€”they were both togetherâ€”I told them we apprehended them for forging Russian rouble notesâ€”they did not make any reply at that timeâ€”I conveyed Harwitz to the station and there searched himâ€”I found this type on him in this brown paper (produced) in his trousers pocketâ€”the type has a figure on itâ€”the brass is the numbers and the type is the borderâ€”there is some brass and some type metal, when put together it forms an ornamental borderâ€”Reichberg was searched by Brettâ€”I was present but I did not see him search himâ€”on the next day I went with Brett and Legg to a house, No. 28, Primrose-street, Bishopsgateâ€”this was on Sunday, 12th Januaryâ€”on going there I saw the prisoner Josephson standing at the doorâ€”I told him we were officers, and wanted to have a few words with himâ€”he took us up to the first floorâ€”I told him we wanted to put some questions to him, and the answers he gave us might be made use of as evidence against himâ€”I then asked him if he knew a person of the name of Reichberg, living at No. 12, Haberdasher-place, Hoxtonâ€”he said he didâ€”I asked him if he had done any business with himâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I asked him what businessâ€”he said that Reichberg was a diamond-setter, and had done several things for him in that businessâ€”I then asked him if he ever got any copper or zinc plates engraved for Reichbergâ€”he said, "No, never"â€”I said, "We must search your place"â€”he said, "Oh, yes; search any
where you please"â€”"By-the-bye," he said, "I must tell you about three months ago, I was in Liverpool, where I met a man named Mercer, who asked me my name and address, which I gave him; he then gave me a zinc plate which had some engraving on it, and asked me if I could get a copper plate engraved like it in London; I said I would try; he also gave me a copper plate of the size that he wanted the impression done, as a pattern. I brought it to London, and took it to London-wall and got it engraved"â€”I asked him where it wasâ€”he said, "Oh, I have not got it; I sent him a proof from it on paper, addressed, 'Post Restante, Liverpool," at the same time he brought this plate from the cupboard, and said, "Here it is"â€”he pulled it from under some paper in the cupboardâ€”I asked him where the copper plate was that he had got as a patternâ€”he said he had sent that to the gen
tleman, who promised to call and see him, but he had never seen him sinceâ€”I then took him into custody, and took him to the stationâ€”this is the plate that he so producedâ€”I had previously gone to 12, Haberdasher-placeâ€”after leaving him at the station I went there again and searchedâ€”I have stated what I found thereâ€”that was on the Monday, about 10 o'clock in the morningâ€”there was Andrews, the landlord, there, and Brett, my brother officer, and Inspector Leonardâ€”I found a great quantity of engraving tools, which are here, some colouring matter for printing, and all these other things which are producedâ€”here is a galvanic battery, tools of all kinds, chemicals, gutts percha, and wax for taking impressionsâ€”they were found in the second-floor front room, on the table, and in different parts, in the drawers and boxesâ€”I also found this paper, cut into sizes, ready for printingâ€”I afterwards went to 6, Bevington-street, that is a place also occupied by Reichbergâ€”I there found a letter-press, and a very heavy press which I do not know the name of; they are hereâ€”they were in the cellar or kitchen undergroundâ€”on Monday, 13th, I went to 65, Lower Thames-street, where a person of the name of Sanskowski had an officeâ€”I there found a copying press, which is

hereâ€”I had previously seen that press four or five days before, at 12, Haberdasher-placeâ€”it was being conveyed to that house, and I saw it in the houseâ€”I saw the prisoner Reichberg accompanying it to the houseâ€”Sans
kowski took me to No. 3, Mitre-square, Aldgate, his residence, and he took from a drawer in his bedroom there this piece of gutta-perchaâ€”it contained this plate, but the plate was not visible thenâ€”I subsequently held it to the fire and developed the plate which is now producedâ€”I have retained it in my possesion ever since, with the exception of the times I have had to produce it in courtâ€”on 16th January I went to No. 7, Somerset-street, Aldgate, that is a house occupied by a person of the name of Kattowskiâ€”I went to the back room on the ground floorâ€”in consequence of information I had received, I searched in that room and examined some of the pictures thereâ€”I took down a picture of Garibaldi, which I produce, and on taking the backboard from that picture I discovered these sixty-five forged ten rouble Russian notes which I produceâ€”Brett found a brass plate in a cupboard in that room; it has a figure "10" upon it, which is used for the water mark of the noteâ€”before the prisoner's were taken into custody I had seen them for something like two monthsâ€”I had seen Harwitz and Reichberg repeatedly in the streets, and at their housesâ€”I have seen them at the houses of Reichberg, where Harvitz was almost a daily visitor, sometimes there would be some week elapse, or a fortnight perhaps, and then Reichberg was out of the countryâ€”when he was in town they were together dailyâ€”I have seen Reichberg and Harwitz go to 6, Bevington-street together only onceâ€”I have seen them myself for about three monthsâ€”Brett has seen them longer.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST (for Reichberg). Q. Are the tools you found at Haberdasher-place such as are used by a diamond-setter or a jeweller? A. That I cannot tellâ€”I am not acquainted with the sort of tools used by a diamond-setterâ€”I never saw any to my knowledgeâ€”none of the things were concealedâ€”Reichberg had evidently done some work thereâ€”things were lying about just as if they had been usedâ€”there was no concealment at allâ€”I only know by hearsay what countryman he isâ€”he spoke English very im
perfectly.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON (with MR. LLOYD for Josephson). Q. Had you this conversation with Joesphson at his own lodgings? A. Yes; I be
lieve he had not the whole house, only the first-floor back and front roomsâ€”to took me on to the first-floorâ€”he did not tell me at that time that he was a travelling jewellerâ€”he told me that he was a jeweller at that time, and afterwards he told me he was a travelling and working jewellerâ€”he did not say that it was in the course of his travels that he received this order about the plate at Liverpoolâ€”he said he was at Liverpoolâ€”he handed me the plateâ€”he did not tell me that plate was given him by the person at liver
poolâ€”he said he gave him a copper plate the size of that that he wanted doneâ€”he said the person gave him the engraving on zinc, and also gave him a copper plate, and on the copper plate he was to get engraved that which was on the zincâ€”I did not find any zinc plateâ€”he said he had sent it backâ€”nothing was said about the coming Exhibitionâ€”this is exactly in the same sate as when I got it from him, with the exception of some proofs having been pulled from itâ€”I saw his jewel-case in the roomâ€”he took this plate from a cupboard at the side of the fire-placeâ€”his wife was in the room, no childrenâ€”I do not know that he has been living there sometime; he had been there the time we had been watching; three or four monthsâ€”I commenced to watch somewhere in November, others had been watching before thatâ€”I cannot say that he has been there all the time I was watchingâ€”I found nothing but the jewel-case having reference to his trade.

Harwitz. Q. Did not I ask you what you took me for? A. Yes; you asked me I should say a dozen times going along, and I repeatedly told you the types that I found in your pocket were wrapped in paper, and the packet was sealedâ€”I found a key in your pocket, of 4, Little Prescott-street, and another key alsoâ€”I believe the landlord of 6, Bevington-street will speak to thatâ€”I told the Lord Mayor that I found a key in your pocket belonging to 6, Bevington-streetâ€”I found some papers in your pocketâ€”I cannot read themâ€”it is some foreign correspondenceâ€”it appeared to me to be Hebrewâ€”I do not know whether it was Russianâ€”I am not familiar with Russian characters.

JAMES BRETT . I am a detective officer of the Cityâ€”at the latter end of last year, I was communicated with, with reference to some persons who were obtaining engravingsâ€”in consequence of that I watched the three prisoners; at the latter part of the time I was generally in company with the witness Scottâ€”I began the watching and Scott assisted me subsequentlyâ€”I produce certain articles which have been referred to by Scottâ€”here are three impressions from a plate which I found in a box at 12, Haber
dasher-place, where the bulk of those things were foundâ€”they were in a book in Reichberg's roomâ€”I also found a paper impression of an eagle, on a table in the same roomâ€”it was lying openly on the table, and in another book I found a piece of metal with Russian characters upon itâ€”it is a thin piece of copperâ€”in this box, which I took from under the bed, I found a quantity of wax, which had originally formed a square; and on examining that wax I found Russian characters on some of itâ€”it is all here, but it is broken nowâ€”it would have formed a square about this sizeâ€”I also found a small box of red inkâ€”also a plain brass plateâ€”I was present when the other things, which have been spoken to, were foundâ€”when I took Reichberg into custody, on the 11th, I found on him two 100 rouble notes, two ten rouble notes, some papers, and that which forms the back border of a 10 rouble noteâ€”the 100 rouble notes, and the 10 rouble notes are goodâ€”at 6, Bevington-street, I found this card, on the letter-pressâ€”I went there with the other officerâ€”I removed this piece of parchment from the fly-pressâ€”it is part of the letter-press belonging to the larger press now produced, which was found in the cellar at 6, Bevington-streetâ€”Scott took a key out of Harwitz's pocketâ€”it did not fit any look, because the lock had been taken off, but the landlord said it would fit the lock that was on at the time they took the placeâ€”at 7, Somerset-place, I found the water-mark plate that has been produced by Scott.
Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. Was Reichberg present when you searched Haberdasher-place and found these things? A. No; he was in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. Did you watch Josephson's house? A. I did; I began to do so on 9th November, and I watched it from that time till he was in custody, occasionallyâ€”I was not always watching it.

MR. BEST. Q. Do you know whether these are jeweller's tools that were found there? A. I should say, certainly notâ€”they are very heavy toolsâ€”hammers, and such things as would not be used by a jeweller, I should thinkâ€”there are a great number of engraving tools and punches.

JAMES WOOD . I carry on business, in partnership, in West Smithfield, as an engraver and type founderâ€”on or about the 5th October last, the prisoner Reichberg and another man calledâ€”I did not speak to him on that occasion, some one else didâ€”I saw him again about 17th or 18th of Octoberâ€”he was then accompanied by Harwitzâ€”all the conversation with Reich

berg took place through Harwitzâ€”he acted as interpreterâ€”they pro
duced an engraved steel punch, and asked me to strike it into a copper matrixâ€”it was an ornamental punch, the back of a 10 rouble noteâ€”when put together the pieces would form the border of a 10 rouble noteâ€”the types were cast more than sufficient to go round the borderâ€”they had five or six pounds of borderâ€”the punch was exactly similar to that one (produced)â€”it is made in steel, and struck into a piece of copper, and any number of types, similar to these, are cast from itâ€”it corresponds in all its character
istics with the types hereâ€”they asked me to cast them four or five pounds weight of type, and I engaged with them as to price, which was our usual list priceâ€”they left the order with me to be executedâ€”they called again a few days afterwardsâ€”I had the order then executed for themâ€”I gave them the type which I had manufactured, and they paid me for it and went awayâ€”two or three days after I had another visit from themâ€”they brought me the type, stating that it was not close enough together; that it spread out too muchâ€”after some conversation that day they left, and came again the next day, and there was a further order for some figuresâ€”it in not in brassâ€”it was like this impressionâ€”I made it of type metalâ€”here is one of them mixed up with the borderâ€”this is a figure "3"â€”this paper was left with me as a pattern, for the purpose of making up a printer's formâ€”it would take about 120 pieces of the type placed together to form thatâ€”they produced this to show me how it ought to beâ€”that writing was on it when I received itâ€”they also left this piece of card with me to show the sizeâ€”after having received these explanations from them, I went on with the work in their absence, and they both called again about 6th Novemberâ€”I then had the border readyâ€”I think I had better refer to my notes nowâ€”my suspicions were aroused on 6th November, and I gave infor
mation to the police, and commenced making notes of every thing afterwardsâ€”they produced a small piece of paper on which was an impression of a Russian eagle, precisely the same size as on a genuine rouble note, as far as I can judge by afterwards seeing a genuine noteâ€”they asked me if I could engrave thatâ€”I told them "Yes"â€”they ordered it to be engravedâ€”a few minutes afterwards, I think about ten minutes, Harwitz came back and requested the patternâ€”he said that the other, alluding to Reichberg (I did not know their names then), was a beautiful engraver, and that he had altered his mind, and would engrave it himselfâ€”I gave the pattern back to himâ€”I next saw Reichberg alone about the 9th of Novemberâ€”on the previous visits Harwitz had acted as interpreterâ€”when Reichberg called alone on this occasion he spoke English quite intelligibly to meâ€”he pro
duced a piece of coloured printing, and asked if I could make him some printing-ink of that colourâ€”it was crimson inkâ€”I and one of my men mixed a few samples and pulled some impressions to show him what could be doneâ€”he said it was not good enough, there was not enough fire in the colourâ€”I had been pulling off some on our own paper, and he produced some paper out of his pocket, the size of which I know to be the size of a 10 rouble note, because we had some of them leftâ€”he requested it to be pulled upon that paper, and that altered the colour again; it did not look so well on his paper, and he wanted the form alteredâ€”I complained that it was not a paper that it should be done on, and he said, "Oh! this is bank-Paper; I want it tried on this paper"â€”two of my men were present at the timeâ€”I did not suit him at lastâ€”he asked me if I had a copper-plate press that I could sell himâ€”I told him I had one, and I walked with him round to our stores to show it to himâ€”he did not buy itâ€”it was too largeâ€”he ordered

a small one, a new oneâ€”I had not any in stock, and I subsequently pro
cured it for himâ€”I did not supply it to himâ€”I supplied him with a letter-pressâ€”I made the border as you see thereâ€”it was scarcely the size he requiredâ€”he wanted it to come in a little closerâ€”I filled in two of these types halfway, so as to put one half in the border on each side, and I said, "I will take this out, as your border will be exactly the size you refer to"â€”he said, "Oh! no; I must have the halves in," and on looking at a genuine note I see that the halves are in thereâ€”this paper was pulled in my establishment from the border which I made for them, and these pencil marks at the side indicate the places where it was altered; where the half pieces were placedâ€”this is the type as completedâ€”these punches are the figures for numberingâ€”Reichberg gave them to me to make types fromâ€”before types can be produced a punch has to be made, and then the metal type is produced from thatâ€”Reichberg brought me this piece of paper, which has figures on it, to show me how close they were to come togetherâ€”I think there were eleven punches altogether, and according to those punches I cast the typeâ€”this is a proof taken from the type cast from the punches which he gave meâ€”the 11th November was the next time I saw themâ€”they were not quite ready then, and they called again on the 14thâ€”on that day they were completed, late in the afternoonâ€”on that occasion they purchased from me a type-holder, which is adapted to take type and hold it in form for the purpose of printing from itâ€”I did not sell them the type-holderâ€”they never had it; they ordered itâ€”on 15th November Reichberg and Harwitz called about 1 o'clock, and paid a further deposit on the press, paid for the border and figures, took them away with them, and took away the figure punches, and had the matrixes four and five alteredâ€”on the 18th Harwitz called aloneâ€”when the account was made up I had occasion to ask what name I should make it out in, and he said, "Wolf"â€”on that occasion the press was taken away by Watson, one of my men, by my directionâ€”Harwitz accompanied him with itâ€”they left my place togetherâ€”I have seen that press here to-day; it is the letter-press with the brass topâ€”this parchment is the tympanum of that letter-press, and there is an impression on that of the figures, and also of the border.

COURT. Q. Can you say by looking at that, that that press has been used for the purpose of taking impressions both of the type you made for the border, and the type you made for the figures? A. Exactly so.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. When did you first begin to make these memoranda? A. On 6th Novemberâ€”Reichberg had been there several times previous to thatâ€”I had communicated with the police before making these notesâ€”I think the notes were made at their suggestion.

Harwitz. Q. To whom did you deliver the types? A. I think you were both present when you had themâ€”I think the first lot was delivered to you; but I won't speak positivelyâ€”I know one lot Reichberg had, because that was when he came aloneâ€”you acted as interpreter for Reichbergâ€”I think the second lot was delivered to Reichberg, but I do not knowâ€”I did not ask you your nameâ€”I asked what name I should put on the invoiceâ€”I made no memorandum until 6th Novemberâ€”I made the memorands because I suspected that you were forging some foreign noteâ€”I gave information to the police, and they were of the same opinion as myself, and after that I immediately made memoranda after every time you calledâ€”I made a matrix for youâ€”when I was before the Lord Mayor I answered the questions that were put to meâ€”I stated that you visited me between the 1st and 2d of Novemberâ€”you visited me on the 9th, Saturdayâ€”I did not
see either of you between the 6th and Saturday, the 9 thâ€”I had no suspicion on the last or 2d.

JAMES WATSON . I am in the employ of Mr. Woodâ€”on 18th November last, I took one of these presses from Mr. Wood's premises, to No. 6, Bevington-streetâ€”Harwitz accompanied meâ€”I placed the press in the kitchen of that house.

EBENEZER COX . I am a typographic engraver, at No. 6, Upper South-ampton-steet, Pentonvilleâ€”I know the prisoners Harwitz and Reichbergâ€”they came to my place on 8th Octoberâ€”I showed them some, specimens at their requestâ€”they gave no names at that timeâ€”Reichberg produced a patternâ€”this (produced) is not the patternâ€”that is the proof that I furnished after the work was doneâ€”I engraved something from the pattern which they gave meâ€”a few days afterwards, I believe on the 14th of Octo
ber, Reichberg called aloneâ€”I showed him this proofâ€”it contains a piece of the border of a ten rouble noteâ€”I have seen one since, and compared themâ€”a day or two afterwards, I think almost the very next day, Reich
berg and Harwitz called, and on that occasion they produced a piece of gutta perchaâ€”this is itâ€”I was to cut alphabets for these three sizes, and also another alphabet of a larger size, a pattern of which he would furnish me withâ€”there was to be 150 in all; 150 punches for the purpose of making types fromâ€”I have forgotten to name that on the 14th Reichberg also asked me if I could cut eaglesâ€”I said, "Oh! yes; anything"â€”they were both together when the piece of gutta percha was given to meâ€”Reich
berg requested me to cut two or three of the punches as specimensâ€”they frequently visited me between the 10th and the 18thâ€”a day or two aferwards I think Reichberg called alone, and then he produced an orna
mental coloured border similar to one upon a Russian rouble note, which he asked me to engraveâ€”certain portions of this border had been cut outâ€”he engaged to have the engine-turned parts done, and only requested me to do the other partâ€”he was also to furnish the paper ready preparedâ€”I engaged to do my part for 3l.â€”I did not do itâ€”he took the pattern away with him, without saying anything about itâ€”I had got a Russian alphabet at that timeâ€”this is it (produced)â€”he supplied me with itâ€”he wrote that on the 18thâ€”he also supplied me with a Russian book some time afterwards, so as to enable me to manage the letters properlyâ€”it was impossible to do it withoutâ€”Harwitz called on me again in the beginning of November, and produced the impressions of two Russian eaglesâ€”these are themâ€”I was to engrave themâ€”I was to have 8l. for the twoâ€”that would be a low priceâ€”he brought me to a lower figure than paid meâ€”I found the pattern was not food enough, it was so indistinct, I could not produce a good eagle from itâ€”I communicated that to both of themâ€”Harwitz and Reichberg called, I think, in a day or two, and they produced thisâ€”that is a better patternâ€”this gutta percha has the impression of a coinâ€”they also produced a silver coin, and also a small Russian eagle, very much better than the, other, to tell how the different pieces were to be doneâ€”the shields were to very indifferent on the one they brought me that I could not make anything of itâ€”this was to give me an idea of the quartering of the shields, and so onâ€”I struck off a proof, and was to send a further proof to St. Martin's-le
grandâ€”Harwitz had told me that Reichberg's name was Hartâ€”he did not my what his own name was, but I received this letter from him in the name of Wolff, after the order for the eagleâ€”after I had received that letter Harwitz came to meâ€”it was on the following Mondayâ€”he asked if I had received letter from him, and I said I hadâ€”(Letter reead:"Calais 13â€”12

â€”61. Dear Sir,â€”I beg of you to send to me, under the enclosed address two copies of the two eagles, however they may be done or undone, as I want to show your work, which will be for your advantage; hoping you will comply without delay with my request, I remain with regard, yours, WOLFF. The enclosed address is the place where I reside. If you cannot send the two copies until Saturday, at 4 o'clock, you do not want to send them at all, as I will leave Calais next Sunday afternoon, and if I do not deserve to receive of you this favour, at least send me a few lines. We re
ceive letters in France on Sunday, and, therefore, if you send an answer on Saturday before 4 o'clock, I shall receive it on next Sunday morning.")â€”I told him the large eagle was not in a sufficiently forward state, and he called again on the Thursdayâ€”I did not at any time give him any proofs of the large eagleâ€”I did of the small one.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. You say you were shown by Reich
berg patterns of eagles, did you give those patterns back again to him? A. No; I kept them uutil I gave them up to the solicitorâ€”they have been produced to-dayâ€”I have had possession of all the patterns that have been shown me to-day.

Harwitz. Q. Who came to you first? A. I think it was Reichbergâ€”I did not make a memorandumâ€”I made the usual memorandum in my bookâ€”you were the interpreter; but Reichberg, I believe, gave me the orderâ€”I asked 4l. or 5l. in brass, and 9l. or 10l. in steelâ€”he offered me 8l.â€”I agreed to do them for 8l.â€”I took 2l. deposit from him, and I afterwards had 2l. on accountâ€”I did not write any letter to Reichbergâ€”I did not call him by his name, or ask his nameâ€”I can't say exactly in what manner you told me his nameâ€”I did not ask it; you told me on one of those interviewsâ€”I only knew your name was Wolff from the letter I receivedâ€”I made the punches for 4l. 6s.â€”I received 30s. for the border punch, and a few shil
lings for the matrixâ€”Reichberg took the punch away, and he also borrowed a small punch to show his friendâ€”I made them for Reichberg; you acted as interpreter: I looked upon you in no other lightâ€”Reichberg asked me the price, and we agreed for 30s.

JOHN GIRLING . I am servant to Mr. Roberts, a printer, of 41, Tabernacle-walkâ€”Harwitz and Reichberg called at Mr. Roberts' at the latter end of Septemberâ€”I saw themâ€”Harwitz was spokesmanâ€”they came to ask the price of printing 1,000 copies of a formâ€”he described the size on a piece of paperâ€”I have not got thatâ€”it was merely a piece of waste paper that was lying on the desk at the timeâ€”I told him that the price would be about 4s. a thousandâ€”he said he would call againâ€”about the beginning of October Reichberg came alone, and produced thisâ€”it is a border similar to that on the back of a Russian rouble noteâ€”it is set up in an iron frame, what we call a formâ€”I took some proofs of itâ€”Reichberg examined itâ€”he made an objection to it on account of their not being sufficiently close togetherâ€”I said I would try to remedy that defect for him, which I did by taking out the side piece that is now here, and substituting an oblong piece of metal; but I found it would not justify; that is, it would not come close enough together so as to give a just or true impressionâ€”in about a fortnight Reich
berg came again, and brought a fresh quantity of type to substitute for that which was in the first frameâ€”that would not do eitherâ€”he told me he was going to exhibit it at the Great Exhibitionâ€”I noticed some half and quarter pieces of borderâ€”he called my attention to them, said that it was to place them in their respective positions, the same as they were in the first formâ€”that would have brought out a similar representation to what is on

that paperâ€”he asked me whether I know a type founderâ€”I gave him the name of Messrs. Caslon and Co.â€”about the litter end of November I saw them againâ€”I then pulled some proofs from a fresh formâ€”Reichberg pro
duced the formâ€”I have not got it, or any of the proofsâ€”there it what we term a make-ready sheetâ€”Reichberg objected to my filing itâ€”it was an impression from a glythographic blockâ€”it was an impression of some foreign charactersâ€”I gave it up to himâ€”that was at the beginning of Decemberâ€”I did not supply him with any paper.
Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. You did not know what the foreign characters were, did you? A. I did not.
Harwitz. Q. Did not you state before the Lord Mayor that I was only there once? Witness. That was the only time I recollect; you were there the first time.

WILLIAM JAMES BALL . I am assistant to Mr. Bettaridge, press
maker of 47, Old Baileyâ€”in the commencement of August last, Reichberg called at Mr. Betteridge'sâ€”I believe the first time he called, he wanted me to make him a steel or brass plateâ€”he gave me the sizeâ€”it was the size of this (the brass plate)â€”there were to be two brass plates, both plainâ€”he also ordered a hundred type and four "No's," "N," and a small "o" at the topâ€”he wanted ten sets in all, consisting of figures, each up to 10; not differ
ent sizes, all one size; and four type keys, adapted to fit tbe typeâ€”I exe
cuted that order for himâ€”on 13th August he took the articles away, and paid me for themâ€”in September, I believe, Reichberg called againâ€”on that occasion he gave me an order for the figure "10" cut in steelâ€”this is itâ€”the plates were quite plain when he received themâ€”Reichberg took them awayâ€”I saw him again two or three days after he received the plates in Septemberâ€”he had ordered some plates in August, but not theseâ€”in Septem
ber he ordered these twoâ€”I made both of these; but they were both plain when Reichberg received themâ€”two or three days after he took these plates away, he brought a paper bag, and wanted to know if we could cut one similar to what if on the plateâ€”I did not do that, and he received the pat
tern backâ€”some days afterwards, Reichberg called and produced some paper, I should think about a ream, and wished it out upâ€”some of it is hereâ€”I cut it for him, and he took it away with himâ€”when he brought the paper, he laid it one way, and wished the whole of the water-mark to be cut offâ€”the water-mark is on the bottom of the paper; it occupies about 2 inches or 2 1/2 inchesâ€”I have a portion of the water-mark hereâ€”I preserved it.

JAMES SKINNER . I carry on business as a photographer, at 47, Lower Whitecross-streetâ€”in November last, Reichberg and Harwitz called on meâ€”they produced a copper-plate, and asked me to make two electrotypes of itâ€”this is itâ€”I said I could not do it perfect except it was left with meâ€”they said they could not leave it, they had borrowed it of a friend; and they took it awayâ€”they called again afterwards, and showed me a small piece of Paper with some foreign engraving upon itâ€”they wanted me to produce a glytho of itâ€”I did so; and they took it away.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. Do you mean to swear to that being the very plate they brought to you? A. I doâ€”I examined it so thoroughly; and I am certain of itâ€”there are things here which have been taken out, and it has been done by a person that did not understand itâ€”I can swear that that is the plate that was shown me.
MR. SLEIGH. Q. You are a practical engraver, I believe? A. Yesâ€”I examined it thoroughly.
Harwitz. Q. Which day did we come to you? A. I have no datesâ€”it
was in November, I think the beginningâ€”I saw Reichberg first alone, and he asked for my card, and said he would call again.

JAMES JOYOE . I was assistant to Mr. Cripps, stationer, of 24, Skinner street, Snowhill, at the time in questionâ€”I have left sinceâ€”in the beginning of August Reichberg called at Mr. Cripps' establishmentâ€”I think he brought a sheet of paper with himâ€”I am not quite certainâ€”he asked the price of our large creamo bank postâ€”I gave him the price, and showed him a sampleâ€”he looked at it and saw the water-mark, and he said, "Can I have it without the water-mark"â€”the water-mark was down the corner, J. Whatman, 1861â€”I said, "No"â€”he said, "Can I have it with a wavy line in it?"â€”I said, "No"â€”he then said, "Get up two or three reams of it from the mill" (as we happened to be out of stock at the time) "and I will call again"â€”I got some for himâ€”he came at the latter end of August, had a ream, and paid for itâ€”this produced is a portion of the paper I sold him.

ROBERT DUNFORD . I am assistant to Messrs. B. Smith and Son, printing ink manufacturers, Wine office-courtâ€”about 27th September last, Harwitz and Reichberg called and asked for some coloured inkâ€”they wanted some particular coloured red inkâ€”they said they were recommended to our firm by Messrs. Adams and Geeâ€”I showed them a specimen of red inkâ€”Harwitz said that was not the colourâ€”Reichberg then took a small border printed on paper, out of his pocket, and said that was the colour he wanted: I said, "You want Carmine:" he said, "Yes, Carmine"â€”I supplied him with a box similar to thisâ€”I have not the least doubt this is the boxâ€”it is exactly like itâ€”I charged him 1s. 6d. for itâ€”it would print at least 500 of the borders that I have been shown.

THOMAS RAWLINS . I am a lithographic printer, at 38, Whitecross-street-place, Finsburyâ€”the prisoner Josephson, called on me, with another man, about a fortnight after Whitsuntide, last yearâ€”he asked me if I would put his brother-in-law in the way of lithographic printing; he pointed out the party who was with him as his brother-in-lawâ€”I asked him in what respect he wished to knowâ€”he said, "The process of pulling an impression from a a copper-plate and transferring it to the stoneâ€”I told him I had no objection to doing so, and I took a copper-plate and pulled an impression, and trans
ferred it to a stone of my ownâ€”I did that before themâ€”after I had shown them the process, and answered several questions that they asked me, they left me with the impression that his brother-in-law would be able to accom
plish itâ€”he said, when he went away, that he should be able to accomplish itâ€”in about ten days or somewhere thereabouts afterwards they both came together again and purchased a sheet of transfer paper; that is paper with a composition upon it that would pull the impression from the plates, for the purpose of transferring to the stoneâ€”they paid me for the paper and leftâ€”about a week or a fortnight afterwards they came again, and brought a copper-plateâ€”to the best of my belief this (produced) is itâ€”the writing looks like it, but I cannot swear positively to itâ€”it is very similar to itâ€”the plate I had had a border round it; this has not, but there has been a border taken out hereâ€”unless the border has been removed this is not the plateâ€”Josephson asked me to pull him two impressions from this plate on my paper for transferringâ€”I asked him for what purposeâ€”I asked the other man, and he said it was for him to transfer to the stoneâ€”I did what was required of meâ€”it took me perhaps half-an-hourâ€”he said he had a lithographic press of his own, that he was an artist, and wished an insight for his own amusement.
COURT. Q. Who said so? A. The other man, Josephson's brother-in-law, as I understood he wasâ€”that other man was neither of the prisoners.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Did they, on a subsequent occasion, call, and did Josephson produce the same copper plate a second time? A. Yes; they came a second time, and I pulled two more impressions, and transferred it to stone for themâ€”the paper was my own paper, transfer paper with the composition upon itâ€”they brought some paper with them some
time after thatâ€”the stone that I transferred it to they took away with them, after I had got it in printing condition.
COURT. Q. Then it was fit to print from? A. Yes.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Did they call again a third time, with another stone, a stone of their own, not yours? A. The next time they came I think they came without bringing the stone, and asked me if I would have any objection to print them a few copies myself from a stone of my ownâ€”I had not made a stoneâ€”they brought the plate for me to take fresh copies from that, and I was to transfer that to a stone of my own, and print them copies from itâ€”they brought the paper then to have it printed onâ€”I printed them on that occasion perhaps thirty or forty impressionsâ€”they took them away with themâ€”it was paper exactly like this producedâ€”the last time I saw them must have been somewhere near Septemberâ€”I struck them off another batch of copiesâ€”after the occasion to which I have last spoken, Josephson's friend came, and was with me I dare say three hoursâ€”he was by himself on that occasion, and I think he had about 200 impressions or moreâ€”Josephson at one time asked me what price I charged per thousand for printing these bordersâ€”I told him it would be 8s. or 9s.â€”this is similar to the plate I had, but it had no eagle on itâ€”it is very similar in general appearance to what I printed, but at the time I printed it there was no eagle, and no numberâ€”the black border and the centre writing were there, not the red borderâ€”this border looks very much like part of what I printedâ€”when I did print I printed with the borderâ€”I think these two top lines were not on it when I had it.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Is there anything peculiar in this paper? A. Nothing more than it is commonly called foreign bank post paperâ€”I know it as suchâ€”I do not know that it is used for other purposesâ€”I have seen it beforeâ€”I have printed note headings on it, to be kept in offices to write notes onâ€”I am quite familiar with the style of paperâ€”this border is very similar to the one I sawâ€”I should say it was the same border, but I could not say it was my printingâ€”I have never put any sort of orna
ment upon paper of this kind before, not for notesâ€”I have perhaps put a coat of arms or a die, or anything which was wastedâ€”I never put a border, I can swear thatâ€”Josephson did not come on all occasionsâ€”the other man came by himself sometimesâ€”perhaps one would call and then the two would call the next time, and one after that againâ€”I never knew when they were comingâ€”no arrangement was ever made.

BENJAMIN HILLINER . I am an ornamental engraver, carrying on business at 5, London-wallâ€”in November last year, the prisoner Josephson called on, me at my place of businessâ€”he brought with him a circular zinc plate with some engine turned work upon itâ€”he wanted me to make a copper plate similar to itâ€”he left it with meâ€”I told him I could do something very near it, not exactlyâ€”he seemed satisfiedâ€”he did not describe himself as of any business, the first time he cameâ€”the second time he came he said he was a travelling watchmaker and jewellerâ€”he carried his case about with himâ€”he came again about a week afterwardsâ€”it was not completed thenâ€”it was completed a few days afterwardsâ€”I then handed it to him; he took it away and paid for itâ€”this (produced by Scott) is the plate.
Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Was the zinc plate a circular one?
A. Yes; the pattern one wasâ€”the engraving in the centre was about the same size as the part that is cut out in thisâ€”I made it as like the one he brought as possible.

ANDREW ROURKE . In July last Josephson called on me and purchased a small zinc plateâ€”for about two months afterwards he called frequently, and had other copper and zinc plates, always about the same sizeâ€”I cannot say exactly how manyâ€”they were about eight inches by fourâ€”they were not so large as this plateâ€”it would be sufficient for the circle to be engraved onâ€”he came in December with Reichberg, and asked me if I recollected his having some plates from me previouslyâ€”I said I didâ€”he said he had brought his friend and wanted me to do a job for him in the making of platesâ€”he said he wanted a copper plate made of an extra substance, extra thick, and he wanted a centre cut from the plate so as to make a borderâ€”I showed him some plates that I had in, but none of them were stout enoughâ€”he left my place then, with the impression that he was coming back again, but he did not come backâ€”the prisoner Harwitz called about a week afterwards, and brought a piece of paper and gave it me as a pattern to cut the border fromâ€”I have not got that; he took it back with himâ€”I was to cut the copper plate so as to represent the piece of paper that he brought with him as a borderâ€”I prepared the border, and Harwitz called and paid for it, and took it away with himâ€”this is the centre that I cut from the plateâ€”there is no engraving upon itâ€”the border was to be prepared for engraving, but the centre was not requiredâ€”Harwitz did not refer at all to the other persons, when he came, he merely said that he wanted me to make a plate the size of the border that he broughtâ€”it was a piece of plain paper that he broughtâ€”I was to cut a plate and prepare it for engraving.

COURT. Q. What you were to do was only to cut a piece out of the solid plate, and prepare it for engraving. A. Yes; the piece of paper was only to show me the size of the piece I was to out; I had nothing to do with en
gravingâ€”it was merely a plate to be prepared for engraving.

Harwitz. Q. Did you ask me if it belonged to me? A.
