You brought the plate yourself; Reichberg had had no plate from me before thisâ€”he wanted a border similar to the one you brought meâ€”Reichberg never brought me any plateâ€”I did not ask you for what purpose you wanted itâ€”it was not my business to ask any such question as that.

ELIZABETH COLEMAN . I live at 6, Bevington-street, Hoxtonâ€”in Novem
ber last Reichberg hired a kitchen in that house from me, for half a crown a weekâ€”he remained until he was taken into custodyâ€”while he was there he had a latch key to let himself in and outâ€”I have often seen Harwitz there, as much as Reichberg, and I have seen Mrs. Josephson thereâ€”I never saw Josephson thereâ€”sometimes one paid the rent, and sometimes the other; Mrs. Josephson, Reichberg, and Harwitzâ€”this (produced) is the key they had.

ABRAHAM SANSKOWSKI . I live at 3, Mitre-street, Aldgateâ€”I have an office at 65, Lower Thames-streetâ€”I have known Reichberg about four yearsâ€”he used to call on me at Mitre-streetâ€”at my place in Lower Thames-street I have a copying machineâ€”Reichberg lent me that, as mine was brokenâ€”after the prisoners were taken into custody, I gave the officer Scott a piece of gutta-perchaâ€”this is it (produced)â€”Reichberg gave it me as a sampleâ€”it was a plain piece then, like this, on both sidesâ€”I could not see that anything was insideâ€”I was to take care of it for him until he should ask me for it.
COURT. Q. When was it he gave it to you? A. I cannot say exactlyâ€”he brought it to my residence.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Was it some months before? A. It was two months or more before he gave me the copying machineâ€”it might be less; I cannot say exactlyâ€”he gave it to me for a sampleâ€”I was to give it him again when he should ask meâ€”he did not tell me particularly to take care of itâ€”I was not to use it for my ownâ€”a man begged me to buy some gutta-percha for him, and I told him I did not deal in it; and one morning I went out and in
quired for a sample, and Reichberg said he would bring me a sample, and he brought me this afterwardsâ€”he said nothing about a copper plate being inside the gutta-percha, and I did not know it until three or four days after it was taken from me.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. Have you known Reichberg long? A. Three or four years, from Odessaâ€”I was away from here about six monthsâ€”I came back at the end of Julyâ€”I cannot say how many times I saw Reichberg between July and the time I saw Scottâ€”it may be four, five, or six timesâ€”I have seen him at a house where I go to eatâ€”he is a man I was not particularly friendly withâ€”he is a diamond merchant, or diamond setterâ€”I am a merchant, dealing in East India goods, or colonial goodsâ€”I buy pepper, spice, coffee, drugs, and such thingsâ€”I did not go to Scottâ€”he came to my office, and asked were I had this machine fromâ€”I and, "From Mr. Reichberg"â€”he said, "What have you got more?"â€”I said, "I have no more from him, only a piece of gutta-percha"â€”he said he was taken for forgery, and that was the way I came to give him the gutta-perchaâ€”I did not know Scott till he came to my office.

ABRAHAM MAURICE KATTOWSKI . I live at 7, Somerset-street, Aldgateâ€”I know Harwitzâ€”he lodged in the same house, and in the same room that I did, in the course of last year, for about six monthsâ€”after he was taken into custody, the officer Scott came there, on a Wednesday evening, the 15th of Januaryâ€”no one occupied that room but Harwitz and I at that timeâ€”there was another young man, but he had leftâ€”I saw Scott take down some pictures, and amongst others the picture of Garibaldi, which has been pro
ducedâ€”that picture belonged to Harwitzâ€”I saw Scott take the back board from it, and find the notes that have been produced to-dayâ€”I had no idea that they were there.

Harwitz. Q. Did not you ask me, when I gave you notice, to make you a present of that picture? A. I asked you what present you would let me have when you left the place, for living so long togetherâ€”that was before you thought of moving, and you said you would leave me that picture; but I did not think there was anything in itâ€”you did not say you would give it me thenâ€”I know Reichbergâ€”I have very often seen him with youâ€”he lived in the front parlour for a few weeks, about a year before.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. I believe you saw the plate found, and directed the officers attention to the cupboard? A. Yes; the officer asked me whether Harwitz had some things left in the place, and I pointed out the cupboard, and he produced the plate from thereâ€”it was sealed upâ€”it is the plate with the figure 10 on it.

EUGENE KLEIN . I am a member of the Russian credit note department, at St. Petersburgâ€”I am employed in the department of the Minister of finance for the manufacture of bank notes, and all other State papersâ€”bank notes and their manufacture come under my supervisionâ€”a ten rouble note is a note circulated throughout Russiaâ€”a rouble represents somewhere about 3s. English moneyâ€”I have with me a genuine ten rouble noteâ€”the sixty-five rouble notes produced, found behind the picture, are forgedâ€”I am sure of that.
COURT. Q. Are they something like a ten rouble note? A. Yes; they are very skilful forgeries, therefore the more dangerous.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. I suppose none but those well acquainted with them would be able to discover they were forgeries? A. I think soâ€”I have looked through the type, and the different engraving tools and things produced by the officersâ€”I do not find any plate that would agree with these notesâ€”as far as I can judge these notes are printed from other plates; not those that have been produced by the officersâ€”as to the back part of the note I am sure of itâ€”this small printing on the back part of the notes contains some mistakes in orthography, which show me that this was not printed from the plates which have been producedâ€”with regard to the eagles, the borders, and the other parts, I am not able to pronounce an opinion about thenâ€”it is very difficult to say as to thatâ€”they may or may not be printed from thisâ€”it would be impossible to say for certainâ€”I have had certain impressions struck from the type that has been produced, and also from the plates.
MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you do it yourself? A. No; I have seen it done.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. With regard to the first one with the water-mark, did you see that struck? A. No; I did not see that struckâ€”I have looked through the translation of that and found it correctâ€”it pur
ports to be the writing that would be on the back of a Russian rouble noteâ€”there are also some characters on a small piece of gutta-percha (produced)â€”I translated thatâ€”it is, "Currency is given," on the first line; "Currency is given," on the second line; and "Currency is given throughout the whole empire the same as silver," on the third lineâ€”that would be on parts of a Russian ten rouble noteâ€”I have seen the water-markâ€”it is an imitation of the water-mark of a Russian rouble noteâ€”the border on a genuine rouble note is a circle exactly like thisâ€”I have got a genuine rouble note here (comparing them)â€”I have seen some impressions produced by the officers from this circle found upon Harwitz or Reichbergâ€”in my opinion they have been struck off from this plateâ€”they are, in all apparent respects, similarâ€”this is quite such a border as would be put on a Russian rouble noteâ€”it is very well doneâ€”here it an impression of an eagleâ€”that would be upon a Russian ten rouble noteâ€”that is very well doneâ€”here is another eagle, which also represents the eagle at the back of the note; and here are some numbers which are quite like the numbers employed in the numbering of a Russian note, and would be required to make them perfectâ€”all that is wanted to make the note complete is the ornamental border on the front part, with the writing; in all other respects there are all the materials for a perfect note, with that exception.
Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. Have you been examined before the Magistrate about this? A. Noâ€”I arrived in this country on 17th February last.

THOMAS DODDS . I was formerly in the employment of Mr. Woodsâ€”I pulled from this plate the impression of a water-mark, a border, two eagles, and figuresâ€”I also did this circle, No. 10 plate, the border, and this eagle, these figures, and numbersâ€”Potter also did a part of it.

WILLIAM POTTER . I am in the employment of Mr. Woodsâ€”I was employed for the purpose of pulling some of these impressionsâ€”I pulled this and several others (pointing them out)â€”I did this from a copper plate.

REICHBERGâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Eight Years' Penal Servitude.

JOSEPHSON and HARWITZâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude each.
(See New Court, Thursday).

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. JUSTICE WILLIAMS; Mr. Ald. ROSE; Mr. Ald. CONDER;

div1.p:
429.
ALFRED BANNOCKS (34),
Stealing, whilst employed in the Post-office, a letter containing 2 half sovereigns, and 18 postage-stamps, the property of Her Majesty's Postmaster-General.

THOMAS JEFFERY . I am one of the travelling inspectors of the missing letter department attached to the Post-officeâ€”in consequence of instructions I received, I went to Belper, on 25th February, and made up a letter, in which I enclosed two half sovereigns and eighteen postage-stamps, each of which I marked with the word "Trent," and "T. J." my initialsâ€”I addressed the envelope in which I enclosed them, to F. Bury, veterinary surgeon, Esher, Surreyâ€”I posted it myself at the Belper post-office at half-past 9 that night: it would be in time to go by that night's postâ€”I then went into the post-office, and saw the postmaster take it from the receiving box, and I left him some instructions concerning itâ€”it would go to London that night, and the bag containing it would be opened in the travelling post-office on the Midland Railway in its passage up to Londonâ€”the prisoner was employed in the post-office tender that nightâ€”he was a sorter, and was also acting as assistant mail-guardâ€”I went from Derby to London by the same train, and arrived at the General Post-office about 5 o'clockâ€”I was there a little before the prisonerâ€”previous to his coming I had received some information, in consequence of which, when he came, I sent for him into the comptrollers-officeâ€”he came there to me, and Child, the Post-office constable also came inâ€”I said to the prisoner, "You were on duty in the Midland sorting carriage last night?"â€”he replied, "Yes;"â€”I said, "You sorted the London letters from Belper, I believe?"â€”he replied, "No; I did not"â€”I said, "I have been informed that you did"â€”he said, "Perhaps I did assist," or "help; it was Mr. Hill's duty"â€”I said, "Did you see anything of a letter directed to Mr. F. Bury, veterinary surgeon, Esher, Surrey?"â€”he replied, "No"â€”I said, "The truth is, circumstances have come to the knowledge of the authorities which have led to the suspicion that you have been taking letters for some time, and the letter I have spoken to you about, was purposely sent from Belper last night, with a view of testing that matter; the letter came into your hands that is now missing, will you let us see whether you have got it about you now, or any of its contents?"â€”he took various things of no importance from his pockets, and turned some of his pockets inside out: after he had done, I said to Child, "It will be more satisfactory if you examine the pockets now"â€”he did so, and took from one of the coat pockets eighteen postage-stamps, rolled up in a small compass, but still all attachedâ€”I said to the prisoner, "Where did you get these stamps?"â€”he replied, "I bought them in London, when I was going down into the country on Monday night; I intended writing to my sister, but have not done so"â€”there were no marks visible on the stamps, at that time, but soon afterwards I applied a liquid to some of them, and then recognized my own mark, "Trent, T. J." on each that I applied the liquid toâ€”I told the prisoner I could identify them as the stamps I had put into the letter I had been speaking to him aboutâ€”he still adhered to

his former story, that he had purchased them on the previous Mondayâ€”he said that he did not know how it was, and I gave him in custodyâ€”these are the stamps (produced)â€”the address that I put on the letter was fictitious.

Cross-examined by MR. DICKIE. Just show us how the stamps were found. A. They were rolled up like thisâ€”I think he had on the ccat he has nowâ€”I believe his great coat was off at the time, but will not swear to itâ€”I was not in the van where the letters were sortedâ€”there were four persons in the van, Garsyth, Hill, Bannocks, and Croftonâ€”I am not quite sure, but I think those were allâ€”the prisoner has been in the Post-office about twelve yearsâ€”the prisoner's house was searched I believeâ€”I believe all the persons who were engaged in the van that night are in the same position still in the Post-officeâ€”it was the prisoner's duty when he got to the station to get into a conveyance, and the driver drives him straight on to the Post-office.
COURT. Q. Had you applied that mark to any other stamps put into a test-letter? A. Not the same word.

MATTHEW ELLIS SOWREY . I am the postmaster at Belperâ€”on 25th February, I received some information from Mr. Jeffery about a letter, and on the evening of that day I took a letter out of the letter-box addressed, "Mr. F. Bury, Veterinary Surgeon, Esher, Surrey," which I could feel con
tained coinâ€”I stamped it, and tied it up in the bundle of letters for London, which I put in the London bag, sealed it, and sent it down to the railway-stationâ€”it would, in due course, go up to London at 11.30â€”I had no communication with Garsyth.

Cross-examined. Q. Who did you give the bag to? A. To Kirk, the messenger appointed to take it to the stationâ€”he is in the employ of the Post-officeâ€”he is not hereâ€”I know nothing of it after it passed out of my hands.
MR. CLERK. Q. Are the bags always sealed before they are dispatched from the office? A. Yes; I sealed this bag.

JOSEPH GARSYTH . In February last, I was a sorter in the Midland district travelling tender to Londonâ€”the mail-train coming up at night does not stop at Belper, but there is an apparatus which holds the letter-bag, which the train touches as it goes by, causing the bag to fall into a netâ€”Mr. Jeffery, the travelling inspector, had made a communication to me about a letter which was comingâ€”on the night of 25th February, the prisoner brought me the sealed Belper bag into the travelling officeâ€”I broke the seal and opened itâ€”among the letters, I found two bundles, in one of which I saw the letter for Mr. Bury, veterinary surgeon, Esherâ€”I opened the bundles, and placed them before the prisoner to be sorted, with that letter among themâ€”it was placed among the letters for the London districtâ€”the prisoner ought to have placed it in the blind letter-box, but I looked there, after he had finished sorting, and could not find itâ€”I knew that it was a test-letterâ€”the Midland train stops At Rugby twenty minutes, and before we got there I tied up the letters out of the blind letter-box, and placed them in a bag with other letters to go to London to be sorted thereâ€”the London district letters are sorted in the trainâ€”the prisoner got out at Rugby, put all the bags on a truck, and brought them to the train to the post office carriageâ€”his post-office duties at Rugby occupied him about eight minutesâ€”on arriving at Euston-square station, the bags are conveyed from there in vans and post-office omnibussesâ€”the prisoner had charge of the Midland bags in the omnibus; there was only him in that omnibusâ€”I made a communication to Mr. Jeffrey's at Rugbyâ€”besides the prisoner and
myself, Hills and Crofton were in the travelling carriage, but Hills and the prisoner were the only two who sorted.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you know that the prisoner was the only person in the omnibus at the Euston station? A. I believe he wasâ€”I do not know of my own knowledgeâ€”the driver would be outsideâ€”the prisoner has orders to remain insideâ€”I have only known the prisoner since he has been on the railway, about eight monthsâ€”we have always been on very good termsâ€”I have smoked a pipe with him, but not every night that I had an oppor
tunityâ€”I was friendly with himâ€”I am quite positive that I saw the letter in the bundle, addressed to this person at Esherâ€”I have no doubt about thatâ€”I was not asked the question before the Magistrateâ€”I am unable to state how many bags the prisoner had to take out at Rugby and leaveâ€”he brought back about eleven, I think, or it might be a dozenâ€”it was not fourteenâ€”the amount of time he took would depend upon whether the bags were ready for him or notâ€”Hills was standing upright, close to the prisonerâ€”they stand to sortâ€”I was about a yard and a half from himâ€”Crofton was about two yards and a half from him on my rightâ€”the prisoner was not working in his shirt sleeves, he was dressed in his coat as he always isâ€”I cannot tell you about his great coatâ€”I am still in the Post-office, not going up and down the line, but in another position.

JOHN CHILD . I am a messenger of the Post-office, and also act as a constableâ€”I was with Mr. Jeffery, and took the prisoner into the Comptroller's officeâ€”he took something out of his pocketâ€”Mr. Jeffery then asked me to search his pockets, and in the right-hand pocket of his great coat I found a roll of stampsâ€”I saw Mr. Jeffery apply some liquid to them, and the marks then made their appearance.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you search all his pockets? A. Yes; this little bundle of stamps was rolled up tightâ€”that was all I found relating to the Post-officeâ€”I did not search his houseâ€”he said that he had purchased the stamps in London to send to a sister or auntâ€”he repeated that more than once.

MR. CLERK. Q. Did he say when he purchased them? A. On the Monday before he went awayâ€”this was on Wednesday morning, immediately after he was searchedâ€”he was not let out of custody againâ€”3d. or 4d. in copper was found upon him.
WILLIAM HILL . On the night of 25th February, I was a sorter in the Midland sorting carriage.

Cross-examined. Q. How were you engaged? A. In sorting the letters for the London districtâ€”I stood next to the prisonerâ€”Crofton was on my right, with Garsythâ€”they stood togetherâ€”the prisoner was merely a helper in sorting the lettersâ€”he had only one coat on.
MR. CLERK. Q. Had he a great coat with him in the carriage? A. He generally had two coats with him, but I believe he had only one coat on while sorting.

MR. DICKIE. Q. Is there a place where you put your outside coats, when at work? A. There are several places where they may be put, at some dis
tance from us.
EDWARD CROFTON . On 25th February, I was in the railway sorting-carriage of the Midland lineâ€”I am in the Post-office now.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

430.
JOHN MARSHALL (16),
Stealing 1 gelding, the property of
Thomas Lomas; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

431.
RICHARD SMITH (20),
Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Wade, and stealing therein 1 jacket, 2 petticoats, and other articles, his property.

JOHN STRETTON (Policeman, K 491). On 11th March, about half-past 2, or nearly 3 o'clock, from information I received, I went to Mr. Wade's, 23, Church-lane, Limehouaeâ€”I got over a boarded fence at the end of the house and found the back door of No. 22 unfastened, by which a person could get into the houseâ€”I looked round and saw the prisoner crouched up in a corner outside the house in the yardâ€”he said that he came there to sleepâ€”I found this shawl (produced) wrapped round his body inside his trousers, and he had on these boots and stockingsâ€”I saw my brother constable pick up two petticoats and a cape in the yard, about ten yards from the prisoner.

SUSANNAH WADE . I am the wife of William Wade, of 22, Church-lane, Limehouseâ€”on 10th March, about a quarter to 11 o'clock, I fastened up the house and went to bed, I was the last person upâ€”a window looks into the garden from the washhouse, which is part of the house, and when I was dis
turbed, I found that it had been broken openâ€”that was about twenty minutes to 3 in the morningâ€”the button of the door leading from the gar
den to the washhouse was pushed off, and some of the wood-work brokenâ€”when you have got into the washhouse you can get into the inner part of the houseâ€”the window frame was broken a little before, but it was broken more afterwards, large enough for any person to put their hands in, lift the window up, and so get into the kitchenâ€”I am sure the window was fastened the night before: I fastened it with a nail, as I could not find a screw; I found the nail on the floor next morningâ€”directly I went into the kitchen I missed a pair of boots, a petticoat, cape, shawl, and stockings, some of which I hare seen sinceâ€”they are my husband's property, and were all safe when I went to bedâ€”they are worth between 4l. and 5l.â€”I do not know the prisoner.

JOHN STRETTON (re-examined). The window was a little way up when I first noticed it, a pane of glass was broken and the frame tooâ€”Ponsford, my brother officer, asked the prisoner whether those were his boots on his feetâ€”he said, "No, those are mine which you have got in your hand"â€”those were the boots I produce.

GUILTY.**â€”He was also charged with having been con
victed at Worship-street Police-court, on 10th August, 1861; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

432.
HENRY JAMES (23),
Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Matthew John Lisle, and stealing therein 79 handker
chiefs, his property.

ARTHUR SMITHERS . I am assistant to Mr. Lisle, a pawnbroker, of 5, Exmouth-streetâ€”on the morning of 24th March, I was called up by a policeman at about a quarter to 5 o'clockâ€”I went to the top of the house and found the trap-door wide open, that is over a loft, under which is a room where goods are keptâ€”some of the tiles were removed that would enable a person to open the trap-door, it fastens with a boltâ€”the moment I went into the room, I missed some silk handkerchiefs, and Cashmere scarves with duplicatesâ€”it is my master's dwelling-house, in the parish of St. James' Clerkenwellâ€”this handkerchief (produced) was in pledge, I know it by the way in which it was rolled round as we always roll themâ€”I do no know these scarvesâ€”I swear to these in the large bundle, we have had people apply for them, most of them were pledges, but some were out of time goodsâ€”there are no marks upon them, but I know this one has been in pledge at our place; it was in the room safe with the others.

Prisoner. Q. The trap-door was bolted, for what I could see of it, it goes up straight from the gutter, which would leave nearly a yard and a half from the roof to the tiles; will you swear that a person could reach the bolt? A. I should think it could be doneâ€”it was not a yard and a halfâ€”this is the way in which I always fold up handkerchiefs (Rolling it up), I then put a little ticket on them and put them in the rackâ€”all these are folded in the same way.

MR. GENT. A. How high is the trap-door from the gutter? A. About a yard and a quarter from the gutter to the top of the trap-doorâ€”two or three tiles were removed, or more than thatâ€”these duplicated (produced) are our's, here is our name on themâ€”they relate to handkerchiefs, and would be such as I should put upon handkerchiefs.

MATTHEW LISLE . I am servant to Mr. Matthew Lisle, pawnbroker, of 5, Exmouth-streetâ€”on 23d March, between 2 and 3 in the afternoonâ€”I shut and fastened the trap-door at the top of the houseâ€”the tiles were all safeâ€”nobody had any business there after that timeâ€”next morning I saw that the trap-door had been opened and the tiles removed.
Prisoner. Q. How was the door fastened? A. With one bolt, I bolted itâ€”a glass tile lights the loft.

DAVID HOLLOWAY (Policeman, D 52). On the morning of 24th March, about a quarter to 5, I noticed a plank between the roof of No. 9 and No. 10, Exmouth-streetâ€”No. 10, is an unfinished house; No. 9, is five houses from Mr. Lisle'sâ€”you could get from No. 9 to No. 10 by the plank, and could then very easily get to No. 5â€”I got to the plank by getting up a ladder half way, I then climbed up the wood-work of No. 10, drew the plank on to the roof of No. 10, then returned, went to Mr. Lisle's, and called Mr. Smithers up, it was then a quarter to 5â€”I went up to the trap-door and saw several tiles removed which were close to itâ€”it was wide openâ€”those tiles being removed would enable a person to open the trap-door if boltedâ€”I went out at itâ€”a person standing in the gutter could very easily take off those tilesâ€”I searched the houses from No. 5, to the roof of the unfinished house; I then went to the roof of No. 4, where I found the prisoner con
cealed in a gutterâ€”I said, "Now then, come on out of that," meaning that gutterâ€”he said, "Oh, all right, I suppose it is a case with me now"â€”I took him to the station and found these three handkerchiefs on him, this yellow one was one of themâ€”he was wearing the scarf (produced) round his neck.

Prisoner. Q. Did not I make a statement regarding that scarf and the yellow haudkerchief at the Court? A. You said that one of the handker
chiefs was your property, you said nothing about the scarves, you asked the Magistrate to allow you to receive your property back.

Prisoner. That was the yellow handkerchief and the scarf which I had round my neck. Witness. You mentioned nothing about the scarf before the Magistrateâ€”you asked for one handkerchief and fivepence in copper, which was found on youâ€”five or six tiles were removed.

JAMES BUXTON (Policeman, G 8). I searched the roof of the house after the prisoner was taken, and found seventy-nine silk handkerchiefs tied up in a bundle, and two loose on the roof of No. 9, and seventy-four duplicates (produced), I also found three handkerchiefs on the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going home at a quarter-past 4, and saw some
body on the roof; I had heard of a robbery at Mr. Lisle's the week before, and went up the ladder as I could not see a policeman; I crossed the plank and found two handkerchiefs; the policeman then came up the ladder and removed the board; I thought if I did not get down some other way he

might conclude that it was me. The handkerchiefs are not folded in a par
ticular way at all. I refused my address because I did not wish my friends to know where I was.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined One Year.

433.
OWEN LEE (28), and
ELLAS BOSWELL (30),
Stealing 1 mare, the property of
Hamond Watts.

HAMOND WATTS . I am a corn-dealer of Wick-road, Hackneyâ€”I was the possessor of a bright bay mareâ€”on 14th March, I turned her out on Hack
ney-common, a little before 9 in the morning, and missed her in the evening about 6â€”I have seen her since in the possession of the policeâ€”I do not know the prisonerâ€”I value her at 15l.â€”I had not sold herâ€”her tail has been shortened very much, but I am sure she is mineâ€”I know her by a brand on the foot.
Lee. I bought the pony on 14th March, so I could not steal it on the 15th.

CORNELIUS ANSTED . I am a farrier of Christopher-place, Euston-roadâ€”on 14th March, between 11 and 12 in the morning, Lee brought me a bay mare for saleâ€”Boswell was not with himâ€”Lee said that it belonged to him, but I refused to buy itâ€”I afterwards bought it on the next day, the 15th, for five guineas, and on the 16th I gave him 20s. depositâ€”he came again on the 17th, the Monday following, for the rest of the moneyâ€”I had my doubts about it, the tail being short, and refused to pay for it, and put the matter in the hands of the policeâ€”the mare had a long tail the first time I saw herâ€”I gave Lee a shilling to go and spend at the public-house while I ascer
tained his addressâ€”I did not see Boswell till the Sunday when he led the pony downâ€”Lee was with him on Monday morning; Lee gave the name of John Boswell, White Post-lane, Hackney-wickâ€”I understood that to be his own address, but when I got to Hackney-wick, I found it to be reversedâ€”I made inquiry there about the pony, and gave both the prisoners in custodyâ€”Boswell came again on the Monday morning with Leeâ€”I gave the pony that I had from Lee to Brenchley.

WILLIAM TYLER . I am a butcher of Wells-street, Hackneyâ€”on 14th March, from a quarter to half-past 10 in the morningâ€”I was in the lane leading to Hackney-wickâ€”I saw a person there, whom I firmly believe to be Lee, with a colt, a bright bay mare with a long tailâ€”I said, "You have a very nice colt"â€”he rubbed his hands and said, "The bâ€”â€”has thrown me, it has been turned out for four months and got fresh"â€”I drove on, stopped at one or two houses, and then he passed, and I caught him again in a lane leading towards Bowâ€”he asked me to buy the mare for 13l. and said he had given 17l. for her to Mr. Kennard of Bowâ€”I asked him if anybody was to offer him a 10l. note for it, if he would take itâ€”he said, "To tell you the truth we are hard up, my father has had the misfortune to break his leg, and 10l. is the selling price to-day"â€”I only saw Lee.

JOHN BRENCHLEY (Police-sergeant, K 2). On 17th March I took both the prisoners at the Rising Sun public-house, Somers'-townâ€”I took Boswell first, and Lee afterwardsâ€”I told them I took them on a charge of horse stealing at Hackney-wickâ€”they made no replyâ€”I got the pony from Ansted, and showed it to Mr. Watts.

JOHN COOK (Policeman, S 198). I accompanied Brenchley to the Rising Sun, and found Leeâ€”I told him that he was charged with stealing a horse from Hackney-wickâ€”he said, "I did not steal it, I bought it of a man in the roadâ€”I asked him if he knew where I could find the manâ€”he said,
"No, I do not; it is no use asking me any questions about it"â€”I took him to the station.

Lee's Defence. I bought the pony on 14th March, about half-past 10, of a man who asked me five guineas for it. I gave him 4l. 15s. and took it away. I walked on with it, and was going down Hackney-road to take it to the market. I met a man who told me he knew a man who wanted to buy a pony. He took me, and the gentleman said he could not deal to-day. I took her home to the market, and afterwards turned her out again. If I had known she was stolen, I should have given the man in custody. Bos
well knows nothing about the pony. I asked him to come and have a drink, and earn a shilling if he could.

Boswell's Defence. I was going along, looking for a job, and saw this man. He said, "Do you want to earn a shilling or two?" I said, "Yes;" being out of work at the time. I know nothing about the pony.
CORNELIUS ANSTED (re-examined). Boswell brought the pony to me on the Sunday, leading it with a halterâ€”Lee was walking on the pavement.

LEEâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined One Year.

BOSWELLâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. COPELAND; Mr. Ald. GIBBONS; and Mr. COMMON

div1.p:
434.
JAMES WHITEHEAD (18),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

SOPHIA DOWER . I am the wife of Joseph Dower, tobacconist, of 50, Limehouse-causewayâ€”the prisoner came there on Thursday, 27th March, for a quarter of an ounce of tobacco, and tendered me a shillingâ€”I had not any halfpenceâ€”I gave the shilling to the child, Sarah Roberts, to get changeâ€”she returned in a minute or two with the shilling bent, and said it was a bad oneâ€”the prisoner said he received it from his brotherâ€”I gave it back to him, and he went away without the tobacco.

SARAH ROBERTS . I live with the last witness, who is my grandmotherâ€”I remember her giving me a shilling one Thursday last monthâ€”I went over to Mr. Miller, who lives just opposite, and gave it to himâ€”he tried it with his teeth, gave it me back, and said it was a bad oneâ€”I came over, gave that same shilling to my grandmother, and said, in the prisoner's presence, that it was a bad one.

WILLIAM MILLER . I keep the Oak beer-shop, at Limehouse-causewayâ€”on 27th March the last witness brought me a shillingâ€”I tried it between my teeth, and it bent quite easilyâ€”it was badâ€”I handed it to the girl, and said it was a bad one.

MARY BRADLEY . I am the wife of Henry Bradley, a confectioner, of 232, High-street, Poplarâ€”on 27th March the prisoner came and asked for a pennyworth of drops, and he gave me a shillingâ€”I had no change, and I gave that shilling to Lizzie Wood, my servant, to get change; and in a minute or so she brought me two sixpences in changeâ€”I then gave the prisoner 11d. change and the dropsâ€”the constable at that time came into the shop, and took the prisoner into custody, with the 11d. and the dropsâ€”the constable asked me, in the prisoner's presence, where the shilling

was, and I told him I had given it to my husband to change for two six
pencesâ€”he told me to look at the shilling; and I sent for my husband to come and look at itâ€”my husband brought it, and turned his purse into the policeman's hand.

LIZZIE WOOD . I am servant to Mrs. Bradleyâ€”on 27th March she gave me a shilling, which I took to Mr. Bradleyâ€”he gave me his purse to take the change outâ€”I opened the purse, took two sixpences out, put the Shilling in, and put the purse down by Mr. Bradley's sideâ€”there was no other Shil
ling in the purse then, only two threepenny piecesâ€”I returned to Mrs. Brad
ley and gave her the two sixpences; and the constable then came in.

HENRY BRADLEY . On 27th March, the last witness brought me a Shillingâ€”I gave her my purse, which had no shilling in itâ€”she opened it, and put it down by my side, after putting a shilling in itâ€”in a few minutes, from what was said to me, I took my purse into the shop, and emptied it into the policeman's handâ€”it then contained a bad shilling, and two threepenny pieces.

SIMON RALPH (Policeman, K 244). On 27th March, the prisoner was pointed out to me by a man in the West India-roadâ€”another man was with himâ€”the prisoner went into Bradley's shopâ€”I stood by the doorway, watched him, saw him tender something to Mrs. Bradley, and saw Mrs. Bradley give him change and the dropsâ€”I went inside, and took from him a sixpence, 5d. in coppers, and the dropsâ€”Mr. Bradley then came into the shop, and turned out his purse in which was a shilling and two threepenny piecesâ€”they fell into my handâ€”this (produced) is the shillingâ€”the prisoner said, "How do I know that is my shilling? that is not my shilling"â€”I took hold of himâ€”he said, "Don't handle me, I am a respect
able boy"â€”I said, "I don't care what you are, I shall take you to the sta
tion"â€”I took him to the station, and on searching him, I found six penny-worth of coppers loose in his left-hand trousers' pocket.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is a bad shilling.

The prisoner's statement; before the Magistrate was read at follows:â€”"I own I gave a shilling; but I do not know whether it was a bad one or not. I never was in Mr. Dower's shop. The shilling was passed through different people's hand before it came to the proper owner."

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

435.
WILLIAM TUNSTALL (32), was indicted
for a like offence.

JAMES ALLERBY . I am a gardener, and live at East Actonâ€”I am in the habit of frequenting the Askew-arms public-houseâ€”I was in there on 25th March last, about 8 o'clock at nightâ€”the prisoner came in, called for a pint of beer, and put down a shillingâ€”the landlady, Mrs. Kemp, took it up, and gave him some changeâ€”he drank the beer, and went away directlyâ€”I made a communication to Mrs. Kemp, and she showed me a shilling, and, in my presence, bent it nearly doubleâ€”on 27th March, I had just gone in there again to get my half-pint of beer, and saw the prisoner come inâ€”it was near 3 o'clock in the dayâ€”I recognised himâ€”he had a pint of fourpenny beer, and put down a shilling which he took out of a tobacco boxâ€”(he had taken the one on 25th March out of the tobacco box)â€”the landlord gave him 6d. and 4d. in copper, changeâ€”I spoke to the landlord who detained the prisonerâ€”I fetched a constable, and he was given in custodyâ€”Mr. Kemp then pro
duced a shilling, and the prisoner snatched it from him.
Prisoner. Q. Did I snatch it from him, or take it out of his fingers? A. You snatched it from him, and said you would give him a good oneâ€”I could
swear to you from a thousand, by the way you came in with your tobacco boxâ€”you came in on 25th March like a labourer, with your trousers dirty as if you had been at work.

ANNIE MARGARET KEMP . I am the wife of Daniel Kemp, and keep the Askew Arms, in the Uxbridge-roadâ€”on 25th March I served a man with some beer, in Allerby's presenceâ€”I cannot say whether the prisoner is the manâ€”he gave me a shilling, which I put in the till where there was no other shillingâ€”I gave him change, and he left, and then, from what Allerby said to me, I looked in the till and found the shilling which I put thereâ€”it was badâ€”I afterwards gave that same shilling to my husband.
Prisoner. Q. Are you sure that it was 25th March or Monday that I came into your house? A. I took the bad shilling on Tuesday, 25th Marchâ€”I do not know you.

DANIEL KEMP . The last witness is my wifeâ€”on 27th March last the prisoner came and asked for a pint of beerâ€”I served himâ€”he gave me a shilling, and I gave him 10d. changeâ€”Allerby was thereâ€”I laid the shilling on a recess, over the till, by itselfâ€”there were no other shillings there; only a few farthingsâ€”after that Allerby said something to me, in consequence of which I looked at the shilling again, and found it was badâ€”I told the prisoner it was bad, and he asked me to let him look at itâ€”I held it out, and he snatched it from meâ€”I asked him for it again, and he tendered me a good shilling, and I gave him 10d. changeâ€”I then detained him, and gave him in the costody of the police-sergeantâ€”he held out a good shilling afterwardsâ€”on 25th March my wife gave me a bad shilling, which I marked and laid on the shelf in the parlourâ€”I ultimately gave it to the same sergeantâ€”when the sergeant took the prisoner in custody I told him that the prisoner had taken a shilling from me, and he searched him in my presence and found a bad shilling in his coat pocketâ€”the prisoner said it was the same at that he gave me; that he had not any more.

JURY. Q. What made you lay the money on the recess? A. I have a habit of doing that sometimesâ€”I put it on the pewter; the till is under
neathâ€”I told him I did not want the good one, I wanted the bad one back, and he put it in his mouth and was going to swallow itâ€”I took him by the arms and said, "You don't swallow it."

Prisoner. He never said anything about that at the police-court. Witness. I was not askedâ€”he put it in his mouthâ€”some one said there was another man outside, and I asked Allerby to hold him while I went out to see, and while I went out he put the shilling somewhereâ€”he said it was gone; I did not get it back.

ARTHUR BONNICK (Police-sergeant, T 19). The prisoner was given into my custody on 27th Marchâ€”Mr. Kemp gave me this counterfeit shilling (produced)â€”on searching the prisoner, I found another counterfeit shilling (produced) in the lining of his coat, between the cloth and the pocket; not in the regular pocketâ€”I also found on him a good shilling, and the 10d. change that Mr. Kemp had given himâ€”there was a hole in the inside of the coat, and it was between the pocket and the cloth of the coat.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are both bad shillings.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

436.
MARY SMITH (19), was indicted
for a like offence.
SARAH TAYLOR . I keep a coffee-stall at 55, Half Moon-street, Cityâ€”on

Monday, 10th March, about 7 o'clock in the morning I was in Farrar's-rents with my stallâ€”the prisoner came and asked me for a halfpenny cup of coffee and a slice of bread and butterâ€”they came to 1d.â€”she gave me a shillingâ€”I was not quite sure that it was a bad one; I pretended not to have change, and asked a little boy to run to a shop and get changeâ€”he brought it back, before going into any house, and said it was a bad oneâ€”I accused her of knowing it was a bad one, and of belonging to young man with one eye who had given me a bad one the week beforeâ€”she made no reply, but walked awayâ€”I sent the polioeman after herâ€”the boy only went a few yards, the distance from one house to another, and then he gave me back the same shillingâ€”I gave it to the constable.

WILLIAM ROBINSON (City-policeman, 656). On Monday morning, 10th March, I was on duty in Bishopsgate-street, and saw the prisoner in company with a man with one eye, coming across the street towards the stallâ€”I went and spoke to Mrs. Taylor, and she gave me this shilling (produced)â€”I then went after the prisoner, and overtook her in Sun-streetâ€”(the man had gone to Long-alley)â€”I said, "Have you any more of those about you?"â€”she said, "Oh! do you think I am a fool?"â€”I said, "Well, you must come back along with me; where is the man with one eye?"â€”she said, "If you want him, you had better go and look for him; if you had got him you might have made a job of it"â€”I took her back to the coffee-stall, and Mrs. Taylor then said, "I believe she is one of the same gang that passed one on me last week"â€”I told a sergeant that was with us if he saw a man with one eye following us to take him in custodyâ€”I took the prisoner in custodyâ€”in going to the station she said the man had got the swag; that she had no moneyâ€”at the station the female searcher searched herâ€”only an empty purse was found on herâ€”I saw the man the following morning at Horse monger-lane gaol, and this morning at the bar.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is a bad shilling.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Four Months.

437.
MARGARET KENNERFICK (43),
WILLIAM KENNERFICK (14), and
JAMES KENNERFICK (9),
Unlawfully having counterfeit coin in their possession.

GEORGE BROWN (Police-serjeant, T 18). On Saturday afternoon, 22d. March, in consequence of information I received, I went to Munden-street, Fulham, accompanied by Swain, another constableâ€”when we got there I saw the prisoner William Kennerfick coming apparently from the direction of the Rising Sun tavern, playing with other boys in the streetâ€”on my approaching him he ran in doors, to No. 2, Munden-streetâ€”I went after him to the first-floor back roomâ€”the door was fastened inaideâ€”I asked for admittance, and said that if they did not open the door I would break it openâ€”it was then opened from the insideâ€”I went in and saw the three prisoners thereâ€”there was also a person named Chambers, who had come in apparently just before, and was in the act of sitting downâ€”the prisoner Margaret was sitting by the fire, William was coming from the right-hand corner as I went inâ€”there was a closet in that cornerâ€”James was standing between his mother and brotherâ€”there was an elder brother there too, besides theseâ€”when I got into the room I addressed the prisoner William, and said, "I want to know where you got the florin from, that you passed at Mrs. Butlin's shop last night"â€”he said, "I was not out of this house last night"â€”upon that the mother said, "My boy was never outside this house

last night"â€”before taking William in custody, I took him to Butlin's, in King-street, Hammersmith, to be identifiedâ€”on the way there he said, "I was there Iast night; I did pass the florin," or "offer the florin," I won't be sure whichâ€”he said, "I did go to Butlin's; a man gave it to me at Hammersmith-gate, for wheeling a load of furniture to Knightsbridge; I did not know as it was bad"â€”the prisoner said that he went to buy a loaf of breadâ€”I said, "Why go so far to buy a loaf of bread when there are two or three baker's shops in your own street?"â€”I do not believe he made any reply to thatâ€”I took him to the station and then to the Magistrate, which occupied about half an hour, and then went back to Munden-street, where I had left Swain in charge of the roomâ€”I found him there when I got back, and made a search in the roomâ€”in the corner of the room, from which I had seen the boy coming, I found these two shillings (produced) among some fire-woodâ€”some more were handed to me by the other officerâ€”I saw Swain make a further searchâ€”I directed him to search a closet, which was situated at the back part of the same roomâ€”he handed me out from there two crown-pieces, rolled up in paper, and nine florins, also rolled up in paperâ€”he could not see what it wasâ€”he said, "Sergeant, here is something," and handed it out to meâ€”I was close to himâ€”he was in the dark, and I was in the lightâ€”he handed them down to me from the closet, also five shillings, wrapped in paperâ€”I also saw him find a fourpenny bit in the corner of the room, on the floorâ€”I took the prisoner James into custody the same afternoonâ€”I told him it was for uttering a counterfeit shilling to Mrs. Felthouseâ€”he said, "Yes; I did give the shilling, but a man in Derbyshire-street gave it to me," or "I received it from a man in Derbyshire-street"â€”afterwards he said, "It was not a man in Derbyshire-street; it was my little brother"â€”I produce this counterfeit shilling which I received from Mrs. Felthouseâ€”I got this florin (produced) from Mrs. Butlinâ€”on the following Monday I took the prisoner Margaret into custody at the same house in Mundan-streetâ€”I said to her, "I am come to apprehend you, being the owner of this room where this counterfeit money was found, for having it in your posses
sion"â€”I believe her remark was, "Oh! my God," or something to that effectâ€”she said, "I know nothing about it"â€”I believe she said, "The boy Crocknell brought it from Fulham-fields on Thursday last, and has been stopping in my house ever since?"â€”I said, "Do you mean that boy that I searched in the passage?"â€”she said, "Yes"â€”I said, "Why, you told me that was your son"â€”she said, "I know I did, but I am very sorry for it"â€”I believe I said, "If you had given me that information then, he would have been in a different position"â€”I am satisfied that he is not her sonâ€”I have made inquiry; he has absconded from the neighbourhood.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Q. What did you mean by saying that she would be in a different position? A. That Crocknell would be in a different positionâ€”I did not know what position he was in at that time, but I am quite satisfied that if she had given me that information he would have been in my custodyâ€”that was what I mean by a different positionâ€”I have known this woman five or six yearsâ€”I never knew anything against her beforeâ€”she was not nursing a child when I went into the room; she was dressing beef steaks and mutton chopsâ€”James meant the bigger boy when he mentioned his little brother; I believe he said, "My little brother Bill"â€”it was the little one called the biggest the little oneâ€”that is my explanation of itâ€”I do not know anything about Crocknellâ€”I have not seen him since:â€”I have been looking after him this last fortnight; I should like to see himâ€”the woman only occupied one room in the houseâ€”there is

a sort of division made in the room; a sort of folding doorâ€”the landlord of the house is hereâ€”I have no reason to doubt what she said about Crock
nell stopping there since the Thursday;â€”from what I have heard since, I believe it is correctâ€”I know that this woman has been ill, and received an allowance from the parish; bread, and so forth; no moneyâ€”I cannot say that she has been living in the parish thirty-three yearsâ€”I have only done duty in that neighbourhood about six yearsâ€”I cannot say how many rooms there are in the house; I dare say there are seven or eightâ€”I believe there is a tenant in each room; I mean a person paying rent for each, besides others living with them.

MR. ROWDEN. Q. Were these chops and steaks part of the parish allow
ance? A. Noâ€”they appeared as if they had been just brought in.

ROBERT SWAIN (Policeman, T 125). On 22d March last I went with Sergeant Brown to No. 2, Munden-street, where I saw the female prisoner and the little boy, besides two more boys in the room, and a manâ€”she told me the two boys were her two sonsâ€”Brown took one of these boys away and I was left in charge of the roomâ€”when he came back I assisted, in searching the roomâ€”in the corner of the room, where the prisoners slept, I found this groat (produced) under the prisoner William's bedâ€”there was a closet on the right hand side of the room, and in there I found four parcels, one containing two five-shilling pieces, done up in paper, the next, six florins, in one paper, and three in anotherâ€”I kept them all separately wrapped in paper as I found themâ€”I also found 5s.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Q. You said, "In a corner where the prisoner slept;" which prisoner did you mean? A. Where both the little boys slept togetherâ€”the mother said both the little boys slept together.

THOMAS GREENHEAD . I am agent to the landlord of No. 2, Munden-streetâ€”some time ago the first floor back room of that house was taken by the prisoner Mrs. Kennerfick, at 2s. per weekâ€”a small conservatory leading from the room, and a closet, were also taken.
Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Q. Have you known this woman any time? A. Six or eight months, that is allâ€”I do not know any harm of her during that time.

ANN FELTHOUSE . I keep a chandler's shop at 3, Vernon-street, Fulhamâ€”on Thursday, 20th March last, the younger prisoner came there and asked for fourpennyworth of baconâ€”I cut it off for him, and was about to serve himâ€”he put down a shillingâ€”I saw it was bad, and told him soâ€”I asked him where he got it, and he said that a gentleman in Devonshire-street had given it to him, and was waiting for the changeâ€”he afterwards asked me for the shilling backâ€”I kept it, and he went away, and in five minutes he came back and said the gentleman had run away, and that he, the gentleman, had a pocket full of the same coinsâ€”he asked me then for the shilling again, and I refused to give it to himâ€”I kept it separate from others, by itself and never put it in the tillâ€”on the 22d, two days afterwards, I gave it to Sergeant Brown.

CATHERINE BUTLIN . I live with my father, a baker, in the Broadway, Hammersmithâ€”on Friday, 21st March, some time in the evening, the prisoner William came to our shop, asked for a half-quartern loaf, which came to 4d., and put down a two-shilling pieceâ€”I bit it, and noticed the marks I made on it with my teethâ€”I should know it againâ€”this is it (Pointing it out)â€”I called my father, and gave him the florin, and he asked the boy where he livedâ€”he said he lived in Munden-streetâ€”that was his right addressâ€”he told my father that his mother had sent him to get the
loaf, and had given it to himâ€”the boy then left the shop, and my father gave me the florinâ€”I gave it the same night to Sergeant Brown, and at the same time gave him certain information.

ALEXANDER JACKSON . I am the landlord of the Rising Sun public-house, Vernon-street, Fulhamâ€”on Friday night, 21st March, the prisoner William Kennerfick came, and an elder brother, I believe, with himâ€”they had a gallon can with themâ€”William asked for two pots of fourpenny ale, and placed a shilling on the counter; the other boy then asked for another potâ€”I asked him if he wanted it in a separate can, or to put it in the gallon canâ€”he told me to put it in the gallon can, and likewise to put in another pot to make up the 1s. 4d.â€”I put the shilling in the tillâ€”about five minutes afterwards, when I went to count the money, I found it to be a bad shillingâ€”the date of it was 1860â€”I gave it to Sergeant Brown on the Saturday after the boy was locked upâ€”this is itâ€”on Thursday, 20th March, the day before that, the witness Felthouse brought the prisoner James to my house, and told me that he had come in for fourpennyworth of bacon, and wanted to tender a bad shilling for itâ€”I told her to keep the shilling, and asked the boy where he got it fromâ€”he said that the same man in Devonshire-street had given it to himâ€”I told him to go back and tell the man the shilling was bad, and if he wanted it to come and fetch it himselfâ€”I knew at that time that James and William were brothersâ€”in conse
quence of information I had I spoke to Sergeant Brown after the boy William was locked up on the Saturday afternoonâ€”I gave him certain information.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you say it in the presence of any of the three prisoners? A. Noâ€”I do not swear that the shilling produced is the shilling I received from the boysâ€”whatever shilling I received from them I put in the tillâ€”there was very little money in the tillâ€”they paid 1s. 4d., the exact money, for the beer they hadâ€”there was an older lad with Williamâ€”I have known the woman nearly three yearsâ€”I have known nothing against her.

WILLIAM HUXLEY . I am a shop boy in the service of Mr. Kapperton, oilman, of 1, Munden-terrace, Fulhamâ€”I know a boy, named John Kennerfick, and the two male prisonersâ€”he is a brother of those twoâ€”on Thursday, 20th March, he came to my shop and gave me a bad shilling, and I went to the female prisoner's lodgingâ€”I found Margaret in the room, and said, "Please, Mrs. Kennerfick, your son John has been passing a bad shilling"â€”I showed it to herâ€”I told her it had been given in payment for a penny candleâ€”she said that her sister had come from London, and given it to her to help her, as she had been ill for a long time, and that she had sent her son for a penny candle and a quartern loafâ€”she said, "My sister came in the afternoon and gave me the shilling"â€”she said that she had not another farthing in the houseâ€”I went to her house again on the following eveningâ€”all her sons, John, James, and William were then there, and her
self and another boyâ€”John asked me in her presence, and in the presence of the other two boys, whether I could swear to the shilling, and I told him yes, I couldâ€”Margaret Kennerfick then gave me a good shillingâ€”I took the bad shilling home to my father, and asked him what I had better do with it, and he told me I had better destroy it, and put it out of the wayâ€”I put it in the fire, and saw it melt and drop down through the grate.

Cross-examined. Q. After she said that she had not another farthing in the house, what did she say about her son? A. That he was going to work the next morning, and he would have some money then, and then she would

give it meâ€”I went the next night in consequence of that statementâ€”the shilling that I put in the fire was the one John brought meâ€”I kept it in my hand all the timeâ€”I kept it from the time he gave it me, not in my pocket, but on my master's shelf, separatelyâ€”there was no other money there; it was wrapped in paper.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . These two shillings found in the corner of the room, of 1836 and 1859, are both badâ€”the shilling uttered to Felthouse is counterfeitâ€”it is of 1836, and from the same mould as one of those found in the corner of the roomâ€”Butlin's florin is counterfeit, and of 1859 (The Court considered that the shilling uttered to Jackson must be excluded)â€”here is a counterfeit groat found under the prisoner's bedâ€”of those found in the closet, here are two counterfeit crowns of 1821 from the same mould, two of the best I have ever met with; here are nine counterfeit florins of 1859, all from one mould, and from the same mould as the one uttered; here are five counterfeit shillings, one of 1852, two of 1859, and two of 1860â€”the two of 1859 are from the same mould as the one found in the corner of the roomâ€”those of 1860 are from the same mould, and from the same mould as that objected to.

p.hi:
submitted that there was no evidence against the two boys for having counterfeit coin in their possession, the coins passed by them on different occasions not being any of those charged in the Indictment, which were those found in the room proved to be in the occupation of the woman; that the boys were not of an age to have possession apart from the mother, and that the four
penny piece was not in the Indictment at all.

contended that the fact of the boys living in the same room, and having been two days previously passing counterfeit coin from the same mould as those found in the possession of the mother, and in the cupboard; was evidence of the possession of all, they having all been together when the money was found.

stated that it would be very difficult for the jury, if it were left to them, to dismiss from their minds the coin uttered to Felthhouse; that there were, no doubt, other coins in the boys' pos
session independent of the mother, but the Indictment only included the coins found in the room; that if they were charged with uttering, the uttering by the boys might be used to show guilty knowledge on the part of the mother, but that there was no evidence to go to the jury in respect of the boys.

could not withdraw the case from the jury, but left it to them to say whether they believed the coins were in that room with the mother's knowledge, and under her control; and whether the boys, or either of them, could be said to have any possession or control over them, or whether they were merely employed by the mother or some other person; if they thought the latter, then the boys ought to be acquitted.

div1.p:
MARGARET KENNERFICKâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

WILLIAM KENNERFICKâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
To be kept in a Reformatory for Three Years.

JAMES KENNERFICKâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

438.
JOHN MARTIN (20),
Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Samuel La Mert, and stealing therein a snuff mull, his property.

MR. SLEIGH, for the prosecutor, stated that he did not wish the prisoner, who was an American, to be confined, but that Dr. La Mert should be secured against personal violence, the prisoner having on a former occasion come to him with loaded pistols and demanded, and obtained, money.â€”
Confined Six Months,
and to enter into securities, himself in 50l. and two sureties in 25l. each, to keep the peace for twelve months.

439.
WILLIAM GEORGE BROWN (18),
Stealing 17lbs. of beef, the property of
John Sylvester; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€ â€”
Confined Six Months.

440.
CHARLES MORRIS (51),
Stealing a pair of boots, the property of
Thomas Jones;
also stealing a pewter coffee-pot, and a tin teapot, value together 15s., the property of
William Chapman; to both of which he

p.rs: PLEADED GUILTY, and stated that he was not right in his head.â€”

div1.p:
441.
MARY HAYDON (16), and
MARIA HOLMES (15),
Stealing 25 scarves, the property of
Thomas Keys; to which they

442.
JOHN LEOPARD (23),
Stealing on 25th February, 1861, 44 yards, on 14th April, 41 yards, and on 3d May, 3 yards of silk, the property of
Robert Henry Hilditch and another, his masters;
also on 7th June, 12 yards, on 24th August, 41 yards, and on 15th November, 38 yards of silk, the property of the same persons; to both of which he
PLEADED GUILTY .

MR. SHARPE stated that the prisoner had given the prosecutors every facility for recovering their property. MR. ORRIDGE stated that that was so, but that of 250l. worth of property which was missed, they had only recovered 160l. worth.

443.
HENRY KEENAN (46),
Feloniously forging and uttering an order for the payment of 5l. 13s.,
also embezzling the sum of 9l. 6s.,
also the sums of 7l. 14s. 6d., and 5l. 13s., received on account of
Harry Bodkin Poland, his master, to all of which he
PLEADED GUILTY , and received an excel
lent character. MR. COOPER for the prisoner, stated that he had a wife and seven children.

444.
WALTER HOMEWOOD (28),
Unlawfully assaulting
William Spong, and occasioning him actual bodily harm.

ROBERT MARTIN . I am a licensed victualler, and omnibus proprietor, residing at Lower Park-road, near Peckhamâ€”on Tuesday, 4th March, about a quarter past 5, I was standing at the end of Talbot-court, Gracechurch-Street, William Spong, an omnibus driver, was standing alongside of meâ€”I saw the prisoner driving an omnibusâ€”his omnibus was drawn round behind our's, with the pole drawn up so close to our door, that I oould not get on the board till the horses movedâ€”I go with the omnibus occasionally at con
ductorâ€”it is well known that the regulation made by the City is, that omnibuses ought to stand four feet apartâ€”the prisoner drove up to the door with the pole as close to the door as he possibly couldâ€”I did not hear the prosecutor say a word to the prisonerâ€”I could not get on the board, and no one could get into the omnibusâ€”I turned round to two ladies to ask where they were going, and Spong was putting the horses of the prisoner's omnibus back, and the prisoner was whipping them upâ€”the prisoner began lashing at him, and the horses tooâ€”I said, "For God's sake come away, else you will be drove through the door"â€”Mrs. Downing, Alderman Abbiss's assist
ant, was very much frightened, and persuaded him to do the sameâ€”the prisoner got down, threw the reins down and ran round the omnibusâ€”Spong

did not come away, but put the horses backâ€”he was at the horses' headâ€”when the prisoner got down, he ran round and took him by the collar of his coat round the neck, shook him against the wheel, and they then went across the pavement together and fell in Talbot-court, Homewood atopâ€”I saw them go down; after he fell, the prisoner took hold of him by the collar of his coat, pulled him up on his bottom as far as he could, hit him with his fist on the front of the head, and then let him go again, and when I looked at him, blood was coming out of his nose, left ear, and mouthâ€”I think he struck him on the noseâ€”he had got a black eye when I saw him the next dayâ€”he lay there for some minutes, and I was frightened and thought he was deadâ€”the prisoner came to me and said, "Now I will serve you the same"â€”I said, "I think you have done quite sufficient, you have killed that man"â€”I did not see Spong strike the prisoner at allâ€”there was no blow struck till after Spong was on the ground, except with the whipâ€”there was none with the fistâ€”he had Spong by the collar almost ready to throttle himâ€”Spong had got his coat and gloves on ready to driveâ€”as I was coming back from Peckham, the prisoner met me again, and offered to fight me.

Cross-examined by MR. HOLDSWORTH. Q. The other omnibus came up, did it not? A. Yes; it followed usâ€”we were not at rest and he moving on, we had pulled up, the other bus was following, and pulled up behindâ€”my bus has been there six years, and he has been there six or eight monthsâ€”I am not opposition against him, he is opposition against meâ€”there had not been any wrangling amongst usâ€”I never spoke to him that dayâ€”there had not been any previously, in connexion with the oppositionâ€”I have had no quarrelling with him at allâ€”there had been something about three weeks previously; he took off his coat and waistcoat and wanted to fight me, and Spong got between us and said, we had better have no bother, and he has got off his omnibus and tried to pull me off by the legsâ€”Spong had not assaulted him before, or offered to fight him for drink, to my knowledge; if he has done it, it has been when he was not in my companyâ€”I cannot say that I know a person named Comfortâ€”I know James Mann the time keeper, he stood there with me and saw the whole of it.

WILLIAM SPONG . I am omnibus driver to Mr. Martin of Peckhamâ€”on 4th March I was in Gracechurch-street, about a quarter past 5â€”the time-keeper gave me the time to startâ€”I had just gone to get up on my omnibus but the pole of the defendant's omnibus bus against the door, prevented meâ€”I could not get up in front because there was a cart close against our pole, and I had to go to the hind partâ€”I wanted to go round to the other side of the bus and get upâ€”I told the prisoner I wished him to put his horses back, for I could not get byâ€”he did not do soâ€”he said, "Your time is called, and it is time you were gone"â€”I then took the horses by the heads and put them backâ€”he whipped both the horses up, my left side was against the step-board, and the horses' shoulder was against the sideâ€”he drove them close against the doorâ€”I put them back again, and he cut me several times across the hands with the whipâ€”while I was putting them back a third time, he came round behind his omnibus, got me round the collar, and threw me up against the wheel of my omnibus, and then ran me up Talbot-courtâ€”that is all I recollectâ€”I became insensible after that, the blood ran down the side of my head which was cut, here is the mark on my hat which came across the iron railing in the passageâ€”I cannot say exactly how long I was insensible, for I found myself down at Billingsgate, sitting on a fish-stall thereâ€”I do not know how I got there, no one was with meâ€”I then came up into Grace-church-street and went home by omnibusâ€”when I got home I sent for a

surgeon and was in his hands a fortnightâ€”I was prevented from going to my work for three weeksâ€”I did not strike the prisoner at allâ€”I had never quarrelled with him or threatened him in any wayâ€”I still feel the effects of the blowsâ€”the back of my head is very bad now, and I feel a singing in my cars.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean to say you had not had any quarrelling with the the prisoner before this occasion? A. Neverâ€”there was a quarrel one afternoon between Martin and himâ€”I never challenged the prisoner to fight me for drinkâ€”I did not do so on this occasionâ€”Mann, the time-keeper, called my time when I was going to get on the omnibusâ€”I was not smoking a cigar at the time this took place, nor afterwardsâ€”I was not smoking a cigar in Gracechurch-street a very short time after this occuredâ€”I was under the doctor ten days or moreâ€”I do not know how I got to Billingsgateâ€”I wandered aboutâ€”I have no recollection of what occurredâ€”I came back to my omnibusâ€”I was there a tittle before 7 o'clockâ€”I was sitting on one of the stalls at Billingsgate, and some boys were playing there and trod on my footâ€”they said, "Look at that man's face, look at the blood all running down," and they took me to the tap and washed my face, and then I came backâ€”I saw no one at Billingsgate that I knew.

ALFRED HOWARD . I am a clerk in the Cityâ€”on 4th March I was sitting on the near side of Martin's omnibusâ€”I had been there about three minutes when Home wood came up on his bus, and drove his pole close against Mar
tin's doorâ€”Martin's time was up, and Spong went to Homewood and asked him to put back his horsesâ€”he did not make any reply that I know ofâ€”Spong took hold of his horses' heads and backed themâ€”the prisoner imme
diately slashed them back again on Spongâ€”Spong pushed them back again and Homewood slashed at him with the whipâ€”Spong again pushed the horses back, and the prisoner threw the reins down, got off the box, came round to Spong, caught him by the collar, forced him against the wheel and the board at the end of the bus, and then took him across up Talbot-court, and fell heavily on himâ€”I saw that Spong was insensible, as the prisoner was getting off himâ€”he hugged him tightâ€”I could not set what passed but he struck him in the faceâ€”Spong was lying on the pavement bleeding, a crowd collected about a minute afterwardsâ€”no one went to Spong for a minute or so, and then a man came and took him in his arms.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see where Spong went to after this? A. Noâ€”I went away with Martin's bus about seven minutes afterwardsâ€”I would not be sure as to the time, that is all I know about itâ€”I was sitting on the end seat, at the near side of the busâ€”there were no vehicles about, that I noticedâ€”I could not see any vehicles behind Homewood's busâ€”I could not see whether there was any bus standing behind; busses do stand very frequently about thereâ€”I merely heard Spong ask the prisoner to put back his horsesâ€”Spong was soberâ€”I did not hear him say anything to the prose
cutor about fightingâ€”I was near enough to have heardâ€”I was right over his headâ€”I was not particularly attending to this matterâ€”there was not a policeman near till after Spong was insensibleâ€”two gentlemen on the bus cried "Police!" and "Shame!"â€”the prisoner whipped Spong across the hands, but his hands were protected with glovesâ€”they scuffled towards Talbot-court, and there they fellâ€”they fell intentionallyâ€”I could see that they were trying for the throwâ€”it seemed that each was trying to throw the otherâ€”there was one blow struck by the prisoner after Spong was insensible; that was as they were lying on the ground together.
MR. KEMP. Q. Homewood raised him up and then Struck him again?
A. Yesâ€”I was at the extreme end of the omnibus, on the near side, over the doorâ€”I could see the whole of it from beginning to end, I could see the pole touch the backâ€”I was on the roof.

THOMAS DENNE . I am a surgeon, residing at Southampton-street, Peck
hamâ€”I was called in to attend Spong on 4th Marchâ€”I found he had suffered from the effects of blows, but from what cause I could not sayâ€”there was a scar over the left ear on the scalp, such as might be made by falling on a scraperâ€”I heard that blood had been flowing from his ears; that would show that some internal injury had been caused, but I think the blood came from the scar and ran down from the earâ€”blood from the mouth would be caused by some external injuryâ€”he had evidently had a severe blow in the faceâ€”his right eye was slightly bleeding, and he had evidently had a blow on the nose.

Cross-examined. Q. Was there any injury of any serious character? A. There was the cut over the left ear, that was not more dangerous than scalp wounds generally are; it was only dangerous from the fear of erysipelas setting in; in itself the wound was not dangerousâ€”erysipelas is more liable to set in from scalp wounds than from others.

JAMES MANN . I was time-keeper at this place in Gracechurch-street, and saw the transactionâ€”at fifteen minutes past 5, I called the time to spong, and Homewood's bus immediately pulled up close to the doorâ€”Spong caught hold of the horses' heads and backed them; Homewood whipped then up and Spong backed them again; Homewood then got down, pushed him from his horses, and then they scuffled togetherâ€”Spong fell on his back and Homewood atop of himâ€”I desired both of them to take their carriages awayâ€”the prisoner got upâ€”I did not see him do anything before he got upâ€”I did not see any blow struck, nor any bloodâ€”as soon as the prisoner got up I desired him to take his carriage away, and while I was doing that, the policeman took him in chargeâ€”I saw the two fall, and I saw the prisoner get upâ€”I did not see anything like his lifting Spong up by the collar and striking himâ€”I did not go close enoughâ€”I was as near as I am to you now.
COURT to THOMAS DENNE. Q. Could that scalp wound have been made without any blood? A. No; there was a great deal of blood at the time, and also blood from the nose.
JAMES MANN (re-examined). I left him in the hands of the policeâ€”I did not hear Spong say anything to the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. Did you see Spong lying insensible there? A. Yesâ€”it is my duty to interfere in these matters, and I summoned them before one of the Aldermenâ€”the summons was dismissedâ€”I did not see any bloodâ€”I did not see any on the pavementâ€”I went as fast as I could to get the carriages away, the obstruction was so great.

GEORGE COMFORT . I am a carman in the employ of Messrs. Christie & Co., of Graoechurch-streetâ€”I saw this transactionâ€”it was on the 4thâ€”about a quarter past 5 o'clock I was opposite Talbot-court, unloading my cart; I saw Homewood drive up behind Martin's bus, which was stopping thereâ€”the moment he drew up, the prosecutor took hold of the horses' heads rather roughly, and forced them back, and Homewood drove them up againâ€”he forced them back a second time, and then Callum, the coachman, who usually goes with him, took hold of the prosecutor's arms and pushed him backâ€”after that Homewood got down and shoved him away, and asked him why he interfered with his horsesâ€”he came up and did the same again, and took hold of Homewood and shoved him back, and after that I saw them

tustling togetherâ€”that is all I sawâ€”I was the opposite side of the street on my cartâ€”I saw the fall, but could not hear any language passâ€”I saw the prosecutor get upâ€”I cannot say there was no blood, as I was at that distanceâ€”I saw Spong get up with the assistance of the policemanâ€”he was up when the policeman cameâ€”I saw him fallâ€”I cannot say whether he was insensible or not, but a second or two afterwards he got up by himselfâ€”I did not see him smoking a cigar a short time afterwards.

JOSEPH STOCK (City-policeman, 589). I was sent for on this afternoon to Talbot-court, and found the prosecutor standing without any assistance, with a crowd of people round himâ€”his nose had been bleedingâ€”I asked him the cause of it, and whether he would go to a hospital or a doctor'sâ€”he refused and said he was all rightâ€”he went to a public-house to wash himselfâ€”I saw him again about 6 o'clock, about three-quarters of an hour aftewards, stand
ing in the court, and I asked him whether he should lose his place through fightingâ€”he said, "No, only an odd man is gone on that journey"â€”he said nothing about fightingâ€”I did not see him insensible.
Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. You did not see the quarrel take place? A. No.
COURT. Q. What time was it when you got there? A. About a quarter past 5â€”I did not look exactly at the timeâ€”the prosecutor was bleeding from the nose, and a small cut on the back of the head.

JAMES POCKETT . I am coachman to Mr. Wheatley, of Greenwichâ€”I saw William Spong on the evening of 4th March, before 6 o'clock, in Talbot-courtâ€”he told me of the occurrence that had taken place, and that he would wait there for William Homewood's next journey from Peckham to fight it outâ€”he did not seem insensibleâ€”there seemed nothing at all the matter with him.
COURT. Q. Did he seem angry? A. Noâ€”he was standing up in the court.

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. Did you see any blood on him? A. No; there was no appearance of any marks of bloodâ€”I did not notice that he had a black eye, or any scar, nothing whateverâ€”I do not know the man who is sitting behind youâ€”I have had no conversation with himâ€”I did not tell him that I saw the blood coming out of his ears.

The prisoner received a good character.â€”
GUILTY.
MR. HOLDWORTH stated that the prisoner was in a position to pay a fine, that his brother was then lying dead, and he had no one to manage his business, and that if he was imprisoned his business would have to be sold, and he would be quite ruined. MR. KEMP stated that he could not concur in that proposition, then having been a large amount of deliberation shown by the prisoner about the transaction.

p.rs: The printer was ordered to pay a fine of 5l. to the Crown, and 5l. to the prosecutor for his loss and expenses;
and to enter into his own recognisances in 20l. and two sureties in 10l. each to keep the peace for twelve months.

div1.p:
445.
CHARLOTTE TAYLOR (26),
Stealing on 21st December 14 boots, on 1st March 12 boots, and on 29th March 6 boots, and 1 yard of silk, the property of
Baer Adolph Manheim, her master; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

446.
CHARLOTTE AUSTIN (44),
Stealing 15 forks, 24 spoons and other articles, the property of
Jeremiah Evans and another, her masters; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

447.
THOMAS MASON (40), was indicted
for feloniously marrying
Sarah Hand, his wife Matilda being then alive.

WILLAM METCALFE . I live at Fenny Stratford, in Huntingdonshireâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”I was present at hit first marriage, somewhere about 8th Oc
tober, 1843â€”he was married at St. Anne's Church, Dean-street, Sohoâ€”I have seen the first wife sinceâ€”I last saw her on Saturdayâ€”I was ordered to call at Colney-hatch Asylumâ€”I called there and saw her, and was with her for about an hourâ€”she is the woman he marriedâ€”I lost sight of them since the marriage for, perhaps, eight or nine yearsâ€”I lived in the neighbourhood and I knew they were separatedâ€”they lived together three or four years before I heard they were separatedâ€”I lost sight of them after thatâ€”I first knew that the woman was in a lunatic asylum about a fortnight agoâ€”(certi
ficate read:â€”"October 8th, 1842. Marriage solemnized at St. Anne's, Westminster, between Thomas Mason, and Matilda Garehern, by banns by me, Henry Charles Seller, in the presence of us, William Metcalfe, and Eliza
beth Metcalfe. George J. Storey, curate.")â€”her name was Garehernâ€”she is a German.

GEORGE BACHELOR (Police-sergeant, 19 G). I took the prisoner in custody, and told him that I wanted him on a charge of bigamyâ€”a few minutes afterwards he said "My cousin has done this for me; she knew I was a married man"â€”the second wife is his cousinâ€”she was present at that timeâ€”I got the certificate which has been produced, at St. Anne'sâ€”this is the second oneâ€”(read.â€”"21st January, 1855. Marriage solemnised between Thomas Mason, and Sarah Hands, by me, J. A. Jacobs, curate; in the pres
ence of us, Sarah Hands and Mary Stevens.")

SARAH HANDS . I was married to the defendant on 21st January, 1855â€”I have a child by himâ€”I continued to live with him two years and a halfâ€”I knew he was a married man at the time I was married to him, but he said his first wife was deadâ€”I have heard that that is not so for some time; but not known it as a factâ€”I did not continue to live with him after I found it outâ€”I have not been living with him for four years.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Q. Have you a mother? A. No; she is deadâ€”she died seven years ago next June, I thinkâ€”the defendant had two children by his first wifeâ€”they were taken charge of by my motherâ€”she had the youngest four years, two years and a half after the date of the marriageâ€”I lived with the defendant when I was married to him, not beforeâ€”he is my cousinâ€”I made no inquiries as to his first wifeâ€”I did not tell, him that I had inquired about his first wife or that I had found that she had been an inmate of the Lambeth workhouse, and she was then dead and buriedâ€”I told him nothing, of the sortâ€”I will swear I said nothing of that sort before the marriage, or anything to that effectâ€”he told my mother that his wife was deadâ€”I cannot say what year it was that the children were with my motherâ€”it was before I was marriedâ€”I do not know how many years beforeâ€”I cannot tell you whether it was in 1847â€”I do not know whether it was in 1847 or 1848â€”the eldest child was with my mother a twelvemonth, and the youngest four yearsâ€”it was not as much as seven years before I was married that they were with my motherâ€”I did not know that his first wife had deserted himâ€”I had a quarrel with him at the end of two years and a

halfâ€”we had many quarrels before and afterâ€”I cannot say which was the last timeâ€”I remember his slapping my face, and I had him up before Mr. Ingram, at Hammersmith, and he got a monthâ€”I did not go to his em
