ployers and tell themâ€”they knew his character full wellâ€”I never told him that I had inquired and found that his first wife was deadâ€”I knew that his first wife was not living with him when the children were with my motherâ€”that is at least six or seven years ago.
MR. METCALFE. Q. You believed that she was dead at the time you married? A. Yes; in consequence of what he told me.

HARRIET OSBORNE . I know the defendant and his first wife Margaretâ€”I knew them in 1846, and 1847â€”they were then living in a court in Drury-laneâ€”the name I do not knowâ€”I was not in the court when his wife went away; but I met Mr. Mason a short time afterwards; and he told me she had gone awayâ€”I did not know them after thatâ€”I never saw any miscon
duct on his part to his first wife.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you see anything of the defendent after that? A. No; I left the court just before they didâ€”when I left they were both in the court living togetherâ€”I saw them twice or thrice a dayâ€”I have seen nothing unkind on his partâ€”I saw him now and then afterwardsâ€”I did not know where he was livingâ€”I did not make any inquiries about himâ€”I had no reason to do so.
COURT. Q. Have you ever seen the wife since you saw them together in 1847? A. Yes; I saw her about five years ago, at the end of Tottenham Court-roadâ€”I did not speak to herâ€”I saw her there.
GUILTY .

p.hi: Sarah Hand, the second wife, stated that the prisoncr had behaved very cruelly to her while she lived with him, and that he was now living with another woman.

div1.p:
448.
THOMAS GEORGE CHAPMAN (73),
Unlawfully obtaining, by false pretences, the sum of 3l. of
Thomas Martin, with intent to defraud.

THOMAS MARTIN . I keep the Albion Hotel, Albion-road, Hammersmithâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”he has often been to my house as a customerâ€”about 30th March, 1861, he said to me, if I would lend him 3l. on his gold watch and chain, which was worth 20l., he would be much obliged to meâ€”he was wearing it then and he took it out of his pocket and wrapped it up in paperâ€”I thought it was a gold watch, and gave him the moneyâ€”I put the watch and chain in my pocket wrapped up in paperâ€”I took it up to Mr. Prince's, a watchmaker, on the Mondayâ€”this was on the Saturday.
COURT. Q. Did he say anything about how he had got the watch? A. No; he represented that it was worth 20l.

THOMAS VALLANCE . I live at 24, Ernest-street, Kensington, and am a working jewellerâ€”not a particle of this watch and chain is goldâ€”the intrinsic value, of them is nothingâ€”there are some works in the watchâ€”the case is of no value, or the chainâ€”the works are only of value as a toy.
Prisoner. I did not know the value of it any more than he did.

ARTHUR TARRANT (Police man, K 192). I apprehended the prisoner, and told him he was chained with, obtaining money under false pretencesâ€”Mr. Martin said, "His name is Chapman"â€”he said, "You are mistaken, my name is not Chapman; I know nothing about it"â€”I took him to Arbour-square police-stationâ€”he gave his address, "2, Church-road, Barking"â€”that was a false addressâ€”I went thereâ€”afterwards he gave me another
address, 22, Toddey-Street, Bridge-road, Bethnal-greenâ€”that was his correct address.
Prisoner. I told him that at firstâ€”have got ten houses in Church-road, Barking.

THOMAS MARTIN (re-examined). This was in March, 1861â€”he did not come to my house again to redeem the watchâ€”he left his house and took the furniture with him, and I never saw him any more till he was apprehended.

p.hi: The prisoner put in a written defence, in which he stated he was a builder, and in the seventy-fourth year of his age; that he had a wife and two children, and that he was not guilty of the charge again sthim.

p.rs: GUILTY.â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury in consequence of his extreme age.

p.hi: There was another indictment against the prisoner for uttering a bill of exchange.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. JUSTICE MELLOR; Mr. Ald. COPELAND; Mr. Ald. PHILLIPS;
Mr. Ald. BESLEY; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
449.
JOHN HAMMOND (34),
Stealing a mare, the property of
George Oakman, having been previously convicted of felony; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

450.
JOHN JAMES COOKE (31),
Stealing, whilst employed under the Post-office, a post-letter containing a half-sovereign and 9 postage-stamps, the property of Her Majesty's Postmaster-general.

WILLIAM SMEE . I am one of the police constables attached to the General Post-office in St. Martin's-le-Grandâ€”in consequence of instructions, I was watching on 12th March, in such a position that I could see the passage which leads from the Inland Office to the District Officeâ€”it is a passage about five feet wideâ€”it runs direct under the hall where the public pass throughâ€”there are steps to go down at one end from the Inland Office and steps to go up to the District Office at the other endâ€”at one end of it there are folding doorsâ€”about half-past 6 that morning I saw the prisoner come from the Inland Officeâ€”I knew him previously by sightâ€”he was a sorter in the Post-officeâ€”he was coming from the Inland Office to the London District Office, through the tunnel, with four or five large letters in his right hand, with his left hand placed underneathâ€”whilst he was going through I observed him draw his left hand with a smaller letter, from under
neathâ€”it was a bluish-looking coloured envelopeâ€”he crumpled it up in his fist, and placed it in his left hand coat-pocketâ€”I believe he has on the same coat nowâ€”he went through into the London District Office, and I lost sight of him for about a minute; not through the folding-doors; he was through them when I saw himâ€”I followed him through afterwards, and met him returning from the Letter-carriers' Office towards the Inland Officeâ€”he had nothing in his hand thenâ€”I stopped him and took him into the Comp
troller's roomâ€”he was close against the door when I met himâ€”he there

commenced putting his hands first into his waistcoat-pocket and then into his coat-pocketâ€”I told him to keep his hands out of his pockets, and sent for the inspector, Mr. Delanyâ€”I had no one with me at the moment but the prisonerâ€”a messenger came in with some letters for the President just at the moment, and I sent him for himâ€”upon Mr. Delany's arrival, I said to him, "I have reason to believe the prisoner has a letter in his pocket that does not belong to him"â€”the prisoner could hear thatâ€”Mr. Delany in reply said, "Have you, Cooke?"â€”the prisoner said, "No, sir; what I have is my pockets belongs to myself"â€”I then asked the prisoner if he had any objection to be searchedâ€”he said, "No"â€”I commenced searching him, and it his left-hand coat-pocket I found this cloth; at that time there was some bread and butter in it, and the letter, now produced, crumpled upâ€”it was the coat-pocket where I had previously seen him put his handâ€”the letter was crumpled up and shoved down by the side of the cloth in the pocket, between the cloth and the side of the pocket, shoved down tightâ€”the letter was not in the state in which it would come from the Post-office; it was crumpled right up: the same as if a person were to take a piece of paper in their hand and crumple it upâ€”it is addressed, "Messrs. F. L. Carver & Co. 57, Skinner Street, London, E.C."â€”it was opened before the Magistrate, and contained a half-sovereign in a card, nine penny postage-stamps, and an order for a new hatâ€”the card was crumpled upâ€”it was smoothed out when it was openedâ€”the envelope bears the London postage-stamp of the morning of the 12th, and the stamp of St. Columb, Cornwall, of the llthâ€”after I had done searching the prisoner I said to him,"Is this your letter, Cooke?"â€”he said, "No; if that came out of my pocket, some one must have put it then; I know nothing about it"â€”I then asked where he livedâ€”he said at 55, Gopsall-street, Hoxtonâ€”I asked what part of the house he occupiedâ€”he said the two parlours and back kitchenâ€”I went there and found a quantity of Money in two cash-boxes, amounting altogether to 312l. and some promissory notesâ€”the prisoner subsequently told me that he had brought it home from Australia, and he was going to purchase a house in Pakington-street, Islington; I think he said for 430l.â€”he said he was endeavouring to raise the money to pay that sumâ€”as I was about taking the prisoner from the Comptroller's room to another room of our own, he said, "This is a piece of villany on the part of some one; I will swear before all the judges in London, if it was necessary, that I never saw that letter before"â€”I said, "It is no use you talking in that way to me, Cooke; it is not the first letter you have put in your pocket, and that I know with my own knowledge"â€”the prisoner replied, "Oh no, sir, you are wrong"â€”he was then taken into custodyâ€”directly I commenced searching him Mr. Powley, the president of the London District Office, came inâ€”I found a pocket-book in the prisoner's pocket, containing some memorandums; there was no other paper in that pocketâ€”Rumbold, a brother officer, was with me when I was watching the prisonerâ€”he was with me at the place where I first saw the prisoner in the passage.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE (with MR. F. H. LEWIS.) Q. What was the amount of the cash you found? A. 235l. in goldâ€”I understood the prisoner to say he was going to pay 430l. for the houseâ€”I did not find a receipt on him for a portion of the rentâ€”I found a copy of a lease in his breast coat pocket; I suppose it was the lease of the house he spoke of; it is hereâ€”all the papers are hereâ€”there may be a receipt from the landlord for 99l. thereâ€”I have not gone through the papers carefully; I have not had my attention called to thatâ€”there is a receipt there, I do

not know for What amount, it is for part payment of the houseâ€”in addition to that there were, I think, two or three promissory notes; everything is here that was brought awayâ€”these were all found on his person; I have kept them separateâ€”I do not see a promissory note amongst theseâ€”to the best of my belief this paper was found in his breast coat pocketâ€”I do not know whether the person who has signed this, "Hy. Chas. Holgate," is a clerk in the Post-office; I do not know himâ€”the prisoner said that he had been applying to some letter-carrier for money that was owing to him; he stated that at Bow-streetâ€”in his box was a license applicable to the diggings in Australia, and one small nugget.

MR. CLERK. Q. Were the papers you found on the prisoner loose or contained in anything? A. Some were in the pocket-book with an elastic band round them; they were in the inside breast pocket, to the best of my belief, and likewise the lease, that was sticking out about two inchesâ€”when I took him his coat was open, not buttonedâ€”I could see the lease sticking out of his pocket as he passed along the passage.

HENRY RUMBOLD . I am a constable attached to the Post-officeâ€”on the morning of 12th March, about a quarter to 6, I was with Smee watchingâ€”I had received instructions, there is a passage going from the Inland Office to the District Officeâ€”while I was watching I saw the prisoner, about half-past 6, going from the Inland Office to the District Officeâ€”the under ground passage is lighted by gasâ€”he had some letters in his right hand, with his left hand placed close under the right with the lettersâ€”as he came towards me, he drew from underneath the packet in hia left hand, a bluish coloured envelope, crumpled it up and put it into his left coat pocketâ€”he then went on into the District Office.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see his pocket searched? A. No, I did not; he was searched before I went into the Comptroller's Officeâ€”I belive he had been sorting from 5 o'clock that morning; that is a process that is done very rapidly.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE to WILLIAM SMEE. Q. Had the prisoner a tobacco pouch? A. Yes; in his right-hand coat pocket, not the pocket where the letter wasâ€”I asked the prisoner, in the Comptroller's room, if the letter was his, and he said "No"â€”to the best of my belief he did not at that time say it was a piece of viliany; that was afterwardsâ€”I will not undertake to swear he did not say at that time, because there was a good deal said.

WILLIAM PAWLEY . I am one of the chief officers of the Post-officeâ€”on the morning of 12th March, I went into the Comptroller's room after the prisoner had been taken there by Smeeâ€”I saw this letter in the officer's hands; it was then crumpled up, like it is now.

JOHN DELANEY . I am an inspector of letter carriers in the Post-officeâ€”the prisoner was a letter carrier in the General Post-officeâ€”he has been engaged there about six yean and a halfâ€”on the morning of 12th March, he was engaged in subdividing lettersâ€”he began his duties about five minutes past 5 o'clookâ€”he would be engaged until about twenty minutes to 7, or a quarter to 7, or nearly 7 o'clock; it all depends upon whether the work is very heavyâ€”he was employed in the Inland Office, in the A section of the East Central districtâ€”this letter, addressed to Messrs. Carver, Skinner-street, would go to the A section, in due courseâ€”there would be three or four persons engaged in sorting there at that time I think; I am not quite sure; there might be moreâ€”the prisoner was not immediately under my controlâ€”I was sent for to the Comptroller's room on this morning; I found

the prisoner and Smee thereâ€”I did not see the letter taken from the prisoner's pocketâ€”Smee said in his presence, "I have reason to believe, sir, that this man has a letter in his possession which does not belong to him"â€”I said, "Is that so, Cooke"â€”he said, "No, sir"â€”a letter carrier should not take letters from one part of the office to the other without he has orders from his superior officer, the superintending sorterâ€”there are collectors regularly employed, who clear away the letters when they are subdividedâ€”a portion is taken to the letter carriers' office, which is the London district office, and there the letters are made up for delivery.

Cross-exmined. Q. Up to what time do the letter collectors collect in the morning? A. Up to about 6.45 or 6.50; they do not sometimes con
clude much earlierâ€”if a collector is not there the superintendent sorter will, at the conclusion of the duty, if he finds the work getting heavy, send one of the sorters to assistâ€”Mr. Richardson is the superintending sorter.

JOSEPH JOHN RICHARDSON . I am superintendent of the sorters of the General Post-officeâ€”the prisoner was employed in the A section on the morning of 12th March, in the East Central districtâ€”when letters are sorted in the Inland office they are taken to the district office or letter carriers' office, to be set up by the letter carriersâ€”there are carriers regularly appointed to attend to that dutyâ€”a certain number of the letter sorters are appointed the last thing to take the letters over, before the despatchâ€”there are eleven persons appointed for that dutyâ€”the prisoner was not one of the persons so appointed on 12th March.

Cross-examined. Q. When you say eleven persons, do you mean eleven of the sorters? A. Yes; they are not appointed by writing, but by my own arrangementâ€”I tell them how they are to actâ€”a person has no right, according to the strict regulations of the business, to do so unless I tall himâ€”I have not been examined before.
JURY. Q. Do you recollect whether you instructed the prisoner on this morning to take over any portion of the remaining letters? A. Decidedly not; it is a permanent arrangement.
COURT. Q. When did you hear the charge against the prisoner? A. Not until some minutes after he was takenâ€”I heard it the same day.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. Do not you know, as a matter of fact, that the sorters who are left last, when there are letters to be conveyed over, constantly take them without any order whatever? A. No; it is no such thing, I am quite certainâ€”the names of the eleven persons employed are taken down in a bookâ€”that book is in existence.

MR. CLERK. Q. What is the last time that letters are taken over? A. Seven o'clockâ€”the letter collectors take them out three times; every quarter of an hour, up to a quarter to 7â€”up to that time, no person engaged in sorting would take letters from the one office to the other except those eleven.

COURT. Q. You say that the collectors come every quarter of an hour? A. Yesâ€”at the last, there being a certain number of letters left, I give instructions to some of the sorters to take them over, so as not to detain the letter carriers in their despatch.

WILLIAM MAJOR CARDELL . This letter, addressed to Mr. Carver, is my writingâ€”I inclosed in it an order and this card, with a half-sovereign inserted in it, and nine penny postage stampsâ€”when I put the card into the letter it was not crumpled up, as it is now, but quite straight.

p.hi: The prisoner received an excellent character.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

451.
FREDERICK ROBINSON (40), Was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
Elizabeth Craze; he was also charged upon the Coroner's Inquisition with the like offence.

p.hi: The details of this case were not of a nature for publication; the death was alleged to be caused by the negligence of the prisoner during his attendance as a medical man upon the deceased in her confinement.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Four Months.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. BARON WILDE; Sir John MUSGROVE, Bart. Ald.; and

div1.p:
452.
CHLOM REICHBERG, alias Hart (45), was again indicted (see page 617) with
ABRAHAM ROSENBERG (55), and
KOIFMAN WEBER (35),
for feloniously having in their possession 2 stones tnd 1 plate engraved with divers parts of a Russian rouble note, without the authority of the Emperor of Russia.

JAMES CORDER . I am a lithographer and printer, of 24, Derby-street, Birminghamâ€”I carried on business in Howard-street at this timeâ€”at the latter end of February or the beginning of March last year, Rosenberg called upon me and asked me if I would do some indecent prints'which be produced, and which I refusedâ€”on another occasion he asked me if I would make my fortune: if I would do somethingâ€”he produced a Russian rouble note, and asked me if I would engrave it; what we call get it upâ€”I said that I would rather not, and after a few minutes he went awayâ€”he called again next day, I believe, and asked me if I would carry out the execution of that noteâ€”he produced it again, and I asked him why he did not get it done in his own countryâ€”be said that the risk was very great there, and the punish
ment was great; in England they were not so severe, but in Russia they would send their wives and families to Siberiaâ€”be said that I should have 300l. for executing itâ€”I was to engrave the whole of the plates necessary for producing fac similes of the rouble note, and I was to print a quantityâ€”I agreed to engrave it, and be said that he would send me a genuine not to work from, by postâ€”I received this note (produced) next morning; it was not in this state; I made it so by means of varnish, and out off the corners for the purpose of executing itâ€”I saw Rosenberg again on, I think, the after
noon of the same dayâ€”be asked me if 1 had received the note all rightâ€”I produced it, and he asked me if I had done any portionâ€”he wished me to do a portion of the red, the chocolate part, the ornamental border, and when I had done it to send it directed to K. Weber, 4, Nelson-street South, Birmingham, to show my abilityâ€”he gave me a printed card of the name of the streetâ€”I have not got it; Mrs. Corder burnt itâ€”I proceeded to execute on stone the border which he required; I think I did it the same dayâ€”I struck off three or four proofs, and sent two to the address givenâ€”I had made a communication to Mr. Glossop, the chief superintendent of police at Birmingham, and to Mr. Collisâ€”I think I traced the note before I spoke to the police, but am not sure; that was the commencement of the process.
COURT. Q. Had you got any further than the tracing? A. I think not, but am not certainâ€”I believe I had not spoken to the police before I sent

that proof, but I called on Mr. Collis, the Vice-Consul for Russia, beforeâ€”that was my first stepâ€”I saw him and told himâ€”that was on the same day that I traced out the border, but whether I traced it after I went or before I do not knowâ€”I communicated with the police that same dayâ€”I went down with Mr. Collis.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. On executing that proof, did you send a duplicate proof to Mr. Tandy, the inspector of police at Birmingham? A. I didâ€”this proof (produced by Inspector Tandy) is of the same stoneâ€”I sent one like this to that direction by post, and on the next day, I think, Rosenberg came and grumbled that I had written anything inside the envelopeâ€”I had asked him in the letter if it was sufficiently goodâ€”he said that I should not have put any writingâ€”he said that it would do very nicely, and I was to go on; he was very well satisfiedâ€”he came again in a day or two with Tobias, who is not in custodyâ€”he said before he brought them that he must show these portions to themâ€”Reichberg also came on another occasion; they were con
tinually callingâ€”Rosenberg came again with Tobias only, and again, I think, the same day with Tobias and Reichbergâ€”Rosenberg produced the proof which I had sent to Weberâ€”he kept that one himself; be always carried it in his pocketâ€”he produced it and described the different technicalities of the note, and the different ways that the border ran, which was a thing I should not have noticed if it had not been pointed outâ€”the ornaments at the top run to the left and to the right, but at the bottom they both run towards the centre; it is a thing which no casual observer would noticeâ€”a conversa
tion took place about the progress of the work, and I was ordered to go on with itâ€”Rosenberg said that if I got on I should have some money on ac
countâ€”from that time, and for weeks afterwards, I received continual visits from them, but not so much from Reichberg as from Rosenbergâ€”I saw Weber about three weeks after the first interview; he came alone, and said that he was a gentleman from London, and then he introduced himself as Mr. Weber, and said he would bring up two gentlemen "On that business; you know"â€”I then mentioned the names, Reichberg and Tobiasâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”he then went away and called with them the same afternoon; the proofs of the note were then produced, and we talked about themâ€”I cannot tell exactly the words, but it was in reference to the proofs, and to several minute details in reference to the shape of the Russian lettersâ€”they did not stop long then, but they came again in the evening and brought some sardines and biscuits with themâ€”they stayed till half-past 12 at nightâ€”they sent out for some ale, and then the notes were producedâ€”they sent the nurse for some water, into which they dipped the note and held it up to the gas to show me the water-mark, which then became very distinctâ€”they showed me several other things connected with the note, especially the shape of the Russian charactersâ€”I had at that time an impression in full, of the face of the note ready for them, which had been struck off from the stone; that is the promissory part, "I promise to pay"â€”that is one of the stones which Mr. Tandy hasâ€”the engine turned work was then doneâ€”these two stones (produced) are for the face; they are quite similar to each other; they are both so exactly alike that I can hardly tell which one I usedâ€”this is the first I made, the smaller one; it was produced and shown to themâ€”I think the plate was engraved subsequentlyâ€”two or three hours were occupied in examining the proofs and the water-markâ€”one evening Weber and Tobias calledâ€”they came up in the office and sketched me conjointly the pattern of the water-mark on a piece of card-board; at least, I sketched it under their directionâ€”I gave it to the policeâ€”

this (produced) is itâ€”they sketched it on another piece of paper, and I believe they tore it upâ€”all these matters were handed by me into the cus
tody of the policeâ€”I got the groundwork of the water-mark engraved sub
sequently in London, on copper, by McCullmn, of Lincoln's Inn-fieldâ€”this (produced) is itâ€”I can tell it by one or two imperfectionsâ€”it was executed in London according to my order, and I showed it to all of the prisonersâ€”they expressed themselves very much pleased with it, and offered to buy me a machine to do the work myself instead of sending it to London to be doneâ€”they then wanted to see the beck border and some of the small writ
ing on the back, which was very particularâ€”I omitted to say that I had two more one rouble Russian notes, one from Weber and the other from Tobias or Rosenberg, I will not be sure which, for the purpose of working fromâ€”this note was not very distinct after it was varnished, and I wanted a clean oneâ€”the letters at the back are very minute; you have to use a glass to see themâ€”they promised to buy me a magnifying-glass, and when I got home I found an eye-glass had been left which I and they used at times in examin
ing the workâ€”I struck off impressions from the copper-plate, and one came from London with itâ€”I struck off impressions for them on very thin paper, and gave them to themâ€”I subsequently procured them two daguerreotype plates on copper, silvered (produced), of the back of the noteâ€”I had two, because this one was not sufficiently distinct to cutâ€”the object of that was to work from it more easily than from the back of the noteâ€”it only required cutting out the work that was daguerreotyped upon itâ€”this (produced) is one of the two notes I received from Weberâ€”I wanted a very nice, clean one, because the work on the back was so minute; and he said he would go to London and get me oneâ€”he brought this excursion bill to me (produced), or a similar one, prior to going, and asked me to write down the date on a piece of paper, the times he could go and come back by, and the fareâ€”this is my writing on itâ€”Weber speaks English very wellâ€”I do not know why he could not see for himselfâ€”this other note was given me by Rosenberg Weber, or Tobiasâ€”a few days after I made out that paper with the times on it, Weber came from Londonâ€”he was away a few daysâ€”I received this letter (produced)â€”I cannot say whether it is Weber's writingâ€”I filed it on my receipt file, and after he came back to Birmingham from London be asked me if I received his letter.

MR. COOPER. Q. Was the letter produced when he spoke of it? A. I had it in my pocketâ€”I cannot say whether I showed it to him; but I believe I merely said, "Yes"â€”(Read:"London, 26, Houndsditch. Dear Sir, I arrived from Birmingham at London safe. I spoke to Mr. Tobias, so he does not know the reason why Reichberg is not come back from Paris. He ex
pected him this week with his partner together; so soon as he will be here they will all come to Birmingham. I am sorry to say that Mr. Tobias cannot walk yet; he has got a young brother come to him from his country, because he write home that he was ill. I would not buy that pattern what you wanted, 52, because Reichberg will bring with him new ones, all sorts of patterns. I shall bring with me what I promised you. Yours truly, K. Weber. My address is 26, Gravel-lane, Houndsditch."

COURT. Q. What is the meaning of "I would not buy that pattern that you wanted, 52"? A. They wanted a 50l. rouble note, and I would not go on with it without the patternâ€”I do not know what 52 is; I cannot make it outâ€”"I shall bring you what I promised you" means a new noteâ€”the letter has the London post mark on it.
MR. SLEIGH. Q. What next was done after Weber's return from London?

A. I went on with different portions of it, and they called at different timesâ€”Reichberg and Tobias were sometimes in London and sometimes in Parisâ€”I was told when they did not call that they were in Parisâ€”I subsquently took impressions as the work went on, and sent some of them to London, to Rosenbergâ€”he gave two addresses: No. 4, Little Prescott-street, Goodman's-fields, London, and 19, Little Alie-street, Whitechapelâ€”I sent him proofs to both placesâ€”he gave me the address for that purposeâ€”one was addressed to Reichberg at one of those addresses, and when Rosenberg came back to Lon
don, on a subsequent occasion, he told me that the proofs had been received all right, that he met Reichberg at a Jew's eating-house or dining-rooms, who told him that he had received themâ€”these two stones are identical as regards the impressionsâ€”the first one was not sufficiently correctâ€”they were so very minute in examining with the eye-glass that they discovered one or two places in some of the lettersâ€”they also said that the paper which I found was not sufficiently good, and they would find other paperâ€”Rosenberg had an im
pression pulled on some paper which he broughtâ€”he said that the paper ought to be very tough, so that it would bear water without tearing; and they all explained pretty nearly the same thing to meâ€”the toughness of the paper was a very important pointâ€”these (produced) are two impressions which I pulled from the first stoneâ€”Rosenberg explained to me that the notes would be many yean before they reached the bank, as it was such a vast country; and that the people were very uneducated, and could scarcely read their own notesâ€”Reichberg cannot speak many words of Englishâ€”they ceased to call upon me about Novemberâ€”they wanted to take away the stones and other materials, but I would not let them have themâ€”I had not produced a perfect note; there are six printings to produce a perfect im
pressionâ€”this is the groundwork for the colour, the yellow, a stone which is destroyed, was for the chocolateâ€”these are for the promissory parts, "I pro
mise to pay;" and these plates are of the back, with the small writing and the borderâ€”the eagle was never done at all; but it is upon these platesâ€”I never engraved a plate like thisâ€”this plate was never finished; I litho-graphed the border of itâ€”about a month or two after the commencement of the matter, Rosenberg proposed that he and I should jointly turn round upon the others, inform the Government, and obtain a rewardâ€”he said that he could obtain 80l.â€”I asked him how I could have any confidence in him if he could tell of his own persuasion, and he said that he only did it to try meâ€”about a week afterwards, Weber proposed the same thing to me, in almost the same words; but he did not say how much money there wasâ€”I told him that Rosenberg had proposed the same thingâ€”he said that he was a bad man; and I said that he said he only did it to try me; and Weber said that he had only done it to try meâ€”Ann Parsons is the person who was at my houseâ€”she was the nurse to my wife who was ill; and was there when the beer and biscuits were got.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. You took the advice of those two prisoners, and did inform the Government? A. I had done that beforeâ€”I was not offered a penny rewardâ€”nothing was said about any reward for my trouble by Mr. Collis; he seemed to throw cold water upon the matter; he said that he had seen so many of these cases that he thought it was a trap to get me to execute the thing, and then they would inform the Government against meâ€”I have been in Birmingham about eight years, carrying on the business of lithographing and engraving; I was employing eight or ten people last year at the time Reichberg was in communication with me about the stones, but printers do not stop very longâ€”they were at work in

my shopâ€”I first saw Reichberg in the entry of the house leading to the shop; that is an entry through which my workmen pass and repassâ€”that was when Tobias and Rosenberg cameâ€”I think it was in March; it was the beginning of the case, but after Rosenberg had first beenâ€”he did not come into the house on that occasion, he remained in the entry; Tobias and Rosenberg were up stairs, and I went down and saw him in the entryâ€”Reichberg first came into the house the day that we had the supperâ€”only my family were living in my house at that time; my wife and children, the servant girl, and Mrs. Parsons, the monthly nurseâ€”the nurse waited on them; the girl, I believe, was there, but she did not stop up so lateâ€”that was the only occasion when Reichberg was in the houseâ€”I distinguish the house from the shop and the office; he had been in the office twice or three times, not more; he was the last there of any.

Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. Do you owe any money to either of these men? A. Noâ€”I have been sued twice by Rosenberg; I disputed the account, but I was out of town and could not attend, and therefore I paid itâ€”it was 4l. or 5l., and was for some framing which Rosenberg had done for meâ€”I disputed it because he overcharged me; I only disputed a part of itâ€”I have only had two sovereigns from him on account; one was on the night of the sardine supperâ€”I was to have 300l., but Rosenberg explained that another engraver in Birmingham had robbed them of 60l., which they had advanced to him, so they would not pay until the plate was complete and I had printed off sufficient to represent 300,000l.â€”I suppose I shall get 3s. 6d. a day for this; I am only receiving my railway fareâ€”I have not been led to expect anything except what the law allows me; in fact, it has nearly mined meâ€”I was insolvent once, some years agoâ€”I paid this money to Rosenberg, and have the receipt on my fileâ€”I was not arrestedâ€”I never was convicted of assaults, or riot, or anything.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. Have you always been a lithographer? A. For the last eight yearsâ€”I was drawing master in a school before thatâ€”this (produced) is similar to the card Weber handed to meâ€”I knew at the time that he was a tailor carrying on business at Birmingham; it says so on the cardâ€”he told me that Reichberg was living with himâ€”I understood him to say that he was a gentleman from London, and not that he came from some gentlemen of London; but before he saw me he saw Mrs. Corderâ€”I was out at the timeâ€”he spoke of the gentlemen from London, and I afterwards mentioned Rosenberg and Tobias, and he said, "Yes"â€”I cannot count how many times Weber came, I was going to say eighty timesâ€”he appeared to be an interpreter to the other men, because Tobias and Reichberg could only speak a few words of Englishâ€”they told me that they made Weber their interpreterâ€”I do not remember them saying before Weber came that they would look out for some man who could interpret for themâ€”I told Weber, before he went to London, that I could not work from the note I hadâ€”I did not ask him to purchase a Russian note for me, but he said that he wouldâ€”I did not pay him for it; I never gave him a half-penny in my lifeâ€”I did not go to his house on a Sunday and receive the note from him; he brought it to me, because I did not know when he came back from Londonâ€”these men were alone with me each time, because we locked the office door, except on the occasion of the sardine supperâ€”I never said, "Do not tell Weber anything about it," or, "You had better not tell Weber anything about it," because I considered them all as one.
MR. SLEIGH. Q. You have been asked if you have ever been insolvent; have you since paid 20s. in the pound? A. Yesâ€”I have never been

convicted of any offenceâ€”many years ago I was I little the worse for liquor and broke some lamps, for which I had to payâ€”I was with a barrister, and I screened himâ€”it was generally after the workmen left at night, that these persons came.

HENRIETTA CORDER . I am the wife of the last witnessâ€”I have never seen Reichberg at my husband's house, but I have seen the other two on more occasions than oneâ€”I have seen these stones and plates a great many times, on the table in the back kitchenâ€”I have seen them both look at them, but not together.
Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. Were you often present when they were there? A. Yes; on domestic affairsâ€”I ran in and out, through the kitchen uninterruptedly, while they were there.

ANN PARSONS . I am a widowâ€”I did live in Birmingham, but do not nowâ€”I am a monthly nurseâ€”I attended Mrs. Corder five or six weeks last year, and saw all the three prisoners thereâ€”I have seen them there togetherâ€”I have seen Reichberg, Weber, and Tobiasâ€”I never saw Reichberg and Rosenberg there together, but I have seen Rosenberg there by himself oftenâ€”I remember one night supper being in the kitchen, sardines, beer, and so forth; I went for the beerâ€”Reichberg was there, and Weber, and Tobiasâ€”I saw some stones on the tableâ€”they asked me for a jug of water, and when I brought it they turned it into a basin and dropped a piece of paper into it

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. This, I suppose, took place in March last? A. The beginning of Marchâ€”Sergeant Brett recalled my attention, about six weeks ago, to what took place while I was a monthly nurse at Mr. Corder'sâ€”he asked me whether I had been nurse at Mr. Corder's, and whether I had seen some people at supper there; I said, "Yes;" and he asked me whether I should know them again if I saw themâ€”I saw them again, all together, in the dock at the Mansion-house, when I came to London.
JOSEPH NORRIS . These daguerreotype plates (produced) were executed by me, at the request of Mr. Corder, in September last.

â€”MCCULLUM. I am a printer, of Carey-street, Lincoln's-inn-fieldsâ€”in April, 1861, a person called on me, representing himself as the traveller of Mr. Corder, of Birmingham, and I executed for him this engine-turned plateâ€”I employed a person, named Fautrey, to do it for me.

GEORGE PHILIP TANDY . I am inspector of the detective police at Birminghamâ€”in March, 1861, Mr. Corder made a communication to me of a certain application made to him, and, with my concurrence, he went on receiving the prisonersâ€”in January, 1862, Brett came down from London, and, on 18th January, I went to Rosenberg's house, 54, Gooch-street, Birminghamâ€”Brett told him that we were police-officers, and that he would be charged with forging Russian rouble notesâ€”we said that we should search his house, and he said that we could do soâ€”Brett asked him if he had any rouble notes in the house, genuine or forged; or any copies or specimens of notesâ€”he said that he had notâ€”we searched and found a small box on the mantel-piece, and among some letters and papers we found this. (The varnished note)â€”I handed it to Brett, who said, "Where did you get this from?"â€”he said, "About twelve months ago an old man came to my house begging, a foreigner; he asked me to buy this, and I gave him 3s. for itâ€”Brett asked him if it was in the same state now as when he bought itâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”he asked him if he knew himâ€”he said, "I did not; he was a stranger"â€”nothing further was found in the houseâ€”we went to Weber's house on

the 19th, and made the same statement to himâ€”he said, "I have nothing at all here"â€”we searched the rooms, and in a room up stairs, which he used as a workshop, found a coat hanging on a door, in a pocket of which I found this paper (produced)â€”I opened it, and showed it to Brettâ€”Weber then said, "Mr. Corder gave me that paper"â€”I found this time table in the same pocket, and this small bit of paper with written instructions on it.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. Can you tell me the exact time Coder made the communication to you? A. On Tuesday, 5th March, and on 11th March I again saw him with an officer from Londonâ€”he then gave me the specimen I have produced; the chocolate paper.
Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. Has there been a watch kept on Rosenberg since March? A. Not continually, but occasionallyâ€”no one in particular watched him.

EUGENE KLEIN . I have the supervision of one of the printing depart
ments of bank notes in the Bank of Russiaâ€”I have had some engravings struck off these stonesâ€”this is the promise to pay part of a one rouble note, and this is the sameâ€”this engraving is an engine-turned ground work, but on a rouble note it is printed in yellow colourâ€”this is a genuine one rouble note; it would fetch nearly 3s. in London; the exchange is a little less nowâ€”here are two photographs taken from the back of a one rouble note.

Mary Ann Taylor, of Birmingham, gave Weber a good character.â€”
GUILTY .

p.hi:
stated that Rosenberg had been previously con
victed of a like offence, but that the fact was discovered too late to insert the charge in the indictment; a certificate of the conviction was put in by Scott, policeman, who identified, Rosenberg as the man to whom it referred.

div1.p:
ROSENBERG and REICHBERGâ€”
Eight Years' Penal Servitude, each.

WEBERâ€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

453.
BENJAMIN COLE (24),
Feloniously uttering a forged 5l. note, with intent to defraud.

JOHN PETHERBRIDGE . I am a butcher, carrying on business in Hastings-street, Judd-streetâ€”on Saturday evening, 1st March, I was in my first-floor room, and saw the prisoner and another person, opposite my shop, in con
versationâ€”the prisoner crossed over, apparently to my shop; and the person who was with him went a little way down the street and back again, and then looked anxiously across to my shopâ€”I had suspicions, came down stairs into the parlour, and Miss King, who was taking money that night, had a note in her handâ€”I went into the shop; she opened the counting-house door, and said, "Will you give this man change for a 5l. note?"â€”I said, "Oh, no;" and the prisoner, who was there, put down half a shoulder of mutton, which he had purchased, on the counter, saying, "Never mind, I can get it changed"â€”I did not see him again that evening.
Cross-examined by MR. DICKIE. Q. Had you known the prisoner before? A. By passing the shop.

HENRIETTA KING . I am assistant in Mr. Petherbridge's shopâ€”the pri
soner bought some mutton of one of the men, and came up to the desk with a 5l. note, and asked for a pen that he might write his address on the back of itâ€”this is it (produced)â€”he wrote this, "Benjamin Cole, 20, Southampton-street, Russell-square"â€”I refused to give him change in consequence of what Mr. Petherbridge said, and he left the shop, saying that it did not matterâ€”he did not take the meat, and I never saw him after.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you have the 5l. note in your hand? A. Yes,
for a minute or twoâ€”I did not ask himâ€”he wrote his name on itâ€”I did not know him before.

WILLIAM TITFORD . I am an undertaker, of 41, Judd-streetâ€”on Saturday evening, 1st March, about 10 o'clock, the prisoner cameâ€”I knew him by sight, but not his nameâ€”he asked me if I could change him a 5l. noteâ€”I said, "No; I am very busy; but if you take it to one of the shops opposite, they will give you change"â€”he left, and returned in three or four minutes afterwards, saying that the grocer would give him change if I would put my name on the back of itâ€”I said, "I do not see why I should do that;" but afterwards I took the note out of his hand, and held it up to the gas; it was very thick, but I thought it had got so in his pocketâ€”it was endorsed, "Benjamin Cole, 20, Southampton-street, Russell-square"â€”I read that out to him, and asked him if he had received the note of that personâ€”be said, "Yes," and I endorsed itâ€”he then leftâ€”this is itâ€”Mr. Heffill brought it back to me on Monday evening, saying that it was forgedâ€”I then went to the prisoner's house in Brunswick-street, Judd-streetâ€”he had moved there since I knew himâ€”I said, "That note you got me to endorse is a forgery; I sup
pose you know it?"â€”he said, well, he was sorry for that; he did not know itâ€”I said, "You had better go with me to this person, Benjamin Cole"â€”I had got the note in my hand then, and read the addressâ€”he said that it was no use going there, for he wrote that himselfâ€”I said, "Is your name Cole?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "You do not live in Southampton-street, Rusell-square?"â€”he said, "No"â€”I asked him who lived thereâ€”he said a person who had given it to him to get change, told him to put down that addressâ€”I said, "You put down your own name and a false address, and brought it to me?"â€”he made no answer, and I said he had better come down to my shopâ€”he said he had taken it to Mr. Smith'sâ€”I kept him at my shop, sent for a policeman, and gave him in custodyâ€”the policeman asked him who Mr. Smith wasâ€”he said he was a person who he knew some three years sinceâ€”I asked him if he lived in Southampton-streetâ€”he said he did not know where he lived.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had you known him? A. Two or three Yearsâ€”I buried the mother of Miss Wilson, who he is living with, and he was at the funeralâ€”he is a shoemakerâ€”his brother keeps a fried fish shop, or his brother-in-lawâ€”I have seen the person he lives with thereâ€”we have not been in the habit of drinking a glass of ale together.

FISHER HEFFILL . I am a grocer and post-master, of 44, Judd-streetâ€”on the evening of 31st March, the prisoner came and asked me if I would give Mr. Titford change for a five-pound noteâ€”I said, "Is Mr. Titford's name on it?"â€”he said, "No"â€”I said, "If you will get Mr. Titford's name upon it I will change it"â€”this is itâ€”he went across to Mr. Titford, got it endorsed, and I changed itâ€”I did not see him again till he was in custodyâ€”it was returned to me as forged on Monday evening, and I handed it over to Mr. Titford.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you compare it with any other notes? A. No; it was dirty, but be had it in his pocketâ€”I came to the conclusion that it was good.

JOHN GASCOYNE (Policeman, E 10). I took the prisoner at Mr. Titford's houseâ€”he said he had got the note from a man named Smith, who asked him to get him change for itâ€”he said, "I knew him some three years ago, but had not seen him for three years until the night I met himâ€”I said, "Where does he live?"â€”he said, "At the address on the note; I put my name and his address on the note"â€”I asked him what Smith wasâ€”he said, "A bricklayer chap."
WILLIAM DAY . I am a confectioner, of 20, Southampton-row, Russell-squareâ€”I do not know the prisonerâ€”there is no person named Smith or Cole living in my house.
VINCENT YARDLEY . I am register of births, deaths, and marriages for St. George's, Bloomsburyâ€”there is no such street as Southampton-street, Russell-square.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know how many Southampton-streets there are in London? A. I do not.
JOSEPH BUMSTEAD . I am inspector of notes to the Bank of Englandâ€”this note is a forgery in every respect, paper and all.

COURT to WILLIAM TITFORD. Q. You say you have known the prisoner for two years? A. Yesâ€”I buried his wife's motherâ€”her name was Wilsonâ€”I never knew his name till I took the note back to his houseâ€”I found out the house because I have seen him in the shopâ€”it is a fish shop, and the name of Wilson is over the doorâ€”I saw Miss Wilson, and said to her, Where is your husband?"â€”she called the prisoner out of the parlour, and he came into the shopâ€”I never heard the name of Cole in connexion with him; only from what he said.
GUILTY .
The prisoner was further charged with having been before convicted at West-minster Sessions, in November, 1856; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

454.
DANIEL RIARDON (22),
Feloniously uttering a forged 5l. Bank of England note, with intent to defraud.

GEORGE HOPE . I am a portmanteau maker, of 5, Star-place, Somers'-townâ€”the prisoner is my brother-in-lawâ€”he came to my place on Tuesday evening, 11th March, and after we had been sitting there some little while he said that he had a 5l. note, and asked me whether I could get it changed for himâ€”I told him it was a thing I so seldom changed, never having changed but one, and that was at Mr. Meadows', and very likely he might give me change for itâ€”I asked him where he had it fromâ€”he said from a man named Phillips, that he was in partnership with, in hawking jewelleryâ€”I went with him to Mr. Meadows, who is a publican, and asked him if he would change a 5l. note for my brother-in-lawâ€”he told me to ask at the bar if they had sufficient changeâ€”I did so, and they changed it, but before that my brother-in-law endorsed itâ€”I believe this "D. Riardon" to be his endorsementâ€”Mr. Meadows afterwards sent for me, and I sent for the prisonerâ€”that was seven or eight days afterwardsâ€”I told him I had heard that there was something wrong respecting the note, and he must come with me to Mr. Meadowsâ€”I took him thereâ€”we were taken into the back parlour, and a policeman who was there questioned him as to how he became possessed of the noteâ€”he said that he got it from a man named Phillipsâ€”we were both given in charge.

JOHN MEADOWS . The endorsement upon this note was made by my sister-in-law's requestâ€”I saw it madeâ€”I paid it to my distillers, Tanqueray and Co., and received it back shortly afterwards, marked "Forged"â€”the prisoner and Hope came back together, and the prisoner said that he got it from a man in the country named Phillips, with whom he was partner in dealing in jewellery.
MISS FELLOWS. I gave change for this noteâ€”I wrote on it "Hope," the name I had known the first witness by for four years.
JOHN COOK (Policeman, S 198). On Friday, 21st March, I went to Mr.

Meadows', and found the prisoner and the first witnessâ€”I asked the prisoner what explanation he could give of the 5l. noteâ€”he said that he had it from a man in the country, who he was formerly in partnership with in hawking, named Phillipsâ€”I asked him what he had it forâ€”he said for a debt that was owing to himâ€”I asked him if he could tell me where I could find Phillipsâ€”he said he could not; he had not seen him for two or three monthsâ€”I took him in custody, and on the road to the station I said, "I believe you had this note from a man named Miller"â€”he said, "No, I did not: I do not know the man, and I do not know who you mean"â€”he was asked by the inspector on duty at the station, what explanation he could give of the note, and he gave the same explanation as he did to me about Phillipsâ€”when he was going to be locked up he called to me, and said, "You were right about that man; my brother-in-law does not know anything about it"â€”on the day after, when he was at Clerkenwell, he was asked by the Magistrate if he could give any explanation, but he need not do so unless he liked, because he might at a future time be committed for trialâ€”he said that he had it from a man who he met in the street to get change, and he was to receive 25s. for his share: he did not know the man, or that he was a bad character, but had seen him before, and that that man was not Phillips, as he had formerly stated, and what he had said about Phillips was false.
JOSEPH BUMSTEAD . I am inspector of notes at the Bank of Englandâ€”this note is a forgery in every respect.

Prisoner's Defence. I am a baker, and work in Tottenham-court-road. On 11th March I was round Burton-crescent, and a man, who I knew by sight, came up to me and said, "Do you know where I can change a 5l. note? I have had it given to me." I said, "I do not know, but perhaps my master will change it for you." I told him to meet me in the shop that night, and I asked my master to change it, who had not sufficient cash. I then thought of my brother-in-law, as being a respectable man. I asked him, and we went to Mr. Meadows, who changed it I brought out the money to the man, who gave me 25s. out. I am quite innocent of knowing it was forged.
GUILTY .
He was further charged with having been convicted at this court in October, 1859; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. COPELAND; Mr. Ald. PHILLIPS; and Mr. COMMON

div1.p:
455.
ANN WILLIAMS (27),
Stealing a purse and 4l. 17s. the property of
Thomas Henry Marnham, from his person, having been before convicted; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€ â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

456.
JAMES BARRETT (23),
Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard Crouch, and stealing therein 40 yards of calico, value 3l. his goods.

DANIEL DAVID (Policeman, H 169). On 28th November, about half-past 1 o'clock in the morning, or the middle of the night, I was on duty in High-street, Whitechapel, and saw the prisoner, and one named William Smith,

and two others whom I do not knowâ€”the prisoner had a basket with a little straw in itâ€”I observed him and Smith go up to Mr. Crouch's window, 110, High-street, Whitechapelâ€”the other two placed themselves apparently to watch for the policeâ€”I was watchingâ€”I placed myself in a dark doorway a hundred yards, I may say, from themâ€”I saw the prisoner and Smith pull the bar out and slip the shutter on one side, smash a pane of glass, and pull out something white, which afterwards appeared to be calico, and several other articlesâ€”Smith gave them to Barrett, who placed them in the basket, which was standing in a doorway close byâ€”that was the basket he was carryingâ€”I then pulled the tails of my coat round me, put my hat under my arm, made a rush at them and secured Smithâ€”the prisoner ran up Com
mercial-streetâ€”I then went back and found the calico in the basket, and several other articlesâ€”I found that the window had been brokenâ€”that house and shop are in the parish of Whitechapelâ€”the place where the offence was committed was right under a lamp, so that I could see very plainlyâ€”I got up to the men before they retreated: in fact, I had Smith in custody before the men saw meâ€”Barrett ran away, and I next saw him on 10th December, at the Thames Police-courtâ€”he was remanded till the 20th on a charge of haying a quantity of clothes in his possessionâ€”he was sentenced on 20th December, to two months' imprisonmentâ€”I had no doubt what ever, when I saw him, that he was the man I had seen at Mr. Crouch'sâ€”I was certain of himâ€”when he was discharged I took him into custody on this charge of burglaryâ€”I gave the calico up in December last when that sentence was passed.

Prisoner. Q. How could you see me? A. You were right under a gas
lamp, and I passed you once before when you were standing at the corner, close to youâ€”I believe you had on a black coatâ€”I would not swear it was the one you have nowâ€”I do not think it was, because it was a single-breasted oneâ€”it was not buttoned upâ€”I noticed your face particularly, not your clothesâ€”I passed within a yard of you on one occasionâ€”I will be on my oath that it was on the 10th that I recognised youâ€”Mr. Deeble did not tell me that you were coming up to the courtâ€”I saw you there by accidentâ€”I did not know you were there till you were brought up, and I told the Magistrate there and then that I wanted you on another chargeâ€”I should have taken you before if I had seen youâ€”I told you I ascertained where the things were sold, but that was since you were inâ€”I did not tell the Magistrate that at Arbour-square.

RICHARD CROUCH . I am a draper, living at 110, High-street, White
chapelâ€”on the morning of 28th November, the police called me up about half-past 1 o'clockâ€”I went to the station and found a man, named Smith, in the custody of a policemanâ€”another officer came there subsequentlyâ€”I lost a considerable quantity of goods from the window, but the calico was the principalâ€”they had been safe the night beforeâ€”the place was all properly secured when I went to bed the night before at 11 o'clockâ€”I saw the property that the policeman produced, and identified itâ€”my house is in the parish of St. Mary, Whitechapelâ€”the property was produced at the trial, and I swore to its identity.

Prisoner. Q. Did the policeman say he recognised any of the others? A. Yes; he said he knew most of them, but being by himself he waited in ambush till they had effected something, and then he pursued one of them and the others escaped.
Prisoner. It is all false what he has said.
GUILTY .
He was further charged with having been convicted at Clerkenwell in October, 1855, of felony; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

div0.p: PRESENT.â€”Mr. RECORDER; Mr. Ald. CONDER; and Mr. Ald. BESLEY.

div1.p:
457.
HENRY COX (24),
Feloniously forging a request for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

458.
GEORGE WINTER (20),
Unlawfully obtaining, by false pretences, 7 brushes and 56 lbs. of white lead, the property of
Alfred Ewen Burrell, with intent to defraud.

THOMAS WALLACE ALLEN . I am a plumber and painter, carrying on business at 123, Pennington-street, St Georges-streetâ€”the prisoner was formerly in my employâ€”to the best of my knowledge he left at the latter part of March, or the beginning of April, in last yearâ€”I deal with Mr. Burrellâ€”I have occasionally sent the prisoner there for goodsâ€”I never sent him with any book containing orders for goodsâ€”I used to send the orders on bits of paper (looking at five receipts produced)â€”I never authorised the prisoner, or any other person, to obtain those goods for meâ€”he was not at work for me during this time, and I never saw him till I saw him at the police-court, after he had been discharged by meâ€”I believe this is the prisoner's handwriting.
Prisoner. Q. How long had I been in your service? A. Altogether about four monthsâ€”you had been at two or three different timesâ€”you came on the 7th of January, but you were there before that.
COURT. Q. Had he not been in your employment since March or April of last year. A. No.

Prisoner. I only came to England on the 4th; I was never in his employ
ment before 7th March.

ALFRED EWEN BURRELL . I am an oil and colour manufacturer, carrying on business in the Minoriesâ€”on 22d April, the prisoner came to me with one of these receipts; he stated be came from Mr. Allen, and I supplied him with seven brushes and 56 lbs. of white leadâ€”my clerk took the receipt from himâ€”I was standing byâ€”it is signed in the name of "Cook, for Mr. Allen."

Prisoner. Have you got any orders from a book? A. No; the only orders we have are little slips of paperâ€”if you brought a book you took it away with you again; my clerk ought to have kept the book if you brought oneâ€”that was our error.

WILLIAM SAVAGE . I am in the employment of Mr. Burrellâ€”on 25th April last, the prisoner brought an order to me, and I supplied him with the goodsâ€”this is the receipt that he gave meâ€”it is for 56 lbs. of best white leadâ€”he came again on the 29th for six brushes, and gave me this receiptâ€”he came again on the 22d May, for 112 lbs, of best white lead, and gave me this receiptâ€”they are all of them signed for Mr. Allenâ€”he signed them all in my presenceâ€”I signed them, thinking they came from Mr. Allenâ€”he brought paper at first, and then he brought a bookâ€”he said Mr.
Allen had no paper and he had bought him a small bookâ€”the goods were delivered up by that book, he giving a receipt for the goods.

COURT. Q. How did he take away the 112 lbs. of lead? A. He came for it before 8 o'clock in the morning, and said he had got a ship he was going to take it to in St. Katherine's Dock, which is close byâ€”I said, "You can't carry 112 lbs. of lead"â€”he said, "Yes, I can "â€”I said, "Come twice for it"â€”he said, "If you do it up I will take it"â€”I put it on his shoulder, and he took it awayâ€”it was an immense weight for him to carry.

Prisoner's Defence. I have only to say that I never robbed my master at all; always what I fetched there I brought him. I have not been four months in England; I only came over to England on, 4th January.
GUILTY .

p.hi: Mr. Allen stated that the prisoner had behaved himself very well, and worked hard while with him, and that after he left he was in distress.

div1.p:
459.
EDWARD SHEEHAN (24), and
JOHN LANGHAM (30),
Robbery together upon
Thomas Atkinson, and stealing from his person 1 watch, 1 chain, and 1 scarf-pin, his property.

THOMAS ATKINSON . I am a currier, at 86, Marlborough-street, Cavendish squareâ€”at a quarter to 1 on the morning of 23d March, I was about enter
ing my doorâ€”whilst putting the key in the prisoners came up to meâ€”I am quite certain they are the menâ€”they asked me the way to Wells-streetâ€”as I was turning round Sheehan seized me by the throat, and robbed me of my watch, chain, and breast-pinâ€”I was rendered powerlessâ€”both came up to me; Sheehan seized me, and the other was behind meâ€”I was thrown down, and the prisoners ran off down Wells-streetâ€”I had such an opportunity of seeing them as to know themâ€”there was a gas-lamp thereâ€”Sheehan asked me the way to Wells-streetâ€”I could see the faces of both menâ€”I ran after them, calling "Polics," and saw a policeman going after themâ€”the two men were running togetherâ€”the policeman followed the two men that I had been following; that I am quite sure ofâ€”I lost my watch, chain, and a gold pinâ€”their value was about 4l.â€”the next morning my housekeeper found the end of the chain on the stepâ€”this was about a quarter before 1 on the Sunday morning, and the same day I saw Sheehan at the station-houseâ€”he was with other men, and I at once picked him outâ€”I saw Laugham the week following at the station; he was amongst others of the same size and appear
ance as himselfâ€”I at once picked him out.

Langham. Q. Did Sheehan speak to you, or did I? A. Sheehanâ€”I had not time to answer himâ€”I was putting the key in the door, the key dropped, and he seized me before I could answer him a wordâ€”I had a better look at Sheehan than I had at youâ€”you had whiskers on on the night in question, and a dark coatâ€”I cannot say which of you took my watchâ€”I saw you in company with Sheehan when he took me by the throatâ€”I saw a constable running after you down Berwick-streetâ€”I went along ten minutes after
wards, and saw Gordon and told him what had happenedâ€”I am quite certain you are the man, although your whiskers are off.

WILLIAM GORDON (Policeman, A 336). A little before 1 on the morning of 23d March, I was going along Oxford-streetâ€”I saw the two prisoners run out of Wells-street, across Oxford-streetâ€”I fancied there was something wrong, and followed themâ€”they turned down Portland-street, into Great Chapel-street, where I ran against a post, and fellâ€”I was senseless on the

ground, and when I got up they had gone out of sightâ€”I afterwards appre
hended Sheehan at a public-house in the Five Dialsâ€”I told him I should take him in custody for stealing a watch, chain, and scarf-pin, from a gentle
man at a little before 1 on that morningâ€”he said, "I was at home; I know nothing about it"â€”I asked him where he livedâ€”he said, "In Donovan's lodging-house, Queen-street, Seven Dials"â€”I asked him if he was known thereâ€”he said, "Yes; the landlady knows me"â€”I went there and asked for the landlady; some one came forward as the landlady of the house.

Sheehan. Q. Did you run in front of us or behind us? A. You ran round a large lamp-postâ€”I was running after youâ€”I was about ten yards from you when I ran up against the postâ€”it was a side corner post I ran against.

Langham. Q. Are you sure you saw me on the night in question? A. I am certain both of you are the menâ€”I did not see you at the lodging-house I went to, in Queen-streetâ€”I went there the same nightâ€”there ware a number of persons thereâ€”you were not the man who spoke to me at that houseâ€”you were not sitting by the tide of the fireâ€”there was another con
stable with meâ€”there were three persons sitting by the fireâ€”I am sure you were not one of the persons thereâ€”I asked who was the landlord of the houseâ€”I was not answered by you; I was answered by a lady, calling her
self Mrs. Donovanâ€”I asked her if she kept a book with the names of persons who lodged in the house at nightâ€”she said, "No;" and I asked her then how she knew who the lodgers were, and what time they came inâ€”I then asked her if a person, named Sheehan, was living there, and she told me she did not know him by that nameâ€”I then asked her what time, to the best of her knowledge, the last of her lodgers was in on the night previousâ€”she said they were usually in at 12 o'clockâ€”I then asked her if Sheehan was in, and she said she did not know himâ€”I told her I would call again that same nightâ€”I did not do so.

BARNARD STANLEY (Police-sergeant, E 3). When the prisoners were taken into custody, and brought to the station, they were placed with seven othersâ€”they were directed to stand where they likedâ€”they were mixed togetherâ€”the prosecutor saw them, and at once picked them outâ€”he pointed his finger like thatâ€”I said, "Go and lay your hand on them," and he didâ€”I asked him if he was quite satisfied, and he said, "Yes."
Sheehan. Four of them were boys, and one was a potman from a public-house.

WILLIAM ACKRILL (Police-sergeant, F 48). I took Langham into custody on 29th Marchâ€”before that the constable Gordon had described him to meâ€”I told him I should take him for robbing a man of his watch, chain, and breast-pin, in company witn Sheehanâ€”he said he knew nothing about the robbery, and he did not know Sheehanâ€”when I got him to the station he was placed with seven or eight grown-up persons, dressed very much like himâ€”I saw the prosecutor come inâ€”he picked him out directlyâ€”I knew Langham before, as being about "the Dials"â€”when I last saw him he had whiskers on, a pilot coat, and a hat; a totally different kind of dress to what he had afterwards.

COURT to WILLIAM GORDON. Q. Did you know either of the prisoners by sight previously? A. Bothâ€”I gave a description to Ackrill, and also at the police-stationâ€”I was disabled myselfâ€”I was knocked down by the post, and was obliged to lay there three or four minutesâ€”I was on duty on the Monday evening afterwardsâ€”I was in search of the prisoners in the morning at the Dials, but could not see themâ€”I described them to the others on
the same night, and I was looking after them myselfâ€”I did not know where Langham livedâ€”I had known him about three monthsâ€”I have known the other prisoner five or six years.
Sheehan's Defence. On the night of the robbery I was at home, and in bed by twenty minutes past 12.

Langham's Defence. I was at home in bed by 11 o'clock on the night of the robbery. They did not go and see whether I gave a right address, and whether I was at home in bed at the time I state. The prosescutor states that Sheehan was the man who had hold of him. I appeal to anybody in this Court whether the prosecutor could state, on his oath, if he saw a man with whiskers on that night, in a dark suit of clothes; and saw him again eight days afterwards without whiskers, and dressed differently; that he was the same man. He says he can speak to Sheehan better than to me. I saw the constable Gordon on Sunday night, afterwards: I was the man who spoke to him when he came in. I know every word he said to the landlady. I remained there that night until 12 o'clock. I saw him on the 27th, standing in plain clothes, in Seven Dials, and passed him within three yards. It is evident, if I was the man he intended to capture for this robbery, he would have taken me then. I was not the person. It is because, perhaps, I bear rather an indifferent character, I am selected as the victim of this case. I think Mrs. Donovan is here to prove that I was in bed.
GUILTY .

p.hi: Langham was further charged with having been before convicted on 7th January, 1855, at Westminster Sessions; to which he

div1.p:
PLEADED GUILTY.**â€ â€”
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

SHEEHAN**â€ â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

460.
JOHN BURLEY (20),
Stealing a purse and 2s. 6d. the property of
William Bastow, from the person of
Anne Maria Bastow.

ANNE MARIA BASTOW . I am the wife of William Bastowâ€”on Saturday night last, about half-past 9 in the evening, I was in Newgate-marketâ€”I felt the prisoner's hand in my pocket, lost my purse, and saw him running awayâ€”I called out, "Stop him!"â€”before I could get through the crowd a butcher and the female witness stopped himâ€”this is my purse (produced)â€”here is a piece of paper in it with a direction bv which I know it; that was in the purse at the time; and there was a half-crown.

ANN BECKLEY . I am the wife of Joseph Beckley, of 10, Castle-court, Lower Whitecross-streetâ€”I was in Newgate-market on Saturday night last, heard a cry of "Stop, thief!" and saw the prisoner running awayâ€”I stopped him, and a butcher came and caught hold of him on the other sideâ€”I had hold of him on the right side by the collarâ€”I saw the purse in his hand, and he threw it downâ€”I saw another butcher pick it upâ€”he gave it to the prosecutrix.
JAMES HARTOPP (City-policeman, 214). The prisoner was given into my charge.
GUILTY .

p.hi:
He was further charged with having been before convicted of felony at West
minster Sessions, on 10h September, 1860, when he was sentenced to eighteen months; to which he

div1.p:
PLEADED GUILTY.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

461.
ALFRED FREDERICK WILLIAM PHILLIPS (21),
Unlawfully obtaining by false pretences, of
Edwin Southern, 40 gross of clay pipes, with intent to defraud.
MR. METCALFE, for the Prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

462.
JACOB SAFFEARD (26),
Feloniously wounding
Michael O'Brien on his head, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

MICHAEL O'BRIEN . I am a tailor, living at Ely-court, Holbornâ€”on Satur
day night, 22d March, I think, I was coming along the Minoriesâ€”I saw the prisoner, another man, and a woman togetherâ€”as I was passing by them, the two men gave me a severe shove on the sideâ€”I turned round and asked them what they did it forâ€”I was walking quite steadilyâ€”they gave me a shoulder with their armsâ€”the other man was nearest to me, not the prisonerâ€”they struck me one after the otherâ€”the other man struck me firstâ€”the prisoner first struck me with his arm, and immediately afterwards I moved from them; and he up with a stick, and before I knew where I was, I was struck with a stick, which broke in two halvesâ€”they went along, and in going along I met a policeman, and said something to himâ€”they went along jeering and laughing as if they had gained a victory over meâ€”I met them again at the corner of Aldgate, and they several times threatened me thenâ€”they said they would give it to me when I got down to Houndsditchâ€”I said that was on my way home; so when I went down there the prisoner struck me with the stick againâ€”that was near Fireball-court, in Houndsditchâ€”there were two young chaps standing by, and in self-defence I struck the prisoner, and he struck me backâ€”I gave the two young lads my hat and the bundleâ€”the prisoner struck me with the stick, and then I hit him in self
defenceâ€”as we were fighting in the street, he gave me one stab here in the side of the headâ€”I did not fallâ€”he was standing and so was Iâ€”we were tangled together, and he stabbed me in the side of the headâ€”when I felt the first stab, I got him down underneath me, and he had not the full power of his handâ€”I could not get away from himâ€”I saw a penknife in his handâ€”I cannot say how often he struck me with itâ€”he repeated it several timesâ€”he gave me one stab before we got on the ground, and he followed up the stabbing directly afterwardsâ€”when I got up I ran off as quick as I could, for medical aidâ€”I went to two or three shops, and they would not dress the woundâ€”I was bleeding frightfully; my clothes were all covered with bloodâ€”I went to the London Hospital at last.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Did not you get him down, and was he not under you? A. After the first stab he was beneath meâ€”I was not kneeling on himâ€”I was lying upon himâ€”this was opposite the courtâ€”we did not go into the courtâ€”I knew the two lads I spoke ofâ€”I had often seen them; but had no acquaintance with themâ€”I knew them by sightâ€”at that time I deter
mined to have a fight with him for the injury they had done to meâ€”when I first came up, there was a lady with themâ€”I did not shove against the ladyâ€”I did not hear her call out at allâ€”she did not call out, "Oh!" very loud, and say I had pushed against herâ€”I did not hear her say soâ€”the prisoner did not say I was very rude to push against the lady in that wayâ€”the lady was on one side, and the two men on the otherâ€”I was outside themâ€”I did not call them names; I know myself a little better than to do soâ€”I used no in
ferior languageâ€”I suppose drink was the cause of my being struck by the two menâ€”I tried to get out of their wayâ€”I still continued going onâ€”it was on my way homeâ€”I want about half a mile, from the time I was first struck, till I got to the courtâ€”I kept on being abused by them, and never saying or doing anythingâ€”there was nobody to defend meâ€”I saw no pipe in the prisoner's mouthâ€”I am quite sure of thatâ€”I saw the blade of the penknife, and the handle in his handâ€”I will undertake to say decidedly that it was not a pipe with a metal end to itâ€”I say that it was a knifeâ€”there is
a reasonable lot of light in the courtâ€”I saw the knife when he first stabbed meâ€”I do not know anything about his being taken: I was told about it at the London Hospital.

MR. LLOYD. Q. How far behind them were you walking when you went from the place you first met them, to where this struggle took place? A. A few yardsâ€”when I got to the court the prisoner made an attack on me.

GEORGE CUNNINGHAM . I am a cooper, and live at 4, Fireball-court, Houndsditchâ€”on 22d March last, I was coming down Houndsditch and saw O'Brien and the prisoner quarrelling for about ten minutes, I should sayâ€”they got fighting and struggling together and fell on the opposite side of Houndsditch, opposite Fireball-court, just underneath a lampâ€”I saw the prisoner raise his right arm and strike him repeatedlyâ€”O'Brien then got up and stood about four yards from the prisoner, and said, "He has got a knife; he has stabbed me"â€”he was covered with bloodâ€”the prisoner then got up and walked over towards Fireball-court side, and went along up Hounds
ditch, and went awayâ€”O'Brien ran just before he got to Fireball-court, to get assistanceâ€”I saw the prisoner taken up past St. Mary-axe, about forty or fifty yards from thereâ€”I was following him and saw him takenâ€”I did not see a stick used of any kind.

Cross-examined. Q. You looked about for a knife when you heard this, did you not? A. Yes; none was foundâ€”I do not remember seeing any
thing of a pipeâ€”I did not hear O'Brien calling the prisoner namesâ€”there was a young woman with themâ€”there were no strong expressions usedâ€”the prisoner said, that if he came home to his house to would fight himâ€”O'Brien gave his hat and bundle to a young chap named Jeremiah Dennis, who was thereâ€”he gave it as the prisoner attacked himâ€”he wanted to defend himselfâ€”they did not fight for two or three minutes after thatâ€”O'Brien got him down, he was lying on the top of him, not kneelingâ€”when the prisoner said to O'Brien, "Come to my house and I will fight you," O'Brien did not push him in the cheek, not for three minutes after thatâ€”the prisoner made a strike at O'Brien, and they fought and fell in Fireball-courtâ€”I heard O'Brien say first, "What did you strike me for?"â€”and the prisoner then said, "Come to my house and I will fight you."

MART ANN CURTAIN . I live at 8, Fireball-court, Houndsditchâ€”on the night of Saturday, 22d March, I was coming on an errand in Fireball-courtâ€”I saw the prisoner and O'Brien struggling on the groundâ€”it lasted about a quarter of an hour or ten minutesâ€”I did not see any blow struckâ€”when O'Brien got up, the prisoner came over to a woman who was with him and handed her a knifeâ€”I do not know what sort of knife it wasâ€”O'Brien was bleeding very muchâ€”I am sure it was a knife, I only saw the blade of itâ€”I saw the prisoner taken up by two policemen at St. Mary-axe.

Cross-examined. Q. You are sure it was a knife because you saw the blade of it? A. Yes; I cannot tell you what sort of a knife it wasâ€”I saw something glitter; it was the blade of a knife; I did not see anything more than the glitter of some metalâ€”that was about ten minutes before the policeman cameâ€”the young lady and the other man went away, and the prisoner remained until the policeman cameâ€”he did not know the police
man was comingâ€”O'Brien went for a policemanâ€”the prisoner waited there ten minutes, till he got as for as St. Mary-axeâ€”I did not say anything to the policeman when he came up about the knife; not till the next morningâ€”a sergeant came the next morningâ€”I was there when the policeman came up.
MR. LLOYD. Q. Have you any doubt as to whether it was a pipe or a knife? A. It was like the blade of a knife.

GEORGE SIMMONS (City-policeman, 623). On 22d March, I took the prisoner into custodyâ€”I told him he was charged with stabbing a manâ€”he said, "I am all right, Sir; I live up St. Mary-axe"â€”I observed some blood on the right wristband of hia shirtâ€”I picked up this stick (produced) in Houndsditchâ€”it broke in the Minories.
Cross-examined. Q. You looked carefully for a knife and found none? A. Yes.

THOMAS NEWBY . I am house-surgeon at the London Hospitalâ€”on Sun
day, 23d March, the prosecutor was brought there, after 12 o'clock at night; he was bleeding very much from the headâ€”I found seven punctured wounds in the scalp; they went through the scalp; they were not quite a quarter of an inch deep; they were inflicted by a sharp pointed instrument; a penknife would do itâ€”he has been out of the hospital for some time; he its discharged, curedâ€”they were not serious wounds.

Cross-examined. Q. Would not you expect, if they were done with a pen
knife, they would have gone in deeper? A. It would depend on the severity of the blowâ€”I should expect to find small punctured wounds; the bone would prevent it going in deep; unless the penknife was very strong, it would break against the boneâ€”I have seen pipes with metal at the endâ€”I should scarcely think that a metal pipe which had been in use some time and had got worn at the end would inflict those wounds; it might do so; I would not swear that it could not; if it were worn it might.
COURT. Q. Have you ever seen such a pipe that would inflict such wounds as those? A. No.
(The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows:)

"I was in the Minories on Saturday evening; I had been to a concert room and was returning home with my friend and his lady. The prosecutor shoved the lady by the arm, and I said, 'You should not shove the lady.' I knocked him about with a stick; he went back and then approached again, and wanted to have some words with us. We told him it would be better for him to retire; I said, 'I do not intend to fight here, but come to my house and I will fight.' He then pushed me on the cheek with such violence that I fell. I had a German wooden pipe in my hand, and struck him with it; I cannot tell how, as I had drunk well. I cannot say what further occurred till I was taken into custody. I can state that I never had a knife in any pocket.

JOHN BECK .
