I was a waiter at Ricart's Restaurant, in Bucklersburyâ€”I am now out of employmentâ€”I have known the prisoner about eight or nine monthsâ€”he is a waiter at Mr. Kraus's Hotel, in Lime-street, and has been there about two yearsâ€”on Saturday, 22d March, I had been to a concert with Miss Viney and the prisoner; we were coming from there about 11 o'clockâ€”I was smokingâ€”we saw the prosecutor; he came and pushed Miss Emmaâ€”she called out, "Oh"â€”I asked what was the matterâ€”she said the man had pushed herâ€”I said it was very rude to push a ladyâ€”he was laugh
ing; I could not understand what he saidâ€”I took him by the left arm and said he must go, and he gave me a knock on my foreheadâ€”he was laughing, and coming against me three or four times, the prisoner gave him a knock with a stick on the head, and the stick was brokenâ€”that was the stick which has been producedâ€”while we were walking on to Houndsditch, he was sometimes behind us and sometimes before us, grumblingâ€”when we came to public-house he asked me for my card to fight me the next morn
ing

â€”I said I would not give him a card; I would not fight any moreâ€”then we came to some court; two boys were steading there, and the boys received the coats, and he was crying out, "Now I will fight you"â€”he have his bundle to the boys, and I gave my hat to Miss Emmaâ€”he then knocked the prisoner down, and they were afterwards on the pavement rolling over and over together to the other side of the pavementâ€”the prosecutor was kneeling on him, and the prisoner knocked him in the face; they knocked each otherâ€”I cannot say any moreâ€”the prisoner had a pipeâ€”I saw him smoking it in the concert room; it was a German pipe with a metal piece for the mouth; it came np to a pointâ€”I am quite sure he had that pipe, with him that evening in the concert roomâ€”in Aldgate-street he asked me for some fire, and I saw him light the pipeâ€”I saw no knife with him at allâ€”I cannot say whether, when they were down, he struck with anything at the prosecutorâ€”Miss Emma took me away; she did not receive a knife from the prisoner, I am quite sure.

Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. Have you brought the pipe here? A. Noâ€”when I first saw the prisoner he was coming the same way as we wereâ€”he was going past us when he pushed Miss Emmaâ€”he went on the right sideâ€”he did not push me at all; only herâ€”I did not feel the pushâ€”he pushed me afterwardsâ€”the prisoner it not in employment now as a waiterâ€”he was at that timeâ€”I did not see any policeman at all before we got to the courtâ€”I had no reason to call for a policeman while we were going along, and he coming after usâ€”the prisoner broke a stick on his head.

COURT. Q. Had you been drinking at all? A. I had two glasses of brandy with water and sugar, with Miss Emmaâ€”the prisoner had about five glasses whilst I was with himâ€”I do not know how many he had beforeâ€”he was in the conoert room before us, and we came away together.
MR. METCALFE. Q. How long were you there? A. From 9 o'clock till 12.

EMMA VINEY . I live at No. 9 St. Mary-axe, and am employed at Taylor Brothers, Brick-lane, chocolate manufacturersâ€”I have been there two years and nine monthsâ€”I had been out with these two young men on 22d March to a concertâ€”upon our return I saw the prosecutor coming up the Minoriesâ€”he walked aside of me and pushed me, and I exclaimed, "Oh"â€”Mr. Beek asked what was the matter, and I said, "The gentleman pushed meâ€”he said it was very wrong to push a lady in that mannerâ€”the prosecutor laughed, and Mr. Beck asked him to get awayâ€”he would not, and he took him by the arm and pushed him, and the prisoner hit him on the head with a stickâ€”O'Brien was walking along jeering us at that timeâ€”he was walking alongside of meâ€”we got some distance up the Minories and we were again joined by him, and he followed us down Houndsditchâ€”he there gave some boys his bundle and made a blow at the prisonerâ€”while we were walking along he was talk
ing and laughing, and jeering at usâ€”he struck the prisoner and he returned the blowâ€”they were some minutes struggling on the groundâ€”the prosecutor was on the top, and the prisoner lying upon his backâ€”I then took Mr. Beck awayâ€”I did not see a pipe at any timeâ€”I do not remember seeing one during the eveningâ€”the prisoner did not give me a knifeâ€”I am quite sure of thatâ€”I did not see a knife in his possession at allâ€”he did not give me any
thing at the time they were struggling in the court, or at all that eveing.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you holding Beck's arm all the time this struggle was going on? A. Yesâ€”there were not many people there; I think about a dozenâ€”I did not notice any women aboutâ€”I was standing close by the struggle for a moment, and then I moved off, and went with Mr. Beck as far as St. Mary-axe, bade him good night, and went homeâ€”I am a friend of
Mr. Beck'sâ€”the struggle was not over when I went awayâ€”I did not see the letter part of itâ€”the prisoner did not give me a knife.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Was there any other young woman there at all? A. No.
COURT to MARY ANN CURTAIN. Q. Should you know the person again to whom the prisoner gave the knife? A. No, it was a young woman; I do not know who.

FREDERICK BAYR . I am waiter at the Ship and Star Hotel, where this concert was, on Saturday, 22d Marchâ€”I remember the prisoner being there, and the young ladyâ€”the prisoner had a short pipe with himâ€”I cannot say what sort of mouthpieceâ€”it was a short German pipe.

CHARLES KRAUS . I am the landlord of the Cape of Good Hope public-house, Lime-streetâ€”the prisoner was in my employment as a waiter for two years, up to the last day he was taken in custodyâ€”he has always been very quiet during that timeâ€”he never keeps a knife in his pocketâ€”I have asked bun for a knife, and he had not had oneâ€”nobody smokes in the houses-all the Germans keep pipes, but he never had one in the house to my knowledgeâ€”Mrs. Kraus brought some pipes over with her from Germany for her cook and her other servantsâ€”I always found the prisoner a very quiet, orderly, respect
able man.

p.hi: The prisoner receivd a good character from three other witnesses.

div1.p:
463.
JOHN FREDERICK OLIVER (25),
Unlawfully obtaining 24, crinoline skirts, and 48 crinoline skirts, the property of
Charles Davies, under false pretences.

CHARLES DAYIES . I am a manufacturer of hair nets and crinoline, at 15, Finsbury-pavement, under the firm of Coldrey and Daviesâ€”I knew the prisoner four or five years in the employment of Messrs. Nathan and Sonsâ€”be came to me on 22d March, about 12 o'clock, I think, and said he wanted two dozen crinoline skirts for John Nathan and Sons, for a foreign orderâ€”I give them to himâ€”I should not have given them to him except from the observation that they were for Nathan and Sonsâ€”the value of them was 5l.â€”I saw the prisoner write this receipt (Read: "March 22d, 1862. Received from Messrs. Coldrey and Davies, 43 crinoline skirts, at 43s., J. OLIVER")â€”the prisoner came again on 26th March, and said he wanted four dozen skirts for John Nathan and Sonsâ€”the value of them was the same as the othersâ€”he gave me this receipt "Received of Messrs. Coldrey and Co., for Nathan and Son, four dozen skirts"â€”I should not have parted with the foods bat for the supposition that they were for John Nathan and Coâ€”I subsequently called on them to payâ€”that is how I found it out.
Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Not for all of them? A. Noâ€”the prisoner brought back two dozenâ€”those he had on the 26th he brought back on the 31st.

JOHN NATHAN . I am a wholesale clothier, carrying on business in Houndsditch, in partnership with my sonâ€”I never authorized the prisoner to obtain these goods from Messrs. Coldrey and Daviesâ€”he was formerly in our employmentâ€”he was not in our employment on 22d or 24th Marchâ€”he left between a fortnight and three weeks before.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you sent any goods to Mr. Davies? A. These goods originally, I believe, came from usâ€”they were sold to them I believeâ€”we had sent them to Davice bona fide to the prisoner's orderâ€”we sent them an invoiceâ€”these goods were ordered by the prisoner, we presuming that he had sold them to Messrs. Coldrey and Daviceâ€”he was employed as

our travellerâ€”they were not sent on approvalâ€”Mr. Davies ought to have the invoice of itâ€”this is it (produced)â€”these are the identical skirts, as far as I can judgeâ€”I have never seen themâ€”I heard Mr. Davies say that those were not sold, but left on approvalâ€”I heard him say so on a former occasionâ€”they were taken to the place by our porter with this invoice and left thereâ€”that was on 21st Februaryâ€”we have got part of the money nowâ€”we asked for itâ€”we sent our collecting clerk to collect the moneys, which is usual at the expiration of the time, giving them notice first that he would callâ€”when he called, Mr. Davies said that he should have to come down for the things, because there was some misunderstandingâ€”he came down to us and represented that the prisoner had obtained from him some portion of the goodsâ€”he said they were left on approval; we repudiated thatâ€”I had never heard of it before.

MR. KEMP. Q. Did the prisoner bring them back to you? A. Noâ€”he did not receive the commisson on the saleâ€”we should not give a com
mission until we received the money.
JOHN NATHAN , Junior. I never authorised the prisoner to receive the goods from Messrs. Coldrey and Daviesâ€”we have never received them back
Cross-examined. Q. Was there some Agreement in writing? A. There was a memorandum writtenâ€”the prisoner had the memorandum; we had noneâ€”I have never seen one in my father's possession.

CHARLES BAKER . I am a detective city officerâ€”about half-past 11, on 2d April, I saw the prisoner in Chespside, told him I was a detective police-officer, and asked him whether his name was Oliverâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said that he must consider himself in custody for receiving a quantity of crinoline skirts from Davies and Co. of Finsbury-pavementâ€”he said he had had the skirts from there, and sold them to Mr. Underwood, 13, Commercial-road, Peckhamâ€”I told him he must come to the stationâ€”he gave me an address 32, Monkwell-street; he had been living thereâ€”I went to No. 13, Com
mercial-roadâ€”I could not find any such person as Mr. Underwoodâ€”I then made inquiries close by Finsbury, and found the skirts had been pawned.

JAMES HAYNES . I am assistant to Mr. Russell, pawnbroker, of Fore-streetâ€”I produce two dosen crinoline skirts, which I took in on 22d March, I cannot say of whom; the address is 38, Monk well-streetâ€”on 23d March, I took four dosen crinoline skirts, in the name of John Brown, of 34, Monkwell-streetâ€”I do not know who pawned themâ€”on 26th March, I took two dozen from the prisoner in the name of John Brown, for 1l. 4s.

CHARLES DAVIS
re-examined. These are all my property.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Were these skirts that you gave up to the prisoner your goods? A. They were in my possessionâ€”the prisoner represented that they were given to me on consignmentâ€”they were left by him on approval, and I afterwards refused to take them because the price was too highâ€”I said I would go down and see Mr. Nathanâ€”I believed the prisoner was taking them back to Mr. Nathan when I let them goâ€”he said he wanted them for a foreign order, to sell to some one elseâ€”they were brought to me on 21st February, the date of the invoiceâ€”it was two days after
wards, I think, that I told him I could not take them at the priceâ€”he said he would endeavour to make an arrangement to take lessâ€”he said that I might send back what I did not wantâ€”I do not know that he said he would try to sell them elsewhere.
MR. KEMP. Q. When you told the prisoner you could not take at at the price, did you subsequently see Mr. Nathan? A. Afterwards; not before the goods were fetched.

p.hi: submitted that the evidence did not make out the case at all, as the goods belonged to Messrs. Nathan, and were obtained by false pretences from them. The
considered that they were obtained by false pretences from Messrs. Davies as well at from Messrs. Nathan.

div1.p: GUILTY .â€”The officer Baker stated that he had ascertained that the prisoner bore a very good character indeed.

464.
JOHN LANE (24), and
JOHN FINNITY (21),
Robbery, with violence, upon
William Morris, and stealing from his person 1 knife, 1 key, and 7s. 6d. in money, his property.

WILLIAM MORRIS . I live at 26, Upper Park-place, Maryleboneâ€”on Friday morning, the 14th of last month, I went into the Leaping Bar public-house in Old Street-roadâ€”I there saw the two prisoners with another manâ€”I had a glass of porterâ€”the men asked me to give them some tobacco; I offered them some out of this pocket, and they said they wanted some out of this; there was a screw in one and half an ounce in the other, and they wanted it from the one with the half-ounceâ€”I then went out; they followed me out, touched me on the shoulder and asked me if I was going to give them some tobaccoâ€”Fiunity that put his arm round my waistâ€”I threw my arms up, and then Lane caught hold of me; they threw open my waistcoats and coatâ€”I had two waiftooats on at the timeâ€”they opened ny pockets and took out a half a crown, a two-shilling piece, two shillings, and three six-pences, a knife, and a key; one sixpence was left in my pocketâ€”they then let me fall backwards, and my hat fell off, and I caught my head against the kerbstone, and I fell on this arm, which was very bad for two or three weeksâ€”they then ran awayâ€”I endeavoured to catch them, but could not see themâ€”I went back to the public-house and stated that I had been robbed, and then I went to the station-house and gave informationâ€”I there described the three men to a constableâ€”I was taken to the police-station soon afterwards, on the same morning, and there saw Laneâ€”on the Sunday night I saw Finnityâ€”I was quite sober on the night I was robbed.

Lane. Q. What time do you say I was in Mr. Short's public-house? A. Perhaps a quarter past 1â€”I was not drunkâ€”there were several people in the public-houseâ€”you drank up part of my pint of beer, and I would not lake any moreâ€”there were some females there; I knew nothing about themâ€”you followed me out directlyâ€”you put your hand in my pocketâ€”Finnity put one arm round my neck.
Firnity. Q. Did I speak to you when we were in the public-house? A. Yes; you asked me for some tobaoooâ€”I offered you a small piece, and you would not take it.

COURT. Q. Your say you saw Lane on the Friday evening at the station-house; was he alone or with others? A. Several others; I picked him outâ€”he was not pointed out to me in any way; there were also three or four perons with Finnity.

JAMES SHORT . I keep the Leaping Bar public-house in Old-street, St. Luke'sâ€”I remember the prosecutor being in my house about I in the morning of 14th Marchâ€”the prisoners were also there; they were there nigh upon Iâ€”the prosecutor came back after he left.
COURT. Q. How long before he came back and complained to you was it that he prisoners had been there? A. More than half an hour; perhaps longer than thatâ€”I was talking to two friends at the bar.
Lane. Q. Was I in at the time the proscutor was? A. I cannot

swear whether you were or notâ€”I was asking them all to go out, and all went out about the same timeâ€”my wife was at the bar at the time servingâ€”I saw the prosecutor when he came back; he seemed very much excitedâ€”I do not know whether he was intoxicated or notâ€”he said he had been robbed.
MR. HORRY. Q. Had you known these prisoners before? A. No; I have see Finnity somewhere about, once or twice.

JAMES PLAYFORD (Policeman, A 438). On the night of 14th March, or Friday morning, rather, I was on duty at the Old-street stationâ€”the prose
cutor came there about twenty-five minutes past 1, and made a complaint to the inspector that he had been robbedâ€”he described the persons to the inspector in my presenceâ€”at that time he was perfectly sober.

WILLIAM MILLER (Policeman, G 148). About 1 o'clock on Saturday morning, from information I received, I took Lane into custodyâ€”I said to him. "I apprehend you for committing a highway robbery in Old-start, outside the Leaping Bar"â€”he said, "Let me go"â€”I said, "I shall not"â€”he said, "So help me God, it was not me."

COURT. Q. You were not present when the prosecutor made his com
plaint? A. No; I was sent from the stationâ€”I was present when the prosecutor was brought, after I had taken Laneâ€”there were three persons presentâ€”he was picked out as the one out of four.

Lane. Q. Where did you take me? A. At the Grapesâ€”the prosecutor was not there at that timeâ€”I did not point you out to the prosecutor at the station-houseâ€”he was fetched by Boobyer after you were at the station.

JOHN BOOBYER . I took Finnity into custody on Sunday night, 16thâ€”I told him I took him on suspicion of being concerned, with another, in custody, for violently assaulting a man in Old-street, and robbing himâ€”he said, "Well, it was not much of a robbery; besides, I was not in Old-street at all that night."
Finnity. Q. Where did you take me? A. At Vine-streetâ€”I believe you have a sister living thereâ€”the other policeman did not take you first.
COURT. Q. Did you fetch the prosecutor after Lane was in custody? A. I didâ€”I was present when the prosecutor identified Finnityâ€”there were two with-him besides himself.

Lane's Defence. All I have to say is that I was not in the house at the time. I was at the station-house by myself when the prosecutor came to identify me. He was there before, waiting for me. I have been bad, but I am innocent of the charge brought against me now.
Finnity's Defence. I work hard for my living; yon can ask any of those policemen.

p.hi: Policeman G 211 stated that he had known Finnity eight or nine years ago associating with pickpockets, but that he had been at work latterly.

div1.p:
FINNITY.**â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

p.hi: Lane was further charged with having been before convicted of felony on 1st August, 1859, when he was sentenced to Three Year's Penal Servitude; to which he

div1.p:
PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

465.
WILLIAM JAMES JARMAN (14),
Stealing a lamb, the property of
John White.

HENRY SKASE . I am a labourer, and work for Mr. John White, of Enfield
chaseâ€”on the evening of Monday, 17th March, I saw my sheep and lambsâ€”the lamb I now produce was then safeâ€”I missed it on Tuesday morning,

about quarter past 6â€”in consequence of something that was said I want to Mr. Robinson, about 9 o'clock, and there found the lambâ€”I knew it at onceâ€”I am sure it is the sameâ€”I took it home to the eweâ€”she knew it directly.

EDWARD ROBINSON . I am a gardener, at Chase-side, Enfield, not far from Mr. White'sâ€”on Sunday, 16th Match, I saw the prisonerâ€”I had occasion to call at Mr. White's about a lambâ€”I was promised oneâ€”the lad came to me and said, "Mr. Robinson, do you want a lamb? if you do, you may have one for a shilling"â€”I said, "If you will bring it down I will have it"â€”he brought it down on the Tuesday, and I gave him a shilling for Mr. White and a penny for himselfâ€”he then said Mr. White had another that I could have for a shillingâ€”after breakfast I went up to Mr. White to inquire about the other lambâ€”I afterwards saw Skase, and he went back with me to fetch the first lambâ€”Mr. White gave me a shilling back.

SIDNEY SNOWELL (Polieman, N 513). I apprehended the prisoner on 29th March, and told him that he was charged with stealing a lambâ€”he said that he did steal it, and that Mr. Robinson told him if he got him a lamb he would give him a shilling for it; he said he took the lamb to Mr. Robinsonâ€”he gave him a shilling for Mr. White and a penny for himself.
HENRY SKASE (re-examined). The boy had been in my master's serviceâ€”he was discharged on Saturday night, the 15th.

p.hi:
â€”
Three Years in a Reformatory.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. JUSTICE MELLOR; Mr. Ald. ALLEN; Mr. Ald. JAMES
LAWRENCE; Mr. Ald. GIBBONS; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
466.
EDWARD DONELLY (19), was indicted
for a rape upon
Mary Ann Davis.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

467.
JOHN RODWAY (40),
Feloniously wounding
William Hilton, with intent to murder.Second Count, with intent to do grievous bodily harm.

GEORGE BIGGS . I am ostler at the Milford Arms, Spring-grove, Hestonâ€”on 24th March, the prisoner and prosecutor were there, in the room where the bagatelle table isâ€”it was between 1 and 2 in the dayâ€”I and Hilton, Martin, Wilson, the prisoner, and two or three others, were all playing bagatelle, until a dispute arose about the payment of some beer, which was settled without any violenceâ€”the dispute was amongst all that were in the roomâ€”we went on playing and jokingâ€”the prisoner and Hilton played a game single-handedâ€”Hilton won, and the prisoner refused to payâ€”they played for a pint of beerâ€”the prisoner called Hilton bad namesâ€”that passed off with joking, no blowsâ€”Hilton was joking the prisoner, and he took offence at it and threatened to pull his moustache offâ€”after some time the prisoner vent awayâ€”he returned in about 10 minutesâ€”Martin and Hilton played a gameâ€”the prisoner bet threepence that Martin would winâ€”Hilton won, and then the prisoner refused to pay; they called each other bad names until the prisoner struck Hilton in the face with his fistâ€”Hilton instantly returned itâ€”they had a scramble in the parlour and both fell, Hilton at the bottom, and the prisoner kept hitting him when he was downâ€”I took bold

of Hilton and Wilson took hold of the prisoner, and we ported them; there was blood drawn on both sides in the parlourâ€”the prisoner went out of the bar and asked for his capâ€”Hilton said he had not got his cap, but if he would come outside he would give him a good hiding, or he should himâ€”they went outside and Hilton began fighting first, before the prisoner was hardly outside; they had hold of each other; it lasted about two minutesâ€”the prisoner walked away; he muttered somethingâ€”I do not know what he saidâ€”I did not see him again until he was taken into custodyâ€”I did not see him doing anything to Hilton mote than striking himâ€”immediately after the prisoner had gone away I saw blood running down Hilton's jacket, behind, from his headâ€”Wilson and Martin went with him to the surgeon's.

Cross-examined by MR. SHARPE. Q. What hour was it that the prisoner was first there? A. I should say between 1 and 2â€”Hilton was there when the prisoner was first thereâ€”the prisoner continued there from between 1 and 2 until past 6, except when he went awayâ€”during all that time he was playing bagatelle or looking onâ€”we were all having sunday pots of beer during this time; not a great many, five, six, or sevenâ€”I did not see that then was anything the matter with tke prisonerâ€”I don't think I was any the worse for liquor; I might have been slightly affected, the same as the rest; the others might have been more affected than me, I being used to the house and the beer tooâ€”there were four disputes altogether; the prisoner disputed that he owed the money, he wanted to say that he was cheated out of itâ€”when I saw them fighting, it was with his fist that I sow the prisoner striking Hiltonâ€”I did not see anything usedâ€”they had their fingers clenched as if they were boxingâ€”I did not see the prisoner with any knife in his possessionâ€”they did not tumble down outside the house; they did in the parlourâ€”there were about a dozen or eighteen people looking onâ€”I don't suppose there were twentyâ€”there might have been from twelve to twenty; I can't say exactly, some did not stop; they merely were passing at the timeâ€”during the fight they had hold of each otherâ€”no one got nigh them while they were fighting; there was no ringâ€”we were standing along by the doorâ€”we did not interfereâ€”there were a few new gravel stones in front of the houseâ€”there was two or three minutes between the first fight inside and the second fight outside; it was during that two or three minutes that the prisoner went to the bar to ask for his capâ€”Hilton did not take hold of the prisoner thenâ€”I swear thatâ€”he began fighting firstâ€”I did not see him lay hold of the prisoner and drag him out
side the houseâ€”I can't say he did not do itâ€”I was away now and thenâ€”I was there from the time the cap was asked for until the last fight ceasedâ€”the prisoner was not dragged out of the house by Hilton during that timeâ€”Hilton struck the prisoner at the door as he was going outâ€”Hilton struck the first blow.

WILLIAM HILTON . I am painterâ€”on 24th March I was at the Milford Arms about a quarter-past 1 o'clockâ€”there were several disputes about the payment of the beer and betsâ€”I had rather a serious dispute with the prisoner about ten minutes to 6, before he went out; he wished me to stop till he came backâ€”I did so, and then we commenced another gameâ€”he brought in a bunch of violets in his handâ€”he passed them round the room and observed how nice they smeltâ€”I asked him if he would give me a few and he gave me them allâ€”we commenced another game of bagatelle, and another dispute arose, and as I was standing against the bagatelle board the prisoner up with his right fist and struck me in tht faceâ€”he danced round me as if he was geing to hit me again, and I was obliged to hit him againâ€”we

had a scuffleâ€”he got me down on the floor, and struck me several timesâ€”the waiter picked him off me, and I went and spoke to the landlordâ€”while I was talking to him the prisoner came and accused me of taking his capâ€”I told him several times that I had not got itâ€”then as soon as we got outside he took hold of me and clung round me, and it seemed to me as if he was scratching me down the backâ€”I did not feel him stab me at allâ€”I had on a white jacket, two waistcoats, and my shirtâ€”he then let go of me and walked away, muttering something which I could not hearâ€”Martin came up to me and said "You are stabbed"â€”he took me into the parlour and I found that my head was laid open, and the blood was streaming down meâ€”my head was not in that condition when I was talking to the landlordâ€”Martin took me to a chemist's shop, and then to Mr. Chapman, the surgeon, who attended to meâ€”the constable has the clothes which I had on.

Cross-examined. Q. You were nearly fire hours at this place, were you not? A. Yes; from about half-past 1 to half-past 6â€”I was not under the influence of liquor towards the end of the eveningâ€”I was perfectly sober at half-past 6â€”I did not take notice how many pots of beer we hadâ€”that is not because there were so manyâ€”there might have been five or six,; not fifteenâ€”I do not think there were tenâ€”I do not think there were, more than five or sixâ€”when the prisoner walked round me, the landlord said, "We will not have any more quarrelling here"â€”I thought then that he was going to strike me againâ€”he came close up to me, but he did not strike at me thenâ€”I do not know that I said, "Come outside, and I will give you a good hiding or else you shall give me one"â€”I do not before I didâ€”I might have said itâ€”I don't remember exactly what I did sayâ€”when he accused me of taking his cap, I told him I had not got itâ€”I did not, either in the passage or the bar, or any where in the house, catch hold of the priaoner by the coat or collar and pull him or try to pull him outsideâ€”I swear I did not do any such thingâ€”I do not remember striking him when we were both going out of the house in the first instanceâ€”I might have done soâ€”I do not know exactly whether I struck him or he struck meâ€”I do not know how many persons there were round at the time of the rowâ€”I should think there were about twentyâ€”I never saw the prisoner before that dayâ€”I did not see a knife in his possession from half-past 1 till the time he left.

JOHN MARTIN . I am a carpenterâ€”I was at the Milford Arms, on 24th Marchâ€”a quarrel took place between the prisoner and Hilton just before the prisoner went outâ€”they had some wordâ€”the prisoner went out and came back, and there was a struggle between him and the prosecutorâ€”the prisoner struck Hilton on the mouthâ€”there were some blows struck, and they fell on the chair, and Wilson parted them, and the prisoner went outsideâ€”he came back; the prosecutor was then standing at the barâ€”I heard the prisoner ask for his capâ€”Hilton then went outside and the prisoner after him, and there were a few blows struck on both sidesâ€”it was not more than about two minutesâ€”I saw some blood running from Hilton's neck, and he came insideâ€”the prisoner muttered some words and went homeâ€”I told Hilton I thought he had been hit or cut with a stoneâ€”I do not know which word I usedâ€”I went with him to the chemist'sâ€”the blood was running down his head.
COURT. Q. Did you see him fall near any stones? A. They did not fall at allâ€”I thought the prisoner had struck him with a stone.

Cross-examinted. Q. During the whole of the time they were outside fighting, had you your eyes on them? A. Well, I was standing at the door all the timeâ€”I am quite certain they did not fall at allâ€”I was one of the parties who had been drinking the beerâ€”I had been then all the afternoon
â€”I don't know why I said, "You have been hit, or cut with a stone;" but it struck me at the moment that be had been hit with a stone.

GEORGE WILSON . I am a gardenerâ€”on 24th March I was at the Milford Arms, and saw a fight in the bagatelle-room between the prisoner and Hiltonâ€”I did not hear the previous disputesâ€”the prisoner struck the prosecutor flrst, and they both fell to the groundâ€”I took the prisoner off the prosecutor, and the prosecutor went outsideâ€”he came back to the bar againâ€”the pri
soner went out of the parlour to the bar, and asked him for his capâ€”the prosecutor said he had not got it, and also said, "If you come outside, I will give you a good hiding, or else you shall me"â€”the prosecutor struck at him as he was coming out, and then the prisoner got hold of himâ€”I think the prosecutor struck first outsideâ€”they got hold of one another, but I cannot say they were hitting one anotherâ€”at the end, the prisoner went awayâ€”I noticed blood flowing from the prosecutor's headâ€”I did not hear any remark made by Martin at the timeâ€”I assisted in taking the prosecutor to the surgeon's.

Cross-examined. Q. When they went out for the second fight, did not Hilton lay hold of the prisoner, and drag him out of the house? A. No; nor pull him outâ€”he did not catch hold of himâ€”he struck at him, and drew back into the road, and another man ran into him.

MR. SHARPE to GEORGE BIGGS. Q. On the second occasion when they went out to fight, did not Hilton pull the prisoner out, and did not they then strike one another? A. No; he did not pull him outâ€”I swear thatâ€”I did not state befere the Magistrate that he pulled him out.

JOESPH CHAPMAN . I am a surgeon, residing at Hounslowâ€”Hilton was brought to my surgery on 24th March, in a very feeble state, bleeding front a clean cut wound, about an inch long, at the back of the headâ€”I could not say exactly whether that had been inflicted with a knife, or whatâ€”it might have been cut by the edge of anything elseâ€”there were two punctured wounds on the buttock, one of them an inch long, and an inch deepâ€”they must have been inflicted by some instrument forced into him; some pooket-knife I should thinkâ€”a stone could not do itâ€”there were also two punctured wouuds on the back of the neck, and a wound and one or two scratches on the armâ€”the wounds on the neck were the same kind as those on the buttock, and inflicted by the same sort of instrumentâ€”I think the scratches might have been inflicted with the same sort of instrument, only with the edge turnedâ€”there were six wounds in all, and two scratchesâ€”the wounds were not in the posi
tion of any important artery, and therefore were not seriousâ€”if inflicted in the front of the person, in the neighbourhood of any important artery, they would have been serious.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose if it had gone in an inch in the artery in front of the neck, it would have been serious? A. Yesâ€”a flint stone with a very sharp edge would not inflict those wounds on the buttockâ€”I know a sharp stone will inflict a woundâ€”it would not make a clean out through corduroy trousersâ€”I have heard of a man's leg being out by a fall on a stone without its cutting his trousers at allâ€”a sharp stone could not inflict such a clean cut wound as these, through the dressâ€”I never saw a nail so sharp as to inflict such woundsâ€”a nail with a very sharp point would not inflict such a woundâ€”one of those on the buttook was an inch longâ€”those in the neck were not above half an inch, and a quarter of an inch deep, I supposeâ€”they had penetrated through the skinâ€”falling on a sharp instrument would not produce all of those woundsâ€”it might oneâ€”a spike might produce one.
COURT. Q. It would not produce six wounds? A. No.

CHARLES BLAKE (Police-sergeant, T 34). I took the prisoner into custody at his lodgings, on the 24th, between 8 and 9 o'clock in the eveningâ€”he was in bed, and appeared to be asleep when I wentâ€”I tried the door; it was locked; and I got in at the window and searched the houseâ€”I shook him up, and told him I wanted himâ€”he said, "What for?" I said, "I want you for stabbing Hilon;" he said, "I know nothing about it;" and I then observed blood between the fingers of the right handâ€”these clothes (produced) were on Hilton when I saw him at the surgeryâ€”I have had them since.
Cross-examined. Q. I think you searched the house for a knife? A. I did; but did not find oneâ€”this was about three-quarters of an hour after the matter occurred.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. RECORDER; Mr. Ald CONDER; and Mr. Ald. JAMES

div1.p:
468.
WILLIAM FARROW (25),
WILLIAM GRANT (22),
JAMES PARSONS (25),
JOHN FELLOWS (30), and
SUSAN GABLE (28),
Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Samuels, and stealing therein 10 watches, 48 breast-pins, and 72 brooches, value 30l. his property.

JAMES CHILD (Policeman, 93 E). On the morning of 15th February, about half-past 1 o'clock, I was on duty in Gray's-inn-road, near Mr. Samuels' shop, 8, Pindar's-place, a watchmaker and jewellerâ€”I saw Farrow, and two others not in custody, standing within six or seven yards of the doorâ€”on seeing me, Farrow pretended to be drunk, and asked me if I would have something to drinkâ€”I told him I did not require anything; and they walked about fifty yards, and returned to the same placeâ€”I waited about for some time for farther assistance, and at last I took Farrow and one of the others in custodyâ€”(while I was waiting there I discovered that a door had been broken open next to Mr. Samuels'â€”it is a little shop where they mend china)â€”they were discharged at the police-court next day for want of evidenceâ€”after I got to the station, I went back and found that Mr. Samuels' had been broken open at the backâ€”I got to it from the mews, by passing over several walls with a ladder, which I found placed against a wallâ€”I went to Mr. Samuels' shop, and found it very much derangedâ€”it was then about a quarter to 2.

Farrow. Q. Did not you ask the owner of the china shop if he would give me in charge? A. Yes; and he refused, because nothing had been takenâ€”I charged you at the station with the robbery at Mr. Samuels'.
MR. MATTHEWS. Q. Was there any evidence besides your own, before the Magistrate? A. No.

EDWARD STEWART (Policeman, 309 G). I was on duty in Gray's-inn-road, at a quarter past 1 in the morning of the 15th, and saw Farrow, Grant, and Fellows, at the corner of Harrison-street, thirty or forty yards from Mr. Samuels' shopâ€”a man, not in custody, was with themâ€”I was about a hundred yards from Childâ€”I did not say anything to himâ€”I went round my beatâ€”I met them again five or ten minutes afterwards, together, in Grays' Inn-road, and again after thatâ€”the last time I saw them was twenty-five minutes past 1â€”I was not there whan Child took them.
Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. How many times did you see them? A. About three timesâ€”I was at the corner of Frederick-streetâ€”it is about a hundred yards from Harrison-street.

GEORGE RANGER (Policeman, G 199). On Saturday, 15th February, about half-past 1, I was sent by my sergeant to Gray's-inn-road, and found the door of the china shop, next door to Mr. Samuels', openâ€”I looked round the shop, and seeing that there was nothing for anybody to take, I hastened to Mr. Samuels' door, and heard something more in the shop, as though jewellery was being movedâ€”another constable, E 54, came upâ€”I told him what I had heard, and we both listenedâ€”I sung out, "Who is there; is that you Mr. Samuels?"â€”the answer was, "Yes; all right"â€”I went to Mr. Samuels' private residence, No. 1, Lisson-street, and rang and knocked, but could not make any one bearâ€”I went back to the shop and listened, but could not bear any oneâ€”I turned, and saw Parsons and Grant come out of the mews, about five yards from where I stoodâ€”that was about a quarter to 2 o'clockâ€”I was on a strange division at that time, and did not know there was a mewsâ€”I got Mr. Samuels up, and found the shop rather disturbedâ€”there is an area, and I went down to the kitchen, and found marks on the water buttâ€”from there I went on to the wall, where there was a ladder, which enabled parties to get over into the mews, where the railings were all broken awayâ€”that was the same mews that I saw Parsons and Grant come fromâ€”I saw them two yards from where the ladder was.
Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. Did you see anybody else come out of the mews? A. Not at that timeâ€”I saw a couple of men making waterâ€”I did not take them in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Was any one with you? A. There was a cabman thereâ€”he is not hereâ€”he lives under Mr. Samuels'â€”he stood at the other side of me at the doorâ€”I did not know Grant and Parsons by sightâ€”they walked very gently away.

WILLIAM WOOLDRIDGE (Policeman, E 63). On the night of 15th February, about a quarter past 1 o'clock, I was on duty near the prosecutor's shop, and saw Farrow at the corner of the mews, about five yards from Mr. Samuels'â€”I had seen him three times previously, at the corner of Lission-street, and in Sidmouth-street, and in Swinton-streetâ€”the furthest of these places was Sidmouth-street, which is a hundred yards from the shopâ€”there were two men with himâ€”I do not know them by sight, and they are not in custodyâ€”just after I saw Farrow first, I saw that the door of the china shop had been broken open.
JOHN BUCKLEE (Policeman, N 406). I know No. 2, George-square, Hoxtonâ€”the four male prisoners live thereâ€”I have frequently seen them go to and from there during February.
Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. Does anybody else live in the house? A. Two females.

Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. Do you belong to the George-square beat? A. Yesâ€”I have seen them go in there twenty timesâ€”it is a private houseâ€”I have not seen other people go in there, except the two femalesâ€”Gable is not one of them.

THOMAS POOLEY . I am a labourer, of 11, Bath-place, Old-street-roadâ€”I have the key of 7, Bath-place, and take the references and the deposits when it is letâ€”I let it to Gable and her husbandâ€”he is not hereâ€”I have seen Fellows go in there two or three times, and have seen Farrow go in with him twiceâ€”another female lived there.
Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. Was Fellows a friend of the family? A. Yes; I suppose so.
Cross-examined by MR. BURNAND. You say Gable did live there with her husband? A. Yes.

JOHN SAMUELS . I am a jeweller and watchmaker, of 5, Pindar's-placeâ€”on 14th February I closed my shop at 9 o'clock at night, and went round at 11 and saw it safeâ€”I was called up by the police at a quarter to 2, and found the house had been broken open by the back kitchen doorâ€”I missed a quantity of pint, rings, pencil-cases, and watches, to the amount of 30l.â€”this brooch, pin, and ring (produced) are mine.

WILLIAM JOSEPH CASELEY . I am assistant to William Russell, a pawn
broker, of Kingsland-roadâ€”I produce a gold ring, pledged on 15th February for 2s. in the name of Ann Gable, by the female prisoner; also a gold pin, pledged on 17th February, iu the name of Ann Smith; I do not know who byâ€”these duplicates (produced) are what I gave.

THOMAS EVANS (Policeman, G 22). I went to 7, Bath-place, Old-street-road, and found the duplicate which the pawnbroker has spoken toâ€”it is in the name of Ann Gableâ€”I found the other other duplicate at George's-squareâ€”I found this centre-bit tool at Bath-placeâ€”while I was searching the place the female prisoner cane in, and said, "They are mine," refferring to the two duplicatesâ€”I then went to George-square, Hoxton, and found the centre-bit which fits the tool, this chisel, about twenty common keys, several duplicates, and among them the one for the pin identified by Mr. Samuels, and a brooch, which he also identifiesâ€”on a ledge in the water closet I found these three double-headed skeleton keysâ€”they have a key at each end, making six altogether, also this coil of rope (produced).

AMBROSE SUITON (Policeman, A 422). I took Gable it custody on 18th March, and told her the chargeâ€”she said, "Oh! I know what it is; it is about the two rings which I bought about a twelvemonth age in Petticoat-lane."

THOMAS MAVETE (Policeman, N 43). On 25th February I went with Sergeant Evans to George-square, Hoxton, and found in the water-closet, in an old rag, these double-headed skeleton keys, also three pick locks, all rolled up together, and this jemmy (produced) lying on the ledge.

WILLIAM GARDNER (Policeman, G 179). I took the four male prisoners on 19th February, about twenty minutes before 6 o'clock in Cumberland-street, Shoreditchâ€”they were all standing together talkingâ€”I spoke to themâ€”they made two or three statementsâ€”I told them that I was not satisfied, and took them to the station for loitering, with the assistance of my brother constables.
Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. Did you speak to them before the other policeman came up? A. Yes; but I did not tell them till I got assistance, that I should take them in custody.

rs.hi: considered that there was no evidence to go the Jury against the male prisoners

p.hi: stated that as Gable was a married woman he did not wish to press the case against her.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

469.
WILLIAM FARROW,
WILLIAM GRANT,
JAMES PARSONS , and
JOHN FELLOWS , were again indicted, with
THOMAS HENDER
SON ,
for unlawfully having in their possession, without lawful excuse, certain implements of housebreaking. Second Count, unlawful attempting to force open a door, with intent to steal.

WILLIAM GARDNER (Policeman, G 179). On 19th February, at 5 o'clock in the morning, I was on duty in Holywell-lane, and saw all the prisoners standing together talkingâ€”I was on the opposite side of the way, and stopped and looked at themâ€”they shook hands with one another, and wished each other good morningâ€”three went into Shoreditch, and two into the Curtain-roadâ€”they were five or six yards from Mr. Syer's shopâ€”I saw them all five again, talking, at about twenty minutes to 6, in Cumber
land-street, Shoreditch, which is about a hundred yards from where I first saw themâ€”I procured help, and took them all in custodyâ€”going to the station Fellows threw away this jemmy, and Henderson this other jemmy (produced), and at the station I found this life-preserver, weighted with lead and studded with spikes on Fellows, and on Parsons some lucifer matches and this knife, also some matches on Henderson, and on Farrow some matches, a pencil-case, and a knife, (produced.)
Farrow. Q. What did you charge me with? A. Loitering.

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. How long had you been watching them? A. Some timeâ€”they were five or six yards from the pawnbrker's shopâ€”I had never seen them before, but will undertake to swear they were all thereâ€”I am quite sure Parsons is one.

MR. ORRIDGE. Q. Where did they say they lived? A. Farrow, at 4, Bethnal-green-road; Grant, at 13, Burman-street, Commercial-road; Henderson, at 16, Bethnal-green-road; Parsons, at 16, Church-street, Shore
ditch; and Fellows, at Fryer's-mount, Shoreditch.
Cross-examined by MR. LLOYD. Q. Did you find the life-preserver? A. Yes; in the leg of Fellows' trousers.

JOHN THORPE (Policeman, G 193). On the morning of 14th February, about a quarter to 6 o'clock, I saw the five prisoners standing at the corner of Cumberland-street, Shoreditchâ€”Gardner and I took them in custodyâ€”going up Cumberland-street, I saw Fellows throw the jemmy into a timber-yardâ€”I afterwards searched the yard and found it.

JAMES CLARK (Policeman, G 149). On the morning in question, I was on duty in High-street, and saw Henderson running down a courtâ€”I caught him, and he dropped this jemmyâ€”I had seen them all standing togetherâ€”I saw Fellow throw the jemmy over a wall.
Henderson. Q. Did you not jump on me, and knock me down? A. No; we both fell togetherâ€”you dropped the jemmy out of your hand as I got hold of you.

JOHN BUCKLEE (Policeman, N 406). On the morning in question, about a quarter to 4 o'clock, I saw Fellows, Parsons, Grant, and Farrow, come out of No. 22, George-square, Hoxtonâ€”I had seen them before at that house several times, going to and fro, early and late, but cannot say whether they live there.

SAMUEL MARTIN SYER . I am a pawnbroker, of 22, Holywell-laneâ€”on the morning of 19th February, I examined the door of my plate shop, and found several marks of an attempt to force it openâ€”I should imagine the marks to be made by such an instrument as this jemmyâ€”the door-jamb was broken away from the force of the pressureâ€”there were six, seven, or eight marks on it.

THOMAS EVANS (Police-sergeant, G 22). I examined Mr. Syer's shop, and found marks on the door and door-jamb, three of which this jemmy thrown away by Henderson fits, and two places on the other side of the door fit this other jemmy thrown away by Fellowsâ€”I afterwards went to 22, George-square, Hoxton, and found these three skeleton keys, this centre-piece, chisel, and
a quantity of common keys in the water-closetâ€”I also found this rope there.
THOMAS MAVETE (Policeman, N 43). I went with Evans to 22, Bath-street, and found in the water-closet, eight skeleton keys, three pick-locks, and a jemmy.
Farrow's Defence. Nothing was found on me but a knife and a pencil case.

Henderson's Defence. The policeman says he saw the others leave the house and I was not in their company. I ran down that court to get out of the way of the police; there were a lot of civilians who threw all sorts of missiles; they threw this jemmy, and the policeman said it came out of my hand, but it did not.
GUILTY .

SERGEANT EVANS stated that in December, 1855, Fellows was tried at this Court, and sentenced to sit years' penal servitude, three or four convictions being proved against him. JOHN GILL, M 299, stated that Grant was convicted in August, 1860, of being in possession of property the proceeds of a burglary, and that he was the constant associate of thieves. STEPHEN REES, G 49, deposed to Parsons being twice convicted, and sentenced to three years' penal servitude; and PORTER WILLIAM DUNNAWAY, H 129, deposed to Farrow being convicted and sentenced to three years' penal servitude.

FARROWâ€” GUILTY.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

GRANTâ€” GUILTY.â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

HENDERSONâ€” >GUILTY.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.
PARSONSâ€” GUILTY.
FELLOWSâ€” GUILTY.

hi.rs: Three Years each in Penal Servitude.

div1.p:
470.
BENJAMIN HOTINE (40),
Unlawfully and knowingly making a certain false statement touching the birth of a certain child.

JOHN JEFFERSON . I am deputy superintendent registrar of the district of Poplarâ€”I have got the register book of births for the district of Bow and Bromley, for the year 1855â€”I have an entry here, dated 16th April, 1858, it is in several columns in the form of the scheduleâ€”the person entered here as the father of the child is Benjamin Hotineâ€”the entry is signed Benjamin Hotine, and the name of the mother is entered as Sophia Hotineâ€”in the column for name and maiden surname of the mother, is "Sophia Hotine, formerly Robins"â€”the entry is signed by tht registrar, James Dunston.

JAMES DUNSTON . In 1855, I was the registrar for Bow and Bromleyâ€”this entry is signed by me, and was made on 16th April, 1855â€”I am the registrar to whom information was givenâ€”I received the information from Benjamin Hotine, who signed the register as the fatherâ€”he gave me the name of the mother as Sophia Hotineâ€”I have got the maiden surname as Robinsâ€”that is the way in which I always enter the birth of a person who is born in wedlock.
GEORGE THOMAS ADAMS FARR . I produce the register.

THOMAS MASON . I was the registrar of the district of Artillery, in 1844; that is in the Whitechapel Unionâ€”this is the register book of that district for 1844, and here is an entry in it of the birth of a child named Benjamin James Hotineâ€”the father is Benjamin Hotineâ€”I do not know whether the prisoner is the person who gave me the information for that entry; it is eighteen years agoâ€”the person who signed this book gave me all the infor
mation, and it is signed Benjamin Hotineâ€”the entry as to the name and maiden surname of the mother is, "Sophia Hotine, formerly Robins"â€”when I

made an entry for any person who gave me information, I asked them the particulars, but I have not been registrar for ten yearsâ€”I had one form of questions which I always followedâ€”I cannot speak to the particular entry, as it is eighteen or nineteen years ago; I can only speak of my custom, which I do not think was ever departed fromâ€”I could not fill it up without information, and the information was from the person who signed it.

RICHARD CRANCH . I am the registrar of the south-eastern district of the City of London, and was so in 1851â€”I have here the register book of that districtâ€”here is an entry on 13th September, 1851, of the birth of a child named Sophiaâ€”I know the defendant perfectly well; he gave me the infor
mation with regard to the particulars contained in this entryâ€”before I made the entry, I asked him when the child was born; he told me on the 3d of August, 1861, at 19, Lime-streetâ€”I asked him the name of the child; he told me Sophiaâ€”I asked him his Christian name; he said "Benjamin Hotine"â€”I asked him his wife's name; he said, "Sophia Hotine"â€”I asked him her name before she was married, and whether she was married before she was married or not; he said, "No"â€”I am obliged to ask both questions together, as the entry is for the maiden name of the mother; it would have been "For
merly so and so," if she had been a widowâ€”he said that she had not been married before, and that her maiden name was Robinsâ€”I made the entry in his presence; he signed it, and so did Iâ€”I put the description and residence of the informant; he signed it, and I pot under it, "Father, 19, Lime-street, London."

JOHN JOSEPH LEE . I am the registrar of St. Botolph districtâ€”I have here the register of that district for 1858; Henry Spencer was then the registrarâ€”here is an entry made and signed by him, on 17th April, 1858, of the birth of a child named Benjamin Hotine, and it is signed by Benjamin Hotine as the informantâ€”in the column for "name, and maiden surname of mother," here is "Sophia Hotine, formerly Robins."

SAMUEL CORNELL . I am superintendent registrar of Kensington districtâ€”I have here the register book for that district for 1857â€”here is an entry, on 26th October, of the birth of a child on 15th Septemberâ€”the registrar is deceasedâ€”the father's name is entered as Benjamin Hotine, who is also the informantâ€”the name and maiden surname of the mother is entered as "Sophia Hotine, formerly Robins"â€”it is signed, "Charles Holloway, registrar."

ROBERT JONES . I am sexton and clerk at St John's, Waterloo-roadâ€”I have here the register of marriages; here is the marriage of a person named Benjamin Hotine, on Norember 14th, 1838, to Mary Ann Saundersâ€”here is the signature of Benjamin Hotine to the entry.

WILLIAM MACKRILL . I am in the Record Office of the Court of Probate and Divorce, and am officer of the Divorce Court as wellâ€”the Courts are combined, and all the papers of both Courts are kept togetherâ€”I am a clerk thereâ€”I produce an affidavit signed by Benjamin Hotine, dated 13th June, 1861.
Cross-examined by MR. GIFFARD. Q. Does the affidavit verify the petition; is that the practice? A. Yes.

RICHARD CARTER . I have known the defendant since 1857â€”I was in his service in 1859â€”I am acquainted with his writing, and to the best of my knowledge I believe the signature to this affidavit to be his, and also this signature to the marriage register produced by Mr. Jones.
COURT. Look at the one above; is that his writing? A. I should not be so positive of that as the otherâ€”there is not the least doubt that many years have elapsed since he wrote this.
Q. But both these are the same date; do you believe the upper one to be his? A. Well, I before it to be.

MR. CLERK. Q. Look at the Poplar register of 1855; do you see there the signature, Benjamin Hotine? A. Yesâ€”I believe that to be the defendant's, and also the one in the Whitechapel register for 1844; also this one in the St. Botolph register for 1848, and the one of 1857.

p.hi: objected to the affidavit being read, unless the petition was read with it, on the ground that the one explained the other; but

was of opinon that the affidavit was a distinct statement altogether. The defendant's affidavit in the Divorce Court was then read: it stated first, that the defendant was lawfully married to Mary Ann Hotine, then Saunders, at St. John's Chruch, Waterloo Road, on 14th November, 1838. Secondly, that at the time of the marriage he was a minor, and did not openly live with his wife, but cohabited with her at Billingsgate, and that she had no issue. Thirdly, that about January, 1839, his wife left the house at Billingsgate, where she had been living as a domestic servant, without communicating with him, and that he was unable to discover her residence. Fourthly, that in consequence of her absconding he went abroad in April, 1840, and did not return till 1841. Fifthly, that on his return about November, 1841, he discovered that his wife was living in adultery with Robert Kemp Foxall. Sixthly, that she had since that continued to live with Foxall, and had had several illegitimate children by him. Seventhly, that no collusion existed between the defendant and his wife. Eighthly, that he had personal cognisance of all the facts stated, except those in the fifth and sixth paragraphs.

div1.p:
MR. GIFFARD submitted that the case was not made out; that the latest statement relied upon as false was four years ago, and that there was no evidence that the defendant knew that his wife was alive at the time he made any of the statements in the register; that he had lost sight of his wife from 1839 to 1861, and therefore might have been legally married to Sophia Robins, and might believe these to be his lawful children. MR. CLERK stated that it was not for the prosecution to prove that the defendant had not committed bigamy. THE RECORDER considered that it was not enough to prove that the defendant had either made a false entry or com
mitted bigamy, and then leave it to the Jury to say whether he had committed the crime charged. MR. GIFFARD (with MR. ORRIDGE) further contended, that if the words "father and mother," in the schedule of the Act, were to be taken to mean father and mother at law, illegitimate children need not be registered at all; that it was the custom, in some places, for a wife to retain her maiden name; the first act of a woman after marriage being to sign her maiden name, she having no other until she acquired by repute that of her husband; that the woman, with whom the defendant lived for eighteen years, had gained his name by repute, and therefore that statement on his part was not false; the Act did not require, or even permit, the registrar to inquire whether the parties were married or not, there being no column in the schedule for that purpose. (See 2 Strange's Report, p. 1162, and Rex. v. the inhabitants of Hardnett, 1 Durnford and East, p. 96). MR. CLERK, in reply, contended that the registrar was bound to ascertain the name of the mother, and her maiden sur
name, which meant her name before she was married; her name in the world might be Hotine, but that was not the question: the question was, whether the defendant gave false information. MR. BEASLEY urged that the maiden state implied "non marriage;" that if a woman married she altered her state and obtained the name of her husband, and that the whole effect of marriage was implied in that column of the schedule.
THE RECORDER, having consulted MR. JUSTICE MELLOR, considered that the

p.hi: point whether them were true answers to the questions or not, had better be reserved for the opinion of the Court hereafter; but would take the opinion of the Jury whether there was a wilful misdescription with the object that a falsehood should be inserted in the register.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: PRESENT.â€”Mr. Ald. COPELAND; Mr. Ald. GIBBONS; and Mr. COMMON

div1.p:
471.
FRITZ KOHSE (20),
Stealing a bill of exchange for the payment of 200 dollars, value 40l., and a piece of paper, the property of
Philipp Detroy, in the dwelling-house of
Theodore Gertun.

PHILIPP DETROY (through an interpreter). I was staying at the Hotel Gertun, in St. John-street, Minoriesâ€”I am a foreignerâ€”I came to this country on Friday morning with the prisoner and the witness Zachâ€”the prisoner and I lodged in the same house and slept in the same room, but in separate bedsâ€”I ob
tained this bill of exchange (produced) for 200 Spanish dollarsâ€”it is a banker's bill, payable at New Yorkâ€”I saw it last Sunday morning; it was then in my pocket-book in my coatâ€”I could not say which pocket; sometimes I carry it in my breast pocket, and sometimes in my trousers' pocketâ€”I missed it at 9 o'clock on Monday morningâ€”it was brought to me in the course of the day by Zachâ€”I had given information to the police before thatâ€”I also lost a sovereign from my pocketâ€”when I missed the bill I went to the prisoner and told him if he had it to give it up, and I would not say anythingâ€”the prisoner had known that I had a bill of exchange in my pocket-bookâ€”before I went to him I went to the cook, and the mistress of the house, and the servantsâ€”when I missed the bill I went upstairs, told the prisoner that nobody else could have done it but him, because nobody else was in the roomâ€”the mistress of the house wanted to send to the police and search him, to see whether he had the bill or not, but the prisoner went outâ€”I cannot say whether he knew that the police were to be sent for when he went outâ€”I cannot say that he heard what the mistress of the house saidâ€”when the police came he was goneâ€”the bill was given to me by Zach about two hours after he was goneâ€”I saw the prisoner again about two hours after he left the house.
Prisoner. Q. Was it 9 or 11 o'clock when you missed the cheque? A. 9 o'clock.

SEXTUS ZACH (through an interpreter). I am a mariner, and live at 3, Haydon-square, Middlesexâ€”I came over to England from Rotterdam with the last witness and the prisonerâ€”I saw the prisoner last Monday in the streetâ€”he said that when Detroy, whom I lodged with, went down early in the morning, he went and stole the chequeâ€”he said he had been to several bankers and wanted the bill cashed; but they would not cash it for him, because they had to write first to New York and see if the bill was paid or notâ€”I then proposed that I should get it cashed for him, and that we should divide the money between usâ€”he did not mention any banking house to which he had been to get it changedâ€”I said he should give me the cheque, as I went to a banker's before, and got some Prussian money changed for English, and he should go with me and get it cashed, and then divide the

moneyâ€”the prisoner gave me the bill to do so, and I went to the bankâ€”the prisoner was to wait outside to be ready to receive the money if I should be able to change the billâ€”that was after the prisoner had told me he had stolen it out of the prosecutor's pocketâ€”I had never changed any money at all; I only told him so, to induce him to give me the billâ€”I went with him under the pretence of changing the bill, and the first policeman I met I told the circumstance toâ€”I gave the bill to the policemanâ€”it was in the neighbourhood where the robbery had taken place; and, when I told the policeman that was the person who had taken the bill, he ran after him and caught him, and we went together and saw the prosecutor almost imme
diately.
Prisoner. Everything he has said is untrue.

ALFRED JOSEPH TURNER (City-policeman, 595). On Monday last I recieved information from the landlady, in consequence of which I waited shout for some timeâ€”the witness Zach came running over to me, gave me some information, and pointed out the prisoner; and I went after him, caught him, took him in custody, and took him to the prosecutorâ€”Zach gave me this bill, which I produceâ€”I took the prisoner to the station, in custodyâ€”the bill is a bill of exchange for 200 dollars, payable in New York; town on a house in New York.
Prisoner. When we came up the street, and saw the policeman standing there, the witness came and gave information to the police to clear himself, or else he would not have done it.
MR. LILLEY. Q. What time was it? A. In the afternoonâ€”I had been watching for him some time.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw the prosecutor about 9 o'clock in the morning, and went out with him; when he came back about 11 o'clock he only missed the bill then. I took it, and only kept it to frighten him. When I went out about 11 o'clock I did not say I had it, but went out with the view of changing it, and bringing him the cash for it I thought it would be more agreeable to him. I could not change it, and I met Zach, and told him; he proposed to change it, and that then we would run away with the proceeds between us. I could not get it back from him, and so I thought I would let him change it, and then try and get the money from him, and bring it back to the prosecutor.
COURT to PHILIPP DETROY. Q. Did you know anything of the prisoner before you came over with him? A. No; he was not a friend of mine.

p.rs: GUILTY.â€”Recommended to mercy on account of his youth.

div1.p:
472.
FREDERICK WHITE (39),
CHARLES ABRAHAMS (30), and
MARY ANN ABRAHAMS (57),
Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Roger Watkins, and stealing therein a jug, a pair of sugar tongs, 2 pepper castors, 3 table cloths, and a shawl, his property.

SARAH SHANK . I am in the service of Mr. John Roger Watkins, of 1, Portland-villas, Bow-road, and was so on 10th Decemberâ€”between 10 and 11 o'clock that night I closed the house and went to bedâ€”the house was then safe and secureâ€”I came down in the morning about half-past 6, and found four bars taken from the pantry window, and the window-frame smashed in so that there were means of getting in through thereâ€”I searched and missed a silver cream jug, two pepper castors, from the parlour cup
board, sugar tongs, and table cloths, from the drawer in the breakfast-room,

a great coat from the hall, and my shawl from the passage by the kitchen doorâ€”these (produced) are the articlesâ€”they were all safe the night before I missed themâ€”the table cloths are markedâ€”they are in the same state as they were on the night of 10th December.

WALTER KERRESEY (Police-inspector K.) About 1 o'clock on the morning of 4th March, the prisoner White was brought to the stationâ€”he said he lived at 12, Violet-street, Devons-road, Bromleyâ€”I saw a key taken from him, and went to 12, Violet-street with itâ€”I opened the front door with it, and went in and searchedâ€”I found a woman and child there in bedâ€”I found this table cloth marked "J. R. Watkins, 1847," a pair of silver sugar tongs, on the dresser, and this shawl on the bedâ€”I found nothing else there relating to this indictmentâ€”I did not receive any information from White or hear him make any statement either before or after I went thereâ€”on Friday, 7th March, I went to Rose-court, Beer-lane, City, and saw Mrs. Abrahams there in a down stairs room manglingâ€”I said, "Is your name Mrs. Abrahams?"â€”she said, "Yes"â€”I asked her if she had a son-in-law of the name of Frederick White, living in Bromleyâ€”she said she hadâ€”I asked her if she ever received any coats, pieces of cloth, table covers or cloths, any silver pepper castors, a silver milk jug, or any other articles from Whiteâ€”she said she had notâ€”I said, "You have not? but White has told me so, and I must search your house"â€”she said, "Well, there is a coat up stairs which White gave me"â€”she went upstairs, I with her, and she handed me this coat, which was identified by the last witnessâ€”she said, "A table cloth I put in the fire yesterday; I saw it was marked with red letters, and I burnt it"â€”I said, "Where are the silver pepper castors and the silver milk jug?"â€”she said they were at her son's house, 3, St. Andrew's-hill, Blackfriarsâ€”I then told her I should take her into custody for receiving those things knowing them to have been stolen, and I went with her and the constable to her son's house, 3, St Andrew's-hillâ€”I went into a back room on the second-floor, where I saw three females, and asked them some questionsâ€”one of them, named Mary Ann Atley, handed me the key of a bureau in the front room, in consequence of something I had said to herâ€”I took the key and opened the bureau with it, and found in it two silver pepper castors and a silver milk jugâ€”they are not identifiedâ€”(MR. BESLET objected to the production of any articles besides those included in the indictment. MR. LILLEY contended that all articles found on the premises of an accused person might bs produced, although not having reference soley to the charge before the jury, and that the particular articles in question might be selected at the end of the case. MR. METCALFE stated that the case of Regina v. Oddy decided that the property could only be produced when stolen from the same person. THE COURT, after referring to Regina v. Oddy, was of opinion that the articles could not be produced)â€”this coat was given me by Mrs. Abrahamsâ€”I also found these two table cloths at St Andrew's-hillâ€”I remained there till about 6 in the eveningâ€”the prisoner Charles Abrahams then came homeâ€”on hia coming into the back room where the three females were, he said, "I am very glad you have come, Sir"â€”I asked him if his name was Charles Abrahamsâ€”he said, "Yes; I suppose you have got those things which White gave me"â€”I said, "What things do you mean? the two silver pepper castors and the silver milk jug?"â€”he said, "Yes; there are two table cloths also which White gave me"â€”he said to Miss Atley, "Give them to him," and she fetched them from another roomâ€”I looked at them and said to him, "They were not in this state when you received them from White"â€”he said, "No, they were not"â€”I said, "The

name is darned over"â€”at my request, Miss Atley, in his presence, ripped out the cotton, and then I found the mark "J. R. Watkins"â€”a part of the other has also been darned over, and the name of Charles Abrahams marked on itâ€”here it is; in marking inkâ€”I then asked him if ever he had received any pieces of cloth or any coats from Whiteâ€”he said he had notâ€”I said, "I shall take you into custody for receiving these things that were stolen," meaning the pepper castorsâ€”he then said that he had given Fred. White a guinea for the silver pepper castors and the milk jug, and I then took him to Bow-stationâ€”I took possession of other articles in the houseâ€”Sarah Shank was at the station, and on my producing the articles she said, in the prisoner's presence, that they were her master's, taken from the house on the night of 10th Decemberâ€”I did not hear him make any reply to thatâ€”on 8th March, Mary Ann Abrahams and Charles Abrahams were each in a separate cell connected with the charge roomâ€”I went to visit the female prisoner's cell at 9 o'clock, and she said, "Can I speak to you, Sir, in the presence of my son?"â€”I said, "Certainly"â€”I unlocked the door of Charles Abrahams' cell, and brought him to the door of his mother's cell, she took him by the hands, cried, and kissed him, and said, "Charley, let us tell all about it and make a clean breast of it"â€”I brought them into the charge room and sat downâ€”I said, "Mrs. Abrahams, before you make any statement to me it is my duty to caution you; do not tell me anything to criminate yourself, but whatever you tell me will be taken down in writing, and used in evidence against you"â€”she then repeated the following statement, which I took down in writing, "When first Fred, White came to me, he brought me eleven pieces of cloth, which he stated he found when coming from work; I sent four pieces of the cloth to my sister Mrs. Taylor, Pearley-cottage, Brighton-road, Croydon; then he brought me what my son has given you last night (meaning these articles;) then he brought me the coat, which I gave up to you last night, and told me he bought it in Petticoat-lane for 6s.; three pieces of cloth I sent to Mrs. Franklin, at Islington, to sell for me"â€”the prisoner Charles then immediately said, "And four pieces I had; "he continued: "Now I will tell you, Sir; you asked me last night if I had not got an Inverness cape and a pair of boots; well, I had; it was got out of pawn by Fred. White himself; the amount was 18s.; I gave him 3s. for the ticket; I disposed of them both, but I can get them back again; I know where there are two pieces of the cloth, one my wife has and one Miss Mitford has; the cape is at Mr. Starkey's, at St Mary-at-Hill; the boots our second mate had on board the Earl of Auck
land"â€”that is allâ€”on the morning of the 8th, at Stepney station, he made a further statement to meâ€”on 11th March, while at the Court and passing the cell, White said, "Officer, can I speak to you?"â€”I said, "What do you want?"â€”he said, "Just tell my sisters I want to speak to them"â€”his sisters came to the cell door and handed him some tea or coffee, and bread-and-bntterâ€”he said, "Officer, I stole all them coats, all them pieces of cloth and table cloths, and them silver things; Mrs. Abrahams told me to steal all that I could, and bring them to her to dispose of them"â€”she was not there.
White. It is false; I never mentioned Mrs. Abrahams to him.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. (For Chales Abrahams.) Q. Is the prisoner a mate on board a vessel? A. I believe he is steward on board the Earl of Auckland, a vessel trading between London and Rotterdamâ€”I do not know whether, when he came in the day I was there, he had just re
turned from itâ€”I believe the vessel goes to Rotterdam, and returns here

every weekâ€”when I came in he asked me whether I had got the table cloths as well as these thingsâ€”I swear that I called his attention expressly to the mark, "J. R. Watkins," and he said it had been alteredâ€”he said they were not in that state, meaning about the mark being darned overâ€”I have heard the evidence of the servant girlâ€”I heard her say they were in the same state as when they were lost, but I do not think she rightly understood itâ€”the two sisters were present when the conversation with White occurred, and they heard what took placeâ€”the police-court and the station oommunicate, and a person passing from the station to the Court the back way, would pass the cellsâ€”I came down stairs at 9 in the morning, and went to look at the prisoner's cell, and then Mrs. Abrahams addressed meâ€”the two Abrahams were not under remand at the timeâ€”they had not been committedâ€”they had been about twelve or fifteen hours in custodyâ€”they employed Mr. Young, a solicitor, to defend them, and yet they made that communication to meâ€”when I was taking it down at the station, the sergeant on duty was presentâ€”he is not hereâ€”I did not take White's statement down; not the part where he denied saying anything about Mrs. Abrahamsâ€”it was in the open yard, and there was no convenience for taking it downâ€”I generally carry a pencil and memorandum-book, but not alwaysâ€”I have not got one in my pocket now of any kindâ€”I have other papers besides this scrapâ€”I might have taken his statement down if I had been so inclined, the two sisters being there made no difference.

Q. It was not so worth while taking that down when they were present as when you had the mother and son all to yourself in the cell; is that the reason you did not take it down? A. No, the reason was that I had no memorandum-book, and it was in the yardâ€”I have been getting up the caseâ€”I summoned some witnesses, and gave instructions in the office for the indictmentâ€”I did not think it necessary to employ an attorneyâ€”I do not understand more about these cases myself.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. (For Mary Ann Abrahams.) Q. Did you put the conversation of 7th March in writing at the time? A. Not at the house, on the first oocasionâ€”I think I said, in the course of the conversa
tion, "I suppose you have heard what has occurred; you know he was appre
hended for housebreaking the other day"â€”I said, "I suppose you know that Fred. White is apprehended for housebreaking"â€”she said, "My daughter told me so the day before yesterday"â€”I asked her if she had a cost, and she said the had not.

Q. Did not she say, "Oh, dear me, the coat is up stairs;" she did not say in that off-hand manner, "Well, the coat is up stairs?" A. No, she did notâ€”I do not know that she was very much affected at the timeâ€”she might have appeared very much depressed in spirits; I do not know, it being the first time I had seen herâ€”she did not appear so, I thoughtâ€”she was very deafâ€”the conversation that I took down was on the following morning, before either of the Abrahams had been before the Magistrateâ€”I think Mrs. Abrahams was charged before the Magistrate with receiving some of the property of Mr. Watkinsâ€”I learnt from her at the first conversation, that she knew of White having been arrested two days beforeâ€”that which I took down I wrote down as she said it to me from her mouth; not at the cell door, but in the charge room where I brought themâ€”at the time she said, "Charley, let us tell all about it, and make a clean breast of it," I was not writingâ€”I am quite sure the expression, "make a clean breast of it," was used; I swear to itâ€”they were her exact wordsâ€”I wrote them down imme
diately afterwards; a second had not elapsedâ€”it is not possible that those

are my words; they are her own wordsâ€”it is a natural expression for a policemanâ€”she did not say at once that she was determined to tell all about itâ€”there was nothing in her statement untrue to my knowledge.

MR. LILLEY. Q. Is your memory quite clear as to what Charles Abra
hams said on that occasion, when you did not take it down? A. Quiteâ€”I have not the slightest doubt that he used the expressions I have used.
COURT. Q. Is the house in the parish of St Mary-at-Bow? A. Yes.

GEORGE ATKINS (Policeman.) I took Frederick White in custody on the morning of 4th March, in the area of Mr. Sunlie's house, Bow-road, at 1 o'clock, and conveyed him to the stationâ€”he said that it was distress that had brought him to itâ€”I found on him 2s. 2 1/2 d., two knives, and some tools.

Mary Ann and Charles Abrahams received excellent characters.â€”
NOT GUILTY .

WHITEâ€”
GUILTY .

473.
FREDERICK WHITE and
CHARLES ABRAHAMS were again indicted for
a burglary in the dwelling-house of
James Martin, and stealing 1 cape, 1 coat, 2 pairs of boots, and other articles, his property;
and also a burglary in the dwelling-house of
Francis Farman, and stealing 2 coats, 1 watch, 1 guard, 1 table-cover, and 2l. 10s. in money, his property; to which

WHITE
PLEADED GUILTY , and no evidence was offered against Charles Abra
hams..
NOT GUILTY .

474.
FREDERICK WHITE,
CHARLES ABRAHAMS , and
MARY ANN ABRAHAMS , were again indicted for
a burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Timberlake, and stealing 3 coats, value 6l., 1 pair of boots, value 10s., 25 yards of cloth, and 10s. in money, his property; to which

WHITE
PLEADED GUILTY .â€”No evidence was offered against the two Abra
hams.â€”
NOT GUILTY .

WHITE.â€”
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

475.
BENJAMIN CORP (17),
Feloniously wounding
David Price upon hit head and left leg, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

DAVID PRICE . I live at 1, Ware-passage, Somers'-town, and am a shoe
makerâ€”last Wednesday evening, 2d April, I was standing at my doorâ€”I walked up the passage, and Mrs. Price my wife, and Mrs. Quinton were rowing with one anotherâ€”Mrs. Quinton lives in the court, and keeps a broker's shop thereâ€”she is the prisoner's mistressâ€”I was bending down to part them; one of them was down likeâ€”I took them partly away from one another, and had a blow on the headâ€”I could not tell who it was thenâ€”I cannot say what it was done with; it made me insensibleâ€”I was taken to the station-house, when I came to my senses I found myself thereâ€”I was suffering very much from that blow, and I had a wound in my leg.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. You had been ill before this occurrence, had you not? A. No, not at allâ€”I am fifty years of ageâ€”this happened last Wednesday weekâ€”I did not do anything on the next day, Thursdayâ€”I did not move any goods on that dayâ€”I was looking after others who were movingâ€”Mrs. Quinton is the employer of the prisonerâ€”I did not strike her at allâ€”I only just tried to separate themâ€”I told her to be quiet, not to be so foolishâ€”they were not fighting, they were pulling one another's hairâ€”I did not see any jars there whateverâ€”I am quite certain there were none about thereâ€”I do not know that there were any brokenâ€”I was in the

passage when I was struck, a little way from my doorâ€”it is a kind of court out of doorsâ€”it was about twenty yards from Mrs. Quinton's shopâ€”I do not know how long Mrs. Price and Mrs. Quinton had been quarrelling before I interferedâ€”I came out of the little parlour and walked up as soon as I as itâ€”Mrs. Price had not gone out from me two minutesâ€”I cannot say that I only had one blowâ€”I did not see the prisoner till I was up at the station-houseâ€”I did not notice him close to Mrs. Quiutonâ€”I saw no one except Mrs. Price and Mrs. Quintonâ€”I saw a lame man, Mils Seanling's father, I thinkâ€”I did not see Charles Whiteâ€”I don't know how long I stopped at the station-houseâ€”I went home and slept that night.

CATHERINE SOANLING .
