I live at Ware-passage, Somers'-town, in the same house with Mr. Priceâ€”on Wednesday, 2d April, I was minding my things outside the doorâ€”I was present when these two woman were quarrellingâ€”Price was also at the doorâ€”he went to separate the two women who were quarrelling, and the prisoner came towards him, made use of the words, "I will settle the bâ€”," jumped on Mr. Price's back, first hit him in the face with his fist, and, before he could turn round, struck him on his head with a hammerâ€”the prisoner was glazing some windowsâ€”he is a bootmaker by tradeâ€”Price turned round to push him away, and the prisoner fell downâ€”when he fell, he turned round and struck a knife into the thick part of Price's legâ€”I saw him do that deliberatelyâ€”Price did not go downâ€”he was senseless; but he did not fall.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite right that Price did not fall? A. Yesâ€”his back went against the lamp-postâ€”he did not fall on the groundâ€”this was a white-handled knife; a putty knife they call itâ€”I saw it distinctlyâ€”it was a wide knife with a pointed tipâ€”he was mending a window with itâ€”I went for a policeman as soon as I saw the blood and the blowâ€”I did not see Mr. Price strike the prisonerâ€”I saw the beginning of the rowâ€”I can swear I saw no crockery about thereâ€”there was nothing broken at Mrs. Quinton's doorâ€”this is the knife (produced)â€”he was using the knife and the hammer when he saw his mistress having a row with Mrs. Price.

DAVID HOLDER (Policeman, S 418). On Wednesday afternoon, 2d April, I was called up to Ware-passage, and took the prisoner into custodyâ€”there were ten or twelve people thereâ€”some one in the crowd called out, "Be careful, policeman, he has got a knife"â€”I then took hold of the prisoner, and he said, "I have not got a knife; but I hit the old bâ€”with a ham
mer"â€”I was then searching himâ€”my brother constable went after the ham
mer, he could not find it, or the knife.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you on the spot when the row took place? A. Noâ€”I saw no earthenware aboutâ€”there was some up against Mrs. Quinton's door, four or five yards off.

GEORGE PARBY (Policeman, S 376). I went with Holder to Ware-passageâ€”just as I turned the corner, I saw the prisoner throw a hammer awayâ€”I said to the other constable, "Search him for the knife"â€”the prisoner directly said, "It is not done with a knife; I hit the old bâ€”with a hammer; I wish I had finished him"â€”he repeated that several times afterwards on his way to the station and at the stationâ€”I was unable to recover the hammerâ€”I went in search of itâ€”it had been taken away by some oneâ€”I then took the prisoner to the station-house, and the prosecutor to the Great Northern Hospitalâ€”he was bleeding very profusely from his bead and from his legâ€”the Magistrate remanded the case for two or three days, to see if it was serious.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see the house surgeon? A. Yes; he exam
ined
the wounds both in the head and the leg; and said they were not of a dangerous characterâ€”he prepared a bandage, and called the porter, which is usual, to bandage them upâ€”I then took him home.

476.
GEORGE WHITE (35), and
JAMES RUSSELL (18), were in
dicted for
stealing 1 sack and 4 bushels of oats, value 13s. 6d., the property of
Arthur Macnamara, the master of White; to which

WHITEâ€”
PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

RUSSELLâ€”
PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

p.hi: The prosecutor recommended White to mercy, believing he, as will as other carmen, had been led into it by Russell.

div1.p:
477.
JOSEPH EDNEY (27),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

WILLIAM QUELCH . I keep a chandler's shop at Stratfordâ€”on Tuesday evening, 11th March, the prisoner came to my shop and bought a quarter of a pound of cheeseâ€”it came to 2 1/2 d.â€”he put down a half-crown, and I gave him 2s. 3 1/2 d. changeâ€”I laid down the half-crown, and when he went out, I took it up and found it was badâ€”I and my son went ont and pursued the prisoner to Bowâ€”I found him with another man, standing under the window of the Three Cups public-houseâ€”they moved onâ€”one crossed the road, and the other went straight on, and the prisoner turned down a gateway, and then came backâ€”I said to him, "You bought a little cheese of me just now;" he said, "No;" I said, "Yes, you did; and gave me a bad half-crown:" he said, "You are mistaken"â€”I was positive of him, and said, "There was another man with you, and he has crossed over;" he said, "Then I will go and find him;" and be ran across the roadâ€”the one that was with him had been, not two minutes before, for half an ounce of tobacco, and gave me three halfpenceâ€”a boy stopped the prisoner, and I gave him into custody to Major, the constable, with the half-crown.

JOHN IRELAND . I assist my brother at the Yorkshire Grey public-house, Stratfordâ€”on Tuesday evening, 11th March, the prisoner came there for a glass of ale, for which he tendered a bad half-crownâ€”I said, "This is a bad one; you had better go about your business; we don't want to have anything to do with you"â€”he paid for the glass of ale with a good two-shilling pieceâ€”my brother marked the half-crown, and gave it to Pearson.
CHRISTOPHER PEARSON (Policeman, K 262). I saw the prisoner come out of the Yorkshire Grey public-houseâ€”Mr. Ireland's brother called me, and gave me this half-crown.

GEORGE MAJOR (Policeman, K 369). The prisoner was given into my custody, on 11th March, by Mr. Quelch for passing this bad balf-crownâ€”the prisoner said Mr. Quelch was mistakenâ€”I searched him, and found on him a half-crown, shilling, and sixpence, and a penny, good money.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . I am inspector of counterfeit coin to the Mintâ€”these are both bad.

GUILTY â€”
Confined Nine Months.

478.
DAVID BARREN (21),
Breaking and entering a building' within the curtilage of the dwelling-house of
John Gibson O'Leary, and stealing therein 5 calico shirts, 3 petticoats, and other goods, his property; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

479.
JOHN ROBERTS (50),
Feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Joseph Harris, and stealing therein 1 gold watch, and 3 gold chains, value 11l. 10s, his property.

CHARLES KEITH . I am foreman to Mr. Joseph Harris, a pawnbroker, in High-street, Deptfordâ€”on Saturday, 8th March, about half-past 11, I was behind the counter in the front part of the shopâ€”I heard a crash of glass, and saw a hand and a stick going from the windowâ€”I immediately ran out, and laid hold of the prisonerâ€”his hand was bleedingâ€”he said, "I beg your pardon, I was drunk," or "had been drinking, and in falling broke the glass"â€”I found at his feet one gold chain, and two others, which I threw back into the window through the broken pane of glassâ€”I took the prisoner into the shop, and sent for a constableâ€”he took him away, and when I had got about six yards, from what I heard, I went and asked the constable to bring him back, that he might be searched, in case he should pass anythingâ€”he was searched in my presenceâ€”the policeman put his hand into his left-hand pocket, and I put my hand into his right-hand pocket; and took out a gold watch, and this ticketâ€”it is part of my master's propertyâ€”the prisoner afterwards assumed to be drunk; but he was not at the time.
MARY ANN PARSONS . I was near Mr. Harris's shop on 8th Marchâ€”I saw the prisoner put his stick through the window and take a watch, and put it in his right-hand pocket

WILLIAM WARRINGTON (Policeman, R 279). The prisoner was given into my charge, and I saw the watch found by the first witnessâ€”the prisoner did not appear to me to be drunk at the time I took him in charge: but on leaving the police-station, to go to the police-court, he threw himself down several times.
Prisoner's Defence. I fell against the window as I was very tipsy, and did not know what I was about. I had no thought of taking anything.
CHARLES KEITH (re-examined.) The watch that he took hung at the height of about five feet eight inchesâ€”he could not have fallen against that.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

480.
HENRY AYLEY (22),
Feloniously forging and uttering a request for the delivery of 5s. worth of postage-stamps with intent to defraud;
also, for another like offence; to both which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

481.
JAMES NARROWAY (25),
Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Thomas Holman, on 21st March, and stealing 9 pairs of boots and 2 pairs of boot fronts, his property.

THOMAS HOLMAN . I am a bootmaker, of Plumstead, Kentâ€”about 12 o'clock, on Thursday, 20th March, I went to bedâ€”I had previously fastened my doors and windowsâ€”I left some boots in the shop windowâ€”I got up

about 6 on Friday morning, and on opening my shop, I found that a pane of glass had been taken out of the window, and the boots were all goneâ€”I saw marks of a knife where the putty was taken out from the glassâ€”there had been no shutters upâ€”these are a portion of what was in the windowâ€”I lost altogether between 4l. and 5l. worth.

WILLIAM SHEPHERD . I am a bootmaker, in High-street, Woolwichâ€”I have known the prisoner about three monthsâ€”he was a waiter at a public-house at Woolwich, and I occasionally repaired boots for himâ€”on 26th February last I met him in High-street, Woolwich, and he asked if I knew where he could sell a lot of boots, for he knew where he oould get someâ€”I told him I did notâ€”on 21st March, about half-past 7 in the morning, he came to me and brought two pairs of uppers, and asked if I would buy themâ€”I said I did not know, he could leave them and I would seeâ€”I left him in the room, and went to the station and gave informationâ€”I gave the same uppers to the policeman.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not say you would go out and see if you could sell them? A. Yes; but I went to Woolwich for a policemanâ€”you told me you stole them on the 21st March, about 2 or 3 in the morning.

WILLIAM YARDLEY (Policeman, R 259). On the morning of 21st March I went to Shepherd's house, and he gave me these 2 pairs of uppersâ€”I after
wards went to 8, Ropeyard-walk, Woolwich, and looked over the house for the prisonerâ€”it is a lodging-houseâ€”he was not there thenâ€”I stood in the back yard for some minutes, and the prisoner and another man, named Brown, came over the wall at the backâ€”I told the prisoner I should take him into custody for breaking into a house at Plumstead, and stealing a quantity of bootsâ€”he said, "Very well"â€”on searching him at the station I found on his feet a pair of the stolen shoes, and in his coat-pocket he had a smaller pairâ€”in his pocket I found a knife with some putty on itâ€”I compared it with the marks on the window of the prosecutor; such marks have been made with this knife.

Prisoner's Defence. I was at work at a coffee-shop till half-past 4 in the morning, and had them offered to me for sale, or if I liked to dispose of them; I was to have one pair for my trouble; I took two pairs and the uppers to Shepherd, and he said he would try and sell them; I knew nothing of their being stolen; I had bought some shoes of the same man some time before.

GUILTY of Stealing only. â€ â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

482.
JOHN RYAN (24), and
PALMER BROWN (20),
Stealing a pair of boots, the property of
John James Look.

WILLIAM YARDLEY (Policeman, R 259). On 26th February last I was employed at Woolwich in plain clothesâ€”I saw the prisoners together thereâ€”Ryan was carrying a pair of bootsâ€”he took them into four shops and offered them for saleâ€”Brown stood outsideâ€”I stopped Ryan and asked him where he got the boots fromâ€”he said he made them where he had been working in Union-square, Woolwichâ€”I asked if he knew where it wasâ€”he said yes, he could show meâ€”he went some distance with me, and then said, "It is no use my telling you a lie; I made them in London, where I have been working"â€”I then told him I should take him into custodyâ€”Brown made off but was brought back by a civilian.

Ryan. The evidence he has given now is not consistent with his evidence before the Magistrateâ€”(The witness's deposition being read agreed with his evidence)â€”He accused me of having a false card in my possession, and he

produced two cards before the Magistrate. Witness. I have them hereâ€”Ryan pulled this one out of his pocket and said, "That is the address of my master"â€”it is a bootmakers' society card; the other card was found on Brown.

Brown. Q. When you took me into custody and wanted to ride my pockets, did not I say, "I will not let a rogue search an honest man's pockets? A. I did not take you into custodyâ€”you ran away and were brought backâ€”you both gave a false address, 8 1/2, Crown-courtâ€”I went thereâ€”I went to the middle floorâ€”there were five or six people in one room, but no one you told me to inquire for.

JOHN JAMES LOCK . I am a boot and shoemaker in High-street, Woolwichâ€”on 27th February the constable brought these boots to meâ€”I then examined my stock and missed a pair from a chair back where ten pain had been placed the day beforeâ€”these are themâ€”my name is stamped upon themâ€”they had not been sold; when they are sold they have eylet holes put, and there are none to these.
THOMAS PORTER . I am a shoemakerâ€”I work for Mr. Lockâ€”I made these boots for him, and my daughter bound themâ€”I took them home on 26th February, with nine other pairs like them.

Ryan to WILLIAM YARDLEY. Q. What card did you find in my possession? A. One belonging to the associationâ€”you told me the secretary's name was upon the cardâ€”it was notâ€”there is no such place as Union-square, Wool
wichâ€”there is a Union-street.
Ryan's Defence. The policeman denies that there is such a person as the person whose name and address I gave; if I had an opportunity, I could prove his statement to be false.

Brown's Defence. I left London with this young man to get employment; I got this card from the president in Woolwich, and was told there was a chance of work there. Ryan said he was going to sell a pair of boots, but I did not know whether they were stolen or not; I knew nothing about them.

RYANâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

BROWNâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

483.
HENRY JOSEPH WALKER (21, an artilleryman),
was indicte for a rape upon
Ann Mills.

484.
JONATHAN LEATHERS (19, an artilleryman), was indicted
for a rape upon
Ann Mills.
NOT GUILTY .

485.
MARGARET BUCKLEY (20),
Stealing 6 handkerchiefs, a ten-spoon and fork, the property of
Emily Martin and others.

GEORGE POOLEY . I am a pawnbroker, in the service of Mr. Edward Carter, of Bear-lane, Greenwichâ€”on 11th March, about half-past 6 in the evening, the prisoner came to pledge three spoons and a fork, for 9s.â€”I asked her whose they wereâ€”she said they belonged to her mistressâ€”I asked her mistress's nameâ€”she said Smith, and she lived at 7, Creome's-hill-groveâ€”I said, "If they belong to your mistress you had better go and fetch a note,

and then I will lend you the money"â€”she said she could very easily do thatâ€”she went out of the shop, and never returned again, leaving the property on the counter with meâ€”I communicated with the police next day; but nothing was heard of her til a fortnight ago, when I met her in Trafalgar-road, Greenwichâ€”I followed her to her matter's house, and then communi
cated with the police again.
Prisoner. I never took them to the shop; I was not these. Witness. I am sure she is the woman.

JAMES MARGETSON (Policeman, R 122). I went to Miss Martin's on 29th March, and she went with me to the pawnbroker'sâ€”I afterwards went back and saw the prisoner; she was living there as servantâ€”I told her that I should take her into custody on a charge of stealing some silver spoons and a fork, which were found at the pawnbroker'sâ€”she said, "I know nothing at all about them; I was not out on that night at all"â€”I had told her the day and the hourâ€”I said, "Put on your things, and come with me to the pawnbroker's"â€”she did so, accompanied by Miss Martinâ€”the witness identi
fied the prisoner as the person who had offered the things in pledgeâ€”I then took her to the station, and she was charged and remandedâ€”on the Friday following I went to the prosecutrix's house and unlocked a box, with a key that I found on the prisoner, and found in it six pocket-handkerchiefs, some rice, and a quantity of lump-sugar.

EMILY MARTIN . I live at Maze-hill, Greenwichâ€”the prisoner was in my employment for five weeks up to 29th Marchâ€”these spoons and fork are mineâ€”the prisoner had no authority to take them or pawn themâ€”I pointed out the prisoner's box to the policeman, and he opened it with a keyâ€”one of the handkerehiefs found in it is mine, and one my sister's, and four belong to some young ladies pupils.
Prisoner's Defence. If I took their handkerchiefs, they nave got mine.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

486.
ANN MASON (26),
Stealing 46 yards of printed cotton, value 21s., the property of
Joseph Gibson, having been previously convicted; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Three Months.

487.
JAMES DAVIS (25),
Unlawfully attempting to steal a watch, value 4l., the property of
Anthony Armstrong, from his person.

ANTHONY ARMSTRONG . I am a Government inspector, and lived at 8, Acorn-Btreet, Woolwich, last Julyâ€”I have moved nowâ€”on a Monday even
ing, early in July, I was at the Pavilion Gardens, North Woolwich, between 7 and 8 o'clock, I thinkâ€”I was looking at a man walking across the tight-rope, and I felt something pulling at my chest, and when I looked down the prisoner had my watch in his left hand, and was giving a twist to the chain with his rightâ€”I took hold of him and gave him in custodyâ€”I got hold of him, and prevented him going awayâ€”I am sore he is the man.

HENRY COKE (Police-sergeant, K 48). I was called by the last witness, he gave the prisoner into custodyâ€”at the station he heard the charge, and said, "I did not attempt to do anything of the kind," or something to that effectâ€”his words were, "You know I never did anything of the kind; I never attempted to steal your watch," or words like thatâ€”the signature to that deposition is my writingâ€”it was read over to, me before I signed itâ€”(The witness's deposition being read, stated, "He said 'You are mistaken; it was not me at all")â€”it might have been those wordsâ€”it is some time sinceâ€”those are the wordsâ€”the prosecutor was holding him when, I came upâ€”I was up a very short time after it took place.
Prisoner. I was standing by the office, and he came and laid hold of me about an hour after his watch was taken.
ANTHONY ARMSTRONG (re-examined.) That is not trueâ€”no one came and told me of itâ€”I saw him with the watch in his hand.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Three Month.

488.
ELLEN SMITH (17), and
MARY ANN DYERSON (18),
Stealing a pair of boots, the property of
Mary Ann White; to which they

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Three Months each.

489.
HENRY CHAPMAN (22),
Stealing, on 8th March, 40l. in money, the property of
George Roberts, in his dwelling-house.

SELINA ROBERTS . I am the wife of George Roberts, a chemist's assistant, of Lee, Kentâ€”on 7th March I received four 10l. Bank of England notesâ€”the prisoner was not present when I received them; but he knew that I had those notesâ€”he saw me put them under my pillowâ€”I kept them thereâ€”the pri
soner was a lodgerâ€”I had the notes safe, under my pillow, on 7th Marchâ€”there was also a small boxâ€”the prisoner was in the room the next morning Saturday, the box was then broken open, and I placed my notes next to the windowâ€”I missed them between 11 and 12 o'clockâ€”I had seen them safe on Friday nightâ€”the prisoner slept in the same room with me and my husbandâ€”he was there on Saturday morningâ€”I was asleep when the notes were taken away, and I missed them afterwardsâ€”I am not in very good healthâ€”I did not get up till after 12 o'clock that morningâ€”I missed them when I wokeâ€”the prisoner had then goneâ€”he did not come back for two daysâ€”I had had no quarrel with my husbandâ€”I never threw the notes in the fire-place, or did I present them to the prisonerâ€”I did not tell him to put them in his pocket and keep them.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you and your husband have a few words? A. We did notâ€”I did not use bad expressions and say I would throw the notes behind the fireâ€”I did not give them to you.

GEORGE ROBERTS . I am the husband of the last witnessâ€”on 7th March I had four 10l. notesâ€”when I came home on that day I gave them to my wife, and she put them underneath the pillowâ€”the prisoner was presentâ€”on the following day, Saturday, between 11 and 12 o'clock, those notes were missingâ€”the prisoner had slept in my house that morningâ€”he never came back after that till Sunday morning, between 10 and 11 o'clockâ€”he was absent again on Sunday nightâ€”I went in search of him on Monday, and found himâ€”I called him out of the house where he was, and I said, "Harry, you must know something about those notes"â€”he said he knew nothing about themâ€”he said, "I do not know anything about them; they must be at home"â€”he said nothing to me about any money being leftâ€”when he was taken into custody he said he did not know anything at all about them; he said he would go home with me and see about them; he knew they were at homeâ€”something passed about 27l.â€”he left that at a public-house called "The Gothic Hall," at Deptfordâ€”I went down there, and found he had left it thereâ€”I gave him in chargeâ€”the sergeant asked me what was the charge, and I said, "For stealing four 10l. Bank of England notes"â€”he then asked the prisoner what he had to say, and be then said my wife had given them to himâ€”the sergeant said, "If that is so there is no charge"â€”I said, "Do you think it is likely that she would give four 10l. notes to him?"â€”we then went home to see whether she had given it to

him, and when we came back he said it was two 10l. notes and two 5l. notesâ€”I said that was not soâ€”I did not give them awayâ€”he took themâ€”I did not see the notes thrown on the fireâ€”I had no quarrel with my wifeâ€”I was rather cross because the box was broken; that was all.

JOHN ALLEN (Policeman, R 140). On 10th March I went with the prose
cutor to a beer-shop in Deptfordâ€”I found the prisoner there, apprehended him, and told him he was charged with stealing four 10l. Bank of England notesâ€”he said there was two 10l. and two 5l. notes, and the prosecutor's wife had given them to himâ€”that was at the station-houseâ€”he did not say that at firstâ€”I searched him, and found 4l. 5s. 5d. on him.
Prisoner. I stated I had had the money outside the beer-shop, and I said it when at the station-house, that his wife had given it to me.

ANN LEWIN . I live at 13, Nelson-street, Deptford, and am the wife of Edwin Lewin, a labourerâ€”the prisoner is my brotherâ€”on Saturday, 8th March, he came to me and said he had received a little money, and was going to buy some thingsâ€”he brought them to my house, and when the policeman came on the Monday I gave them up to himâ€”he left 8l. with me, and a lot of new clothes, half an hour before the police cameâ€”he told me he had been to receive a little moneyâ€”he had done so twice before, and I thought he had been again.

THOMAS DAVIS . I live in King-streetâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”on Satur
day, 8th March, he came to my place as a usual customerâ€”he was the worse for liquorâ€”he was with two or three partiesâ€”he had some clothes with him, and a hat boxâ€”he said he had had some money from a division in the familyâ€”I believed him, as I knew they had some property a few years agoâ€”I persuaded him to go homeâ€”I took him home, and he came back after
wards without anythingâ€”I changed a 10l. note for himâ€”he had money in his possession then, in a large port-monnaieâ€”I did not change the note for him thenâ€”he asked me to take care of it, and I did soâ€”on Sunday night he came in with a young man, and said, "Mr. Davis, will you lend me a sovereign?"â€”I did soâ€”on Monday he came in again, and asked me for another, and I gave him 9l. down at once, to get rid of it.

EDWARD FIELD BARBER . I keep the Dover Castle public-house, Broad
way, Deptfordâ€”on Saturday, 8th March, the prisoner and a man named Haynes came into my houseâ€”I was asked to change a 10l. note, with Haynes' name and address on itâ€”I afterwards changed anotherâ€”they had been over the way to the clothier's, and they came back and changed the 10l. note with meâ€”Haynes was with the prisoner at that time.

WILLIAM BUNCE . I am clerk to Mr. Smith, a coal merchant, at Green
wichâ€”about 8th March the prisoner came and ordered some coalsâ€”he offered in payment, to the best of my belief, a 10l. note.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "I have nothing to say any more than this, that Mrs. Roberts gave me the notes on Friday night. I was wrong in changing them. She threw them into the fire, and if it had not bean for me they would have been burnt."
Prisoner's Defence. She gave them to me on that night. Mrs. Roberts the worse for liquor. I spent the money.
COURT to MR. ROBERTS. Q. Was your wife the worse for liquor on that night? A. No; neither of us.
Prisoner. They were both the worse for liquor.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

490.
JOHN SAWYER (34),
Rape on
Margaret Cobley.

491.
JAMES ROBERT WILSON (34), and
JOSIAH CROWN (31),
Feloniously killing and slaying
John Smith.

DAVID BROMER . I am a private gentleman, of 9, Caroline-place, Camber
well-greenâ€”on the morning of 24th December, about 11 o'clock, I was in Camberwell-road; at the corner of Southampton-streetâ€”I saw an old gentle
man crowing the road I did not see him leave the pavement; he stood still and remained about the centre of the roadâ€”there was very great shouting, and I turned round and saw a gig approaching me from London towards Camberwell-green; it was about forty yards from the old gentleman when I first saw itâ€”the prisoners were in the gig and Wilton was driving at about twelve miles an hourâ€”they were shouting at the top of their voices in a very noisy manner, and when they had arrived within about twelve yards of the old gentleman they all but polled up and approached at a much slower rate, not exceeding seven or eight miles an hour; I should say about seven miles an hourâ€”the old gentleman stood still, hearing the shouting; and they ran over him; the off wheel went over himâ€”there was plenty of room on the other side of him for it to have passed without knocking him down; there was no vehicle in the road at all; there was much more room on one side of him than the otherâ€”it did not stop after it had run over him, but I stopped it; I seized the horse and took hold of the bitâ€”they pulled up within the length of the horse and gig, and I went and took hold of the bit and unbuckled the rein, as they tried to go onâ€”they first one got up and then another; they made a demonstration; I could not find a policeman, and I took them to the station-houseâ€”one got out of the gig first; they were very violent and would not leave go of the horse's headâ€”they were both drunkâ€”I took them to the station and charged them with being drunk and incapable, and they were locked upâ€”I am accustomed to driving; up to 1834, I always kept one or two horses for my own riding or driving, and I have had six or seven in my stableâ€”I did not know the old gentlemanâ€”I afterwards saw him dead at his house in January.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. (For Wilson). Q. What were you when you were driving these horses? A. A. gentlemanâ€”I am a civil engineer, and had the contracts for her Majesty's Military Roadsâ€”the old gentleman had left the kerb to go from the near side to the off side, and the prisoners were driving upon their own side of the way when I first saw them, but they were driving all manner of ways; they were not keeping so close to the near side as they ought; they were nearer to the near side than the offâ€”it is a very wide roadâ€”there was no vehicle to prevent them driving anywhereâ€”I have no animus in the caseâ€”the near wheel was, perhaps, seven or eight feet from the kerb when they struck himâ€”I have been a Government road-maker for yearsâ€”I have not also been a policemanâ€”the road is forty feet wideâ€”when I first saw the prisoners they were forty or fifty yards off, and were calling out at the top of their voicesâ€”the old

gentleman was in the road at that time, he was stepping off the kerb when I first heard them cry outâ€”there was plenty of time for him to cross if he had not stood still when he got to the centre of the roadâ€”he walked to the middle of the road and then stood still. but when he left the kerb, the gig was forty yards away from himâ€”when they began shouting to him he had just stepped from the kerb, and when they shouted he stood stillâ€”I was not in the least excited; I was as calm as I am nowâ€”I do not take stimulants; I am gene
rally calmâ€”when we got two-thirds of the way to the station-house they wanted to go back to see what was the matterâ€”when I seized the horse's head one jumped off, and I made the arrangement that if one would walk alongside of me the other should walk by the horse's head, but they would not, and I unbuckled the reinsâ€”they tried to drive over meâ€”I am on my oathâ€”they did not want to get back to see what bad happened to this poor man.

WILLIAM TWENTYMAN . I am a private gentlemanâ€”on 24th December, about 11 in the morning, I was near the corner of Southampton-street, Camberwell-road, and heard some peoplet calling outâ€”I saw the prisoners in a gig, going from the City towards Camberwell-greenâ€”I saw the old gentleman in the centre of the road, about sixty yards from the gig, which was going between eight and nine miles an hour, as near as I can guessâ€”it knocked the old gentleman down and passed over his footâ€”the shaft or the breast of the horse knocked him down; some part of the side of the vehicle or horseâ€”I did not see whether the prisoners slackened their pace at allâ€”the gig was stopped about four or five yards after knocking the old gentle
man downâ€”I cannot say whether it was stepped by any one, but I should say that the driver stopped itâ€”I then saw that the prisoners were drunk, Crown was the worst of the twoâ€”there was plenty of room for the gig to pass on either side of the old gentleman; there were very few vehicles in the road.

GEORGE DENINGTON . I was a policeman on 24th December, but am not nowâ€”I went from the station and met the prisonersâ€”I cannot positively say whether they were sober or drunk, for I saw very little of themâ€”they were charged with being drunk and incapable, and were detained at the stationâ€”I took them before the Magistrate at 3 o'clock in the afternoon; they were not taken before that, because they were drunk and incapable.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. Were they charged with being drunk and incapable by the first witness? A. Yes; but I saw very little of them, and therefore should not like positively to swear whether they were drunk or notâ€”I know a drunken man when I see himâ€”if I had seen them at the station I could have judged betterâ€”Mr. Wilson was not inca
pable of getting out of the gigâ€”I did not see any one carry him to the station.

HENRY NUTALL (Police-sergeant, P 17). On the morning of 24th Decem
ber, I was on duty at the stationâ€”the prisoners were brought there a few minutes before 11, charged with being drunk and incapable of taking care of their horse and gig, and driving over Mr. Smithâ€”they were both drunkâ€”they left the station at twenty minutes to 3 to go before the Magistrate; they were not sent before that because they were not in a fit state to go.

HARRIETTE ANN HURT . On 24th December, I was in the service of John Smith, who lived with his wife at 16, Avenue terrace, Avenue-road, Camber
wellâ€”he was 87 years of age, but not at all deaf, nor was be infirm for his ageâ€”he left home on that morning between 9 and 10 o'clock, and was rought home in a cab about 12 o'clock, having met with an accidentâ€”he remained ill till 27th January, and then died.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. Had he any relations? A. He had a daughter in the same house, but she was incapable of attending him; she is dead nowâ€”his collar-bone was broken, and his foot and arm were injuredâ€”the prisoners called once together to make inquiries about him, and Wilson called once or twice by himself, and he has sentâ€”I have not heard that a sum of money was arranged to be taken before the death.

CHARLES TAYLOR . I am a surgeonâ€”I attended Mr. Smith on 24th Decemberâ€”he died on 27th January from the injuries he had receivedâ€”his collar-bone was broken, his left arm and leg were injured, and the left side of his body generallyâ€”they were such injuries as would be inflicted by being knocked down by a horse.
Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. I suppose he died from exhaustion? A. From the injuries and old ageâ€”the injuries were themselves sufficient.
(MR. METACALFE appeared for CROWN.)
NOT GUILTY .

492.
JOHN GRANT (22), alias
GEORGE WRIGHT
, was indicted for
uttering counterfeit coin.

EDWARD BARLOW . I am the landlord of the Ridley Arms public-house, Kingslandâ€”on 19th February last the prisoner came there between 3 and 4 o'clock, called for half a pint of beer, and tendered a counterfeit shillingâ€”I told him it was had, and said, "Where did you get it?"â€”he said he had it in change for a half-crownâ€”I asked him if he had any other moneyâ€”he said, "No;" that was all he had leftâ€”I gave him into custody, marked the shilling, and gave it to the police-officer Luff.

DANIEL LUFF (Police-sergeant, N 7). On 19th February I took the prisoner, and received from the last witness this shillingâ€”I searched the prisoner, but found nothing on himâ€”he gave the name of Charles Williams, 2l, Glo'ster-street, Drury-laneâ€”he was taken to Kingsland police-station, and then to Worship-street, remanded till the 26th, again till 4th March, and then discharged.

JOSEPH MALPAS . I keep the Lord Nelson, Nelson-square, Blackfriar's roadâ€”the prisoner came there somewhere about two months before 10th Marchâ€”I served him with half a pint of beer, and he gave me a counterfeit sixpenceâ€”I gave him change, and he leftâ€”directly he was gone I found that the sixpence was badâ€”I had not mixed it with other moneyâ€”I kept it separate till 10th March, when the prisoner came againâ€”I knew him directlyâ€”he asked for a pint of beer, which was twopence, and gave a counterfeit shillingâ€”I sent for a police-constable and gave him into custody, and gave that shilling and the sixpence to the constable Crumpâ€”I said to the prisoner, "This is not the first time you have been; you have been here before and passed a bad sixpence"â€”he said nothingâ€”I am quite sure he is the man.
DAVID CRUMP (Policeman, M 290). The prisoner was given into my custody on 10th March, and Mr. Malpas gave me the counterfeit shilling and sixpenceâ€”I searched the prisoner, but found nothing on him.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to Her Msjesty's Mintâ€”these coins are all bad.
Prisoner's Defence. I am very near-sighted, almost blind, and I hope you will have mercy on me.
GUILTY .

p.hi: He was further charged with having been before convicted at this Court,

div1.p: on 17th December, 1860, of unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin, when he was sentenced to Twelve Months' imprisonment; to this he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Four Year's Penal Servitude.

493.
WILLIAM BROWN (22),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

EMMA STUTTART . I life at 9, Alfred-place, Spa-road, Bermondseyâ€”my mother keeps a greengrocer's shop thereâ€”on Monday, 24th February, the prisoner came in and I served him with two herringsâ€”he gave me shillingâ€”I gave him change and he leftâ€”I placed the shilling on the shelf, where there was no other moneyâ€”the same evening I served him with two haddocksâ€”he then gave me a two-shilling pieceâ€”I got change from my mother, gave it him, and he went awayâ€”I gave that two-shilling piece to my motherâ€”some time after, she gave me a two-shilling piece to get some butter withâ€”I took it to Mr. Johnson's, gave it to Mrs. Johnson, and she gave it me backâ€”it was badâ€”I took it back to my mother, and I then looked at the shilling that I had put on the shelf; and gave it to my motherâ€”that turned out to be badâ€”on 27th February I saw the prisoner again, when he was given into custodyâ€”I am sure he is the man who gave me those pieces of money.

JANE STUTTART . On Monday, 24th February, the prisoner was in my shop twiceâ€”on the first occasion he came for two herrings, and I gave my daughter change for some moneyâ€”on the second occasion he came in for two haddocks, and I gave her change for a two-shilling piece, which she gave me thenâ€”I afterwards saw a shilling on the shelfâ€”I sent her with the florin to get some butter, it was found to be bad, and she brought it back to meâ€”I put it in a bag and put it in my pocket by itselfâ€”on Thursday, 27th February, the prisoner came and asked for two herrings, and gave me a had shillingâ€”I tried it and told him it was badâ€”he said he was not aware of itâ€”I told him it was the fourth shilling he had brought me that weekâ€”I sent for a policeman and had him takenâ€”I gave the two shillings and the florin to the policeman.

Prisoner. I did not pass the florin or shilling at all. Witness. I am sure he is the manâ€”I feel satisfied that the florin I gave my daughter to go out with and buy the butter was the same she had given meâ€”I had no other in my possession.

ELIZA JOHNSON . I am a servant at a cheesemonger's, in Alfred-place, Spa-roadâ€”on Monday, 24th February, Emma Stuttart brought me a florin to pay for some butterâ€”it was bad, and I gave it her back.

EDWARD JAMES BROOKS (Policeman, M 222). On 27th February, I took the prisoner in custody, and received from Mrs. Stuttart these two counter
feit shillings and a counterfeit florinâ€”the prisoner said nothingâ€”I found nothing on him.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These coins are all bad, and the two shillings are from the same mould.
Prisoner. I was not aware the last shilling was bad.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

494.
JOHN NEALE (27), was indicted
for a like offence.

FANNY BUDD . I live at the Marquis of Wellington, Wellington-street, Dookheadâ€”a fortnight before 8th March, the prisoner came and asked for half a pint of porterâ€”I served him with it, and he gave me a bad shilling

â€”I told him it was a bad oneâ€”he said he was very sorry, he had taken it at the Docksâ€”he went awayâ€”I took back the porter, and kept the shilling and I put it on the shelfâ€”on 8th March, my sister Lucy called me to the barâ€”I went and found the prisoner thereâ€”he leftâ€”I saw his face, and knew him againâ€”from what my sister said to me, I followed and overtook him, and told him to come backâ€”he said, "Very well, ma'am"â€”I told him he had given me a bad shilling about a fortnight agoâ€”he said he had notâ€”I said he hadâ€”he went back with meâ€”my sister Luey then had a shilling in her handâ€”the prisoner attempted to take it from herâ€”I did not see whether he took it or notâ€”a constable was sent for, and he was given in custody, with the shilling and the shilling that he had given meâ€”it had been on the shelf since he gave it to meâ€”I cannot say that it was the same shillingâ€”it had been broken and defaced, so that I could not tell it.
Prisoner. I was never in the shop in my life.

LUCY BUDD . I am the sister of the last witnessâ€”on 8th March, the prisoner came, asked for half a pint of porter, and gave me a shillingâ€”I told him it was a bad oneâ€”I had sever seen him beforeâ€”I called my sister, and he ran away directly he saw her comeâ€”she went alter him, and he cane backâ€”I had the shitting in my handâ€”he said, "Let me look at it"â€”he snatched it out of my hand and broke itâ€”he threw one piece on the ground, and I had the restâ€”I kept them till my father came in, and I gave them to himâ€”I saw the constable receive themâ€”the prisoner gave me one penny for the beer; that was when I told him the shilling was bad, before he ran away.

Prisoner. Q. When I snatched the shilling out of your hand I gave it you back again? A. No; you threw one piece away and put the other on the counterâ€”I do not remember saying at the station that my sister thought you were the man.
JAMES M'CARTHY (Policeman, M 154). I took the prisoner in custody, and received from the last witness these two pieces of a shilling (produced)â€”I searched the prisoner and found nothing on him.
COURT. Q. Does he work at the Docks? A. No; he is a hawker.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are two pieces of a bad shilling.

Prisoner's Defence. It does not stand to reason that a man should go in and get one broken up, and then go in three or four weeks afterwards and get another broken up; what the witnesses have been saying is all false.

GUILTY.**â€ â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

495.
JOSEPH TARVOUL (27), and
JAMES GREEN (34),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

JANE BELL . I live at the Star beersbop, Webber-street, kept by my nephew, George Kingsmillsâ€”on Wednesday night, 26th February, Green came in with another person whom I could not swear to; but I believe it was Tarvoulâ€”I am quite positive as to Greenâ€”he asked ma for some aleâ€”I served him, and he gave me a 5s. pieceâ€”I had not sufficient change, and I sent Mrs. Carpenter for change for it, and she brought me changeâ€”I gave her the crown piece, and gave Green the change; and the two men, and two others who had come in after them and had a pint of ale, went away togetherâ€”on the following Saturday Mrs. Carpenter gave me back a crown piece, which I found was bad, and afterwards gave it to the constable Collinsâ€”I next saw Green, I think, four or five days after the 26th February, in the Holly Branch public-houseâ€”I pointed him out to the policemanâ€”I would swear to him.

Cross-examined by MR. PATER. Q. What do you do at the Star? A. It is in my care; I manage the business for my nephewâ€”no one was in the bar before the prisoner and the other came inâ€”Green appeared to be tipsyâ€”I saw him put some halfpence and a half-sovereign on the counterâ€”he was not helplessly drunk; in fact, I do not think he was tipsy, but only pre
tending, because be went out very quietlyâ€”I do not remamber a little girl coming into the shop or being sent out for anythingâ€”I swear Green gave me the 5s. piece on 26th February, and I took for the ale out of itâ€”I sent it in next door by a young man, a bedstead-maker, that uses the house, to get it changedâ€”he did not bring the change back; Mrs. Carpenter didâ€”the other two persons that I mentioned came in directly after the prisoners, while they were drinking the ale, and shook hands with them, and said, "Hallo, captain, are you going on board to-night?" and they said they did not knowâ€”I can only swear to oneâ€”they did not pay for anything; the four were all drink
ing the ale togetherâ€”the change was brought in whilst they were drinkingâ€”they had another pint of ale after that, and as soon as they drank it, they went outâ€”they did not sit down at allâ€”I was the only person present when they came inâ€”my nephew was not there.

MR. POLAND. Q. Did you give the crown piece to Mrs. Carpenter? A. No; I sent it in by a customerâ€”the prisoner stood at the bar at the timeâ€”the customer is not hereâ€”I should know the crown piece again if I saw itâ€”Mrs. Carpenter brought it me backâ€”I knew it to be she same that Green had given meâ€”I could swear to it.

ANN CARPENTER . I live in Webber-street, next door to Mrs. Bellâ€”on Wednesday, 26th February, I went into the Star to give change to Mrs. Bell for a crown pieceâ€”I put the crown pieoc in my purseâ€”I saw Green in there; I can swear to himâ€”I kept the crown piece in my purse till the following Saturdayâ€”it was mixed with shillings, but no other crownsâ€”on the Saturday I gave it to my husbandâ€”he brought it back to me the same dayâ€”I then looked at it, and found it was badâ€”I took it in to Mrs. Bell, and gave it to her; my husband had marked it.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you give it to your husband? A. On Saturday morning about 8 o'clock; he gave it me back about 11â€”I had kept it in a little port-monnaie, looked in a drawer, and I had the key in my pocketâ€”I put it in the drawer as soon aft I received itâ€”the drawer is always kept lockedâ€”it is looked now; the key is on a bunch at home, in a little drawerâ€”a man brought the crown piece to me to changeâ€”I could not swear to that man.

RICHARD CARPENTER . My wife gave me crown piece on Saturday, 1st Marchâ€”I took it to Billingsgate, and gave it in payment for some articles there; they gave it to me back, and I took it back to my wifeâ€”I marked it.
Cross-examined. Was that after you had been to Billingsgate? A. Yes.

WILLIAM HALE . I am a fisa-bawker, and live in Pear-street, Waterloo-roadâ€”on Monday evening, 3d March, I was at my stall, opposite the Carpenters' Arms beershop, in Lower Marsh, Lambethâ€”I saw both the prisoners there, a few yards from the beershopâ€”they were on the pavement, about twenty yards from each otherâ€”Green beckoned with his finger and walked away, and Tarvoul turned back and went into the Carpenters' Armsâ€”I afterwards saw the constable Collins go into the Carpenters' Arms, and I ran across from my stall, and told him what I had seenâ€”I found Tarvoul thereâ€”I had seen Green about before, but did not know his name.
ANN SMITH . I am the wife of Thomas Smith, who keeps the Carpenters'

Armsâ€”on 3d March Tarvoul came in and asked for some beer and tobacco; it came to 1 1/2 d.â€”I served himâ€”he gave me a half-crown in paymentâ€”I found it was bad, and told him soâ€”he said, "Is it?"â€”I sent for a constable and gave him in charge, with the half-crown, after marking itâ€”Hale came in at the time.

JOHN COLLINS (Policeman, L 184). On Monday evening, 3d March, I went to Mrs. Smith's beer shop, and Tarvoul was given into my custodyâ€”Mrs. Smith gave me this half-crown (produced)â€”I found 1d. on himâ€”I received a description from Hale, and took Green, on the 3d March, in the Holly Branch public-houseâ€”Mrs. Bell pointed him out to meâ€”the home was fullâ€”I told him that he was charged with passing a counterfeit crownâ€”Mrs. Bell showed it to him, and gave it to meâ€”he made no replyâ€”I found on him 4s. 4d. in silver and 3 1/4 d. in copper, all goodâ€”I took him about 6 o'clock; it was shortly after 5 when I took Tarvoul.
JANE BELL (re-examined.) This is the half-crown that Green gave me.
Cross-examined. Q. How do you know it? A. Here is the mark on it; I can swear it is the one I sent to Mrs. Carpenter.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These coins are both bad.

The prisoners' statements before the Magistrate were here read at follows:â€”Tarvoul says: "I did not know the half-crown was bad; I acknowledge uttering it. I never saw Smith before; he is a perfect stranger to me. I took the half-crown on Saturday night for some wood." Green says: "I never spoke a word to that man; I never saw him before. If I did go into Mrs. Bell's it is unknown to me; and whether I gave her a crown piece or not I do not know.
Tarvoul's Defence. I know nothing of this man; he is a perfect stranger to me. I did not know the half-crown was had.

TARVOULâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

GREENâ€”
GUILTY .

496.
JAMES GREEN was again indicted
for unlawfully uttering a counterfeit crown to
Jane Bell.
JANE BELL . (The evidence given by this witness in the former case was read over to her by the COURT, to which she assented.)
Prisoner. Q. Will you swear that that is the 5s. piece you gave to Mrs. Carpenter? A. Yes; and it is the one you gave me.

p.hi: The evidence of Ann Carpenter, Richard Carpenter, and John Collins, was read over to them, to which they assented.

div1.p: WILLIAM WEBSTER . This crown is bad.
Prisoner's Defence. If I knew it was bad, I should have thrown it away. Do you think I should stop there and have two more pints of ale? It had been through five or six different hands.
GUILTY .

p.hi: He was further charged with having been before convicted at this Court, is the name of John Marshall, in January, 1855, when he received a sentence of Eighteen Months' imprisonment; to which he

div1.p:
PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Four Years Penal Servitude.

497.
WILLIAM LAWSON (42), was indicted
for Embezzlement.
SAMUEL WADKIN . I am in the service of Mr. Lange, tailor and draper, at Rotherhitheâ€”the prisoner succeeded me as shopman in that employmentâ€”

he entered the service on Saturday, 29th Marchâ€”whatever he told was to be entered and accounted for to me, and with reference to the money be was to account to me for it, and put it in the cash-bookâ€”he had been told that by Mr. Lange in my presence, and I told him tooâ€”I recollect leaving the prisoner in charge of the premises on the 30th March, from 2 o'clock in the Afternoon till 9 at nightâ€”when I came home at 9, I asked him if he had said anythingâ€”he said, "No"â€”I looked in the book and found no entryâ€”he did not account to me on that night for 1s. or 2s. 6d.â€”I have seen the pocket-handkerchief; the price of that was 2s. 6d.; it had a ticket on in for that amountâ€”the scarf was 1s.

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. Mr. Lange has another shop, has he not? A. Yes; at Trinity-square, Tower-hillâ€”he does not attend to the shop at Rotherhitheâ€”I do not know whether I was to have leftâ€”the arrangement about the prisoner coming into the service was made between him and Mr. Lange.

CHRISTIAN REINSON . I am a carpenter on board the barque Oxfordâ€”I saw the prisoner on 30th March at the door of his master's shopâ€”he said, "Is there anything you wish to buy to-day"â€”I went in and bought a necktieâ€”I paid 1s. for it to the prisonerâ€”this is it (produced.)
Cross-examined. Q. Was there anybody else there at the time? A. No, no other shopman.

JOHN MOSS . I am a seaman on board a barge at the Commercial Docksâ€”on 30th March I went into the prosecutor's shop at Rotherhitheâ€”I saw the prisoner there, and bought this silk handkerchief of him for 3s., he wanted 3s. 6d.
Cross-examined. Q. You took the handkerchief back afterwards, did you not? A. Yes; to have it hemmed, and I left it there with the prisoner and came back for it at 6 o'clock.

DANIEL LANGE . I am a draper, residing at 5, Trinity-square, Tower-hillâ€”the prisoner came into my service on 29th Marchâ€”he was told he was to enter every article he sold into a book directly he received the money, and put the money in the tillâ€”he has not accounted to me for the sum of 1s., 2s. 6d., or 3s., for a handkerchiefâ€”the price of the handkerchief was 2s. 6d.

Cross-examined. Q. You do not reside at Rotherhithe? A. No, it was the prisoner's duty to take charge of that shopâ€”the other young man, who had been there, was not to leave; he was to be clerk there as well as in the other shop, to look over the thingsâ€”the prisoner entered my service at 1l. a week, and five per cent, commissionâ€”he was to account to me or my clerk every dayâ€”it was not understood that he was to deduct his wages from sums that he receivedâ€”I never asked him for this 1s. and 3s.â€”he had to keep the booksâ€”I looked over the goods every day or every other dayâ€”I went to Rotherhithe every other day, when I could spare time, if they were busy, I should be there every dayâ€”the prisoner was given into custody by me for Embezzling this money.

HENRY KELLY (Policeman, M 55). On Tuesday week, 1st April, I took the prisoner into custodyâ€”I told him that Mr. Lange accused him of selling some goods and not entering them in the books or accounting for the moneyâ€”he stated that he did sell some handkerchiefs, but it was only 3s. 6d., and the reason he kept the money was, he wanted to have a shilling in his pocketâ€”I searched him and found this handkerchief upon him.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

498.
WILLIAM LAWSON was again indicted
for stealing, on 30th March, 1 handkerchief, the property of
Daniel Lange, his master, upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

499.
ALFRED REPATH (28),
Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Joseph Braidbeer, and stealing therein 1 shawl, 1 coat, 1 curtain, 12 knives, 12 forks, and 11 spoons, his property.

RUTH BRADBEER . I am the will of Joseph Bradbeerâ€”our house is in the parish of St. Mary, Lambethâ€”on 11th March last I was awoke by a policeman at a quarter to 5 in the morningâ€”on coming downstairs I found the parlour window brokenâ€”some person had entered; taken a coat, shawl, ten teaspoons, a dozen knives and forks, or it might have been more, and a curtain, which us attached to the windowâ€”I used some of the knives and forks at 10 o'clock the night before for supperâ€”they were placed on the window-sill in a basketâ€”the shawl and coat were hanging up behind the door on a pegâ€”I have seen half a down teaspoons and three forks sinceâ€”these are them (produced)â€”I bought these two forks the day before, from a person next doorâ€”this one I have had ten yearsâ€”this spoon I have had quite as long as the forkâ€”those I bought of a man about three weeks before the robbery, and used them dailyâ€”I saw these things at a wardrobe shop facing the Victoria Theatre, where they buy second-hand clothes and different thingsâ€”the forks were at a marine-store dealer'sâ€”I saw those on the same day as I saw the others; the Friday after the robberyâ€”the curtain was with the spoonsâ€”this is my shawl (produced)â€”I know it by having it dyed, and by the plaid I see in itâ€”this is my curtainâ€”I saw it the evening before the robberyâ€”I fastened the window myself at a quarter-past 12, and bolted all the doorsâ€”no glass was broken at that timeâ€”I know the prisoner by his coming to my place and sleeping with his fatherâ€”his father was a lodger for sixteen weeksâ€”the prisoner was often to and fro during that timeâ€”the father often brought him to sleep thereâ€”I saw him frequentlyâ€”he came to me last Friday, the 4th, and said that he had heard that I had lost these things; that he had bought them of a man and woman, and he felt very unhappy after he had heard they belonged to me, as I had been so kind to him and his father; and he came to give himself up, and hoped I would forgive himâ€”I said I could not think of doing that, I wanted my shawl, which was a present, and I set great value on itâ€”he said he would give me ten shillings to buy a new shawl.

Prisoner. Q. The first words that you said were, "Hallo, what do you do here?" A. Yes; I did not tell you what I had lostâ€”you said you were very unhappyâ€”you must have known this shawl belonged to me.

ANN GARRATT . I am the wife of Charles Garratt, of 17, Webber-street, Southwarkâ€”we keep a marine-store shopâ€”I saw the prisoner first at the station-houseâ€”I did not know him before thenâ€”I never saw him before 11th Marchâ€”he came to me about that time, and said be had got some knives and forks to sellâ€”I asked him if they were his own, and whether he got them honestlyâ€”he said, "Yes; particularly honest;" he was out of em
ployment, and he was very sorry that he had got them to sell; he was very sorry to do itâ€”he said they were hisâ€”he asked me 1s. 6d. for them, and I gave him 1s.â€”those that I gave to the police are the same I had from himâ€”I did not buy the curtain and the coatâ€”this was about 11 o'clock in the morning.
RICHARD HARRIS . I am assistant to a pawnbroker, of 82, Marsh Lane, Lambethâ€”I took this shawl in on 11th Marchâ€”it was left by a womanâ€”the prosecutor came to identify it.

SAMUEL WATTS (Policeman, L 77). The prisoner was given into my charge on 4th April by Mrs. Bradbeerâ€”I told him the chargeâ€”he said he acknowledged selling the goodsâ€”I asked him what goodsâ€”he said, "Mrs. Bradbeer's knives and forks, and curtain"â€”he said he did not pledge the shawl, he got a female that he knew to pledge it, he bought all the goods of a man and woman opposite the Olive Branch public-house, New Cutâ€”he said he knew nothing about breaking into the house whatever.

Prisoner's Defence. I have learnt a trade since I have been a convict. I have had four years' imprisonment, and twelve months for robbery, and ever since I came out of prison I have been at work. I believe this policeman can say that he has seen me coming from work at half-past 6 in the evening. I was working for Mr. Davis, and for a gentleman who is now in Horse-monger-lane. I have not associated with any bad characters. I turned over a new leaf twelve months before I came home. I gave myself up, I never had a better friend than Mrs. Bradbeer. My father bad been out of work sixteen weeks, and she kept him, aad she gave me victuals while I was in the hospital I saw Mr. Davis the other day, and he said be would give me a character.

GUILTY**â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

500.
CHARLES BASSETT (38),
HENRY STOKES (30),
HENRY TIMOTHY GRAY (63), and
JAMES KEMPSTER (46),
Stealing 5 tons weight of rope, 2cwt of spun yarn, 1 cwt. of lead lines, and 1cwt. of manilla, of the
London Ropery Company (Limited), the masters of Bassett and Stokes.

GEORGE HOUNSELL . I am a clerk in the employ meal of the London Bopery Company (Limited)â€”their warehouse is at Rotherhithe, and the manufactory at the Jamaica Level, Bermondseyâ€”the prisoners Bassett and Stokes were in our employment; Stokes as foreinau and Baasett, as under-foremanâ€”they both lived on the premises in Jamaica Levelâ€”Stokes had the keys of the placeâ€”on 20th February last I was shown a quantity of rope by the police-officer Hughes at the police-stationâ€”I have identified it as the property of the Companyâ€”we have also some rope that was in the possession of Mr. Vane and Mr. Willisâ€”I identify that also.

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. (For Gray). Q. Who was the manager of this Company at this time? A. Mr. Morgan; and he is stillâ€”I keep the Company's books at the worksâ€”I am aware that the Company have lost some 2,000l. worth of ropeâ€”I arrived at that fact by the aid of an accountantâ€”we went through the whole of the books since the last stock-takingâ€”I do not know whether the Company gave a bill of sale on their property a short time agoâ€”I am the clerk, And do not know what they do in that wayâ€”not long back they sent aa amount of rope to the City Roadâ€”that was a long time after the 2,000l. which we lostâ€”that tranaaetion was entered in the booksâ€”the manager is not here.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Has the manager been suspended by the Company? A. Yesâ€”be is under an agreement with themâ€”he must remain their trade manager for another month, though his powers of buying and selling have been annulled by advertisement in the Timesâ€”he cannot do any work at presentâ€”I do not know whether he drinks very hardâ€”I do not know any
thing about himâ€”notice has been given to the public that he is suspended from buying and selling.

JOHN TIMOTHY HUGHES (Policeman, M 249). On 20th February I ob
tained a search warrant, and went to the prisoner Kempster's premisesâ€”they

are a stable, in Smith's-place, Dockhead, with broad folding doors, at which a cart can go inâ€”the shop is some distance from there, in another streetâ€”he keeps a small shop in Charles-Street about a hundred yards from there, and carries on a coal and chandlery businessâ€”At the other place there are two horses, I think, and a cartâ€”there is no appearance of any dealing in rope being carried on thereâ€”I saw Kempster peter when I went thereâ€”I told him I had a warrant to search his premises for some ropeâ€”he replied,"I have got no rope, and never had"â€”he went with me to the stable, and unlocked it when I asked himâ€”behind the cart there was a heap of grass matsâ€”I removed them, and be
tween two beer barrels and the wall, there were two coils of ropeâ€”I called his attention to itâ€”I said, "This is rope, yon know; where did you get it from?" he said, "I took it from a man who owed me some money;" I said, "Who is he?" he said, "Don't know;" I said, "Where does he live?" he said, "I do not know;" I said, "If you will give me his name and address I will leave an officer in charge of the place and you, while I go and make inquiries;" he said, "I know nothing about him;" I then said, "I must take you in custody; "which I did, and took him and the rope to the stationâ€”that is the rope that I showed to Mr. Hounsellâ€”Stokes saw it at the police-courtâ€”we went before a Magistrate, and Stokes was there as a witness to identify the rope, and did so, and then the case was remanded for further inquiries.

ALFRED SANDELL . I am a labourer, living at 19, Edward-street, Dock-headâ€”I know Kempster's place, at the back of the Catholic Chapel, Ber
mondseyâ€”it is a coal shed and chandler's shopâ€”about half-past 7 in the evening of 18th February, I saw Stokes and Bassett go to Kempeter's shopâ€”they were in there about a minuteâ€”Kempster came out with themâ€”law them separateâ€”Bassett and Stokes went towards their own home, the ropery worksâ€”next morning, about a quarter to 9, I saw Kempster's van coming by the shop, loaded with ropeâ€”it was driven by a man named Wardâ€”I followed it to the George public-house, Commercial-roadâ€”Bassett was follow
ing 500 yards, I dare say, behind the van.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. (For Kempster). Q. Have you lived any length of time in the neighbourhood? A. Yes; ever since I can recollect; and Kempster has been living there as long as I can recollectâ€”his wife manages the chandler's shop and the coal shed; and be has a stable in Smith's-place, and a van, and cart, and two horsesâ€”he attends to business as a carmanâ€”it was some weeks before I said anything about thisâ€”I do not know whether it was as much as three weeksâ€”I did not say anything about it till the detective called on me; I think it was three weeks afterwards.

Bassett. Q. What was your intention in following the van that morning? A. Because Ward asked me if I would come with himâ€”I was following the van myselfâ€”I was not 500 yards offâ€”I was not 40 yards behind you.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Were you behind him? A. No; I was on the other side of the pavement, walking very near, even with him; I was nearly 500 yards behind the cart.

JOHN WARD . I live at 3, Fly-court, Dockheadâ€”on 18th February I was working for Kempster, as carmanâ€”I took the cart with some rope that even
ingâ€”my missus, between 7 and 8 o'clock, told me to take the cart and load some furniture between 8 and 9â€”I was then in the shopâ€”I had come in and asked for the keyâ€”in consequence of that, I took the cart to the Green Man public-house, which is right facing the warehouse of the Ropery Companyâ€”I waited there about twenty minutesâ€”my orders were to wait thereâ€”at the end of the twenty minutes Bassett came to me, and told me to back in

when he unlocked the gateâ€”he did not tell me what gate, or point out any gateâ€”I did not know what gateâ€”I saw the factory gate open a few minutes afterwards, and I backed inâ€”I did what Bassett told me to do, because I was ordered to go down there, and wait till some one came to me, and to obey their directionsâ€”when I had backed in, I and Bassett loaded up about a ton and a half of rope, and then he told me it was too late to take it away that night, I had better take it round to Kempster's stables that night, and take it away in the morningâ€”I look it to the stableâ€”I did not see my master that night: I did the next morning, and asked him where it was to go toâ€”he said he did not know, he believed to the George, in Commercial-road, and wait till tome one came to meâ€”I drove it down to the George, and a man, whom I know now to be Evans, came to me, and told me to follow himâ€”we went down Commercial-road, and turned down into Broad-street, Ratcliffâ€”Evans went into the Stone Stairs public-house at the corner, and called Gray out, and a man named Bigfordâ€”then they went into a shop opposite Mr. Vane's or Mr. Willis's, I won't be sure whichâ€”then they told the young man to pick what he liked out of the van, and he ulti
mately bought someâ€”I handed it out, and it was taken into the shopâ€”then we went to another shop, and they would not buy it, and then we went to Mr. Vane's and the rest was all taken thereâ€”Bigford went with us to the other shop, and waited in the public-house until they came outâ€”then I un
loaded the rope, and came home with the vanâ€”no one told me to come homeâ€”when I got home I saw my masterâ€”he asked me where I had been, and I told himâ€”he did not say anything thenâ€”I have, at other times, seen rope is Kempster's premises, in the place where they kept the Tans and cartsâ€”I have seen about three tons there, not oftenâ€”I saw it when I first went to work there, which was two or three months before Christmas; and then I and Mr. Kempster took it down to Mr. Leary's, into his shed, and left it thereâ€”Mr. Kempater went with me thenâ€”that was after I had been there about a month, I should think; somewhere about November or Decemberâ€”there was none left in the shed then, that I am aware ofâ€”it was lying there when I first wentâ€”when I got to Leary's, besides Leary and Kemster I saw Bassett, and the man I believe to be Stokes; but I should not like to swear to himâ€”they came out of the coffee-shop, which Leary keepsâ€”I do not know the name of the streetâ€”I should not like to say it was Stokes who came out with Bassettâ€”I think one was Bassettâ€”they went down to the abed, unloaded the cart there, and I brought it awayâ€”they helped to unload this load of rope that I had takenâ€”the man I took to be Stokes did not un
load; but he was standing not far offâ€”I left the van for my master.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Kempster is a carman, and drives himself occasionally, does he not? A. Yesâ€”he is out from home a great deal, and in his absence his wife takes ordersâ€”I saw Kempster the morning after the rope was taken to the stableâ€”when I asked him the name of the man who was to come to me, he odd he did not know, for he did not see the manâ€”I returned about 1 o'clock in the day, and saw Kempsterâ€”he asked me what had made me so long, and I told him where I had been toâ€”he asked me who came to me, and I said I had been waiting at the shop to unloadâ€”I told him I did not know the man who came to meâ€”I went into Kempster's service about two or three months beforeâ€”when I first went, there was rope on the premises, and it remained there about a month, or it might be a little longer, before any of it was taken awayâ€”Kempster then had one van, and two carts and horses.
JURY. Q. Was the rope exposed, or covered up with anything, during
the whole of the month? A. Lying open, with tome grass mats over it, which, I believe, were given to Kempsterâ€”he did not sell mats.
COURT. Q. Did they cover the rope? A. Yes; very nearly all overâ€”any one could see, on entering the shed, that there was a quantity of rope there.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Were there any beer barrels? A. I believe there were twoâ€”it was in front of the beer barrels; stowed alongside of thernâ€”the yard gates do not lock; they are often open; they have to be open when we shove the van or anything inâ€”there are two gates to the shed; they open direct into the streetâ€”we could not open the one without opening the other, if we were going to put anything inâ€”they are generally kept locked, except when a van or cart, or anything is going inâ€”this is quite an enclosed place.

THOMAS MARSHALL . I live at 41, Heath-street, Stepneyâ€”I have known Gray some timeâ€”on 19th February 1 bought 10cwt. 3qrs. and some pounds of rope of himâ€”I paid him 18l. 9s. 9d. for itâ€”I have about 7cwt. of it left, which I showed to Mr. Hounsellâ€”this is the receipt Gray gave meâ€”(Read: "February 19th, 1862.â€”Mr. Willis, bought of Mr. Gray, 10cwt. 3qrs. 141bs. of cordage, at 34s.â€”18l. 9s. 9d.â€”Paid, H. T. Gray.")

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q, Who wrote this receipt? A. A person that was with Mr. Grayâ€”I paid him with three 5l. notesâ€”I cannot say whether the rest was in small change or half sovereignsâ€”I did not know who it was with Mr. Gray, nor have I since ascertainedâ€”he did not hand the money to Gray in my presence, I did not see what he did with itâ€”they went out together.

EDWARD MARRIOTT VANE . I live at Bromley-street, Stepney, and assist my father in carrying on business as a ship-riggerâ€”on 19th February, about 10 o'clock in the morning, as near as I can say, Gray came alone, and said he had a quantity of rope to sell, and wanted us to purchase itâ€”I told him we had bought largely, and did not want any rope, and had also entered into contracts besidesâ€”he said the rope was made for a person that had disappointed him, and my mther then called me into his office, and, after some conversation with him, he said, "Well, there is poor old Gray; he appears to be very much broken down in life; what does he want?"â€”I explained what he wanted, and then told Gray that if he liked to bring the rope I would look at itâ€”I then asked him his priceâ€”he first wanted us to go and look at itâ€”I did not ask him where it wasâ€”I told him we would not go and look at it; that if he thought fit to bring it we would look at it and value it, and tender him a price for it; that, in consequence of his condition, we should feel inclined to buy it of himâ€”he then told us the price was 36s.â€”I told him we could not give any such priceâ€”I know nothing further of it but that when I returned at a quarter to I, I saw the rope thereâ€”I then saw this bill and receipt (produced,) and saw the price which was given for itâ€”I saw about 12cwt. of new rope and upon yarn.
Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. Was any one with Gray at this time? A. No oneâ€”I have not known him some time but my father has for many years.

JOHN VANE . I assist my father, in Marion-street, Batcliffâ€”I was present on 19th February, when Gray brought the ropeâ€”he made out the bill and receipted it, and I paid himâ€”I wrote out this cheque for 19l. 4s.â€”no one was with him when he cameâ€”he did bring the bill already written outâ€”he wrote it himself in my presenceâ€”(Cheque read: "Messrs. Prescot, Grote,

and Co., pay Mr. Gray, or bearer, 19l. 4s. Indorsement. H. Gray." (Bill read: "No. 1, Prospect-place, Cambridge-heathâ€”19th February, 1862â€”Mr. Vane, bought of H. T. Gray, to cordage, 12cwt. at 32s. 19l. 4s., settled same time. Paid H. T. Gray" On a stamp).
Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Have you any experience with respect to rope and cordage? A. None whateverâ€”I have only been in the business twelve months.

JOHN BIGFORD . I live at 11, Rose-lane, Commercial-road East, and am a dealer in tar and other articlesâ€”Gray called on me in February, and said there was a ropemaker over the water who was in difficulty, and had some rope which he wanted to turn into ready moneyâ€”he asked me if I knew any one who was likely to buy itâ€”I said, "I do business for Mr. Willis; he is a ready-money gentleman; he always pays ready money, and if he wants any I dare say he will buy some of you," and then he went up to seeâ€”I spoke to the foreman before the rope came, and introduced Gray to Mr. Willie's foremanâ€”he came again the morning that the rope came, 19th Februaryâ€”he walked up, and said the rope would be there about 10 or 11 o'clock, and walked up to the Stone Stairs public-house, opposite Mr. Willis'sâ€”the rope came, and Evans with itâ€”I do not recollect who fetched Gray out; very likely it was Evansâ€”I think I went to Willis's door and said, "Well, you can see Mr. Gray and do business, because I know nothing about rope"â€”I then went to the public-house, and Gray came there to me afterwards, and gave me 18s. or 19s.; 19s. I believeâ€”that was half the com
mission which he said he would give me for my introduction.

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. Did you see him with a cheque in his hand? A. Yes; he gave it to Evansâ€”I could not swear to the cheque; I did not know the amount of itâ€”I could not be positive, but to the best of my knowledge, this is itâ€”I have known him a good many yearsâ€”he sells rope on commission.

FRANCIS LEARY . I am a general dealer, and keep a coffee-house at 175, Rotherhithe-streetâ€”Mr. Vare keeps the Ship public-house, Queen-street, Rotherhitheâ€”in December last he, Bassett and Stokes, came to sell me some new ropeâ€”Bassett spokeâ€”he said he had a quantity of new rope for sale, and it laid at Dockhead, at the back of the Catholic chapelâ€”I know that now as being Kempster's placeâ€”he made an appointment with me to meet him at the Sugar Loaf, Dockhead, to look at itâ€”I went there, and went to Kempster's stables, where I saw about two tons of new rope, as near as I can calculateâ€”Bassett went to Kempster's shop and got the keys to open the stable doorâ€”on inspecting the rope Bassett asked 60l. for itâ€”I offered 46l.; he refused that, and I gave him a week to considerâ€”a night or two after that they all three called on me again, and Bassett said they had come down to do business with me one way or the other, they wished to dispose of the ropeâ€”they agreed to take 46l.â€”they were to bring it down between 9 and 10 the following morning, 10th Decemberâ€”the next morning, between 9 and 10, it came by a van and a cartâ€”a man, whom I do not know, and a lad were with the cartâ€”Mr. Vare paid the 46l. to Stokes, and Stokes gave this receiptâ€”this, in the name of Wood, is the one written by Stokesâ€”he wrote this bill and receipt in my presenceâ€”I sold the rope for 58l. 16s., and it has gone abroadâ€”(Receipt read: "10th December, 1861; received from Mr. Francis Leary the sum of 46l., for a quantity of lines and cordage. Received, H. Wood.")
Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. When you went to the stable, did you see Kempster there at all? A. No.

WILLIAM VARE . I keep the Ship public-house, Queen-street, Rotherhitheâ€”in November last a man named Evans called on me about a purchase of ropeâ€”I afterwards went with him to Leary's, where he showed me a sample of ropeâ€”a month after that Stokes and Bassett came to meâ€”I did not ask them their names; they did not call themselves by any name to meâ€”they said they had about two tons of rope for saleâ€”they both spoke togetherâ€”they said they made it, and they asked me to buy itâ€”I said I did not understand rope myself, but I would introduce them to a friendâ€”I introduced them to Mr. Leary, and heard an appointment made with him to meet for the purpose of seeing the rope at Dockheadâ€”I saw Mr. Leary when he came back from there, and had an appointment to meet them on the evening of the 9thâ€”they came on 9thâ€”I saw the bargain made for the rope, and heard that it was to be brought on the following morningâ€”it was brought next morning, in a van and cart, by a man and a boyâ€”I advanced 46l., and saw this bill and receipt given by Stokes.
stokes. Q. Did not Mr. Evans bring me to your house that night? A. On the first commencement of it?

COURT. Q. Did Evans carry on the conversation? A. No, Stokesâ€”I had never seen the two men beforeâ€”they spoke to me; not Evansâ€”Evans brought the sample of rope and introduced the two men to me, but I never saw him afterwards.

CHARLES DAY . I bought the rope of Mr. Leary, and sold it on conm
mission, to a person who has gone abroad.

JAMES TURNER . I am a shipbroker, of 79, Great Tower-streetâ€”I have known Gray since November last; he came to me in December and asked me if I would buy any ropeâ€”I said if it was cheap I wouldâ€”he said that the price was 36s.â€”I said that, before I could buy it, I must send some person competent to judge of its quality, to look at it, and I sent Mr. Robert Gilchrist to examine itâ€”Gray and Gilchrist met at my office, and went over to look at it, and then Gilchrist came back and reportedâ€”Gray was not present thenâ€”Gray afterwards came back again, and I offered 30s. for itâ€”he would not to take less than 34s.; he then came down to 32s. and then took 30s.â€”he had told me it was to be seen at Benmondsoyâ€”this is the card he gave me to view it. Read: "J. Kempster, carman, 4, Charles-street, Parker's-road, Dockhead, bottom of Tooley-street. Goods carefully removed by spring van or cart. Please let the bearer see the cordage, J. T. Gray, 4th December, 1861."

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. Was Evans present? A. No; I never saw him in my lifeâ€”I know that Gray deals on commissionâ€”I have been in the trade thirty yearsâ€”I am not a pretty good judge of ropeâ€”I have been in the shipping tradeâ€”I did not exercise any judgment about the priceâ€”Gilchrist saw the ropeâ€”I told Gray I should like to see it if I had a customer, and it was in consequence of that that this card came to meâ€”Gray had urged me very much about his terms, and wanted me to let him have a commissionâ€”he said he generally had oneâ€”he appeared to be an honest man, and I thought he was acting as a commission agentâ€”I asked him if there was anything wrong or the slightest suspicion about it, as it was rather a low price, and he said that there was not; that it was simply the ordinary case of a man wanting to dispose of an article that he wanted to raise money on.

ROBERT SHAFTO GILCHRIST . I live at Northampton-villas, Tottenham, and am a sail makerâ€”early in December last, I went to Mr. Turner's counting-house, in Great Tower-street, and there saw Grayâ€”Mr. Turner

said "This is Mr. Gray; he will take yon to where the rope is," and. I went with him to Bermondsey, and found the rope in a stable, which I have since found to be Kempster'sâ€”I examined it and came away with Gray, and the other two parties, whose names did not transpire, a short distance, and there left themâ€”one of those parties joined us in Tower-street; he accosted Mr. Grayâ€”he was a stout man, whose name I have since heard is Evans, and afterwards another man joined us, who I do not knowâ€”he was standing by a public-house, and we all went down, and I examined the ropeâ€”I said that it was worth 46s. to 50s. all through and some of it 60s. a cwt.

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. Was it very heavily tarred? A. Some of itâ€”I should think rope in that state would be more difficult to dispose of than ordinary rope in a proper stateâ€”Gray was the person who took me there, and the stout man answered me about the priceâ€”I cannot say that he appeared to be the master, and to exercise authority over the ropeâ€”then I spoke, Evans answered me.
Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Was any part of the rope you saw called spun yarn? A. Yes; a few cwt. of it, I should thinkâ€”there was nothing particular about the manufacture of it.

JAMES MORRISON GILCHRIST .
