I am the captain of a merchant vessel, and live in Willoughby-terrace, Stockwellâ€”I am the brother of the last witnessâ€”I went with him in the early part of December to Kempster's shop and stableâ€”the first day I went I saw no one but Mrs. Kemspterâ€”I had some conversation with herâ€”I did not see any rope on that occasionâ€”about two days afterwards I was in Tower-street, and a strange man came up to meâ€”I do not know now who he is; he is not hereâ€”in consequence of what he said, I went over to Kempeter's stable with him, and saw a quantity of rope; I think from three to fire tons, by the appearanceâ€”it was in a stable or cart shed, covered over with bags, mats, and some stable refuse, strawâ€”from what I saw of it I formed an idea that it was the make of the London Ropery Companyâ€”I could not be certain, but I was so sure that I intended telling the Company as soon as I saw themâ€”I have frequently handled quantities of their ropeâ€”I served my time with a rope maker, previous to going to sea, and I understand it perfectlyâ€”I was called to Liver-pool for five weeks, and after I returned Mr. Spratt, the Company's traveller, called on me, and I communicated what I had seen.
Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. You did not see Kempster at all? A. No.

Stokes. Q. How can you tell the London Ropery's manufacture from any other? A. They have been manufacturing some very poor rope; that is the way I know itâ€”they have lately, for the last year or two, and even in Mr. Morgan's time, put a large quantity of tar in it and a great deal of Russian yarnâ€”I found both these things in itâ€”it is rope of an inferior qualityâ€”I know other persons who use a great quantity of Russian yarn in their rope, but not of so inferior a kind.

HENRY SMITH . I am a sergeant of the detective policeâ€”on 10th March, I saw Stokes at a public-house close to the Company's worksâ€”I called him out and said I wanted to speak to himâ€”I told him my name was Smith, that I was a sergeant of the detective police, and I wanted to ask him some questions relating to seme rope which had been stolen from over the way, but he could do as he thought proper about answeringâ€”I then said, "I have been told you were down at Mr. Kempster's on the evening of 18th February, with Bassett"â€”he said, "No; I was not; I was never there in my life"â€”I said, "Do you know Kempster?"â€”he said, "Yes; I never

saw him till I went up to give evidence against him at the police-court"â€”I asked if he had ever employed Mr. Kempster to remove any rope, or any
thing from the factoryâ€”he said, "No"â€”I said, "I have been told, that about two tons was taken out by Kempster's van on the evening of 18th February"â€”he said, "No, that could not be; if one coil of it had been gone off the premises I must have missed it"â€”I told him I did not belive the account he gave me of it; I must take him into custody for stealing, with Bassett, a quantity of rope, the property of the London Ropery Companyâ€”(Bassett was not present)â€”he said, "The Company are rogues and thieves; they have robbed themselves, and now they want to lay it upon me, and the books will prove it; there was a great deal more went out than ever came in on the premises; which they know"â€”I was on the premises on the previous Saturday, the 8th, and he then put to the gates and showed at how he fastened them at nightâ€”he said he locked up at 6 o'clock, and always took charge of the keys himself every nightâ€”on 12th March I saw Grayâ€”I followed him from his home into the Cityâ€”I told him, I "am a sergeant of police, and I want to ask you some questions about some ropes which has been stolen, the property of the London Ropery Company"â€”I asked where he got the rope from that he sold on the 19th to Mr. Marshall, of Broad-street, Ratcliffâ€”he said he had not sold Iâ€”I said, "Where did you get it from?"â€”he said, "From a man named Wilson or Evans"â€”I asked him what business Mr. Wilson or Evans was, and where he livedâ€”he said he did not know; he should knew him again if he saw him; he met him sometimes in the Cityâ€”I said, "I have seen the receipt you gave Mr. Marshall for the money for the ropeâ€”he said, MI did not sell it; a man named Bigfbrd sold itnâ€”I asked what business Bigford was, and when he livedâ€”he said in Horseferry-street or Rose-street, St. George's-in-the-Eastâ€”I asked where he got the rope from which he sold to Vane the same morningâ€”he said from the same man, Wilson or Evansâ€”he said Bigfbrd sold it, and received the moneyâ€”I said, "That can't be; there is your name on the receipt"â€”he said, "Bigford sold it, and not me"â€”I then told him I did not believe the account he had given me, and I should take him into custody for stealing this rope, in connexion with men named Bassett and Stokesâ€”he afterwards said thst he had sold it by commission, and had 19s. for his troubleâ€”I found this card on him, "W. Hinchiffe, wholesale dealer in corn flour; Kempster, Parkers-road, Dockhead;" on the badt of it is, "4, Charles-street, Dockhead, total, 163cwt. 30th November, 1861, Clapton, Lea-bridg"â€”I also found on him this letter. Read: "18th February. Dear Sir, I have a purchaser for six to eight tons of rope; I hear the same man has some on hand; look out, and let me know at once. James Turner."

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Q. You knew Evans, do you not? A. No; I know there is such a manâ€”I do not know thai his name is Thomas Wilson Evansâ€”I never heard him called soâ€”I have only heard of Thomas Evansâ€”I have never seen this bill until nowâ€”I have been the officer con
ducting a portion of this caseâ€”Gray did not tell me that Evans was employed by Pickering, Dyer, and Co. of Bow-commonâ€”when he mentioned the man who sold it, he said Wilson or Evans, not Wilson Evansâ€”I am quite sure about thatâ€”he said he received 19s. for his troubleâ€”he did not say anything half commissionâ€”I am quite positive that he said he always locked up and kept the keysâ€”that was on the Saturday, when I went on purpose to make myself acquainted with the premises.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Have you been eudeavouring to find Evans? A. Yes I have, but have not been ableâ€”I have been to some places, and Hughes has been to others, where it was at all likely to find him.

JOHN TIMOTHY HUGHES . (Re-examined.) I apprehended Bassett on 10th March, about 9 in the evening, at the Company's premisesâ€”I said to him, "My name is Hughes"â€”he said, "I know; the detective"â€”I said, "I want some conver
sation with you respecting some rope that has been stolen from the Company's premises; I must ask you some questions about it; you can please yourself about answering them, do you know a man named Kempster?"â€”he said, "No"â€”I said, "Did not you assist in loading some rope into Kempster's van on these premises a short time ago?"â€”he said, "No, never"â€”I said I find you were seen over the water with Kempster's van, containing some rope some time ago"â€”he said, "I know nothing about it; I don't know what you are talking about"â€”I said, "I must take you into custody for being concerned with others in stealing some rope belonging to your employers;" and I took himâ€”after the second examination I saw Grayâ€”I was present when he was apprehended, and about two days afterwards he sent, and wanted to see meâ€”he was out on bailâ€”I went to his house, and saw himâ€”he said, "I wish to tell you all about this rope affair, and all I know about it"â€”I said, "It is unfortunate you did not say all about it at first, when you were apprehended"â€”he said, "I was cautioned not to say anything"â€”I said, "That was not telling you to say what was not true"â€”he then told me that a man named Tom Evans brought him a sample rope, and took him to Kempster's stable to see the rope; that Evans sold it; and received the money for it, and that he (Gray) only received 19s. of it.

Cross-examined by MR. KEMP. Did he give you any information about Evans? A. Yes; he told me where he might be foundâ€”I do not know Evans; I have heard of himâ€”I do not know that his name is Thomas Wilson Evansâ€”I heard Gray tell Sergeant Smith something about Wilson, but Evans was not mentioned then; I am quite sure of thatâ€”he might have metioned it; he walked before me to the stationâ€”Gray has been giving information to the prosecution throughout these proceedings, doing every thing he can to assist usâ€”he has told me since, that conversation, that he had been to Kempster, and where Kempster wasâ€”he made no concealment of these facts since he sent for me; I had no former conversation with himâ€”I did not hear all the conversation, because they walked some few yards before meâ€”Gray has been trying to find Evans for us, in company with Mr. Elder, who knows him.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. When you went to Kempster's house, on 20th February, were you in uniform? A. No; I announced the position that I held; I had been on duty in that neighbourhood for yearsâ€”I know Kempster by sight, but did not know his name or where he livedâ€”I did not know him as a very long resident in that part of Bermondseyâ€”I remember seeing him aboutâ€”he did not say anything about spun yarn, in reply to any of my questions, or refer to anything like yarnâ€”there is a wooden partition between the places where the carts and the horses are keptâ€”the same doors do not open into bothâ€”both the folding doors open into where the rope was, and where the cart and van wereâ€”Kempster was admitted to bail.

MR. ORRIDGE. Q. After Evans had got out of the way, did Gray say that he would tell you all that he knew about it? A. Yes; I had been after Evans before that, at places where I heard he was at work, and I had been to his house in the middle of the nightâ€”I found that he had been travelling with samples for some manure works; but he had not been there since this transaction.

GEORGE HOUNSELL . (Re-examined.) On 17th March, Stokes' wife called me into her house, and said Stokes and Bassett wanted to see meâ€”in con
sequence

of that I went to Horsemonger-lane Gaol and saw themâ€”I saw Bassett first; Stokes was in a separate cellâ€”I put down the same evening, as near as I could remember, what passed between asâ€”these (produced) are the notes I madeâ€”I asked him what he sent for me forâ€”he began by say
ing, "I have been eleven years on the premises and never had anything found against me"â€”I asked him if he had nothing else to sayâ€”he said he had only been concerned in the two lots discovered, and that a short time ago a man came to the works and induced him to send some goods to Mr. Learyâ€”he did not know whether he or Stokes first accepted the proposal, but Stokes could tell us more about it; it was a long time for a man to remem
berâ€”the money for the goods sent to Mr. Leary was received by the strange man, whose name he did not knowâ€”he either said "We" or "I"â€”I believe he said, "I never received any of the money, nor saw the man again;" that the goods last taken away had been sent to Mr. Vane's and another man's; "but I know of nothing else except 5 cwt. of twine; that is everything that has ever gone out by night; but as to anything being sent off by day, I could not say, as I am always in the rope ground, and could not tell what went in or out"â€”I said I knew what he was saying was incorrect; that we held the receipt for the moneyâ€”he then said, "It is a mistake; I mean the last lot and not the first, that I did not receive the money for"â€”I told him it was no good wasting my time in telling me what was incorrectâ€”he said he told me the truth and nothing but the truth, and all that he knewâ€”I said he had no business telling lies and making statements he could not prove; that was all with himâ€”then I went to Stokes' cellâ€”he said, "I have never been concerned in taking away any goods: on the evening of the 18th, I was out with my wife till half-past 9; when I came home I found that all was not right, and in the morning I found the rope house all in a scurry;" that was the expression, I believe, meaning confusion; "and missed some of the goods, I then spoke to Bassett about it, and about three or four hours afterwards he said, "I sent the goods away"â€”Stokes said he did not say anything about it, because he wished to save Bassett from trouble; that was the only time such a thing occurred; everything that went out he had enteredâ€”he said he had put a great quantity of money into the Company's pocketâ€”I asked him who authorized him to do so.

COURT. Q. What? asked him who authorized him to put money into the Company's pocket? A. He meant by weights being incorrectâ€”I do not remember the exact wordsâ€”I believe he said, "By false weights"â€”I said, "Who authorized you to do that?"â€”he said, "No one; but it was for the good of the Company"â€”I asked him if he had suspected any oneâ€”he said he suspected Mr. Morgan; he knew nothing except that, a month ago, Mr. Morgan had given orders to send up two men with needles, to pack rope at Fresh Wharfâ€”that is not part of our present premises; it is by the side of London Bridgeâ€”he said that he sent up two men, Charles Bassett and Alexander Dryâ€”they were there a day and a half, and that was the only lot of goods that had gone out by nightâ€”that was on the 18th.

MR. ORRIDGE. Q. Did he say what he had for that lot of goods that went out on the 18th? A. He mentioned some sum; I believe it was 10l.â€”I told him he had not spoken the truth, and I could not waste my time any longerâ€”he begged me to think of his wife and childrenâ€”I said, "I will do so as soon as you think of the Company"â€”nothing more of importance passed.
Bassett. Q. When you came to Horsemonger-lane, what was the first word you asked me? A. You sent for meâ€”I said, "You have sent for me, what

have you got to say?"â€”I have no recollection of your asking me to be as merciful as I could on account of your confinementâ€”your words were that you would make a clean breast of it, and did not care who it would implicate so long as you found out who it wasâ€”I did not tell you I would get you your liberty if you would make a clean breast of it, or anything like itâ€”when I found you were not speaking the truth I went awayâ€”I believe you said, "I know of nothing else except a lot of twine," or "5 cwt of twine."

Stokes. Q. When I told you a great deal of money had been put into the Company's pocket by false weights, did not I tell you it was you gave me orders to put 10 per cent on all goods that went aboard ship? A. No; I did notâ€”(The witness's deposition being read, stated, "I never told Stokes to put on false weights; I admit he told me of it, and I reported it. I do not recollect saying anything about 10 per cent")

COURT. Q. Do you mean you had heard he had put on false weights before this happened, or that he told you of it in the gaol? A. Not in the goal; he had told me of it before any of this happenedâ€”some goods were being weighed at the time, and he told me he was in the habit of occasionally, in shipping orders, making the weight a little more than it actually was, and I reported it upon a lot that was then weighed; nothing further came of itâ€”I did not say one day, when Stokes was weighing a lot at the scales, "I think, Stokes, you had better put some weights on those, for I do not think they weigh those at the Arsenal"â€”I did not say anything of that sort.

Stokes. If I never live another moment, you said so; you told me all throughout to do it; did not you put four cwt. on two tons of goods that went to Barking? A. I can produce the receipts; Mr. Hewitt weighed them; I sent the weights perfectly correct.

Stokes. He put four cwt. on two tons, and said, "Weigh every coil separate, and make a mistake in the addition, so that if it should be found out I can copy off every weight, and send it down and say it was a mistake in the adding up." Witness. The weights were all correct that I sent to Mr. Hewitt; I will admit there was a mistake in the adding upâ€”I was aware when the bill went in that it was not correctly added upâ€”some of the coils came back; that did not lead to the bill being set rightâ€”I sent down the weight of each coil separatelyâ€”I can show it on my lettersâ€”I gave the weight at the officeâ€”I did not send the original bill; but I wrote a note to Mr. Hewittâ€”there were about 18 lbs, over in one, and 18 lbs. under in another, so that it came equivalent, and a little in his favourâ€”I put down the weights correctly, but did not add it up right, and then that bill went to the officeâ€”(The witness was twice asked the question by the Court, whether he added the bill up wrong intentionally, but gave no answer.)â€”Stokes first of all told me that he thought it would be practicable, and I mentioned it at the office, for I had only recently come up to Londonâ€”I did not know what were the rules of the tradeâ€”I was only a clerkâ€”I will admit that I did so to that lot; but I reported it the same as I did a previous lot.

Stokes. When he found I would not put weights on, he actually told me to make no notes, and he told a lad also the same. Witness. I told him to put no weights on any ship's notesâ€”it is not a usual thingâ€”it is never done in any other house in the tradeâ€”when these goods were taken away there was nothing like ten or twelve tons of rope sent away.

Bassett. Q. How can you tell that the two coils found at Kemp
ster's were the property of the London Ropery Company? A. Because I recognise them as being spun at Whitbyâ€”I saw the remainder of the spun yarn of which that was partâ€”I said at the time it was spun yarn, and at

the police-station they said it was a species of rope, and I said, "Yes, it is"â€”spun yarn is the yarn of rope not twisted; it is always sold with rope; it is the same price, and they are sold togetherâ€”I recognised it imme
diately.
Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. How long had you been with the Ropery Company? A. Five months.

MR. ORRIDGE. Q. I understand you called Mr. Hewitt's, the customer's, attention to the weights? A. Yes; he sent me an account, saying he kept so many coils, and I sent him an account of the weights of those coils; which he kept, giving him the weight of each size by itselfâ€”I had taken those weights as the coils left the yardâ€”I sent him my account, and when I went down there he said, "This weight is not correct, there is 18 lbs. deficient; but on the other lot you sent there is 18 lbs. too much"â€”it was equivalent, except that the things which I charged 18 lbs. under were more expensive than those on which I charged 18 lbs. over.

COURT. Q. Was that wrong addition which anybody who added up the account could find out? A. I had seen Mr. Hewitt before, and had actually told him, speaking of the rope-making trade, that it was the practice to do so, and in February we had a conversation about it, and I leave it to you to think whether it was probable he was going to be taken in in that way.

Bassett's Defence. The first lot before Christmas, belonged to a man named Wood, and never came from the Ropery Company. We were ordered to sell for him if we possibly could. The parties were entire strangers to us; we sold the rope and had the money returned to us, and we gave it to Mr. Wood. There is no proof that that rope came from the Ropery Company; it never did come from them. The rope was in Kempster's place before we knew anything at all about it; I went there to look at it, and said I would see if I could get a customer for it, and I and Stokes went down to Mr. Leary's and bargained with him, and sold it to him and returned the money to this Mr. Wood.

Stokes' Defence. One day before Christmas, a stout short man, came with rather a seafaring man to the gate, and asked if Mr. Morgan would buy any rope. I said, "I do not know; trade is very slack; I don't think he will;" he said, "If he will, we have got a lot we will sell cheap;" I said, "I am almost sure he won't buy it." I promised to ask him; that was in the afternoon. In the evening after dark he came again, knocked at the door of our house, and said, "I know a party that will buy that rope; they know me very well, but I don't understand representing in the matter of rope, like you; there is a Frank Leary down town; he don't buy it himself, but his partner Vare will advance money to any extent; we want 60l. for the lot; it is a lot all put together." I said, "I don't know anything about it;" he said, "If you, will come with us, we will pay you for the trouble; you represent yourself as the seller of it." I said I did not mind, and they took me to Mr. Vare's, and he took us to Mr. Leary. Evans did not go there with us; I dont know why. Leary appointed to meet Bassett next day. I declare that I never saw the rope; a lad drove the van and met me going down; a gentlemen called for me after breakfast and told me to go down and get the money at the public-house this side of the Surrey Canal bridge. (Stokes here asked the witness Ward if he remembered meeting him there, and Ward replied, "Yes, I think it was you".) I met Leary and Bassett, and they took me into a public-house; 46l. was what they agreed to take. Bassett not being able to write, Leary told me to write a receipt; I said I did not understand doing so, and he told me the words and I wrote them;

that is all I know about it: and as for knowing about anything going off the premises, I assure you I did not. Last Christmas I captured two lads that had been robbing the premises, and the officer Hughes knows that I was out till 12 o'clock at night after the other one, and captured him the next day at Greenwich.

p.hi: Stokes, Gray, and Kempster, received very good characters.

div1.p:
BASSETT and STOKESâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude each.

KEMPSTERâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

GRAYâ€”
NOT GUILTY . MR. METCALFE stated that about 2,000l. worth of property was missed.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, 12TH MAY, 1862.
